column2:
Collision of Worlds
Invasion
Part 2
By Michael DeBuse

Chapter 1 
“Self-Loathing” 
Eydis
Dim yellow light pierced the darkness revealing a blend of subdued browns and shadows.
The sole distinguishable feature of the scenery was the light’s source, a small, glowing yellow orb affixed to the ceiling.
The only sounds in the haze of dull colors were an incessant mechanical hum and the first groan of the room’s waking occupant, Eydis FeAmel.
“Aahh…” Eydis’s memories were just as clouded as her eyes.
She did not know this place.
Training.
Who’s training?
Symra’s?
Evhial’s?
Yes, Evhial’s.
Life magic.
Eydis tried using life magic to clear the haze in her eyes, but she struggled to think of the right magic to use, and her ven was unresponsive.
Symra’s training, then, she thought, but Eydis could not move her arms.
She could not feel them.
She only felt cold, sick.
“Where… Hel…”
The haze found motion in the rampant patter of feet down what sounded like creaking wood steps.
A shadow loomed over Eydis in the shape of a person, blocking the light.
Two red dots glowed at the eyes.
Eydis felt herself wrenched from the ground.
A burning pain in her shoulder that made her cry out increased the cold sickness she felt.
The haze darkened, and the last Eydis saw in the blackness was two small red dots.
Dim yellow light broke the darkness, and the blend of dull colors found shape.
Eydis instinctively silenced the groan that nearly passed her lips.
Something, she felt, should not be alerted.
The two red dots should not know she woke.
Instead, Eydis blinked more clarity into her eyes.
A crude wooden stairway rose to the left, and shelves lined the far wall, but the scene would not focus enough to show what sat on them.
In the back right corner stood a tower of brown boxes; maybe cardboard.
Eydis did not recognize this place, but the incandescent light bulb glowing on the ceiling showed she was still somewhere on Earth, possibly--hopefully--still in Gullivan.
After a deep breath, Eydis tried to sit up, but her wrists would not part.
Something cold and rigid bound them behind her back.
She tried to move her legs, but the same cold rigidity bound them as well.
Every ounce of her will was required to pull her knees up to her chest, and she could not find the energy to roll onto them to sit up.
The ground was paved, and she felt the grating texture against the skin of her legs.
She noticed the same grating chill on her hip, shoulder, and arm.
Only now did she realize that she was not just bound but also naked.
Eydis looked down at the binds of her ankles and saw two shining silver shackles chained together.
They glimmered with a dull, light-blue hue; fahil, a rare metal that, though brittle on its own, when made into an alloy it could become stronger than steel.
Pure fahil was silver, almost white in color, giving it the name of fa-hil or white-iron.
Common alloys of the metal tinted it blue.
The chains were an alloy to increase their strength and decrease the brittleness of the pure metal.
Her captor did not want her to escape.
No barrier Eydis created could break such binds, and wind could hardly cut them.
Life magic was useless against metal.
She could teleport, but if these binds were fahil, there was a greater risk.
Resfahil, an even rarer form of the metal, was impervious to, and even dispelled most magic.
It could not be manufactured but was said to have appeared from the cataclysm that destroyed the first civilization on Whinhlem, a remnant of divine anger for breaking universal taboo.

The nature of the taboo had been forgotten to all but the ageless, but given the metal’s distaste for magic, it was commonly believed that some forbidden magic was the cause of the first civilization’s downfall.
Resfahil made portals highly unstable due to its magic resistance.
If resfahil needed to be transported by teleportation, it was sent on its own.
Eydis could open a portal with her hands bound and try to crawl through, but if this was resfahil, she could expect to be highly wounded if not dead when she exited the other side.
Wearing resfahil, including simple accessories, was banned for the royal family so that the spatial magic guard, the Namie, could evacuate the royal family quickly in emergencies.
Emer demonstrated the reason for the ban in one of his earlier spatial magic lessons using a small resfahil ring and a live fowl.
The mangled and bloody bird was all she needed to see to be fearful of wearing any.
A door opened out of sight atop the stairs.
Eydis acted as if she was asleep to not alert whoever approached.
The boards of the stairs creaked less under the lighter steps of the new arrival.
The unknown individual walked around out of sight behind Eydis.
Eydis felt so vulnerable in her nakedness.
She did not know who this individual was, but all of Eydis was bare for them to see.
Metal creaked behind her, followed by the sound of scraping.
Crackling accompanied faint warmth, and Eydis realized that the new arrival lit a fire.
“Sorry,” the arrival, a girl, said in a quiet voice before returning up the stairs.
Eydis chanced a quick glance at her and saw a young Forrest Elf girl in a yellow floral dress.
From the angle, Eydis saw her, the girl looked familiar, but Eydis could not be sure.
This room was clearly on Earth, not Whinhlem, so why was there a Forrest Elf here?
Once the girl was gone and the door atop the steps closed, Eydis turned her head to see the source of the subtle warmth.
A small black furnace crackled with flame, and the metal pan beside it was filled with ash.
The girl’s apology was possibly from letting the fire die.
There was only a small wood billet in the furnace and no other around it, so perhaps the apology was due to the lack of fuel.
The fire produced from the single billet was small.
Eydis grew confused.

The red eyes and pain in her shoulder still haunted her like a horrible nightmare, as if her naked imprisonment wasn’t nightmare enough, but now a Forrest Elf girl was taking care of her and even apologized.
Over the following hour of solitude as the fire removed the edge of the chilling sickness Eydis felt, she tried to remember what happened and how she got here.
The last clear memory Eydis had was arriving with Justin in the health and fitness building to prepare for her self-defense class.

She went to change in the changing room attached to a restroom next to the small classrooms where she had formerly taught her friends magic, but as soon as she entered the changing stall she was teleported into a snowy field.
A fight ensued.
She was overwhelmed.
Someone saved her.
There was a Lurr, a Lurr that looked just like her.
Her doppelganger.
And that doppelganger attacked her.
The glowing red eyes and pain she felt in that nightmare of a memory made sense now.
The severity of her situation finally hit her.
This building, wherever it was, was the Lurr’s den, and Eydis was imprisoned as the Lurr’s source of food.
She had to escape.
She had to return to Justin and Sammy and warn them, not only about Tolmyur finally coming to Earth but also that Lurr had arrived with them.
An idea came.
Even if a portal might be lethal when entered, it might still be of use.
If she created one and let part of the chain through, when it collapsed from the metal’s disruption, the chain might sever.

Eydis created the formula for a small portal near her hands, but when she tried to tear it open, she found her ven unresponsive, and the attempt only increased cold shivers that the fire could not ebb.
She was far past the critical point.
Her ven levels were too low.
The doppelganger was preying on her, and so long as she did, Eydis would be unable to use magic.
The fahil shackles were only an extra precaution.
Eydis had trained in using ven below dangerous levels under Symra.
She was able to give all her ven to Justin when she expelled his toxic ven in an emergency.
She could do it again.
Using the teleportation formula she created, she forced out the ven her body withheld.
Her finger entered a crack in space, and she peeled it open.
The portal was incredibly unstable due to her low ven, and Emer would berate her to no end for trying to create a portal with her ven so low, but she did not need to enter.
She wanted the portal to collapse.
She slipped the chain into the small crack in space, and immediately sparks flew from the portal collapsing.
The metal was a rasfahil alloy.
The edges of the portal closed around the section of chain but could not sever it.
The chain sparked and heated as it barely held the portal open until the portal spat it back out intact.
The yellow-hot chain slapped her forearm, burning her.
Eydis hissed through her teeth and tried to hold her arms as far away as she could to keep the heated chain taut and away from her skin.
She could not hold the position for long but endured the debilitating shivers of ven exhaustion until the chain cooled.
She then collapsed to the ground.
Eydis could not find the energy to try again.
She lay on the cold cement floor as the fire slowly died, removing her sole feeling of warmth, to await the return of the monster.
“Justin… Sammy…”
Tears welled in Eydis’s eyes.
She whimpered the only names in which she could find comfort despite knowing that they had no way to find her.
For the first time since arriving on this world, she was alone.
Eydis’s tears ran dry in the silently passing hours.
She fought mentally to ignore the cold, but that only served to tire her more.
She tried to change position to keep as much of her naked body off the cold floor as she could, but the chains were staked to the ground and too short to give much range of motion.
After several attempts, she worked herself into a squat, but it did little to stop the shivering.
A door from the stairway.
The wooden steps creaked.
“You are looking much better today.”
Someone with Eydis’s voice, face, and tattered clothes walked in carrying a bundle of wood under her arm.
The young Forrest Elf girl followed.
Eydis knew her, Rynn.
Her face was emotionless, and she held a bowl in both hands as she followed behind the doppelganger.
“You are probably hungry.”
The doppelganger nodded to Rynn, and she set her bowl on the ground in front of Eydis.
It contained a thin vegetable soup.
“Food here is a bit heavy, so this is probably more than enough.
Drink up.”
Eydis looked at the bowl.
Her hands were shackled behind her back, giving her no way to lift it.
Eydis’s eyes met the doppelganger’s.
A sly grin that said “drink” grew on the doppelganger’s face.
The shackle chains extended just long enough for Eydis to bend down if she shifted her ankles as close to the stake as possible.
She placed her face in the bowl and sucked up the soup.
The doppelganger stoked the furnace with a content smile.
Eydis could not bend far enough down to drink the entire bowl.
When she tried scooting the bowl closer with her chin, the bowl tipped, spilling what remained.
Even though Earth food was dense and filling, that thin soup hardly sated her hunger.
She hung her head low, weak and humiliated.
“That’s a waste.
I assume you are done?”
The doppelganger handed the bowl to Rynn and ordered her to return upstairs.
“Why?” Eydis mumbled.
“Hmm?”
Eydis shook her head, new tears running down her tear-stained cheeks.
“Why are you doing this?” Eydis’s voice fell quiet, almost to a whisper.
“Why?
The humans were increasing their search for you, sending more and more people to this world.
It was only a matter of time before they found you.”
That was not what Eydis wanted to know.
In her confrontation with her doppelganger, she vaguely remembered her saying that she wanted to help her fight Jethro, and yet her doppelganger attacked her first.
“I had to keep them off your trail so that they would not learn you were walking out in the open like you were a human.
Had they known you were living such a care-free life in this world, they would have found you much faster.
Those fools believed you sought asylum and kept looking for military or government facilities.”
“I thought you wanted to help me fight Jethro,” Eydis said meekly, hoping to somehow turn the situation around.
If cooperation was at all possible, she needed to grasp it before her situation grew more dire.
However, her words had the opposite effect.
The doppelganger’s eyes flared red.
“Now you care about defeating Jethro?
Now that I have you trapped, you want to save your people?!”
She grabbed Eydis by her neck and lifted her until the chains binding her grew taut.
“You already made your choice to abandon the Amelian Empire.
While you were living a peaceful life, my country fell to ruin!
The capital city fell to the humans!
People live in fear and poverty.
Meanwhile, you were laughing and chasing after a human male like some bitch in heat!”
Eydis’s mind could not comprehend the doppelganger’s accusations.
The Amelian Empire was powerful.
Tolmyur could never overpower them in such a short amount of time, even without her father.
She expected that the royal council would be more than sufficient to run the country in the absence of an Emperor or Empress.
What her doppelganger said had to be a lie.
There was no way Amel would fall, but to Eydis’s horror, the doppelganger’s next words hammered in the truth of what was happening back on Whinhlem.
“The Amelian Empire is no more.
The races that once found protection under its banner now sell their liberties to the humans in fear.
The pride of the fairies was crushed when they alone stood up to Tolmyur’s tyranny, spurring the largest genocide in history.
I would not be surprised if there were no fairies left by now…
Even that half-breed mage who saved you is sharing everything he knows with the humans and making them even more powerful.”
The doppelganger’s grip tightened.
Eydis could no longer breathe.
Left to the mercy of her captor, tears flowed from her eyes.
Her consciousness was fading fast.
Her vision grew dark.
When Eydis was about to lose herself, the doppelganger released her grip, dropping Eydis to her knees and to her side.
Eydis gasped for breath, but a foot landed in her stomach, forcing her to her back and expelling the air she so desperately needed.
That same foot pressed down on Eydis’s chest.
The doppelganger looked down at her distressed face with disgust.
“Do you really think you deserve to return to your world?
Do you really think that I would let you become a martyr after you abandoned your own people, after you abandoned girls like Rynn?
Jethro will not have you.
You will not die for your people.
You will live in your shame until I am complete.
Then I will kill you myself.
It is only fair.
You created me to die in your place.
Now you will die so that I can live in this world in your place.
There is no empire for us to return to anyway.”
The doppelganger lifted her foot, allowing Eydis to breathe a little easier.
“I had to wait a few days to make sure Tolmyur was off my trail.
They were observing me in secret somehow while I searched for you.
I did not find anyone, so I think we are safe for now, but I am curious.
What is it about those humans you lived with that made you abandon your people?
What was his name?
Justin?
I feel it is time to pay your man a visit.
He is probably very worried about you.
I wonder… What should I do to him?”
Eydis tried to call out, to plead for mercy, but only a desperate gasp for air escaped.
She could not let a Lurr near Justin.
He had provided for her.
He offered everything he had freely so that she could live as peacefully and happily as possible after losing her entire family and after having been sent to a strange and unfamiliar world.
Creak.
The doppelganger began climbing the steps.
Justin laughed with Eydis when she was happy.
He comforted her when she was sad or insecure.
He shared with her his favorite foods, his favorite places, his favorite hobbies.
Creak.
He gave his home.
He gave his room.
He gave his money.
He gave his time.
He was always with her.
Creak.
He did all this without fear of those who were after her.
Creak.
Eydis remembered his warm hand clasped tightly in hers.
When she was near him, when she held his hand, all worries felt so small.
When she thought Justin wanted to send her away when a room opened in the girl’s dormitory, a deluge of anxiety swept her away like the sole anchor holding her steady in the storm had been cut loose.
The doppelganger was wrong.
The state of her home, the Amelian Empire, was always on her mind.
She worried about it every day.
She had nightmares about it in her sleep.
She could see the dead faces of her father, her brothers, her mother, and Ceil.
She could see the bodies of her people piling up in the streets.
The worry would have crushed her long ago if not for him.
Creak.
He was her support.
His reassuring smile brought peace.
Justin was the only man who ever cared about her for who she was, who she truly was, not for what position she held.
The realization of her own feelings struck Eydis’s heart like lightning.
I love him…
Eydis forced out the dregs of her ven and pushed herself deeper into the critical levels.
She channeled everything into her feet.
With as much strength her worn body could give, she kicked her legs at the doppelganger.
A blade of wind flew from her feet and cut through the wooden beams lining the stairs.
Rynn saw the blade and dove down the steps into the doppelganger.
The edge of the blade cut across the girl’s face as she and the doppelganger tumbled downward.
The blade imbedded into the wall and dispersed.
The light in the cellar went out.
Only the faint amber glow of the furnace lit the room.
The doppelganger scrambled in panic for Rynn who lay limp beside her.
Blood gushed from a line across Rynn’s cheek and past the bridge of her nose.
The blade had carved deep, digging into bone.
She channeled life ven into her hand and immediately worked to stop the bleeding.
Rynn lost a lot of blood by the time the bleeding stemmed.
The doppelganger glared at Eydis with red eyes like burning coals in the dark.
She rushed to Eydis and grabbed the hair on the side of Eydis’s head.
Eydis swung her knees at the monster.
She lacked the motion and ven to fully utilize Symra’s training, but the alignment of two key wellpoints in Eydis’s legs caused the monster’s knee to buckle when struck.
This hardly perturbed the Lurr, and she slammed Eydis’s head into the cement floor.
Eydis’s head erupted in pain.
Her head was slammed once more, blurring the crimson puddle that steadily grew in the corner of her vision.
Eydis laid there, unwilling to surrender but unable to retaliate.

Perhaps, she thought, this was proper punishment for failing to kill the doppelganger and instead harming Rynn who had always taken care of her and even now apologized for the cold, and who very well could have been captured by the monster.
The doppelganger pulled Eydis’s face close.
“Do you have any idea what that girl has been through?
She gave herself to Jethro’s men to protect her family and people.
Do you have any idea the evils she’s witnessed, the horrors she’s experienced?
If you feel any remorse at all, you will wait here patiently for your death.”
The doppelganger licked her lips.
“But no, you would not care.
You only thought of protecting your human.
I need to ensure you can do nothing more to her.
I drained far too much the first few times I fed and nearly killed you.
I went easier after that but feared you were still too weak.
Now I know that I cannot hold back.”
The doppelganger pulled a small knife from her pocket and slit the side of Eydis’s neck.
She placed her mouth over the gushing wound and began sucking.
Eydis’s head grew light.
The cold hand of death caressed her body.
Her vision darkened.
Her body grew numb.
Only faint sounds reached her ears.
“You are lucky I cannot kill you yet.”
The sound died, leaving only two red eyes in the darkness and a desperate cry for help in Eydis’s heart.

Chapter 2
“Home Life”
Eydis
Eydis successfully captured the princess and evaded Jethro’s men.
Hidden in a house that no one visits on the edge of a residential district where the poor kept to themselves, Eydis felt safe.
However, in her hubris after her hard-fought victory, she neglected to notice the danger she had brought inside that very house.
A major oversight allowed the captive princess to severely injure Rynn, the adolescent Forrest Elf she saved from the lustful hands of the humans.

In her own underestimation of her original-- someone whose capabilities she should have known better than anyone--she let harm come to the girl for whom she obtained this home to shelter her from further harm.
Guilt ate at Eydis.
It twisted in her stomach.
Tears burned her eyes as they fell on the bloody face of the girl she swore to protect.
Eydis apologized again and again while carrying the light frame up the steps of the cellar and to the bedroom.
She had originally planned to contact the princess’s human associates, but that plan had to wait.
Eydis focused all her efforts towards treating Rynn.
Her education in the Amelian palace included practice in life magic, which she excelled at, but she was ill-prepared for something this severe.
Treating flesh wounds was simple.
Accelerated healing through life magic fixed most damage, but it often left terrible scars that needed further treatment to erase.
Bone was far more difficult.
Depending on the damage, accelerated healing could fuse the bone wrong, and if the bone was badly damaged, full repair was not possible.
The cut Rynn received from the princess nicked her jawbone, shattered two upper molars, cut deep into her cheekbone, and extended through the bridge of her nose.
The gash barely missed both eyes.
If Rynn had not been at the top of the stairs, if she had not seen the attack, Eydis would have lost her head.
That much was certain.
Rynn saved Eydis’s life.
Eydis worked to the best of her ability to regrow the bone carved out by the blade of wind.
Once bone grew, it hardened and would not grow any further, so Eydis had to shave off some of the new bone to allow more to grow.
The process was long and infuriating, and when her frustration peaked, she took it out on the unconscious elf in the cellar.
The end result was poor, but she filled the carved line through Rynn’s cheekbone and jaw.
New flesh covered the damaged bone and hid Eydis’s unskilled work.
Eydis lay on the floor tired and sweating, but Rynn rested soundly in her bed.
She barely had enough ven to finish the surgery and could feel the shivers of ven exhaustion.
The remaining tissue damage could be dealt with after Eydis next fed on the princess, and if she was careful, no scar would remain.
“I guess I will wait another day…”
Eydis fell asleep on the floor.
Eydis shifted and turned over in her sleep-drunkenness, pulling the blanket up close around her face.
It faintly smelled of Rynn, slowly overpowering the former owner of the bed.
Something felt off.
Eydis woke with a start in the bed in which she thought she had placed Rynn.
She turned her head looking for the girl but did not find her in the sheets.
Rynn stood at the door holding a plate of flatbread.
The girl had found flour, herbs, and greens, learned to use the peculiar range of this world, and prepared a simple meal.
“Food.”
“Did you lift me into bed?”
Rynn nodded.
“Come here.”
The girl approached the bedside.
Eydis set the plate aside and pulled Rynn into an embrace.
“I am sorry, and thank you.
Thank you for saving me.”
Rynn shook her head, rejecting the earnest word of gratitude.
“Repayment.”
When shown kindness, repay twofold; the first half of an ancient elven adage.
Eydis saved Rynn, so Rynn felt it only natural to save Eydis.
Eydis held the girl tighter, Rynn’s starched dress scraping against Eydis’s chest.
It was then that Eydis noticed that she was naked.
The shivers from ven exhaustion were also gone.
Rynn must have held her while she slept to help her recover.
The care Rynn took brought tears to Eydis’s eyes.
She pulled the girl off to look at her.
The cut across Rynn’s face had begun scabbing over, although most of it was still raw.
Even the light movement of the air would cause it to burn, yet the girl showed no sign of pain.
The poor girl was already accustomed to pain.
“Eat,” Rynn said, looking down at the plate Eydis set aside.
The building tears fell loose from Eydis’s eyes when she nodded in agreement.
Rynn sat on the bed beside Eydis, and they shared the heavy flatbread.
The quality of Rynn’s cooking surprised Eydis.
The ingredients of this world should have been foreign and yet she skillfully used them to make a meal that tasted similar in quality to what Eydis expected a baker to sell.
It lacked the same quality as the bread Eydis ate in the palace, but it was not so far off.
Due to the heavy nature of this world’s food, half the bread remained.
Rynn set it on the bedside table and extracted the moisture using simple water magic to dry it for later consumption.
Eydis headed for the hallway to go to the kitchen, but Rynn rushed in front of her and blocked her path.
“I am only getting some water.”
Rynn shook her head.
“Rest.”
“You are the one who needs to rest.
Despite the blood you lost, you still exerted yourself.
You cannot see your own face, but I can.
You are pale.”
Eydis moved past Rynn into the kitchen and burst out laughing.
She half expected a mess from how Rynn reacted, but what greeted her was flat bread in different degrees of being burnt piled all over the counters.
Various vials of spices scattered between the stacks of bread wherever they would fit.
She walked over to a stack on one end and broke off a piece that was not burnt, ignoring the panicked waving of Rynn’s hands.
It tasted not too different from the bread she just ate.

Thinking that it may have been one of the later incarnations, she went over to a stack on the opposite end of the counter but was surprised when that bread tasted exactly like the bread Rynn gave her.
She laughed again.
“What are you worried about?
All the bread is fine.”
Rynn shook her head.
In all the time since Eydis took custody of Rynn, she never had the chance to see how Rynn acted in a home setting.
Rynn might have been a perfectionist.
Her skill in cooking was obvious; able to understand the nature of the ingredients she found in the kitchen and combined them into a passable meal.
All the burning must have been from learning how to use this world’s odd range, or perhaps the ingredients cooked far faster than those on Whinhlem.
The strange atmosphere might have affected the heat of the flame.
There were many possibilities.
Eydis had never cooked, so she wouldn’t know.
She was confident that if Rynn had a range or stove or oven from her world, she would have been able to create perfect bread on the first attempt.
If the burnt sections were ignored, the bread could be preserved and used to feed them for some time.
“Are you not satisfied with the bread?”
Rynn shook her head once more.
“It tastes bad.”
“Of course.
Why did I not realize it before,” Eydis spoke under her breath.
Forrest Elves were originally scavengers that relied on their senses to determine the safety and quality of food.
They had an extraordinary sense of taste.
Eydis recalled hearing that the head chef and chef staff of the palace were all Forest Elves.
Rynn prepared and brought all the meals when she was Austin’s slave.
If the bread contained any burnt or overcooked parts, the flavor would bitter.
If the combinations of spices were modified even slightly, the resulting flavor would drastically change for a Forrest Elf’s tongue.
The bread she made was not poor.
It just didn’t stand up to Forrest Elf scrutiny.
“Can you dry the rest of this bread?
We can live off of it for a time.
I will eat the more burnt sections.
It is better we not let food go to waste.
Restocking provisions might be difficult.”

Rynn might have been used to the infinitely abundant provisions of the palace and so did not think anything wrong with making so much bread that she did not intend to eat, but here on Earth nothing should be wasted.
Rynn nodded and began drawing the moisture from the bread.
Eydis walked back into the hall and to the closet.
She opened the door to the cellar and took a deep breath.
Only a single night passed since she last fed on the princess.
After all that abuse, she doubted the princess would be a threat, but after what happened to Rynn, she could not take any chances.
She erected a wind magic barrier around her body and walked down the steps into the darkness.
The princess’s attack had broken the light orb in the ceiling by hitting the wall near the switch that lit it.
The only light came from the faint orange glow of the furnace that Rynn had likely kept stoked.
The princess lay in her chains on a blanket that was not there before.
The blood on the floor from Eydis’ abuse of the princess had been cleaned.
A towel only large enough to cover her midsection lay atop her.
She could smell the fain fragrance of the human soap.
Rynn had also bathed the princess right here in the cellar.
There was the possibility that the princess had soiled herself, and that was the reason Rynn washed her, but another thought crept into Eydis’s mind.
Rynn was a citizen of the Amelian Empire who worked in the palace.
She knew who Eydis kept captive.
She was not willing to go against Eydis’s wishes, but at the same time, she still respected the rightful heir of the Amelian Empire.
While avoiding crossing any line that would anger Eydis, she did her best to care for the princess.
Rynn was far too kind, and her kindness caused a small portion of guilt to twist in Eydis’s chest.
But still, Eydis could not risk becoming lax on her treatment of her prisoner, not after what the princess did to Rynn.
She needed to make sure the princess’s ven stayed well below usable levels.
Eydis lifted the princess to bring her forehead close to measure her ven and blood levels.
She could have touched any location on the princess’s body to read her vitals, but the forehead was special.
It was one of a number of ven wellpoints on the body and was specifically attributed to the soul.
Socially, touching foreheads was a sign of intimacy and care.
Medicinally, contact between the wellpoints in the forehead made the reading of vitality easier and far more accurate.
If Eydis wanted to weaken the princess enough to prevent magic but not weak enough to endanger her life, she needed to know precisely how much ven she could safely drain.
A dull gaze stared at Eydis through the thin slits of the princess’s nearly closed eyelids.
Eydis dropped the princess in surprise, but there was no reaction when the princess’s shoulder and head hit the hard floor.
The princess was not asleep as Eydis had thought, but at the same time she was languid, seemingly lifeless.
Either her mind was absent or she had given up.
Eydis was still wary of the princess, but the princess could do nothing in her current state.
Their foreheads pressed together again.
Blood levels were rather low due to the events of the previous day, but they were not low enough to be life-threatening.
A little feeding would not endanger the princess.
Ven levels were only slightly above the critical point.
Eydis had nearly drained the princess dry in her anger, so this much was expected.
The amount that could be drawn this time was small, but Eydis would have to make do.
Rynn’s recovery might end up taking longer than expected.
Eydis bit into the princess’s shoulder, tearing an opening in the skin.
She placed her mouth on the wound and began sucking the slowly seeping blood.
A euphoric high radiated from her stomach, and Eydis could feel the small effects the blood had on her body.
With how much she was feeding now, the estimated one year or so for completion would only take a minute fraction of a year.
This realization pleased Eydis.
She wanted to be rid of the princess as soon as possible.
When Eydis about finished feeding, the pleasant feeling in her stomach changed.
It developed into nausea and then acute pain.
Her chest tightened and her heartbeat grew erratic.
Eydis pushed the princess away and stumbled back.
In the slits of the princess’s eyes animosity stared back.
Eydis began sweating profusely.
She grabbed her chest and writhed on the ground, crying out in pain.
Life magic surged through her body to try and find what the princess had done.
Her heart felt close to bursting, and in each prolonged absence of a beat Eydis felt herself slip closer into darkness.
Each painful beat could be her last, and if she did nothing, death alone awaited her.
The patter of small, panicked feet flew down the steps.
“Stay back!”
Eydis could not risk Rynn getting hurt again, and in her writhing and convulsions, she feared that she might injure the frail girl if Rynn tried to help.
Her leg spasmed, kicking the lower shelf along the wall.
The wood shattered in a spray of splinters, sending a cascade of glass jars to the ground, but the shelf was low enough that only a few shattered upon impact with the cement floor.
The powerful and erratic palpitations continued.
Eydis vomited the blood she had not finished absorbing.
She struggled against the life magic of one who was far superior even in a weakened state.
Eydis’s body grew cold.
Breathing became difficult.
Her body ran out of energy to writhe.
She lay motionless on the floor, fighting for her life with only her own life magic to save her.
Rynn stood back and watched in fright.
Unable to bare the silence, she ran over to the princess and wrapped her arms around her.
“Please!
Stop this!
Don’t hurt her!”
She begged and pleaded, but the princess did not respond.
Rynn dragged Eydis’s limp body to the princess.
She pushed the two bodies together and embraced them, holding them as tight as she could.
“I beg you, Eydis FeAmel… Please…She is not evil… She saved me… I can’t lose her… Please, don’t take her from me…”
Rynn’s pleading became incoherent cries, and her tears fell on the princess’s cheek.
The princess looked up at the young girl’s injured face and then closed her eyes.
An arm raised and hit the side of the princess’s head, knocking the princess limp.
Eydis pushed away.
Lying on her back, Eydis’s breathing slowly regulated.
She was still sweating profusely, and her body grew feverish from ven exhaustion, but the palpitations ceased, and the pain subsided.
She stared at the ceiling and focused on her recovery.
The danger had passed.
Did I beat it?
Or…
Eydis rolled her neck to look at the unconscious princess, but Rynn dove down and wrapped her arms around Eydis’s neck, crying in relief.
Eydis let Rynn hold her, lacking the energy to stand and leave the cellar.
She had depleted the ven she drew from the princess in her struggle.
The blood she ingested had been vomited back up and was now useless.
The princess won, again.
Just as Eydis was careless the day before, she had been careless now.
She set up defenses against wind magic but completely neglected the most deadly of magic available to the princess, life magic.
The princess was still fighting with all her strength.
“Knock her out first, I guess…” Eydis moaned.
Rynn stripped and clung tight to Eydis to help her recover ven as fast as possible through contact.
After an unknown amount of time, Eydis could move again.
Using Rynn as a crutch, they walked back up the steps and to the tub to wash off the sweat, dust, food from the jars, and bloody vomit.
“Sorry, Rynn.
Your recovery will have to wait another day.”
Rynn shook her head as she scrubbed Eydis’s back, now covered in light scrapes from writhing on the rough cellar floor covered in shattered glass.
“Let it heal.”
“But the scar!”
Slender arms wrapped around Eydis, and Rynn’s cheek rested on Eydis’s shoulder.
“I’m fine.
It’s my trophy… for saving you…”
Eydis felt the cheek resting on her shoulder flex.
Was that a smile?
It couldn’t be.
She had never once seen Rynn smile.
But, Forest Elves treated scars as badges of honor, and if the scar brought Rynn even the smallest feeling of joy that Eydis had yet been unable, she could not turn down the girl’s wishes.
“We will let it heal, then.”

Chapter 3
“Kind Humans do exist.”
Eydis
Eydis delayed her departure another three days to make certain she could safely regulate the princess’s ven recovery.
To prevent further danger, Eydis used gloves she found to choke the princess unconscious before feeding.
She feared that continual blows to the head would cause complications that could not be fixed with life magic and might lead to death.
Asphyxiation had its own dangers, but they were not as severe.
At least she assumed they weren’t.
Only time would tell.
After donning the princess’s unwashed and damaged shirt and pants from her fight with Jethro’s men, Eydis made sure all the windows were closed, curtains were shut, and doors were locked.
“I will be spending much of my time with the Humans of this world for now, but I will be back once or twice a day to check up on you.”
Rynn nodded, but her countenance fell.
She did not want Eydis to go.
Eydis embraced the small girl and ran her fingers through her wheat-colored hair that glistened with strands of silver.
“Do not worry.
I will never abandon you.
We will be living in this human world from now on, and the humans I am meeting are accepting of our kind.
Once I feel it safe, I will let you join me.
If it does not work out, I will leave them, and we will find somewhere else in this world to live.
Besides, the humans of this world must have investigated the fight.
They might know the movements of Jethro’s men better than I, and that is information we must learn.”

After one last caress of Rynn’s cheek, Eydis tore open a portal in the air like a fissure through space that brought her to the river on the opposite side of the apartment where the princess’s man, Justin, lived.
She hid in the shrubbery to keep out of sight.
Eydis refrained from bathing and added self-inflicted cuts and bruises at different levels of healing to allude to the battle and a struggle during her escape or abuse during captivity.
Now in a location with dirt, she rubbed some on her body and in her hair.
Much of the snow had melted, but the weather remained rather wet, so to complete her mask, Eydis drenched parts of her clothes with river water.
She scanned the river path to watch for any travelers.

A middle-aged jogger ran down the path exhaling large clouds of white breath every couple of steps, but it was otherwise deserted as it had been most days when Eydis observed the princess’s daily routine.
After the Jogger continued far enough down the pathway, Eydis opened a portal and stepped into it, bringing her to the other side of the river.
Justin would not return for another hour if he still adhered to his normal schedule, so Eydis sat beside a bush next to the gate to his apartment.
Time passed, and the time Justin should have appeared passed with it.
Eydis expected the sudden disappearance of the princess to cause changes in Justin’s hard-set routine, but she hoped he would arrive soon.
The clothing Eydis wore was light and nowhere near sufficient to ward against the near freezing wind-chill, especially when wet.
She shivered and rubbed her arms and legs to work circulation back into them.
If Justin took much longer, she would have to use life magic to warm her body.
She had been avoiding doing so because her cold and frail appearance would elicit a better reaction and hopefully mask any minute differences that Justin might notice between her and the princess.
The sun set over the city skyline.
Soon the grey clouds grew light purple ripples and then faded dark blue.
The cold became unbearable, and Eydis began to wonder if Justin had even left his apartment at all.
The loss of the princess might have caused him greater shock than she thought.
Justin had multiple women, so the loss of one should not have been so great a cause for concern.
Then again, Austin was obsessed enough with Rynn to force the girl into slavery, and when Eydis freed her, he became far more violent with Wian, his other Forrest Elf slave.
If Austin’s demeanor changed from the loss of one slave, then Justin might have also changed with the loss of the princess.
She was confident that any human of this world would think the princess an exotic prize, and no doubt the princess was the favorite among Justin’s women with how often Eydis saw them together.
Disgust wormed in Eydis’s stomach.
Was she really to place herself in a similar situation to Austin’s slaves?
Even Justin’s name was too similar.
At least the women seem happy with Justin, so it might not be so bad?
She did not know, and that minor assurance did not ease her disgust.
She only knew how they acted in public, not in the privacy of their home.
Eydis searched her heart with earnest consideration to the thought that she did not actually have to meet up with the princess’s humans.
Their information not only on the aftermath of the battle with Jethro’s men but also on this world in general was invaluable--true.
And they were accepting of elves--also true.
She would have to interact with the humans of this world now that she decided to live here, and this was the most beneficial time to do so.
She wanted to leave and have nothing to do with them, but something inside of her was telling her to stay.
Intuition?
Doppelganger Instinct?
She didn’t know.
Eydis’s unease increased as night set in, and she felt that she would have to catch Justin another time.
The next day, Justin would leave later in the morning for work.
With or without the princess, he should still attend to his employment, she hoped.
She could catch him then.
Or maybe not catch him at all.
This could be fate telling her to abandon the idea, or at least to spend another night thinking it over and discussing options with Rynn.
Eydis stepped out onto the path.
She looked both ways to check for anyone who might see her teleport and noticed someone walking down the path with two white sacks in each hand.
The man with blond hair stood shorter than most.
She had seen his threadbare and tattered grey coat many times before.
Finally.
Eydis held her arm and walked slowly towards the figure.
His pace slowed and then stopped.
Even from his distance, Eydis could see the man’s mouth agape and quivering.
He dropped his bags and ran forward, nearly tripping once on the path.
She prepared for a collision, but Justin slowed and embraced her lightly.
“Eydis.” Justin rested his face above Eydis’s left breast but quickly pulled himself off.
Eydis was grateful the embrace was short.
In her disgust at a human male holding her so endearingly, she almost threw him off herself.
It took immense control not to.
He held her at arm’s length and scanned her with his eyes.
“Are you okay?
Are you injured?
What happened?
Were you involved in that mess outside town a week ago?”
Sure enough, Justin made the connection with the disappearance of the princess and the fight with Jethro’s men.
She might be able to get some useful information from him after all.
That would be repayment enough to tolerate the embrace.
Without waiting for a response from Eydis, Justin grabbed her hand and pulled her towards the gate.
She immediately felt a powerful syphon of ven, far stronger than her High Elf slave back in the palace.
Justin’s ven regeneration must have been astoundingly fast, odd for a human.
Before Justin could pull Eydis too far, she stopped him and pointed down the path.
“Your bags.”
Flustered, Justin ran down the path to retrieve them.
Both white bags in one arm, he grasped Eydis’s hand and led her to the apartment.
Another man whom Eydis did not know lived in the apartment.
He was similar in height to her, though a little shorter, with a rather austere aura about him, but that aura melted when he saw Eydis.
“Eydis, are you alright?
Where have you been all this time?”
Genuine concern leaked through his stern expression.
The princess lived in a small abode with two men.
Justin was obviously her man, but then who was this?
Just as a man could have multiple women, a woman could have multiple men if she chose, but it was far more uncommon, at least on Whinhlem.
She could not make any guesses about this world.
His reaction was not as endearing as Justin’s, so she doubted he was a second lover.
Justin was clearly poor, comparing his abode to the other homes and buildings of the city, so this might simply be another resident who shared the home.
Eydis did not know how much this man knew about the princess’s situation, so she did not know how to respond.
She did not even know his name.
“I am fine now, but…” She left her statement hanging to allow the man to reason about whatever he imagined could fill the blank.
“We can talk after.
She’s turning purple.”
Justin pulled Eydis away and to a washroom similar to the one at the house she and Rynn used.
“Take a bath and warm up.
We can talk after.” He paused for a moment, trying to work his panicked thoughts into words.
“I’m… I’m so glad you are back.
I was so scared that you might have been captured or killed.
Eydis placed her hand on Justin’s shoulder.
His concern was heartfelt.
He shook from the fear and relief that battled inside him.
There was no doubt that this man cared deeply for the princess.
A smile grew on Eydis’s face.
The full nature of the relationship between the princess and Justin was still unknown, so Eydis wanted to test it.
Using the meekest voice she could, she spoke to the trembling man.
“I am almost too weak to stand.
Can you help wash me?”
Justin’s reaction was unexpected.
He looked as Eydis’s slightly embarrassed yet pleading face with dumbstruck silence.
He then glanced into the living room where the other man sat out of sight and then back at Eydis, almost worrying that the other man might have heard her request.
Justin looked into Eydis’s eyes, and with a deep, silent breath, he nodded.
“Yah, if you need me to.”
Justin’s reaction was innocent, but it was not the innocence of a virgin youth.
It was of a man uncomfortable with the request but willing to help.
He was either unaccustomed to such intimacy and the request took him by surprise, or the request was not something the other man who lived here was supposed to hear.
She could think of two possibilities.
Either the relationship between Justin and the princess was not sexual, or it was and needed to be kept secret from the other man for whatever reason.
Eydis hoped with all her soul it was the former.
“No, sorry.
I think I will be fine.
Can you bring me new clothes?”
Justin hurried down the hall and turned to the first door on the left.
Eydis now knew the location of her room.
Justin returned with a shirt, soft and fuzzy pants, and what looked like a set of pastel green undergarments not unlike the damaged ones the princes had worn but were now unusable after the fight.
After thanking him, she entered the bathroom and closed the door.
“Haaaaaa…”
Eydis leaned on the counter and breathed a tense sigh, confident that the loud ventilation fan would mask any noise she made.
The heart in Eydis’s chest pounded with adrenaline.
So far, her infiltration worked.
She knew little about the princess’s private life, practically nothing, but if she hung on her absence and her capture as an excuse, she should avoid any major pitfalls.
She undressed and found how to get the faucet of the tub to work.
It was different than the one at Rynn’s home, but the mechanisms were similar enough.
Taking one bottle and soap at a time, she smelled them to match the fragrances to the two men who lived in this apartment.
Those on the left side of the tub matched Justin while those on the right matched the unnamed man.
There was no other set for the princess, so either the princess used one of the men’s or none at all.
Eydis recalled the princess’s scent during her first feeding after the battle with Jethro’s men.
The original smell of soap on the princess had faded from that day, erased by the scent of the soap Rynn used to wash her, but she felt there was a match, unmistakably Justin’s.
Eydis kept the water in the tub shallow with the faucet continually running.
She rinsed off the dirt and scrubbed the sweat and oils from her body.
She then turned off the faucet and let the water drain before standing to air dry.
The undergarments the princess used were peculiar.
The bottom was thin, covered little, and insufficient to hide her tail.
The breast supports were the most peculiar part.

Eydis’s chest, and thus the princess’s chest, was not large enough to need supportive undergarments, but if this was common for the humans of this world, and if the princess wore such things regularly, then she would have to wear it.
She slipped her arms through the straps and found that the cups fit perfectly.
The back had to have some method to fasten, but Eydis could not find it.
She removed the supports and inspected them.
There were three tiny metal hooks that matched tiny flat loops on the other end.
She placed the supports back on and struggled to get the hooks into the loops.
She quickly grew frustrated with her inability to fasten it correctly, so she removed the supports and decided to go without.
She could use the excuse that they were agitating her injuries.
The pants sent shivers up her back from the fabric’s soft and strangely pleasant texture against her skin as she slid them up her legs.
Once dressed, she left the bathroom and returned to the living room.
Justin met her with a small amount of food prepared.
“I thought you might be hungry.
I didn’t know if you had anything to eat.”
Eydis was grateful for Justin’s thoughtfulness.
Aside from feeding on the princess, she refrained from eating for two days as part of her preparation.
Indeed, she was rather hungry.

The portion Justin provided was small and did not appear enough to satisfy her, but she knew the food of this world was heavy and filling, and Justin would also be aware of how much the princess regularly ate.
She grabbed the knife and fork and cut into what looked like a fried egg folded over an orange cheese, placing a piece of it into her mouth with the tip of the knife.
It did not taste anywhere near as good as Rynn’s flatbread, but her stomach rejoiced.
“So, what happened to you?
You suddenly disappeared before the self-defense class.
Did the assassin find you?”
The other man looked surprised and then irritated.
Eydis finished eating.
She did not know the meaning of the word assassin but reasoned that Justin was talking about Jethro.
“The assassin, his name is Jethro.
Yes… his men found me.”
The other man stood from the couch and paced in irritation.
“How long have you known that an assassin was after Eydis?”
Justin looked sheepishly back at the man.
“Sorry, Sean.
I didn’t want to worry you.”
“Worry?” The man named Sean rummaged one hand through his hair.
“This goes beyond worrying.
What happened outside the city the day you disappeared, was that part of this?”
Eydis nodded.
“They teleported me there.
They were using that house as a base.
I had no choice but to fight back.
I killed most of them, but I was captured…”
“Then you were the one who killed all those people?”
Eydis buried her face in her hands.
“Yes.
I had no choice.
I had to fight.”
“Then…” Justin paused for a moment before coming to a shocking realization that drained the blood from his face.
“The people who are after you, the one who tried to assassinate you, they are humans from your world?”
“We are at war in my world, my Empire and the humans of Tolmyur.”
“Your caution and fear when you arrived, all your anxiety, everything.”
Justin pulled Eydis into an embrace.
“I’m so sorry I never realized.
All this time, you were not only in a strange world, but you were surrounded by people who are the same as your enemies.
I’m so sorry.”
Eydis wanted to push Justin away but stopped herself and let him try to comfort her.
She reluctantly wrapped her arms around him and rested her chin on his shoulder.
“It is fine.
Humans of this world are different.
We are not enemies.”
Sean sat back down on the couch.
“Are those assassins still after you?”
Eydis separated from Justin and nodded.
“Yes.
There are more in the city.
They had a portal at the house I burnt down, but they can easily move it.”
“What are the chances that they will come here and attack us or anyone else?” Sean asked.
“I am sure they have already killed many people in the city, but I do not think they know I live here.
They only knew of the school.”
Sean shook his head in frustration.
“What a mess you have gotten us into…”
Justin balled his fists and glared back at Sean.
“Can you not accuse her the moment she gets back from nearly being killed!?”
“I was not talking about Eydis.
I was talking about you!”
Both Justin and Sean stood.
“That doesn’t matter!
Eydis will still feel like it’s her fault if you say it like that!
You should know that!
Can you at least show some concern?”
“I am only saying this because I am concerned!
If there are dangerous people coming into the city that are not afraid to take lives, we need to go to the police and explain everything!”
“Then what will happen to Eydis?!
She’s already refused to contact the police many times!
What happens if they take her away and start running experiments on her or something?
She’s not human, you know!”
Eydis sat back, mildly entertained by the ensuing spectacle.
“What kind of sci-fi fantasy are you living in?
I doubt experimenting on her will even be considered.
We can keep Eydis’s identity secret and still tell the authorities that there are more dangerous people out there.
And what about us?
Now that they know Eydis works at the university, I’m sure it will not take them long to find out she is connected to us, or Sammy, or anyone else.
If anything, we need to talk with everyone who knows the truth about Eydis and decide what to do from here.
However, with or without your and Eydis’s permission, I will be contacting the police,” Sean asserted.
“Fine, but wait until after we talk with everyone before deciding what to tell them.” Justin knelt next to Eydis and grabbed her hand.
“We don’t blame you for any of this.
I knew what I was getting into when I decided to take you in.
You’ve already been through a lot, so please rest for now.
I’ll call everyone to let them know you are back.”
“Yes, I am tired.
Thank you.” Eydis walked into the hall.
“I am going to heal myself, so do not come in.”
The two men nodded.
The princess’s scent enveloped the bedroom, and entering brought with it an incredible urge to feed.
Much to Eydis’s surprise, the room itself was rather plain.
There were no decorations or embellishments.
None of the Amelian regal flair could be found.
The bed was smaller than the ones in both Jethro’s base on the outskirts of the city and the house she and Rynn were using, but at least it was long enough to lie comfortably across.
A desk sat in the corner, and a single dresser stood next to the closet.
The top drawer contained the princess’s undergarments, but the remaining drawers held Justin’s clothes.
The closet was divided between Justin and Eydis’s clothes as well.
The two shared the room.
Was their relationship sexual?
That could not be right.
Although Justin’s scent was present, it was faint.
He spent little time in the room.
The smell could just be from the clothing or lounging in the room, but she had to make sure.
Eydis smelled the bed.
It was masked by the princess’s stronger scent, making her salivate, but Justin’s scent was far more present there than elsewhere in the room.
If Justin only spent brief moments in the room and his scent fell strongest on the bed, then Eydis reasoned that there could be only one possibility.
Their relationship was sexual.
This brought about a terrifying realization.
“I have never been with a man,” Eydis spoke in frantic whispers.
“He would know immediately that I was not the princess if we…
Then to keep him from finding out, I would first have to…”
Eydis held her stomach and covered her mouth to fight back the nausea from the prospect of not only lying with a human male but also needing to break her own hymen beforehand.
Unable to bear the thought, she opened a portal and stepped through to a more familiar bedroom using her memorized formula.
Rynn sat lonely on the bed.
Seeing her cleansed Eydis’s troubled mind.
Rynn’s eyes lit up with excitement, showing even more emotion.
Eydis could not have been happier.
She smiled at the girl and spread her arms.
“See?
I told you I would be back.
Although, I was not planning on returning so soon, but I could not stop myself.”
Rynn hopped off the bed and hugged Eydis.
Her hands felt the soft pants and immediately grew fascinated with them.
“They are quite nice,” Eydis boasted.
“I cannot believe the princess has been lounging in these all this time.
Anyone in our world would pay a fortune.
They certainly outclass those silk skirts.”
“Then…”
“Yes, I made it in, but the real test will start soon.
The other resident of the home is not happy that dangerous people are after me, and he is going to involve everyone who knows about the princess’s true identity.”
Eydis removed her clothes and sat on the bed to finally heal her self-inflicted injuries, ending their incessant itch from the scabbing.
“Will you be caught?” Rynn sat beside and placed her hands on Eydis’s shoulders to help her recover ven.
“I do not think so.
If the man closest to the princess did not notice, then no one else should.
But, I must be careful.
I cannot assume I or they know anything.
Playing a fresh slate is the best choice.”
“That is dangerous.”
“It is, but if I can build new connections and information, then I can rely on that and ignore anything the princess did or knew in the past.
Everything else, I will avoid.”
Eydis finished healing and lay back across the bed, pulling Rynn on top of her.
She held the girl close and ran her fingers through her hair.
“I will not be able to sleep with you tonight.
Will you be fine on your own?”
Rynn gave a slow nod and buried her face in Eydis’s chest.
“I will hold you for a bit longer, but I will need to go back soon.”
Eydis continued holding Rynn until Rynn became drowsy.
She then laid Rynn on the bed, pulled the blankets over her, and touched foreheads.

Despite Rynn’s short stature and childlike demeanor, she was a young woman and capable on her own, but when she was with Eydis, her childish side came out and stirred the mothering instincts in Eydis.
Rynn wanted to be spoiled, and Eydis would happily give the world to her if possible.
After one last glance at the girl, she grabbed her clothes and opened the rift back to her room in Justin’s apartment.
“Sammy, let her rest.”
“Shut it.
You can’t expect me not to see her now that she’s back.
The light is still on.
She hasn’t gone to sleep yet.”
The handle turned.
Eydis dropped her clothes and quickly erased the portal behind her.
When the door opened, the shortest of Justin’s women poked her head inside.
At one glance, she turned back to the man behind her and pushed him away.
“She’s not decent.
Go.” She then slipped inside and quickly closed the door behind her.
“S…Sammy?” Eydis tried to hold in her panic.
If she had been a moment too late or decided to stay with Rynn longer, they would have found out that she had been elsewhere.
Tears welled in Sammy’s eyes, and she rushed over to embrace Eydis.
Her arms wrapped snugly around Eydis’s back and pulled her in, almost bending Eydis over her.
The woman was only half a head taller than Rynn, rather short for a human, but her bone structure was not thick enough to be a Dwarf.
After crying for a moment, Sammy pulled herself off and wiped her cheeks and the tears she left running down Eydis’s stomach.
“Sorry for barging in.
I’ll let you get dressed.”
Eydis grabbed the soft pants and stepped into them, feeling that alone sufficient.
Sammy only shook her head, wiping more tears.
“I’ll let it pass this time.”
Was simple attire improper even in one’s own home?
Eydis look down at her chest and arms, wondering if there was something wrong with exposing her upper body, but then shook her head feeling that was foolish.
“I know, I know.
Men have breasts too, so it’s no big deal.
This is what, the fifth time we’ve had this discussion?” Sammy chuckled, but it was a bit forced.
“I’m not going to ask you to explain what happened, because I’m sure that you will have to tell everyone all over again when we meet with Dr. Shuman tomorrow.
I… I just couldn’t wait to see you.
You suddenly disappeared.
And then that bloody fight outside town?
I’ve been a nervous wreck all week.
I kept fearing the worst, that you would never come back.
I kept telling myself you were still alive.
I just…”
Tears fell again, and Sammy tried futilely to wipe them away.
Eydis knelt and pulled Sammy into another embrace.
She found herself running her fingers through Sammy’s shoulder length, wavy brown hair out of habit.
She could not find it in herself to hate this girl.
It may have just been their size, but something about Sammy reminded her of Rynn.
“I am fine.
Everything is okay.”
Sammy fought to regain composure and soon stopped crying.
“Sorry.
I’m sure you had a hard enough time without coming back to me sobbing all over you.”
After a deep breath, she separated and flashed a radiant smile on her tear-drenched face.
“I’m glad that you are back.”
A small tinge of guilt pricked at Eydis’s heart.

This girl was such a loving friend to the princess, and Eydis expected to encounter such reactions and had steeled herself against it, but Sammy’s free-flowing emotions breached the wall, even if only a little.
“I completely understand if you would prefer to just rest on your own, so you can turn me down if you want, but if it’s alright, can I stay here tonight with you?
Justin won’t complain since you are still up, so…”
A small chuckle escaped Eydis’s lips.
Sammy was just like Rynn.
This human was alright.
“Yes, you can stay tonight.”
Sammy bounded into Eydis and gave her a tight hug.
“Thank you!
Oh, Sorry!
Justin said you were hurt, and I just…”
Eydis laughed lightly as Sammy jumped away and waved her hands apologetically.

Chapter 4
“Those who Know”
Eydis
The sweet metallic taste swirled in Eydis’s mouth and trickled down the back of her throat.
She did not want to swallow, choosing to let it pool in her mouth to savor the flavor.
The amount of blood she could safely draw from the princess slowly decreased as the princess’s body was unable to replenish it at the rate Eydis fed.
This caused a problem because ven was not directly associated with blood levels even if much of it resided in blood.
In order to keep the princess’s ven low enough that she was not a threat, Eydis had to drink a certain amount of blood.
This time was an experiment to see if Eydis could separate the draw of ven from the draw of blood as she fed, but she was unsuccessful.

By keeping the princess’s blood levels low enough, she could leave the princess too anemic to use magic even if the princess had the ven to do so, but that created far greater health risks than critically low ven alone.
Forcing herself to hold back and heal the wound, Eydis swallowed the accumulated blood in her mouth and licked her lips.
Her body begged for more, but that was just not possible.
She laid the princess back down on the blanket and walked up the stairs to say goodbye to Rynn.
Rynn wanted her to stay longer, but her time was limited.
She could not leave the humans waiting.
She rested her forehead against Rynn’s for a short farewell and opened the portal back to the bathroom of Justin’s apartment.
She then flushed the toilet, washed her hands and mouth, and opened the door.
In the living room, Justin, Sammy, and Sean waited by the front door.
“Thank you for waiting.”

The previous evening, Justin contacted everyone who knew about the princess’s true identity using this world’s peculiar communication device and arranged a meeting at an office belonging to someone named Dr. Shuman.

Instead of using the river path and catching the bus like Eydis had seen Justin and the princess do almost every day, they turned right and walked to the front of the complex to a paved lot full of metal carriages.
They all entered the one belonging to Sean with him driving, Justin in the front passenger seat, and Sammy next to Eydis in the back seat at Sammy’s request.
Eydis fought to hold in her amazement as the vehicle roared to life and moved on its own as if powered by some strange magic.
It rolled out of the lot onto the road and picked up speed.
The homes of the residential district flew by the windows, as did other vehicles and people.
Once they reached the main street and crossed the river, Sean took a different route from the bus that the princess usually rode.
Using back roads, he avoided heavier traffic and drove them to the east side of the campus to more large, paved lots.
The group walked across campus to a structure Eydis knew well, having stood on its roof to monitor the princess because it was the tallest building on campus.
They entered the building and then an extremely small room behind a metal door.
Again, Eydis forced herself to hold in her surprise at the sudden increase in gravity and the short arrival at the top of the building.
The princess was used to these strange technologies and sensations, so Eydis had to feign familiarity.
Justin knocked on one of the doors down the long hallway, and it immediately flung open.
Two women stood in the doorframe, Chloe and Miriam, although Eydis was not sure who was who.
They both pushed Justin and Sammy away and embraced Eydis.
“I was so worried about you.”
“I’m so glad you are safe.”
“Let’s continue this inside.
We have a lot to talk about.” Sean tried to coax Miriam and Chloe inside, but Sammy pushed him through the door.
“Give them a moment, would you?”
Eydis wrapped her arms around the two girls and walked them to the room.
“I am happy to see you again, but Sean is right.”
The girl with long, orange hair let go but the girl with short brown hair clung to Eydis’s arm as they walked inside.
Justin closed the door behind them and turned the latch on the handle.
The aged professor sat near his desk in a black leather chair.
He appeared relieved to see her, but that relief masked a lot of worry.
Everyone told Eydis to take the only remaining chair in the room.
She sat down and took a deep breath.
This room was filled with everyone most familiar with the princess.
They knew her true origins.
If there ever was a time she would make a mistake, it would be now.
She had a transmission formula ready in the event that she made a mistake and needed to make a quick escape.
Do not assume anything.
Let them control the conversation.
Only talk about events after the disappearance of the princess.
Eydis reminded herself of her plan and looked forward at the chinstrap-bearded man who would conduct the meeting.
Like Sean, he had the austere air of a rigorous scholar about him, but his first words surprised Eydis.
“I am happy you are back safe, Eydis.
I’ve been worried.” A simple smile spread on Dr. Shuman’s face.
“Sorry to worry you,” were the only words Eydis could think to say.
She bowed her head lightly at the man who could be seen as the senior of all those present and crossed her ankles out of respect.
“No, no.
You had no control over what happened.
Justin told me over the phone that you were captured and managed to escape.
You said there was little chance that the assassin could come to our world, but it seems we were all gravely mistaken.
Now, people in the city have died, and I am part to blame for not warning the authorities ahead of time.” Dr. Shuman grimaced apologetically at Sean, who nodded sternly back.
“But you did contact the police immediately when Eydis went missing,” Sammy cut in.
“Only to give a missing person’s report,” Sean chided.
“The most you all did when questioned was explain where you last saw her.
Not one of you mentioned the people who were after her.”
“Neither did you,” Sammy retorted.
“I did not know anyone was after her until yesterday.”
“You never told him?” Sammy looked at Justin dumbfounded.
“I would have thought after Sean learned who Eydis was that the assassin would be the first thing you told him.”
“Sean would have called the police right then and there,” Justin said in his defense.
“We are in this position because no one called the police in the first place,” Sean rebuked.
The two other girls stood silent as finger pointing bounced back and forth between Justin, Sean, and Sammy.
Dr. Shuman waved his hand to break up the argument.
“There is nothing we can do about what has passed.
We are here to discuss how to move forward.
Eydis, can you tell us what happened.”
Eydis took another deep breath.
Justin placed his hand on her shoulder and gave a reassuring smile.
“While Justin was setting up the class, I went to change.
I noticed the use of spatial magic but was too slow to defend myself.
They teleported me outside the city to the field behind the house you probably know about…”
Eydis recounted the events of the battle with her in the position of the princess and included her own fights with the Dwarf commander, Mordok, and the human fire mage.
She also explained that Jethro’s men brought a monster with them, and because she could not let such a dangerous monster remain in the city, she could not run and leave the monster behind.
Each time she called the Lurr a monster, a faint pain pricked her heart, but she continued claiming as such because those were the princess’s own words.
Any clues about what a Lurr was might lead them to noticing something about her.
She continued the story with the death of the monster.
In the process of using a terrible magic to kill it, she used too much ven and collapsed from ven exhaustion.
When she came to, she was captured and bound with chains resistant to magic.
She stayed in captivity waiting for Jethro to open another portal because they could not open one from this world.
When the portal opened, her guard’s watch became lax.
She decapitated him with wind magic, took the key, freed herself, and teleported away.
“…and then I ran into Justin on the river after teleporting back.
I do not know how many came through the portal after or how many more are in the city.”
“The police tried to censor much of the footage of the scene, but it is going viral.” Sammy removed the small, rectangular communication device from her pocket.
She showed Eydis an aerial picture of the field the morning after the battle.
The large patch of ice from Mordok’s war hammer was visible, as was the crater from the fire mage’s suicidal explosion.
Smaller craters from the Lurr Giant peppered the field.
The most prominent part of the scene was the long scar along the ground and the blood and gore of the Lurr that dyed the field behind it.
Eydis could never hope to achieve such magic in her current state, but as she fed on the princess, she also felt her ven capacity increasing to match.
Her strength in magic should also follow.
“Where did they hold you,” Sean asked.
“We might be able to send the police there.”
Eydis shook her head.
“I do not know.
I was kept inside a building.”
“What about their descriptions?”
Again, Eydis shook her head.
“The one who watched me was the one I killed.
I did not see the others.”
“Then all we know is that there are more people out there,” Sean grumbled to himself and leaned against the wall behind him.
“The biggest issue is what to tell the police about where they came from or how they are getting here.”
“Well, Eydis is a refugee, and there are a lot of wars going on all over Asia, the Middle East.
You know, terrorists and the like,” the brown-haired girl replied.
“That is where most of the refugees are coming from.
We could just tell the police that they are terrorists who slipped in with the refugees.”
“That’s a terrible idea!” The orange haired girl’s shout surprised everyone.

“With how much abuse and bad press the refugees are already receiving right now, suggesting that terrorists have actually made it in with them would only add fuel to the fire, especially because this is a sanctuary city.
They are just trying to escape and live a better life here.”
“It’s not like I am saying we make it public or anything.
We’ll only tell the police.
We can add your concern so they know not to make it a public issue.”
“I still don’t like it.
It’s a lie that could hurt innocent people.”
The brown-haired girl sighed, and the other did not argue further.
“We can go with that for now, but what about Eydis’s connection to the terrorists,” Dr. Shuman asked.
“What reason would they have for targeting her?
It can’t be information on them, because they would then want to know what that information is.
It’ll only add fabrication to fabrication.”
“Why not be more truthful here?” Justin piped in.
Everyone looked at him with a mix of confusion and doubt.
“I’m not saying that we tell them Eydis is an elf from another world.

What we can say is that she is a daughter of someone that was in open opposition to them, possibly part of a family that fought against the terrorist’s rise to power or the former rulers that were overthrown by the terrorists.
They executed her family, but she was able to escape and join refugees fleeing the country, so a small faction is chasing her.
This would be more believable because the terrorists have been publicly executing foreigners.
We can tell them that the terrorists are not radicals who attack indiscriminately but instead are actively searching for Eydis.”
“Wow. That is actually a surprisingly good idea.”
Once Sammy gave her approval, everyone else followed.
“That takes care of the police side of things, but what about us,” Sean asked.
“Eydis said that they know she is associated with the university.
We should tell the police that as well.
In any case, there is a chance that the assassins will come after us.”
The room grew silent until the orange haired girl spoke.
“What about the students of Eydis’s self-defense class?
They are not involved with any of this.”
“I will stop teaching.”
Eydis never received martial training, so she would not be able to continue.
“That’s probably the best choice,” the brown-haired girl agreed.
An idea jumped into Eydis’s head.
While she had accepted Sammy to some degree, she still disliked the number of women around Justin.
It made her feel less important, despite her own general disdain for him.
If she could remove the other two here, her risk of becoming discovered as a fake would also decrease.
Killing them was out of the question, for now, but making them leave of their own will could be possible.
“I am glad you worry about my students, but what about you?
Sean is right.
Jethro’s men know I am here now.
They know I come to this school.
You saw the field.
That is what a fight in my world is like.
You all live in this peaceful city.
I taught you how to fight, but none of you truly know how to fight.
If they find you, you will be lucky to be killed.
They might choose to capture you.”
Images of Rynn severely beaten flashed in Eydis’s mind.
“They are filthy people!
You will beg for death before they are done!”
Eydis’s outburst stunned all in the room.
She was confident that Sammy would not shy away at this warning, but the orange haired girl looked meek.
The brown-haired girl was another matter.
She appeared the unshaken type.
Still, Eydis directed her ending statement to her.
“You should forget about me.
You are safer that way.”
Tears formed in the corners of the orange haired girl’s eyes.
Perfect.
She will run.
The brown-haired girl laughed, stunning Eydis in return.
“You haven’t learned.
First was your announcement in your class to try to get your students to stop your meditation.
Then in the magic lessons you tried to scare us away from continuing magic.
Now that real danger arrives, you try to scare us away with death and rape warnings?”
The girl placed her hand on the corner of the back of Eydis’s chair, turned the chair to face her, and leaned her face in close.
“My grandmother prophesied that I would meet you and Justin.
She cried death and destruction.
I told you that already.
All her other predictions came true, so this one was bound to as well no matter how absurd it sounded.
If I was not prepared to encounter the danger in her prophecy, I never would have moved here and enrolled in this school.
Stop trying to scare us away.
I know you are concerned, but we are just as concerned about you.
Right, Chloe?”
Chloe wiped her eyes and nodded.
“We are your friends.

If you are worried about us, that we cannot fight, then teach us how to fight!” Chloe clenched her hands into tight fists and took a practiced stance as if ready to fight the moment Eydis gave the word.
“That’s what I am talking about!
Because of where I live and campus rules, I couldn’t bring any of my guns with me, so if I could learn to fight with magic, that would help us defend ourselves.”
“You own guns?” Chloe asked in amazement.
“A few.” Miriam smirked.
The identities of the two girls were now revealed, but Eydis was too shocked to feel any relief.
Her plan failed spectacularly.
She stared blankly at Miriam who had her arm around Chloe’s shoulders, smiling.
They were now even more eager to remain associated, not less.
“We should include Sean, too,” Sammy said.
“Sean, hold out your hand with your palm up.” Sean obeyed, and Sammy held her hand above his.
“Feel anything?”
“No. What am I supposed to feel?”
Eydis recovered from her shock and watched in confusion.
“Chloe next.”
Chloe then held her hand over Sean’s just as Sammy had.
“Nothing,” Sean repeated.
Miriam went next, and again Sean denied any feeling.
“You’re next, Eydis.”
Affinity assessment!
Eydis was relieved she caught on before problems could arise from her lack of understanding.
She held out her hand and tried wind ven.
“Nothing.”
“Then not wind,” Eydis said.
“What is this about?” Sean looked puzzled.
“We are trying to find out what element you have an affinity for.
I am water, Chloe is fire, Miriam is earth, and Justin is time, but we cannot use him to check if you have an affinity because he cannot even feel his own ven let alone control it.”
Eydis’s breath froze in her throat.
That human had a time affinity.
How was that possible?
An incredible ven regeneration rate was rare enough, but he was also a time mage?
Was that why the princess was so attached to him?
Was that how he attracted so many women?
A person with an affinity that was rare for magically adept species let alone those who were not, like humans, would naturally attract mates that desired their offspring to have that rare blood.
The number of women surrounding Justin began to make sense.
They sought after his bloodline.
“Eydis, what about life and spatial?”
Eydis extended her hand.
No response.
“Unless you have time or gravity, that means you have no affinities,” Sammy explained.
“That’s fine with me.
I didn’t plan on learning magic.”
“What about Dr. Shuman,” Chloe asked.
“No need to include me in this.
I’m far too old for this kind of thing.”
Sammy poked Sean in the chest.
“Even if you do not have an affinity, you should join us for our magic lessons instead of staying cooped up in your apartment reading.
If you do encounter one of the assassins, knowing what they can do might save your life.”
“I’ve been thinking,” Justin cut in, “Why don’t we just leave the city?
The world is huge, and if Eydis is not here, they would have no choice but to give up the search.
Staying here is the only reason there is any danger at all.
If we leave, then there will be no reason to fight.”
Rynn flashed in Eydis’s mind.
Taking her with would not be possible unless she found some way to introduce her to Justin and his women.
Then there was the princess.
She could not take her without first finding a new location to hide her, and there was no telling how difficult that could be.
“I… I do not feel that is smart…” Eydis said, not knowing how she would convince Justin.
