“I agree,” Miriam added, much to Eydis’s relief and surprise.
“I cannot explain it well, but something is telling me that we shouldn’t leave the city.”
Eydis almost thought she saw a wisp of something floating around Miriam’s head, but it vanished when she looked at it.
Justin’s eyes also narrowed, and he glanced around the room, searching.
Did he see it as well?
“Yah, and you graduate in a little over a month,” Sammy yelled, pulling Justin back into the conversation.
“What are you thinking, trying to quit school so close to finishing?
We still don’t even know if anything will happen.”
Sammy added her disproval by rebuking Justin, but Justin did not look convinced.
Eydis stumbled upon the key she thought might tip the discussion to her favor, Jethro’s genocide of the fairies in his search for the missing wife of the emperor.
“Justin, staying here is the safest option for the people of this world.
If Jethro learns that I left to another city, he would destroy city after city looking for me or to draw me out of hiding.
That is the kind of man he is.
With me here, he has chosen to stay hidden and not disturb the people of this world as much as possible.”
“You seem familiar with those searching for you.”
Dr. Shuman’s question froze Eydis in her chair.
In Eydis’s haste to convince Justin, she had made a mistake.
The princess only met Jethro when he tried to assassinate her.
She would not know anything about him.
If she already told them she knew nothing, her comment would raise suspicion.
Her mind raced to come up with an explanation.
“Jethro… He is well known in my world.
He leads the humans that are at war with the Amelian Empire.”
“If you know a lot about him, then we might better understand the tactics he could use.
This information will be helpful.”
Eydis held in her sigh of relief but could not stop the thundering of her panicked heart.
She reminded herself once again not to assume the princess or the humans knew anything and to only focus on knowledge gained after her capture.
She was walking along the edge of a knife, and the slightest misstep could rend her in two.
“If that is the case, then Eydis should stay,” Dr. Shuman said, ending the topic of running away.
“However, we will need to exercise extreme caution.
Eydis will know best what the enemy is capable of, so make sure to listen to her.
I have a class that I need to attend to, so we should end our discussion soon.
Do we all agree on what to tell the police?”
Everyone nodded, but Chloe still expressed her disapproval of blaming refugees.
“You will not be joining us?” Sean asked.
“I apologize, but I cannot cancel this class.”
“Then I will take charge of the discussions with the police.
I have connections there.
Is everyone fine with this?”
“I hope you know we are all going with,” Sammy said.
“I expected as much.”
“Then I’m fine with it.”
Once everyone agreed, they filed out of the room.
Eydis was the last to leave.
Justin stood beside her and grabbed her hand.
“Don’t worry.
Everything will work out.”
His grip tightened and a confident smile grew on his face.
Justin’s calm demeanor had the opposite effect that he intended.
It only increased her worries.
She inhaled deep and breathed out slowly.
Can I even do this?

* * *
The group left the university by bus.
Even though Sean’s car had sufficient room for six, he vehemently refused letting four sit in the back seat when there were only three seatbelts.
They traveled to the inner city and exited the bus next to a large three-story stone building with shallow concrete steps in the front leading to pillars that lined the front entrance.
A few casually dressed civilians stood near the windows or front counter inside, but the black-uniformed men and women stole Eydis’s attention.
They appeared completely different than what she would expect on Whinhlem, especially due to the lack of armor, but the badges were definitive markers.
These were city guards.
The association called the police guarded the city.
What struck Eydis as odd was the lack of visible weaponry.
If the humans of this world could not use magic, what means would the guards have to fight Jethro’s men?
Even if the police excelled in unarmed combat, they would be at a disadvantage against the combined weapons and magic Jethro’s men employed.
The ability of the police to repel the assassins grew more and more infeasible in Eydis’s mind.
“Will the police even be able to do anything?” Eydis asked Justin in a whisper.
He continued holding her hand and squeezed it lightly.
She tolerated this level of contact because she had seen him hold the princess’s hand often, and she was recovering ven as well, a surprising amount for the light contact.
“They would be able to fight them better than us, at least.”
His weak response did not calm Eydis’s worries.
Sean approached one of the receptionists and explained that they had information on the bloody events outside of town a week ago.
He added that Eydis’s missing person’s case filed by Ryan Shuman was involved and that she was here with them.
The receptionist asked if Sean would like to fill out what he knew in writing, but he demanded that he speak with the highest-ranking officer available because lives were at stake.
Sean’s words reeked with urgency, so the receptionist left the counter and spoke briefly with a female guard in the back.
“Someone will be here for you soon.”
After a ten-minute wait, one of the police approached.
“Sean, I heard you have some urgent information for us.”
Sean shook the man’s hand.
“Major Wickenny, I would like to request a private room to discuss this.
Is that possible?”
“Of course.
Your friends included?”
“I would prefer them included, because this involves all of us to varying extents.
Can we use one of the conference rooms?”
Major Wickenny scanned his eyes over the group.
“I hope you understand that due to the nature of what your information might entail and what you just told me, we would prefer to discuss with each of you individually in private.”
“I understand that, and I am sure everyone here would be willing, but there are parts of this that we would prefer to explain together.
Before I speak any further in the open can we move to somewhere more private?
You can decide if you need to hear from us individually there.”
Major Wickenny paused for a moment of contemplation and then nodded.
“Follow me.”
Major Wickenny led the group through a locked door and up two flights of stairs.
He engaged in idle chat with Sean as they led the group.
Eydis had to wonder about the nature of their connection.
If Sean was associated with the city guards, was he planning on becoming a guard, a police, as well?
Nothing about Sean’s stature suggested that he was fit for combat.
Many of the officers were not as fit as guards and soldiers from her world, but she could tell that they exercised.
Sean looked like he had never worked a sweat in his life.
“Sean is doing graduate studies in crime analysis,” Justin replied, having noticed Eydis’s confused gaze directed as Sean and Major Wickenny.
“He did an academic internship of sorts here earlier last year.”
Justin’s explanation only furthered Eydis’s confusion.
All she gleaned from Justin’s complicated terminology was that Sean probably worked here for a brief amount of time.
Given Justin’s explanation, it seemed this was information that the princess was never told.
Major Wickenny led them to a room with a large rectangular table in the center.
The room sat at the corner of the building with windows along the entirety of two walls.
Blue vertical blinds hung open allowing them to see the city.
Much of it was obscured from view due to the room being on the second floor, but many of the taller buildings were visible above the shorter roofs of the nearby structures.
Everyone sat on the length side of the table with Eydis in the center and Justin and Sean beside her.
The girls took the remaining seats, filling every seat on their side save one chair.
Major Wickenny sat across from them and removed a small device from his pocket.
“Do you mind if I record our discussion?” he asked.
“Of course not,” Sean replied.
Another two police, one man and one woman, entered the room and sat beside Major Wickenny.
“You mentioned you have information on what happened outside of town, and all present are connected in some way?”
“Yes, but I would like to begin with a missing person’s report filed five days ago by Dr. Ryan Shuman, a professor at the university.
It was for Eydis FeAmel, a refugee who was working at the university as a fitness instructor.
She disappeared the night of the events outside town and only recently showed up last night.
She is seated here next to me.”
Eydis closed her eyes and bowed slightly after Sean’s introduction.
“You are saying that the two are connected?”
“They are.
The increase in missing persons cases in Gullivan; I believe Eydis’s case may be connected to the others.”
The male police on Major Wickenny’s left leaned in and whispered something into his ear.
None heard it on Eydis’s side of the table except her.
“The evidence found at the house suggests a connection, does it not,” she repeated verbatim aside from the affirmation at the end.
She felt that this was information her side of the table needed to know, that these police were involved in the investigation of the property and Jethro’s assassins.
More importantly, if they were going to gain the aid of the city guard, these police needed to understand that their citizens had also fallen victim to Jethro’s men.
The police officer’s eyes widened.
He sat straight in his chair and removed a small memo pad and writing utensil for future silent communication.
Perhaps there was more to be said, but Eydis spoke too early.
She silently chastised her impatience.
“I’ve been following the cases out of curiosity, and the original owner of that house was never added to the list of missing persons, to my knowledge.
Anyone who might have discovered the owner missing ended up missing themselves, at least if they visited that location,” Sean mused.
“If those who occupied that house had means of disguising or altering the location the person went missing, they could continue occupation of that house without suspect.”
Major Wickenny cut him off.
“Sean, because this is a multiple homicide with an ongoing investigation, I have to stop you there.”
Eydis felt she finally understood Sean’s relation to the city guard.
He was very intelligent and made connection to Jethro’s men hiding the bodies and abandoning the automated carriages in far-away locations.
Perhaps he was an inquisitor for the city guard.
“As I suspected,” Major Wickenny continued, “we will need to speak with you all individually.
You understand why.”
“I do, but none here were personally involved in what happened outside the city except Eydis,” Sean replied.
“More precisely, those terrorists who occupied that house were searching for Eydis specifically.
They abducted her from the university.
Eydis fought them but was captured in the end.
When the few survivors attempted to remove her from the city, she managed to escape.
If you are looking for the culprit of the deaths in that field, it was Eydis, but it was all in self-defense.”
Major Wickenny’s eyebrows furrowed either from Sean’s insistence on continuing or because he did not believe Sean’s story.
He looked at the two officers at his side and then voiced his disbelief.

“Disregarding the improbable timing of Ms. FeAmel’s disappearance and the massacre at that house she was supposedly involved in, are you saying that all that damage out there was caused by a fight between Ms. FeAmel and a handful of who you claim are terrorists?
Sean, you have done wonderful work for us in the past, so I value the information you give, but--”
“I can prove it,” Eydis interrupted.
Major Wickenny fell silent.
If the police were going to cooperate and help confront Jethro’s men entering the city, they needed to believe Sean’s story.
Only she could prove it without a doubt.
“I can describe the bodies you likely found.
There were ten men in total.
Two were dead in the house and were cut down.
Their bodies were likely burnt from the fire.
A short yet muscular one was lying in the field with no physical damage.
He died from his heart failing.
Three other men in the field died from being stabbed or cut.
One man blew himself up.
The largest crater was from him.
There was one larger man, and his body is in pieces all over the field.
And what might be the strangest for you are the last two men.
They look as men but were much, much smaller, like young children.”
The officer on Major Wickenny’s left wrote something on the memo pad and handed it to him.
Eydis did not need to hear or see the message to know the contents.
The descriptions matched up.
“There is still something I cannot follow,” the female guard on the right said.
“I find it hard to believe that you alone were able to defeat that many people given how much damage was done to the property.”
Sammy, who sat next to Justin, raised her hand.
“Eydis has been teaching self-defense classes at the university.
If you ask Dr. Calliby or any of her students, the girls here included, we could tell you that she is very skilled at fighting.
She’s been practicing for 19 years.”
“That’s not it,” the other guard cut in.
The two extra police seemed to have dropped the idea of questioning everyone individually, much to Eydis’s relief and Major Wickenny’s annoyance.
“The explosions, the craters, the large trench dug across the ground, the damage to the house.
In all of that, there was not a single trace of any explosive or shell or bullet.
The only weapons we found were swords and knives.
You cannot tell us that all that damage was done with those.”
Sean rubbed his temples with his thumb and forefingers.
Almost as if on cue, everyone else on their side of the table looked to Justin.
He exhaled loudly.
“It’s always up to me to decide what can and cannot be said…” he moaned.
“If you have something to say, I suggest you say it,” Major Wickenny warned.
Justin placed a hand on Eydis’s shoulder.
“The reason we came to the police about all this was because there are more of those terrorists out there in the city.
If you encounter them, you will find out anyway, and not knowing might cause otherwise preventable casualties.
This goes against what we were planning on telling you because Eydis wishes it to remain secret, but for your safety as you track these people down, you need to know.”
Major Wickenny leaned forward in his seat, resting his elbows on the table.
“Eydis, can you create a light breeze in the room?
Just a little wind is fine.”
The three police glanced at each other, perplexed by Justin’s peculiar request.
Eydis hesitated.
Did the princess not try her hardest to prevent her magic from being widely known?
The princess trusted Justin, but Eydis was not so foolish to rely on another’s trust in an individual.
However, Eydis’s origins and abilities remained secret from the masses under Justin’s supervision.
To everyone else that Eydis saw during her observations, the princess was just another human, so perhaps showing her magic to the guard would be safe if Justin felt it safe.
Eydis readied her transmission formula in case her trust in the princess’s man was ill-placed.
She breathed in, and air swirled above her outstretched hand.
It built until the air in the room circulated in a light breeze which ebbed after Eydis withdrew her hand.
The faces of the police were a mixture of confusion and surprise.
“This is the reason the terrorists are after her,” Justin continued.
“She can use magic, as could her family.
They opposed the terrorists and were assassinated.
She alone was able to escape and found her way here as a refugee, but they followed because they do not want anyone to live who can use magic to oppose them.
None of us were expecting that.”
“Sorry, but this is just hard to believe…” the female guard said, trading glances with Major Wickenny and the other guard.
“It’s not that hard to believe!” Miriam pounded the table to draw the attention of the officers.
She held out her hand, and above her palm tan granules appeared from nowhere and condensed into a monochromatic tan-colored stone that she slid across the table to the police.
Major Wickenny grabbed the stone and inspected it with wide eyes.
“We are risking our own safety to tell you this so don’t go disregarding our warnings.”
Sammy followed Miriam’s example and created a cloud of mist above her hand but did not condense it into water.
Chloe lit a small flame on her forefinger and sent it dancing across the tips of her fingers.
“What we are saying,” Justin cut in, “is that the terrorists are capable of using magic as well, just like Eydis.
What Eydis taught us is very simple and harmless, but the terrorists are far more powerful.
The man who blew up did not use a bomb.
He detonated himself with fire magic.
All the damage you saw at the scene was not from a weapon.
They do not need bombs or firearms.
Each terrorist is a human weapon.”
Major Wickenny’s eyes widened larger than Eydis felt was natural.
“The one we recovered, what is his condition?”
The male guard contracted Major Wickenny’s panic.
“We received word that he stabilized early yesterday and was expected to wake at any time from then on.”
Major Wickenny glared at Eydis.
“I want you to make yourself absolutely clear.
Is everything you said real?
Are these men dangerous without any weapons?”
Eydis looked back into Major Wickenny’s eyes with all seriousness.
“I impaled the stomach of the fire mage and he was still able to create that explosion before he died.
He nearly killed me.
Weapon or not, injured or not, they are very dangerous.”
Major Wickenny removed a rectangular black object from his waist and held it up to his mouth.
“Emergency.
We need backup at the hospital on West 6th.
Evacuate the entire north wing and lock it down.
Small Man is considered armed and dangerous.
I repeat, Small Man is considered armed and dangerous.
Exercise extreme caution.”
“One of them survived, and you kept him alive?!”
Eydis could not believe what she heard.
One of the minums lived and was being kept at some place called a hospital.
Of all the people they could have saved, the minums were the most dangerous unarmed due to their aptitude for magic.
Major Wickenny frowned.
“I don’t know what country you escaped from, but here, we don’t simply kill unarmed and injured people.”
The response that came back over the communication device stated that the third floor of the north wing of the hospital was already ablaze as of no more than five minutes ago.
Major Wickenny stared in shock at Eydis’s reproachful glare.

Chapter 5
“Secrecy is no longer an option.”
Fect
“Kimmel, Fect, Penk, you three are the brightest fire mages under my command, so there is advanced magic that I want to teach you.”
… “Fect, did you hear?
Kimmel was sent to another world!”
… “Kimmel is missing in action.
Fect, be on standby for deployment.”
… “Fect, because there are no Minums in that world, stay hidden and observe.
There will likely be places you can go that the others cannot.
Use your high sensitivity to ven to try and detect when the princess might use spatial magic.
You have no time limit, and I will not contact you directly.”
… “Mordok is ordering us to be present during her capture.
Be careful.
He brought his Lurr with him.”
… “Hello, princess.”
… The Lurr’s fist hammered the ground with tremendous force.
Rock and frozen earth shot from the crater and approached at incredible speed.
Fect woke in a panic.
He writhed and screamed and patted his body.
Each impact of his small hands was felt on his child-sized torso.
He did not know what death felt like or if there was any feeling at all, but the coarse feeling of his hands on the charred remains of the swiftly burning garment was real.
A spark from the contraption beside him drew his attention to the blazing inferno inside the small room.
He was alive, and in his fright, he had expelled flames that now covered the bed, walls, and ceiling.
A high-pitched sound rang incessantly, and he could not concentrate enough through the deafening noise to reason about where he was.
His mind was clouded as if having awoken from a deep slumber.
“Where am I?”
The door to the room flung open, and a man in black clothing stood in the doorframe.
He shielded his face from the intense heat and marveled at the small man who stared back at him unaffected by the flames that would surely burn him alive.
The man noticed something on the ground out of sight from Fect’s position atop the bed and drew a small object from the sheath on his belt, aiming it at Fect.
Fect sensed aggression in the posture.
Fect gathered concentrated fire ven into his eyes and expelled it as a thin beam focused on the center of the man’s torso.
The man erupted in flames, but what Fect did not expect was the thunderous noise that followed.
He felt a sharp pain in his left arm as if he had been stabbed.
He touched the wound and felt the flakey powder of his blood flash-drying and burning in the intense heat as it left his body.
The handheld item was a weapon, and the projectile it fired was too small and too fast to see.
Its offensive capabilities nearly rivaled his.
If it had hit him somewhere vital, he knew he would be dead, but to his relief, the tiny object passed through his arm.
It hurt, but he was alive and could manage the pain.
He needed to escape before more armed people appeared.
Fect weakened the heat resistance of the wound to let the heat of the room cauterize it.
He jumped off the thin, metal-framed bed onto the floor.
There he saw what caused the man’s hostility.
A woman had the misfortune of being in the room when Fect awoke in an enflamed panic, and she now lay blackened and burning.
He kicked her legs aside and ran out the open door.
White light blinded his eyes, and the incessant ringing blared full force.
A man in a white robe approached, and in Fect’s irritation and confusion, he focused on the floor at the man’s feet.
It heated rapidly, and the formulated fire ven in the beam from his eyes erupted in a flaming pillar.
It engulfed and charred him black instantly before the he could cause Fect any harm as the black-clothed man had.
The flaming pillar clung to the nearby wall and spread to the ceiling as screams echoed louder in the hallways.
A misty rain fell from the ceiling as if attempting to quell the inferno.
Everyone who saw stopped helping others evacuate and either ran for their own lives or collapsed on the ground in fear.
No one assaulted him or even dared to approach.
Fect had time to assess his situation.
“Where am I?”
His words from back in the small room repeated themselves with redoubled confusion.
He scanned the parallel hallways connected by a small room or lobby no wider than the distance between the two hallways.
The floor was smooth and polished and reflected the unnatural white light from the ceiling and the orange glow of his flames.
The ceiling was tiled with a strange material that was quick to catch a flame.
In his time investigating the city for Jethro, he had infiltrated many buildings, but he had never seen the likes of this.
The orange glow of the quickly spreading flames made the blinding white floor, walls, ceiling, and lights more tolerable.
The cowering few appeared unarmed, but the man who entered the room was armed and hostile.
“Is this a government facility?
Military?” Perhaps this was a government facility he missed or was in some confined or hidden location inside one he thought he searched thoroughly.
Fect looked back into his room at the machines and menacing metal arms that bent over his metal bed, entangled in melting cables and wires.
Burning straps hung from the sides of the bed to the ground.
They bound him in a small room with someone overseeing him and a hostile guard waiting just outside the door.
This was a prison, and they were waiting for him to wake in order to interrogate and possibly torture him.
Color drained from Fect’s face.
This world had technology that could never be imitated in Whinhlem.
He could not imagine what methods of torture were available to a city with such incredible and terrifying ingenuity.
He needed to escape this place.
He could not risk being recaptured.
Fect rushed over to one of the cowering women and grabbed her by her hair.
She screamed and flailed her arms, trying desperately to push him away, but Fect held fire in his hand close to her face.
Her struggling immediately ceased.
“Where go?!
Where out?!”
Fect spoke what broken English he knew, but the woman was unresponsive.
She stared at the flame as its heat drew out beads of sweat that ran down her face.
The orange glow of the fire reflected in her terrified, watery eyes.
He would gain no information from her.

He doubted he would be able to understand what she said even if she was willing to tell him the location of the exit, and he wished that his deployment had been delayed so that he could learn this city’s language from an educated instructor like many of his comrades.
Everything he knew was self-taught, and that amounted to little.
Giving up on asking for the location of the exit, he pressed the fire into the woman’s face and increased its intensity until she died in the blaze amid her wailing screams.
He then turned to the final person cowering behind the desk in the center of the room.
The man’s face bled horror from watching such a gruesome execution.
Tears streamed from his wide eyes as he shook his head pleading.
Fect lit a pillar of fire beneath him.
The room was now fully ablaze with fires too strong for the mist to extinguish.
Fect could handle the heat, and the rapidly growing smoke was no cause for concern either.
Using wind magic, he held his hand near his mouth to purify the air he breathed.
His affinities were perfectly suited for fighting in fires within closed spaces.
Large metal doors located at the end of the hallways not only prevented the fire from spreading, but they also kept in the smoke.
The doors to each of the rooms along the walls appeared to provide the same function.
Even the first pillar of fire Fect created had not burned through the door right next to it.
Whatever the purpose of this facility, it was designed to suppress and even extinguish fires.
If he wanted to escape, he needed to pass through one of the doors.
The question became which one would lead to an exit.
Not knowing where to go, Fect ran down the hallway to his left.
He thought he recalled more people fleeing down that direction.
He threw a volatile fireball at the door.
The metal buckled and blew outward in the explosion.
Just as Fect had guessed, the smoke had not passed the door.
The wide intersecting hallway spread in both directions.
People dressed in white and light shades of blue and green rushed others out of rooms on metal-framed beds similar to the one Fect was strapped to not moments before.
Their quick evacuation hastened with fear after seeing the explosion of the door.
The scrambling people avoided Fect.
None showed any hostility towards him, so he reasoned that they were noncombatants.
Only the man in the black uniform was armed, but he could not make any assumptions.
If the color of their clothing carried some significance, there may be others who wore a color other than black that were also armed.
Fect quickly scanned the hallway for a direction to flee.
Far down the hall to the right was a large window that stretched the entire length of the wall.
He could see the white overcast sky and the tips of the trees.
He ran with haste and jumped onto the padded blue benches that lined the underside of the window.
He saw a large building complex.
Two other buildings were visible from his, and from the level of those buildings, he was on the third floor.
Only part of the cityscape was visible.
He could not recognize his location.
A small fear bubbled up from the depths of his mind that he had been taken to a different city.
If that was true, how then would he find his way back?
Location was the least of Fect’s unanswered concerns.
Metal carriages with red and blue flares affixed on top of them poured into the paved lot below.
Men in black uniforms exited the carriages and weaved past the evacuating people to enter the building.
Reinforcements arrived.
The city was not unguarded as previously believed.
The speed of the carriages enabled the guards to quickly respond to threats and removed the need for large numbers or regular patrols.
A missing piece of the puzzle that was this bewildering city had been found but in the worst manner possible.
Escape was now far more difficult.
Fect ran to the left along the windowed hallway in the direction he had seen others flee.
It opened into a grand stairway that led down to a two-story balconied lobby.
The second level balcony at the bottom of the steps was lined with a fogged glass railing.
Warm climate plants with broad leaves grew from large brass vases.
This was grandeur unfitting for a prison, but if not a prison, what was this large building where in they kept a spy bound and under guard?
“Hey, boy, follow me.
We need to…”
Someone’s hand grabbed Fect’s arm from behind.
In a panic, he set him ablaze in another pillar of fire.
Screams broke out on the first and second floors from those still evacuating the building.
Fect ran across the balcony to the stairs.
There he encountered two black-uniformed guards with the same small projectile weapons in hand.
“Get on the ground!
Get on the ground!”
They did not immediately attack but instead shouted commands.
If Fect retaliated, they could attack even if he killed them just as the first guard had.
He shrouded himself in fire ven and meticulously formulated the heat to refract the light around him.
His body blurred in the waves of heat until he disappeared.
The two guards watched in disbelief.
One began to lower his weapon, and the other motioned him to stay alert.
Fect was annoyed by that guard’s wisdom.
Although he was concealed, the covering was not perfect.
Jethro explained that if perfected, this magic would conceal while in motion, but Fect was yet unskilled.
If he moved, the covering would weaken, and his blurred outline would become visible.
The concealment magic also drained his ven at a staggering pace, and he could not keep it active for long.
The guards asserted their aim while their eyes scanned their surroundings.
Fect tried to slowly inch to the side so that his camouflage would not waver, but the experienced guard had keen eyesight.
“He’s still there!
The air is distorted!”
“Suspect is armed and dangerous.
Exercise extreme caution if contacted.”
A muffled voice spoke from the direction of the two men.
One of the guards reached for an item on his waist tethered by a thin, coiling cord.
“Target encountered, lobby, second floor.
He… he has some sort of cloaking tech.
He turned invisible right in front of--”
Fect dove to the side while simultaneously throwing a fireball.
The two weapons fired with the same thunderous noise, but the projectiles missed.
The fireball exploded, covering the stairs where the two men stood and part of the balcony where Fect dove.
He hid in the flames and ran down the stairs past the two wailing, burning bodies to the first floor of the lobby.
Outside the large windows, the number of carriages with blue and red flares had increased drastically.
Numerous guards gathered, heading in Fect’s direction.
For the first time, Fect saw the black-uniformed men carrying something that was clearly a weapon.
He could tell it was similar in design to the small handheld weaponry the earlier guards used, but these were the length of a grown man’s arm.
If the small ones had the power to send a projectile through his arm, the larger ones would be far greater.
Common sense dictated that the larger the weapon, the greater the power, even if the nature of the weapons was unknown.
No sensible weaponsmith would increase the size of a weapon at the cost of power.
Exiting the main doors of the lobby was no longer safe.
Fect feared that the moment he opened the door, he would be killed in an instant.
Fect noticed three stragglers run off in a different direction.
He pursued them down a side hallway, and to his relief, there was a door at the end that led outside.
He waited until the three escaped so that they would not see him exit.
Once outside, he activated his concealment magic.
Behind him, the fire from his attacks on the third floor set the side of the building ablaze.
A large pillar of black smoke billowed into the air.
The fire should keep them preoccupied.
Fect slowly walked across a narrow road, weaved through the grass and shrubbery, and climbed over the fence.
There he removed his concealment magic.
A wide, busy road stretched in both directions.
Fect stood in grass atop a wall about thirty feet above the shoulder of the road.
He ran along it until the fence became another wall on his left and the thin patch of grass grew wide enough for shrubs to grow.
Now that he was out of the building complex and had traveled some distance down the wide highway, he sat down behind some thick brush to catch his breath.
After looking around, he was able to rid himself of one of his worries.
Although this part of the city was unfamiliar, he recognized the same distinct buildings that towered above into the sky.
By using these buildings and the mountains to orient him, he found that he was on the opposite side of the city from the house his team used as a base of operations.
It was an hour’s walk outside the city on the other side of the river and possibly three hours from his current location.
His only hope was to reach it and wait until Jethro opened the portal once more.
The adrenaline in Fect’s body calmed, and the pain of his injuries fired back through his nerves at full force.
He lay back behind the shrub and fought in a mental struggle to endure the pain.
His skin stung, and his muscles ached in specific locations on his torso, arms, and legs.
All over his body, injuries were sealed shut.
The small pockmarks along the wounds suggested they were sewn but the threads burnt in the flames.
When the Lurr giant attacked the princess, Fect had been in the path of the debris.
The many injuries that had nearly killed him had been treated at that facility.
Aside from the guards, those at the facility were non-combatants.
There were others on similar beds to the one he was bound to.
He was not being restrained as a criminal.
His injuries were severe enough that movement could be detrimental to his recovery.
That was a medical facility.
The severity of Fect’s actions struck him harder than the debris of the Lurr.
How much time had passed?
If his comrades were successful in capturing the princess, would they have need of opening the portal again?
What if he was left behind?
What if he was abandoned for dead?
He removed the witnesses near his room, but many saw him during his escape of the building, and those who recovered him after the battle with the princess knew his appearance.
The city guards also knew he was there.
No others in this world could use magic.
It was a skill unique to him.
While investigating the city and searching for the princess, Fect had stayed hidden.
Not once had he taken a life of someone in the city.
Although he was associated with those who had killed and captured citizens, he had not taken part.
His job as a scout was to observe, and he only participated directly once the princess was located.

If he had realized his situation and stayed in the medical facility until he was healed, he might have received a lighter punishment if he explained why they were hunting the princess and could have even helped the city as had the princess.
If Jethro truly left him behind, all hope of integrating himself into this world’s society was destroyed the moment he killed medical staff, guards, and set fire to a medical facility.
“My life is over…”
Fect was a soldier, and though younger than most, he was trusted with a mission to this foreign world that he knew had no guarantee of survival or return.
“If Jethro has abandoned me, then I will die with honor.
But first,” he looked in the direction of the nearby mountains, “I must return to base.”
There was no guarantee that the mission had been successful or that Jethro had lost all interest in this world even if the mission was a success.
He had to make certain the portal would not reopen.
Fect rolled to his knees to stand.
His body fought him with every movement, but his legs held solid.
His body ached, but the pain was bearable.
One foot led the other.
He pushed himself forward with a third step and then a fourth, slowly forcing his body into an unstable run.
After a few minutes of flight, the wall he stood atop descended to only a couple feet off the highway.
The road gradually bent to the right, the opposite direction Fect needed to go.
The wall on his left prevented him from leaving the banked shoulder, and there was no visible way through it down the road.
The city guards had not pursued him thus far, so Fect risked breaching the wall, but he had to be subtle about it.
Fect stopped next to the wall behind a shrub large enough to conceal him.
With an intense but small fireball, he blew a hole in the base of the wall with minimal smoke from the blast.
The masonry was far stronger than he anticipated.
The stone blew out weakly and only crumbled to the ground on the other side.
Metal bars lined the inside.
Heating metal was easy for a fire mage, but melting it was often difficult.
Kimmel was his superior in fire magic and was adept at heating and manipulating stone and metal due to having affinities to both fire and earth.
Fect could not melt or bend the metal, but he had another method at his disposal, again taught him by Jethro.
Fect lit an intense flame on the tip of his extended fore and middle fingers.
He then expelled wind from between those fingers.
After gauging the intensity of the flame and the purity of the air, the flame elongated and grew white.
It cut through the metal reinforcing in a shower of sparks to give him enough room to slip through.
On the other side, small trees and shrubs grew sparsely between the wall and another fence.
Fect had to wonder where this city’s obsession with perimeter barriers came from and why they were all inside the city on individual properties but not a single wall surrounded its borders.
The fence encased a field of grass where children played in the distance.
Three children stood near the fence and watched Fect emerge.
“Look!
He’s naked!”
Two boys laughed, but the girl ran away.
One of the boys was taller than Fect, but the other was close to Fect’s size.
Fect ran to the fence and climbed over it before the two could react.
He knocked out the taller boy with a kick to the side of his head as he jumped down.
The smaller boy began crying, so Fect placed his hand over the boy’s mouth.
“Give clothes,” Fect ordered.
The crying child was too scared to obey, so Fect knocked him out and stripped him.
Down the field, the girl returned with a woman who immediately sprinted towards him after noticing his assault on the children.
She removed something from her pocket.
Fect tucked the shirt and pants under his arm, grabbed the cap the taller boy wore, and hopped back over the fence.
The woman did not chase, but she held the communication device all humans of this world carried to her ear.
She was reporting him.
City guards would surely follow.
Now that he obtained this world’s clothing, blending in as one of the city’s children was possible, but Fect’s facial stubble was a problem.
His beard grew quite full for his age.
He rubbed his cheeks, chin, and neck.
The stubble burnt off in the heat of his hand, resulting in a much younger, youthful face that had often been a point of ridicule among his colleagues.
Fect could do nothing about his youthful appearance being only a one-and-a-half-year-old minum, but now it was his saving grace.
So long as no one looked too closely, he would appear no different than a slender-faced human boy of half a year old.
The end of the fence opened into a mixed residential and small commercial district of the city.
The buildings were not as grand as those at the medical facility or closer to the center of the city.
They reminded Fect of the far side of the river.
If he continually travelled in the direction of the mountains, he would meet the river and could follow it most of the way to the outskirts of the city.
But first, he needed a rest.

Running along the highway wall, converting wind ven to cut through it, hopping a fence twice, and then running again to distance himself from the field of children severely shortened his breath in the thin air of this world.
He was confident in his endurance, and his incredibly light weight made acrobatics easier, but in his injured state, he was reaching his limit.
The field of children was far behind him, and the wooden fences of the surrounding houses hid his location, so Fect risked a short rest.
He sat against one of the wooden fences and inspected the clothing.
The blue pants were no different than those generally worn by many of this world’s citizens, but the shirt was peculiar.
It was blue with caricatures of strange animals on the front.
In the bottom center was a yellow rodent.
On the rodent’s left was a large, shelled creature with two short metal tubes protruding from its shell.
On the right was a stocky lizard with a flowering plant growing from its back.
Behind them all in the top center was an easily recognizable dragon blowing fire into the air.
There was no reason behind the caricatures or why they would be on a shirt worn by a child.
Perhaps they were legendary creatures or gods of this world?
Perhaps that was an orphanage run by the local religion.
The same sirens Fect heard at the medical facility grew louder in the distance.
The short rest was over.
He donned the shirt and pants and found them a near perfect fit.
The sirens were likely heading for the field where the children played, so Fect waited.
The sirens passed by, heading further down the road.
He used this opportunity to run from between the houses and down the street of the residential district.
The river was an unknown distance away, but because it bisected the city, he would reach it so long as he headed towards the mountains.
The road turned, so Fect cut across the yard of a house and hopped a plank-wood fence.
He then continued through the small kempt yard and over another fence.
A strange sound met his ears that he had never heard the like of before.
It was comparable to the rapid flapping of large wings but was far more rhythmic and unnatural.
He looked to the sky and found a machine traveling through the air.
The sight took his breath away.
It was clearly not an animal or monster of some kind.
Although the shape was different, it had windows like the carriages on the ground.
Some blurred force attached to the top of the contraption fastened it to the sky.
Even without knowing what it was, he knew who piloted it.
The city guards controlled the air!
That flying machine was searching for him.
It was still far off, but he could no longer risk taking any actions that would draw attention.
If he could see it, the machine could see him.
He needed to find a populated location and blend in.
Fect ran along the road towards the direction of larger buildings.
The road left the residential district and widened.
Four lanes of traffic traveled it, and there were more people passing along its walkways, yet there were no children, so Fect stood out.
There were many children in that far field, and possibly more inside the adjacent building.
What if all children were communally watched in similar locations?
Fect would have no hope of hiding among them in plain sight.
Cloaking himself with fire magic to become invisible for long enough to escape the city was impossible with its incredible cost.
He kept a brisk stride down the side of the road looking for any means to travel hidden or be further disguised.
The sound of the flying machine grew louder, so Fect dove to the side into some leafy bushes near the road.
The passing people paid little attention, and those that did take notice only shook their heads, maybe thinking he was a child at play.
The flapping of the machine quieted.
Fect was about to leave his cover when he noticed a station across the road.
Carriages lined up beneath its canopy.
Their drivers tended to some screen and then placed a tube in an opening on the side of their carriage.
Fect ran to the pedestrian crossing, waited until another human started crossing, and then ran across the road to the station.
He waited concealed near the hedge line separating the road from the stands under the canopy where the carriages parked.
Carriages came and went.

The order of the actions and level of attention changed from person to person, but each driver that serviced their carriage at the station stood in front of the screen twice: once when arriving before placing the tube in the side of the carriage and once more when removing the tube and returning it to the stand.
All that he required was a suitable victim to pull their carriage up closest to the hedge.
The opportunity arrived quicker than anticipated.
A finely crafted carriage pulled in.
The driver was younger, appearing no more than a year older than Fect or perhaps less.
He was far too skinny and unstable in his gait to be skilled in any form of combat.
He left his door ajar and walked to the other side of his carriage to the screen as all drivers had.
Once Fect was sure no one was watching, he dove out of the bushes and into the box seat.
He crawled into the back behind the box seat and waited.
A small white bag that smelled of fried food sat beside him, and its enticing aroma made his throat constrict and saliva pool in his mouth.
How log had it been since he last ate?
How long had he been unconscious?
Fect reached for the food, but the driver finished servicing the carriage too quickly.
The driver entered and closed the door.
The carriage grew alive with a loud hum.
It rolled out of the lot and turned onto the road.
Fect jumped into the passenger seat beside the driver.
The driver startled at the sudden appearance of a child and swerved on the road but managed not to collide with any other carriages.
Loud horns blared all around.
“The fuck you doing, kid?”
Fect looked at the man whose expression quickly grew surprised after seeing an adult of Fect’s stature.
“No kid.
You,” Fect pointed at the mountains in the distance, “go there!”
“What?
No!
Get out of my car!”
The man turned the wheel, and the carriage turned with it, pulling towards the side of the road.
Fect conjured a small flame in his hand and increased its intensity without increasing its size so that the man could feel the heat.
The fabric ceiling of the carriage began to smoke.
The driver stopped the carriage suddenly before reaching the roadside.
Fect held onto the back of the seat to not get thrown forward and pointed to the mountains again.
Once more a cacophony of horns blared around them.
“Go there!”
“You serious!?”
“GO!”
The scared man directed the carriage without another complaint.
Fect extinguished his flame, but a large brown spot remained on the fabric ceiling smoldering with small embers.
If Fect had learned to control these carriages as some of his companions had, he would not need this fool’s help.
Then again, he was short in stature and would not have been able to operate it well even if he had learned.
These machines were not built with consideration to short people.
At least he had a ride.
Fect reasoned that if he could leave the city, traveling would become much easier.

The only question in his mind was whether to stop the man at the river and follow the river out of town or to continue out of town to the road up the mountain and then walk around the city to the base.
The former would keep him in the city longer, increasing his chances of being spotted by the guards on the ground.
The latter would give him more freedom of movement, but the distance was further with little cover, increasing the chance of being spotted by the guard in the air.
There was a third option, directing the man to the base, but Fect was unsure if the location was compromised.

If it was, the guard in the air might notice if a carriage headed for it, or if there were guards stationed at it, an unknown carriage approaching could be reason enough for them to attack with those lethal ranged weapons, so Fect decided against it.
There were many guards on the ground but only one in the air, and that guard was still circling this part of the city.
Fect made his decision.
He would drop the initial plan of traveling along the river and instead travel from the foot of the mountain.
The city that Fect feared would take far too long to cross on foot was now passing by at incredible speed.
Inside the carriage, he had no risk of being spotted so long as the driver followed his order.
They turned left and after a short distance crossed the river.
The size of the buildings shrunk as did the number of people.
After a few more turns, they pulled onto a larger straight road that Fect recognized from the shops and signboard landmarks.
This one would lead out of the city.
Fect was grateful that the city had no walls, no gate, and no customs inspections.
Travel in and out of the city was free, something he felt was foolish for such a large and populated city.
Any dangerous individuals could get in, or in his case, out.
After leaving the city proper, the buildings disappeared.
Only a large plain of dirt and dead grass with small ponds of water from the snowmelt spread before him.
When the road began its incline, Fect stopped the driver.
The man pulled off to the side of the road, relieved that he would not need to travel further.
“I took you where you wanted, now get out of my car.”
“This.
Give this!” Fect held his hand to his ear, mimicking the use of the small communication device.
“Give what?”
“This!” Fect made a rectangle with his hands and again acted like he was holding the device to his ear.
“My phone?”
“Yes, phone!
Give phone!”
“You serious?”
Fect produced another hot flame.
The man quickly removed his phone from his pocket and handed it over.
Fect brought the two together, destroying the phone instantly.
Now the man would be unable to immediately summon the guards.
Fect looked at the door and tried to find the means to open it but couldn’t.
“Out.”
“You don’t even know how to open a door?”
Fect blew out the window with a weak fireball and jumped out after grabbing the bag of food from the back seat.
He ran across both lanes of traffic to the other side of the road and sprinted across the field.
The base was still a long way off, but the guards were not following, and the flying guard was a small speck in the sky over the city.
The wet grass and dirt chilled Fect’s bare feet as he ran.
There were ways to warm his body with fire magic, but he did not know what he would encounter at the base.
If there were guards there, he might have to eliminate them, and he was already running low on ven.

* * *
In his injured and tired state, the sun sunk low in the sky by the time Fect reached the familiar withered fields on the outskirts of the city.
He kept his distance to monitor the area around the house before he approached.
When he was close enough to see it in the distance, the setting sun painted the field dark orange.
The temperature was dropping fast, and there was little shelter available.
The house was in ruins having clearly burnt down in the struggle with the princess.
All that remained was a charred frame and walls.
The fire had been dealt with before it could consume the structure, but far too much of it was destroyed.
Still keeping his distance, Fect circled to the back of the house where the battle occurred.
The struggle had been far more intense than Fect thought.
A massive scar was carved over the field, and a large crater sat off to the side.
Worst of all, there were no signs of his comrades anywhere in the vicinity.
The house itself had a perimeter of thin yellow ribbon surrounding it as if warning people to stay clear.
It was likely set up by the city guards, but thankfully none were present, at least that he could see.
After reaffirming that the property was deserted, Fect activated his concealment magic and crept to the back of the house where a large part of the wall had been blown inward.
The inside was far more damaged than the outside.
Some of the furniture was burnt to coal, and a few of the walls had collapsed.
Structural stability was questionable with many sections of ceiling caving in.
The kitchen was where the portal exited, but there were no recent signs of anyone entering or leaving the kitchen.
Jethro opened the portal once every nine or ten days in this world, and Fect had no way to tell how long he was unconscious other than how far his injuries had healed.
The areas on his body that had been penetrated or cut by debris had not fully healed.
This world did not have life magic, so healing was left to the body’s natural processes, much like in his home country.
From Fect’s former experiences with the healing of similar injuries, he had been out anywhere from three to five days on Whinhlem, which was anywhere from six to eleven in this world.
The last portal was the day before the fight with the princess.
This meant that either the portal had not yet opened, or it opened and he had just missed it.
Jethro opened the portal periodically throughout the day until contact was made, so Fect had a large window if it had already opened once or twice.
If he missed one opening, he could catch the next, until the day passed and the portal would no longer open for another nine to ten days.
If the second attempt at communication failed ten days later, then Jethro would send more people to assess the situation.
If Fect missed this opening, he could wait for the next.
If that portal did not open, then he would know the mission was a success and that Jethro abandoned him for dead.
Fect huddled in a corner of the hallway near exposed wooden beams that still looked like they held the skeletal roof sturdy.
He opened his now cold bag of food and began eating the long and slender fried vegetables.
There was little food in the bag, so he had to ration it.
Given his estimates, he could survive three days through extreme rationing, or about six in this world.
If the portal did not open then, he would have to leave for more permanent shelter and food.
The sun set and took with it what meager warmth was there, leaving only the deep chill of night.
The destroyed house did little to insulate Fect from the cold, and he was forced to search the house for any blankets or clothing that had not burnt in the fire.
Luckily, there were some that were only partially damaged in the bedroom.
He gathered any fabric scraps he could find into a pile in the shell of one of the lower cupboards of the kitchen in order to remain within sight of the portal’s location.

Once inside, he covered himself in the charred fabric and prepared to weather the cold night, but the peaceful air was disturbed by the sound of one or two of the carriages rolling over the gravel out front of the house.
The glow of the red and blue flares showered through the gaps in the ruined walls and windows.
The guards were cunning.
They expected him to return here, or perhaps they were told by someone that he would return.
What if the princess survived and was working with the city guard?
Fect huddled himself deeper inside the cupboard.
Steps approached the back of the house, and three guards entered with those handheld weapons drawn.
They moved with silent steps and inspected the living room, kitchen, and down the hallway.
When each guard came up empty, they regrouped in the kitchen.
“Major said he was likely to return here.”
“From the informant, that girl they were after?”
“That’s my guess.”
“He might not have made it here yet.
He’s probably hiding somewhere in the city for now.”
One of the guards motioned the other two to stay silent and pointed at the floor.
There were tiny footsteps in the soot.
The footsteps led into the living room and down the hall into the study and bedroom, but they did not stay there.
One of the guards noticed that the footsteps entered the kitchen from outside but never left.
Fect’s heart beat strong enough for his injuries to sting.
The guards narrowed his location to the kitchen.
He converted fire ven in his hands in case they located him, but something immediately drew their attention.
The air in the middle of the kitchen grew a long crack that widened into a black void.
The guards backed away in fear and aimed their weapons at it.
This was information that the city guards of this world could not know.
Fect dove out from the broken cupboard in a blaze of fire and roasted the guard nearest him.
The other two guards pointed their weapons and fired multiple shots.
One projectile penetrated Fect’s left shin while another hit his right shoulder.
Undaunted, Fect ignited a pillar of fire beneath the guard to his left, killing him instantly.
The kitchen grew ablaze with new fire.
The final guard ran into the living room for cover because fire blocked the exit of the destroyed back wall.
Fect pursued to prevent the guard from exiting the front door and reporting the portal.
The moment Fect entered the living room he was shot again, a burning pain passing into his stomach.
He spat up blood but kept his composure.
He was a soldier, a special operative personally trained by Jethro.
By life or death, he would complete his mission.
Wind and fire channeled into each hand.
Fect expelled a large funnel of flame that burnt everything within sight until shivers stronger than the cold racked his body.
The guard rolled from his hiding place behind the burnt sofa and flailed on the ground in a wailing inferno before falling immobile.
From outside, another guard called out.
There was one more.
Fect could barely keep himself steady.
He had to get the portal closed before that final guard saw it, before he collapsed from injury and exhaustion into death.
He ran back into the kitchen and was about to run into the portal but noticed one of the small projectile weapons lying on the floor.
He grabbed it before diving into the portal.

Chapter 6
“A more powerful form of teleportation.”
Jethro
“Close the portal now!”
Fect appeared from the black abyss and landed at Jethro’s feet, blood spitting from his mouth as he screamed.
Jethro immediately closed the portal and opened another.
He reached his arm in and pulled out a female High Elf slave.
“Treat him.
Quickly!”
The slave overcame her surprise and knelt next to Fect to begin sealing the wounds but stopped.
“There is something foreign inside.
I am in need of a knife.”
Jethro removed the knife from his belt and handed it to the High Elf.
She skillfully cut in and dug out two metal pellets from Fect’s leg and shoulder.
The one in his stomach was far more difficult, but with the aid of life magic, the invasive procedure was successful.
She stopped the bleeding and mended the fatal damage to Fect’s stomach, saving his life.
Fect stared blankly up at the intricately carved and painted ceiling of the large council room of the palace.
The pain of the emergency operation had exhausted him, and his eyes were half glazed over.
Jethro looked down at the pale minum, worried that Fect would be incapable of reporting what happened on the other side.
Never had any of his men returned from the other world so terribly injured.
It was then that he noticed the strange but almost familiar object in the minum’s hand.
The source of the wounds became clear.
He picked up the weapon and admired it but took care not to touch the trigger.
It was crude in design, almost rustic, like a relic of ancient history.
He aimed at the headboard of one of the balcony seats and fired.
The High Elf yelped, and the two nearby human soldiers started at the noise.
The wood splintered just off from where he had aimed.
“A physical projectile handgun.
So, they do not have magic but have technology like this.” He set the weapon on the arm of the throne and knelt beside Fect.
“What happened?”
After a few pats on the cheek, weak life returned to Fect’s eyes.
He looked at Jethro, finally remembering why he was here.
He shot up to a sitting position and spat out the blood that pooled in his mouth.
“The princess, was the mission successful?!
Did you capture her?!”
“That is what I would like to ask you.
What happened?”
Fect slouched as though Jethro’s words cut the final strings supporting him.
“As I thought… They failed…” After a deep, painful breath, Fect elaborated.
“The Doppelganger located the princess.
Mordok ordered my squad to aid in her capture.
She sent the princess to us, but I fell injured at the beginning of the fight.
I woke in a medical facility and had to fight my way out.
I escaped back to the base, but they knew I would return there.
Someone was informing them.
I fear that it may have been the princess.”
Or the Doppelganger, Jethro thought.
While Jethro had hoped that the Doppelganger would be cooperative, he only had faith in her inborn desire as a Doppelganger to replace the princess to prevent her from running or crossing him.
Sending the princess to his men was a surprise, and betrayal was always a possibility; however, even if she did betray him, he was no worse off than being without her help.
In fact, she proved very useful in confirming the princess resided in the city, and she may still prove useful in the future.
“That means the princess remains in the city.
She has not moved on,” Jethro stated for confirmation.
“Yes, at the educational institution from what Austin told the Doppelganger.
We thought the city unarmed.
We were wrong.
They have weapons.
I was lucky not to be killed by them.
I almost was killed by them…” Fect’s eyes fell to the floor.
“Which would you say is more powerful, our magic and weaponry or their weaponry alone?”
“Those I fought were only city guards.
I saw much larger of those strange weapons.
If they had power to match their size, I would not have survived being shot once.
They also control the skies.
One had some sort of flying… thing.” Fect’s eyes shot up at Jethro showing the disbelief in his own words.
“It was not a creature, but one of their carriages hovering in the air!”
“They have even developed air travel far enough to produce machinery capable of suspending itself in flight.
This world is far more advanced that I formerly thought.”
A bit of worry crossed Jethro’s mind.
Fect was badly injured and had stated that he fought with city guards.
“Did the guards see the portal?
Do they know we come from another world?”
Fect stayed silent at first but responded after another breath.
“I killed all the guards near the portal.
I do not think that anyone else saw it, but there was one more guard approaching.
I had no confidence I could kill him with my injuries, so I prioritized reporting to you over making certain I was not seen.
He was well out of sight of the portal when I entered, but I do not know if he saw it before it closed.”
The young minum prepared to receive punishment for potentially revealing a vital secret to the other world, but Jethro had no desire to punish him.
Fect was able to make the best decision in such a short time during an emergency.
This showed a level of judgement that Jethro hated to admit most of his soldiers lacked.
Revealing that he and his men were from another world was worth knowing that the princess was still in the city.
There was always the possibility that the princess already informed the city as such.
Fect weighted his priorities correctly.
Jethro was already preparing Fect for a position as a commanding officer of his army, following after Fect’s father, but perhaps he could go even further.
He decided to discuss Fect’s potential with the generals at a later date depending on Fect’s future achievements.
“I do not feel we can be secret about our desires to find the princess any longer,” Fect said.
“They know we are there, and they have seen our magic.
If the princess really did side with the city, I feel they have become our enemy.
They will be ready for us next time.”
“If we want to find the princess, then sending only a handful of men through a stationary portal will be of little use from here on out,” Jethro mused.
“I believe so.”
Jethro lifted the minum and placed him in the arms of the High Elf slave.
“See to his full recovery.
Fect, I will have need of you again soon, so rest well.
Know that I am proud of what you have accomplished, and you will be rewarded accordingly.”
Once the slave carried Fect away, Jethro dismissed the two soldiers with him and slouched back into the throne.
“So, that location has been compromised.
Assuming Eydis would not abandon the city knowing we are there… No, she would not abandon it.
She would stay to protect it, and if the Doppelganger is still alive, she would remain there as well because Eydis is there.
Both of them, and now with the addition of the city guard, they will be far more vigilant.”
Jethro exhaled a large sigh, but it was not one of frustration.
A small smile spread on his lips.
Things were becoming entertaining.
“Time to pay Emer another visit.”
He grabbed the handgun, placed it in his belt, and opened a portal back to the Tolmyur Kingdom.
The portal exited into a dimly lit stone corridor.
The torches on the walls were small and spaced far enough apart to provide only the minimum light required to see.
The air was humid despite the chill and carried the sour odor of mildew.
The old wooden door next to him was growing moss.
Despite the appearance, Prison Fort Tammonurk on the norther tip of the Tolmyur Kingdom was among the finest in the kingdom.
If Jethro had sent Emer to a lesser prison, Emer might not have lasted.
He could have kept Emer in the palace, but the humidity of this location was ideal.
Jethro unlatched and opened the door to the small room.
It contained a molding bed mat made of course fabric stuffed with straw, a small table with parchment and an ink well with a quill, a single chair next to the table, and a brazier by the door.
On the bed sat what looked like a short High Elf, but he was not alone.
The other resident was the reason for requiring high humidity.
A rare species of ivy dryad, a kissiae named Keeya, clung to his back.
After the fall of the Amelian Empire, the dryads were one of the first to submit to Jethro.
He ordered them to give him an able kissiae shaman in order to make use of Emer’s knowledge.
Kissiae were being sheltered in the Elos marshlands of the dryad controlled territory, Dhuillir, and were few in number due to being hunted all over the world.
Like all dryads, kissiae were female.
The difference between a kissiae and the usual dryad breeds was that kissiae were smaller than their dryad counterparts, about the size of minums, and they were parasitic in nature.
They secreted a poison from their bodies that affected the minds of those who came in contact with them.
With a potent enough dose, the host would become a submissive puppet to the kissiae.
The kissiae could then leach nutrients from the host through their skin and ivy hair.
It was their manipulative power that Jethro required, but he ordered the kissiae shaman to take her domination one step further.

Keeya appeared to have her legs wrapped around Emer’s exposed torso at the waistline with one hand crossing his chest and the other pressed to the side of his head, but upon closer inspection, the appendages of the Kissiae were fused with Emer’s body.
Small vines and fine fibers grew from her skin and rooted into Emer’s skin and muscles, wrapping around his bones and intertwining with his internal organs.
The vines of the hand fused to his head left bulging lines across his forehead, cheek, and down his neck.
Keeya’s body was pressed against his back but was not fused like her arms and legs.
The head of the kissiae that rested against Emer’s shoulder took notice of Jethro’s entrance.
Keeya turned to look at Jethro with her weary and slightly sunken eyes.
Her variegated ivy-like hair slid to one side as she lifted her head.
Jethro grabbed the torch outside the door and lit the brazier in the room.
He then returned the torch and closed the door.
Keeya winced from the light of the fire, her eyes accustomed to the dark.
Jethro reached behind Keeya and plucked six small buds from her long ivy hair that extended down her back and coiled on the bed.
Like all dryads, when their hair flowered, pollen collected and could impregnate the dryad.
In her state, pregnancy was very problematic.
Kissiae birthrate was extremely low, and being far from the pollen of her native ivy further decreased the chance, but a risk was a risk.
She watched in shame as he once again threw her budding flowers into the brazier.
Jethro could not cut off her hair because removing a kissiae’s hair made them very ill, and sickness would drastically weaken her control over Emer.
Because kissiae were so small, much of their body’s fluids resided in the long and thick vines of their hair.
To remove an adult kissiae’s hair was equivalent to removing no less than half of the life sap circulating nutrients in their body.
This was a problem that kissiae life magic could not heal, so the hair must remain.
Jethro sat cross-legged on the chair in the room and folded his arms.
“Is he awake?”
Keeya nodded.
“I am awake.”
The voice of the man carried the monotone depression of one who had given up all hope.
The mind-altering drug did not remove the freedom of thought of the individual but made them unable to resist the will of the kissiae or those the kissiae wanted the host to obey.
If the kissiae wanted their host to kill themselves or a loved one, they would be unable to refuse.
Kissiae were hunted out of fear or to process this drug for use on slaves, prisoners, or others as a form of mind-control, leading to the kissiae’s small population.
Emer was fully aware of his situation and that he was helping Jethro hunt Eydis FeAmel, but he could not refuse.
“What do you need me for this time?”
“Continuing our former discussion.
Circumstances arose that require me to expedite our research.
Have you made any progress on your end?”
Keeya nodded.
“Yes,” Emer replied.
Jethro reached over and touched the hand attached to Emer’s head.
Keeya removed the ven trace for the spell Emer had been developing in Jethro’s absence and passed it to him.
Jethro sat back and focused on reverse engineering the trace back into the teleportation formula, a trivial but time-consuming act.
His hand flew over a piece of parchment on the table beside him as he drew the formula, adding notes where more explanation would be needed.
Jethro considered himself a master of spatial magic and had knowledge of the capabilities of spatial magic that Emer lacked, but Emer’s understanding and ability to manipulate it was far superior.
Emer often had to elaborate on many key points of his formulas to help Jethro comprehend them.
The finished formula on the paper made Jethro’s head spin.
“As expected of transmission, the ven cost is far lower, but… Hold on.”
One of the sections of the formula he noted for additional explanation became clear with further inspection.
“This peculiar section is for stability, correct?
Transmission normally does not require stability because the portal is instantaneous and does not need to be held open.”
“The transmission is not instantaneous, because the distance between worlds is so great.
The portal must hold long enough for the target to reach its destination.”
“Do you even realize what you have here?” Jethro’s heart raced in uncontainable excitement.
The strangely designed stability section of the formula hinted at something he formerly thought impossible.
Jethro grabbed another sheet of parchment and scribbled out his revelation.
“Emer, what are the 3 laws of spatial teleportation?”
Emer’s dead voice answered as if reciting a text.

“First, the number and estimated mass of objects to be sent through the portal must be known beforehand and built into the formula, and the complexity of formula and expenditure increases exponentially with the number of objects to be sent through.
Second, portals created in close proximity of either entrance or destination will fuse and collapse on each other.
Third, the larger in size the portal, the more unstable and prone to collapse it is, with three jurs being the maximum possible safe diameter.”
“Take a look at this.”
Jethro held up the formula Emer had devised in one hand with the minor alteration Jethro had scribbled out side by side.
Emer opened his eyes to scan the parchment.
His eyes opened wider and wider.
He grabbed both parchments with his one remaining hand and read them again and again, looked back at Jethro, and then read them one final time.
“I was only looking for a way to use transmission to teleport to the other world, but this… THIS is groundbreaking!
You, Emer, are a wizard in every sense of the word.
Laws of spatial magic be damned.
We have our work cut out for us tonight.
Keeya, if this works out, you will have some sun tomorrow, so make sure Emer is in top condition as we work.”
Keeya’s eyes quickly grew attentive.
“Sun?” She nodded her head repeatedly.
Jethro pulled the table between him and Emer, and they got to work finalizing the formula in a creative fever.
Late morning after the early mist had cleared, two giant soldiers accompanied Jethro and Emer outside the fort to a vast grassy clearing dotted with a few large coniferous trees.
The field provided a sturdy foundation for the large fort in a territory known for its near-uninhabitable marshlands.

Jethro wished that the field had been used for a village or other settlement that could make use of the small grassland for well needed crops, but due the hostile goblin domain to the north of Tolmyur, the former kings felt the strategic benefits of the fort outweighed the crops the land could provide for the starving people.
They stepped out from the shade of the fort into the sun.
When the variegated leaves of Keeya’s hair met the radiant warmth, they shook lightly and furled out.
Emer broke into a sprint.
The two giants were about to make chase, but Jethro called them back.
“There is no need.”
Jethro did not fear Emer fleeing.
So long as the kissiae remained attached, any attempt at escape or betrayal was impossible, and he did not doubt the kissiae’s loyalty.
He bested Keeya in front of the remainder of her kind in Elos, proving that he had the power to either protect them or destroy them.
He vowed to protect the last of the kissiae as the Amelian royalty once did if she swore her undying fealty to Jethro.
This was their agreement, and Keeya would never break it.
When Emer reached the center of the field where no shadows could touch him, he spun with his outstretched hand grasping at the celestial warmth.
He leapt with a limber step and pranced with youthful glee through the golden-brown blades of grass.
With a swing of his head and a lithe twist of his hips, the verdant vines of Keeya’s hair spun in a wide fan.
A euphoric laugh of effeminate joy danced along the light morning breeze.
The two giants watched the scene with perplexed expressions, but Jethro could only smile.
“Keeya seems to be enjoying herself.
We can let her have her fun.”
The feminine laugh grew to an entrancing song in a language unknown to Jethro.
Emer’s dance followed the rhythm of the light tune as he leapt and spun with his arm curved above his head and then unfurling to brush the leaves of Keeya’s trailing hair.
He arched back to fall into the golden field but turned down to his knees in a limber motion before spinning to his feet with one leg gracefully extended outwards.
Another spin followed the last with his arm reaching for the sun as if trying to hold it in an embrace, just as the bewitching dance had begun.
Jethro felt the scene would have been beautifully captivating if it was a woman dancing, not the grotesque fusion of dryad and elf.
“Fetch a water mage,” Jethro ordered.
The giant on Jethro’s left jogged back to the fort and returned with an annoyed minum hanging in his grip by the back of the minum’s robe.
Emer had finished his dance and sat in a ball with his arms and knees tucked under him in the center of the field so that Keeya’s back faced the sun.
Her long ivy hair fanned out in a large circle as far as it could stretch with the plentiful variegated leaves fully opened and bathing in the sunlight.
Only the sage-colored skin of her back remained uncovered by her hair.
Jethro approached with the minum in toe.
“Dampen the leaves with a little water, but not too much.”
The mage sent a mist over the ivy hair, coating the leaves in little droplets of water.
Keeya shivered and laughed with glee.
“Why do I get the feeling that Keeya is the one being rewarded?” Emer’s voice was muffled through the dead, wet grass.
“As a fellow academic, your reward will come from whether or not this experiment is a success.
Keeya has not seen the sun since you two met.
The day is still young, so we can give Keeya her moment.
I do not expect her to sunbathe for long.
Too much sun is not healthy for her kind.”
Despite Jethro’s assurance that Emer would not have his face in the ground for long, Keeya did not stop sunbathing until well past midday.
The minum kept her leaves moist, and Jethro was able to enjoy an elegant lunch in the grass.
Emer was not able to eat until Keeya finally stood him up and walked him to the shade of the trunk of a nearby tree.
Her complexion had drastically improved, her eyes were no longer sunken, and she was overall in higher spirits.

Even though she could draw all her nutrients directly from Emer, she had Emer feed her small samples of the quality meal Jethro prepared of fowl and red squash accompanied by a deep purple wine made from a grain-sized black berry called kanak, native to the marshlands.
“Shall we?”
Jethro beckoned Emer to join him back in the field.
The two giants had prepared a set of battered target dummies staked into the ground.
The first few were the size of a giant but the others were much larger, about three times the height of a giant.
A minum earth mage was brought out, again hanging by the back of his robe, to dig a hole for the log-like stakes supporting them.
The experiments could now begin.
“The smaller targets are about three jurs tall, which is the maximum width for portals.
If we make it bigger, the dummy should come out damaged and the portal collapses,” Jethro explained.
He tore open a portal a little bigger than the first dummy with the exit far to the left of where they stood.
The edges of the portal wavered when he pushed it forward until the giant-sized dummy was engulfed.
The portal cracked and dispersed immediately after.
The dummy that came out the exit was fractured with a few parts missing.
Those parts remained at their original location.
Had this been a live target, the teleportation would have been fatal.
“If we increase the stability as much as possible, the portal still collapses.”
The portal Jethro sent at the next giant-sized target did not waver, but the swirl of energy surrounding it showed its instability.
Once it engulfed the dummy, it collapsed, but the dummy that exited to their left was still intact with only minor damage.
It would not have been fatal to a live target, but the target would still exit injured, making it impractical.
“A portal any larger than this would be more unstable and collapse easier.
Transmission has the same issue.”
Jethro flicked his wrist, and a giant-sized dummy vanished with a loud crack as the surrounding air rapidly sucked inward from the void created by the missing space.
