It appeared on the right side of the field in a bright flash as the teleported contents rapidly forced what had occupied the space outward, and some of the grass beneath the target was blown away.
The target was just as tattered and damaged as the first.
Jethro’s transmission lacked any stability measures.
“This is where your genius comes in.
I never included stability in the transmission formula because frankly, I could not figure out how.
And due to its instantaneous nature, stability was not needed.
But you, you cracked it.”
Another flick of Jethro’s wrist sent the next dummy to the right side of the field with a loud crack.
A little dirt and grass blew away once more in the flash of light, but the dummy appeared completely undamaged from the teleportation.
“Yes!” Jethro threw his fist in the air, and Emer’s mouth hung agape.
“Let’s try one bigger.”
The next dummy to vanish was one of the larger.
The far greater volume of air that was sucked into the vacuum created by the suddenly missing dummy created a deafening crack the other transmissions could not even compare to.
On the right side of the field, the flash was a blinding explosion that sent out a wave of heated air.
Jethro shielded his eyes.
His ears rang.
Debris from the ground below the destination peppered Jethro and the other observers.
When the dust settled, the dummy was on its side in the small crater created by its appearance.
There was no damage to the dummy.
Jethro could hardly contain his excitement.
The third law of spatial teleportation had been broken by a combination of his transmission magic and Emer’s stability function.
It was still not perfect.
Transmission could only be used on a single target near the caster, but size was no longer an issue.
Now, he wanted to test its full capabilities.
He ordered the two giants and two minums to draw close and surrounded the group with a barrier to not only block debris but also mute outside sound and dim intense light.
“You once asked how I assaulted Amel, and I explained that it was using transmission.
Let me give you a little demonstration.”
Jethro extended his hand at the remaining seven smaller dummies and four larger dummies.
In rapid succession, each dummy vanished with a crack and reappeared further down the field in eleven separate explosions.
The undamaged dummies sat in their respective craters based on their size once the dust settled.
In his adrenaline-filled excitement, Jethro pointed his hand towards the nearby tree that towered twice the height of the fort behind them.

It vanished, creating a suction that threatened to pull the group, barrier and all, into the void created by the suddenly missing tree, but that suction was interrupted by a massive explosion of superheated air that blew out from the far side of the field.
Jethro quickly added another barrier to support the last and shield both them and the fort from the heated wave.
The dust did not take long to clear, but mud continued raining from the sky long afterwards.
The trees nearest to the destination bent away from the explosion, and much of the grass near the crater was burnt brown.
The crater itself was about as wide as the tree was tall and was filling with water from the high water table.
The tree leaned on the side of the crater completely undamaged aside from its roots that were severed when the transmission magic grabbed hold of it.
Emer was the first to walk towards the crater once Jethro’s barrier fell.
He stood at the edge and felt the flash-dried grass from the heated air.
Jethro followed not too far behind.
From the fort, countless soldiers ran out in file onto the field with their weapons drawn under the command of their captains for what they assumed was an attack.
Jethro waved them down and sent the minums to explain the reason for the commotion before continuing towards the crater.
“Jethro… I do not think that we can call this stable,” Emer said once Jethro neared.
“In fact, I feel it far more unstable than normal teleportation.”
“Hardly.
The physics behind the explosion is separate from the teleportation itself.
Transmission was only the catalyst.
We can consider this a glorious success.
But I must say that it is highly impractical for anything too large.” Jethro looked up at the sky.
“Perhaps if done in a vacuum…
In any case, this is not exactly what I was hoping for, but a success is a success.
From your world to mine, we have just changed the foundation of spatial magic law!”
“Will you be using this to capture Eydis?”
Jethro sighed.
“I know we are enemies, but can you at least be a little more excited about what we just accomplished?
We can save discussion about your princess for when we are back to finishing the formula for transmission to the other world.”
Jethro reached over Emer’s shoulder and patted Keeya on the cheek.
She startled awake.
Immediately Emer jumped back in fright, unwillingly expressing the Kissiae’s surprise.
“But I am happy to know that you are an academic over anything else.
Keeya passed out, so you could have escaped if you wanted to, but instead you were curious about the spell we developed.”
Emer’s face froze in distress.
“Looks like your princess was not as important to you as you thought.
Shattering a law of magic that has held since the dawn of spatial magic research is far more important than a single ephemeral life.
Subconsciously, you understand this.
Do not worry.
I will make sure your name is included with mine in history.”
Jethro stretched his arms above his head.
“We have been up all night on this, so I am going to sleep.
I suggest you do the same.
Keeya, take him back to his room and make sure he sleeps well.
We will continue our research tomorrow.”
Keeya eyed with confusion the destruction of the field she had just danced in, her mind still somnolent from the wine.
She nodded back at her master and followed him to the fort.

Chapter 7
“Living in Another’s Shadow”
Eydis
“What is your name?”
“Eydis FeAmel.”
“Where are you from, Ms. FeAmel?”
“A city called Amel, the same as my name.”
“Not the Amel in Belgium?”
“No.”
“Any relation to Jabal Amel in Lebanon?”
“No.”
“If you could explain where it is near to--”
“You will not find the city on your maps, and I would not be able to point you to it even if I wanted to.”
The man across from Eydis wore a dark suit, a white shirt, and blue tie about his neck.
He introduced himself as Jason Botteger, a member of an investigation organization, the FBI, for the nation to which this city belonged.
Gullivan was not a fully autonomous city-state as Eydis had originally thought.
This man came to speak with her at the city guards’ request, she assumed to investigate if those who pursued her could be a threat to the nation as a whole.
She anticipated and feared the detailed questions she would be asked but soon grew disappointed, almost bored, as the interviews progressed.
The man flipped through the small stack of paper in front of him.
“And your family is influential in that city?
I would assume so, given your name.”
“We were the ruling family, yes.”
Eydis tapped her fingers in annoyance.
“I do not see the reason for questioning me again.
You have all my answers in those papers, do you not?
If you failed to believe me the past three times, you will not believe me now.”
This FBI agent only repeated the same questions the city guard asked over the past two days.
“We believe you.
Your fingerprints matched those we found on the broken table in the field and the blades of two of the swords we recovered.
There is enough evidence to justify your claim that you were fighting in self-defense.
We just need to know your situation better so that we can help you.”
Eydis’s tapping fingers balled into a fist.
“I can tell when you are lying.
Your heart quickened when you spoke.
I could hear it.
You do not believe those notes, so you are asking me again.”
Agent Botteger’s eyes widened in surprise.
“I can assure you that we mean well.”
“The police said they meant well when they asked me to answer questions like my friends.
When my friends were released in the evening, the police demanded I stay here.
When I wanted to leave after more questioning the next day, they informed me you would arrive today to speak with me and demanded I stay again.”
“That was all for your protection.”
“I do not need protection.
Your city does.”
“All the more reason to cooperate with us.”
Eydis sighed.
“We will leave the matter of whether we feel it safe for you to leave until after we better understand the situation you are in.
Just humor us for now.
The FeAmel family--”
“The Amel family,” Eydis interrupted.
“Fe marks the first child.
We ruled the city and the area around it, yes.”
“So you are eldest child and heir?”
The scene of the princess chained in a dark cellar flashed in Eydis’s mind.
“Yes.
There are two younger sons, twins of a different mother.
They died in the attack.
All that information is in the notes the police gave you.”
“Learning about your origins will tell us more about where these terrorists are coming from.”
“I told the police that as well.
They come from Tolmyur, a mostly desert nation.
Like Amel, you will not find it on your maps.
They are entering the city because you cannot stop them.
Read your papers.
You are wasting my time and yours.”
“Can you give detailed descriptions of the men who captured you?”
“No.
All I knew that were in the city I killed that evening.
I did not see the faces of those who captured me.”
“Then a general description?
Perhaps race or ethnicity.
We have the bodies, but we cannot quite discern where they come from, and that is only one of the many oddities about them.”
Chloe’s concern for refugees came to Eydis’s mind.
Eydis did not know to what lengths this nation’s government would go to eliminate a threat.
If Chloe’s warning had any weight, perhaps innocent people might be killed if wrongfully suspected.
“I cannot give you one.
I have seen some in this city who are similar enough to those of Tolmyur that providing you such a description might jeopardize their wellbeing.”
“Okay, assuming these terrorists come from a place called Tolmyur, how was that one able to create fire?
Does magic really exist there?”
The sides of Eydis’s lips curled into a smirk.
“You are asking this question for yourself, not the police.
Let me show you.”
A thin barrier surrounded Eydis just above her clothes and skin, invisible to Agent Botteger’s eyes.
The barrier quickly expanded.
The metal chair she sat in bowed out from the pressure of the barrier, and the table in front of her pushed forcefully into Agent Botteger’s stomach.
He lurched forward in shock, both from surprise and from the impact.
“There is your proof.” Eydis ignored the dazed stare and walked to the door.
“I will be in my room.”
The police left Eydis alone for the remainder of the afternoon.
They provided her a small room containing no more than a bed, cushioned chair, and side table.
Even though the police expressed a slight hint of hospitality in the arrangement, the bed and chair were of lower quality than those in Justin’s apartment.
The bed was also too short, leaving her feet to dangle off the end.
There was no doubt in her mind that this was a provisional prison cell in guise of a guest room, that they were confining her until they decided what to do with her.
Why did I trust Justin?
Now that this city’s guards know I can do the same as Jethro’s men, they view me as just as dangerous.
“Then again, he had no idea that his city saved one of Jethro’s men.” A melancholy breath escaped Eydis’s lips.
Why must this be so troublesome?
Why could I not live with Sammy and Justin and not worry about Jethro or anyone else?
The princess lived such a carefree life here.
“Why can I not live just as happily in this city as well?”
Evening came before Eydis received any visitors.
A light knock on her door announced the arrival of a female officer, Joyce Hellings.
She did not wait for Eydis to answer before entering, perhaps taking Eydis’s silence as permission.
This was not the first time.
She reminded Eydis of Jethro.
He never announced his arrivals, so Eydis was forced to assume he would arrive at any moment to prevent unwanted or embarrassing situations.
Every time Eydis saw Officer Hellings, she could not help but think Joyce looked smug with her blond hair pulled back into a bun so tight it pulled at the skin of her face.
Officer Hellings brought Eydis to a small meeting room where Major Wickenny and Agent Botteger sat waiting.
Eydis took her seat across from them, and then Officer Hellings sat beside her.
The file containing all the information Eydis told the police sat on the table in front of Major Wickenny.
“Am I to be questioned a fourth time?” Eydis folded her arms and breathed a sigh of boredom.
She slouched in her seat with her eyes closed to await the coming questions.
“No, we feel that we have enough for now.”
Eydis opened one weary eye to look at Major Wickenny.
He just lied.
They obviously wanted to know more but did not know how to make her talk.
She would willingly tell them more if she did not believe doing so would ruin her chances of a peaceful life in this city.
Telling them she was from another world was the same as betraying her dream of a peaceful life.
Revealing magic to them already caused no shortage of distrust, leading to her confinement over the past few days.
“I will move straight to the point.
We have discussed the information you have given us in light of the events surrounding the fight you were involved in and the man who could use fire magic that disappeared.”
Both of Eydis’s eyes opened, now wary about what decision the city guard came to.
“We feel it too dangerous to keep you in the city,” Agent Botteger continued for Major Wickenny.
“We have victim protection and relocation programs in this nation and would like to provide you that service until the terrorist situation is resolved.
We have contacted Fort Samper, an Army base about two hundred miles south of here and explained the situation to them.
They will give Gullivan their support in routing out the terrorists as well as protecting you until more permanent accommodations can be made.”
“Army?” Eydis asked.
“The Army is a branch of our country’s military,” Agent Botteger replied.
First they keep me prisoner in the city, and now they plan on keeping me captive by their military?
There was no way that she could leave the city behind, especially with both Rynn and the princess here.
She could teleport back and forth, but responding to emergencies would be far more difficult if she was not present to react to them immediately.
And being under constant watch at the human’s military base would be no different than her situation under Jethro, possibly even preventing her from freely returning to Rynn.
At least the room Jethro provided was regal because the palace became his base.
This country’s military could never provide similar accommodations.
“I refuse.”
“Mr. Botteger informed me that you were under the impression that we were confining you here,” Major Wickenny replied.
“If we made you feel that way, I apologize.
That was not our intent.
I never considered that you might think our requests were demands.
We requested your cooperation because we want to protect you and the people of this city.”
Eydis laughed within herself.
Even though Major Wickenny was not lying, he was likely not telling the whole truth either.
Humans could not be trusted.
“We, the police, need to prioritize the safety of the citizens, and the Department of Justice will prioritize your protection.
If more people with such destructive power are in the city and you are their primary target, removing you from the city is the best decision for everyone.”
As Eydis expected, they did not care about her feelings on the matter.
They would exploit her for the benefit of their people, just as Jethro had.
Eydis’s hands balled into fists.
She gritted her teeth and glared at Major Wickenny.
“I will not become a war prisoner again!”
Officer Hellings placed her hand on Eydis’s balled fist.
“You are not going to be a prisoner.
You can receive better protection at Fort Samper.”
“All I want is to live a normal life here in Gullivan.”
Major Wickenny lightly waved his hand to drawn Eydis’s attention back to him.
“These arrangements will only be temporary.
Once the terrorists are dealt with, you will be free to live as you please.”
“And how long will that take?
You do not know these people like I do.
Their tenacity knows no limits.”
“All the more reason for you to take us up on the offer,” Agent Botteger replied.
“We cannot protect you well if you wander about the city freely.”
“I cannot be free?
Then that makes me no different than a prisoner.
I refuse.
I only stayed here because Justin asked me to help you.
Now that you have decided and have no more questions, I am leaving.”
Agent Botteger shook his head.
“I beg you reconsider.
I will be upfront with you.
The existence of magic has created a complicated situation for the police, the FBI, and the Department of Justice as a whole.
The bodies we found look normal, but the autopsies revealed a lot about them that is, frankly, inhuman.
We don’t know if that is because of their magic abilities or not or why else they are so different.
There is much more that we need to know, and to better deal with this threat, I need you to cooperate with me.”
Heat rose in Eydis’s chest, and she fought to suppress her anger to prevent her eyes from changing color to a deep Lurr red.
After a broken and frustrated breath, she spoke.
“Do you think you can force me to go?
I am not your enemy.
Do not make me one.”
Eydis stood from her chair.
Officer Hellings followed, so Eydis placed her hand on the woman’s shoulder and pushed her back down into her chair with her far superior strength.
“Do not come too close or you will be hurt.”
Without another word, Eydis activated the transmission spell she had saved for the entirety of her confinement by the police.
Those in the room could do nothing but stare with gawking faces at the empty space where Eydis once stood.
Eydis appeared in the cellar of Rynn’s house in the southeast corner of the city.
The princess lay on her side on a blanket with a towel draped over her.
The color of the princess’s face was slightly better than it had been in the past, but she remained unconscious.
Eydis was unsure where or how the police were watching her, so she had not risked returning to feed over the past two days.
After feeding a little more than usual as a reward to herself for calmly enduring the police’s interrogations, she walked up the stairs with a refreshed smile on her face.
Rynn was there to greet her with teary eyes in the bedroom.
“Sorry I could not come back and visit.
I was held for questioning by the town guards.
Did I worry you?”
Rynn nodded.
Eydis knew her sudden unannounced disappearance for a few days would worry Rynn, especially after only just contacting the princess’s associates.
For all Eydis knew, Rynn might have thought the infiltration failed and that Eydis was captured or killed.
“Those foolish guards saved the life of a minum I failed to kill.
He escaped after killing many guardsmen and civilians, so they demanded I tell them everything I knew.
The guards were persistent.
I am the one being targeted, or so they believe, but they still had the audacity to treat me like some war criminal.”
Eydis grabbed one of the many dried flatbreads from the bedside table and handed it to Rynn to rehydrate.
“They wanted to take me captive to their military base!
Can you believe that?”
“Are they our enemies now?”
Rynn returned the now softened bread, surprising Eydis by how fast and skillful Rynn’s magic was when it came to food.
“I do not think so.
Not yet.
If they are competent, they will realize that I am stronger than all of them.
They have seen the aftermath of the battle.
If they could not kill even one injured minum, how could they confine someone who killed many men just as strong or stronger?
And now that they know I can teleport, their plan to keep me captive is ruined.
They do not like me being here, but that will be the extent of it.”
Eydis sat on the edge of the bed, and Rynn sat beside, leaning against her.
“Making me an enemy is suicide for them.
Of course, I do not want to fight them either.
I made it clear to them that I intend to live a peaceful life here.
But still…”
That dream of a peaceful life was moving closer and closer to becoming nothing more than a dream.
The minum disappeared, so the only explanation was that he went into hiding until Jethro opened another portal.
Perhaps the minum already returned and informed Jethro that their plan to capture the princess failed.
If Jethro assumed that Eydis was still alive, he would conclude that she either escaped or was helping the princess.
Either way, he would not leave her alone.
Replacing the princess.
Being treated as a threat by the city guard.
Becoming a new target for Jethro.
The number of trials barring her from a peaceful and happy life was only increasing.
“What’s wrong?”
Rynn leaned forward to look up into Eydis’s eyes.
“Nothing.
Just one thing piling upon another.
I am a little frustrated.
That is all.”
Eydis pulled Rynn into a full embrace before setting her back down on the bed.
“I must be going.
I am sure the city guard will be coming to Justin now that I disappeared.
If I am not there, that will cause more trouble for him, and thus me.”
Rynn nodded, and Eydis teleported back to her room in Justin’s apartment.
Rynn was left alone on the bed with the flatbread she rehydrated only nibbled on.
No one was home.
For how late in the evening, this was odd.

From her observations of Justin’s daily schedule in order to formulate a plan to capture the princess, Justin was only out this late when he was with Eydis at her magic lessons, and there would be no reason for him to be training because she was with the city guard.
“Where is he?”
Eydis sat on the couch and waited.
Time passed, but neither Justin nor Sean returned.
Despite her earlier concern, the city guard did not arrive at the apartment either.
Staying idle afforded her nothing, so Eydis decided to take the time to familiarize herself with the apartment.
The princess knew where everything was, so Eydis should know as well.

Starting from the kitchen and moving to the living room, bathroom, and eventually her bedroom, she inscribed to memory the objects she found and their names if they had one printed even if she was unsure what the object was or its use.
Sean’s bedroom was the only location she felt no need to investigate.
The princess’s relationship with Sean was not one where she would be familiar with his belongings, or so she assumed.
Eydis had the time to comb through the apartment three times before the front door finally opened.
Eydis was in her room, so she rushed out only to find Sean returning.
The corner of her mouth twisted downward in frustration.
Sean looked at her with a hint of surprise.
“When did you get back?”

Even though Sean could not know that the police planned to make Eydis a prisoner of war, the lack of concern on his face for the two days she had been imprisoned at the guard station flared up anger inside her.
Sean had amiable ties with the city guard, so he would not question any decision they made.
There was even the possibility that he would help them capture her if needed.
Sean was someone Eydis could not trust.
“Where is Justin?” She asked.
“He is still out with Sammy right now.
He should be back in another hour or so, probably.”
Justin spent the evening with another one of his women now that Eydis was away.
That was to be expected.
Eydis sighed.
Growing accustomed to being with a man who had multiple women would take time.

Having a home large enough for all of them to live together would make his life much easier than having to go to them, but they were all independent, and he did not seem to have wealth enough for his own house.
He was boarding with Sean after all.
“I will be in my room.
Tell Justin I am here when you see him.”
Eydis returned down the hallway.
She closed herself in her room and curled up on her bed.
Just as Sean had predicted, Justin returned promptly.
He opened Eydis’s bedroom door with Sammy in tow.
In stark contrast to Sean’s lack of concern, both Justin and Sammy were elated that Eydis had returned.
“Is everything alright?
What happened?
How did it go?”
Justin’s immediate questions of concern helped lift Eydis’s spirits.
“They held me in a single room and only let me out to ask the same questions they asked many times before.
They did not believe me, so they had someone from your government come ask the same questions again.”
“What did you tell them?” Justin asked.
Eydis rolled over to better look at the two of them.
Sammy had knelt next to the bed, her worried face only inches away.
“Only what I told you about Jethro.
Do not worry.
I kept to the story about them being terrorists, for that is what they are, and I did not speak anything of Whinhlem.”
“I’m glad they finally let you go,” Sammy said, slightly exasperated.
“Two days is a long time to hold an innocent victim.”
“They weren’t holding her,” Justin countered.
“When I called, they said Eydis agreed to stay and help.”
Eydis grew irritated.
Although she did agree to stay, their offer was certainly a demand, even if they lacked the means to force her compliance.
She thought that Justin would have been a bit more concerned over the confinement of his princess instead of blindly trusting the city guard.
“I at least wish they would have contacted us when they let you go,” Sammy said, ignoring Justin.
Eydis shook her head.
“They did not let me go.
I escaped.
They see me as evil because of those who are after me and want to take me prisoner to some place called Fort Samper.”
Concern grew on Justin’s face.
“Prisoner?
That can’t be right.”
“I have never heard of Fort Samper,” Sammy added.
If Sammy had never heard of that location, was it real?
Where were the guards planning to take me?
Justin ran out of the room, leaving Eydis and Sammy in silence, but he was only gone a moment.
“According to Sean, Fort Samper is an Army base south of here.
A military base would be the ideal location to protect you,” Justin said when he returned.
“Not you as well…”
Eydis buried her face in her blanket, prompting Sammy to punch Justin in the leg.
“Did you not learn from the last time,” she chided.
Justin immediately shook his head and corrected himself.
“I’m not saying you should go there.
I don’t want you to leave.
You just came back to us.
I was just trying to think of why they would send you there.” Justin leaned over the side of the bed.
“And you said it yourself, right?
If we take you out of the city, Jethro will only become more dangerous.”
“Still, it annoys me that they would try to take you away without even contacting us first.
What are the police thinking?”
“They did not try.
They told me of their plan, and I escaped before they could.
They saw me teleport, so they should know now that they cannot keep me prisoner.”
Sammy smiled.
“Basically, you need to be willing before they can do anything to you.
I bet that made them squirm.”
Justin looked at Sammy with suspect.
“Do you hate the police or something?”
“It’s not that I hate them.
I just don’t really trust them.”
Eydis loved Sammy even more after hearing she shared a mutual distrust of the city guard.
“Think about it,” Sammy continued.
“This is something that they have never encountered before.
They shouldn’t have rules or procedures for handling magic-using terrorists.
This means that they might decide to do something unconventional or that breaches normal police conduct.”
Sammy’s warning mirrored what that FBI agent said at the end, worrying Eydis.
“I doubt they would do anything rash.”  Justin did not sound convinced of his own words, and that made Eydis worry more.

* * *
Eydis was unsure what procedures the city guard followed in this world, but the involvement of the police began the very next morning.
Sammy once again stayed the night and shared Eydis’s bed.
When the three of them were about to leave for the university, there was a knock on the door.
Two police arrived to request that Eydis return to the station stating that there was much that the police and FBI still wanted to know.
“You came to your decision, did you not?
I will not let you take me prisoner.
I have told you all I can.
It is now your job to protect the city.”
Eydis did not wait for a reply.
She used the formula destination she had memorized in preparation for the day she captured the princess, reformulated it, and tore open a portal.
She pulled Sammy and Justin through and glared at the stunned faces on the other side of the portal as she closed it.
Justin and Sammy were likewise stunned.
From their reaction, they had never been taken through a portal before.
Sammy looked around at the shrubs and red-brick structure beside her.
There was no one around the back side of the building where they exited, so she jumped down from the elevated garden to the grass for a better view the structure.
“This is the Wilks Math Building.
We are on campus?”
Justin hopped down and extended his hand to help Eydis.
“I did not want the police following us,” Eydis explained.
“That’s amazing!
Why have we never done this before?”
“What if someone saw us,” Justin retorted.
“If someone saw us teleporting around, it would cause problems.
And can’t some of the people from her world feel when spatial magic is used?”
Eydis was amazed at Justin’s understanding of the dangers of spatial magic when one desired to remain hidden, but this understanding might also come from being a rare affinity user himself.
Time magic could be felt by those sensitive to it, same as spatial magic.
Justin looked at Eydis for confirmation, so she nodded.
“I do not teleport often for that reason.
This time was special.
The more those police realize they cannot hold me, the better.”

The following days, the police did not confront Justin and Eydis personally, but she noticed them monitoring from a distance, particularly in keeping an eye on their neighborhood and adding foot patrols on campus.
Such precautions were justifiable, so Eydis did not mind at first until she noticed some people acting peculiar in her presence.
They were not uniformed like the police, but after the number of days she spent at the station, she had grown accustomed to how the city guards carried themselves, their mannerisms and quirks.
Even though they behaved casual, it felt to her like an act, lacking the air of natural realism emitted by everyone else.
Every one of her senses told her that these plain-clothed individuals were police, or possibly members of that investigation agency.

Eydis decided to join Justin in his lectures instead of joining Sammy’s company, and once she saw that self-same individual also join in the lecture, she asked Justin about him, bringing up her concern.
“Never seen him before in class.
Might be an undercover police.”
“They can’t do anything to you,” Sammy said to Eydis after Eydis noticed that self-same individual in Sammy’s lecture the following day.
“Now that I know of them, I cannot relax,” Eydis admitted.
She found speaking her honest feelings to Sammy surprisingly easy, possibly because she still felt a likeness of Rynn in Sammy.
“I know it’s for your protection, but they could lay off a little.”
“I do not need protection, and they know this.
They do not trust me and are watching for when I give them reason to think I am an enemy.”
An extra set of observing eyes is not what Eydis wanted.
Living as the princess was already difficult enough.
Sammy noticed Eydis’s growing discomfort and quickly grew just as irritated with the police.
“Could you leave us alone,” Sammy called out to the police who stood in the corner of the commons the following day.
No police or campus security was ever posted in the commons, and this one just happened to arrive once Sammy invited everyone to eat lunch together.
“That’s not going to do anything,” Miriam said, absentmindedly twisting her plastic fork into her polystyrene takeout box.
“If they can’t hold Eydis anywhere, all they can do is watch her.”
“Eydis is not the problem!”
“No, but Jethro’s men are after her, so the best option is to follow her and react to anything that happens.”
“Who’s side are you on?”
Miriam pointed at Eydis with her fork.
“Hers, of course.
I’m just saying that it’s the best course of action for them.”
A whispering group of students passed the table eyeing Eydis and the police officer standing about twenty feet away.
Another two female students approached the table immediately after.
“Eydis, is it true that the police are following you?
I heard that you were a witness in a major crime and that they are protecting you to make sure no one tries to silence you.”
Eydis’s eyes narrowed.
Of course some would make the connection between Eydis’s disappearance and reappearance and the sudden increase of security on campus, especially given the bloody fight outside the city.
“What kind of excuse is that?
Kim, do you really think that anyone could kill Eydis?” Sammy replied with mild exasperation.
These two girls seemed to know Eydis, and Sammy even replied to one by name.
Perhaps these two were the princess’s students.
“Then why are the police following you?
Are you going to come back to the self-defense class?”
Eydis’s assumption was validated, so she felt safe replying.
“Sorry.
I do not want to put any of you in danger, so I will not go back.”
“It is something that dangerous?”
“Eydis, don’t make the rumors worse!” Sammy chided.
Eydis was tired of dodging questions, but Sammy was right, even if not for the same reasons she was telling Eydis to stop.
The city guards wanted to monitor Eydis’s movements, but it came with an unintended side effect.
The rumors spread further, and the number of people who came to Eydis grew until she no longer had any time alone with Sammy or Justin while at the university.
Eydis did not know their names or anything about them, so any conversation involving such people was a risk to her identity.
Being unable to talk with any of the students without fear of making a mistake, Eydis could only make one decision.
“I will no longer accompany you to the university.”
Eydis expected Justin to protest, but he only looked at Eydis’s crestfallen face with understanding.
“Keep your smartphone on you in case of emergencies, but I’m sure you can handle yourself.”
After a nod from Eydis, Justin left her in the apartment.
Eydis remained in her room throughout the morning until she heard Sean talking with someone in the living room.
She peeked out from the hallway to find that Sean had let one of the police inside.
The guard noticed her and stood.
Eydis did not give the police the opportunity to speak.
Using a transmission formula she had prepared for such an occasion, the guard vanished with a loud crack.
“What did you do!?
He was only here to talk!”
“I sent him into the river just outside the apartment.”
“The river?
What if he drowns?”
“What good is a guard in a city with a river if that guard cannot swim?”
“This is very unlike you,” Sean yelled as he rushed out the door.
“And what do you know of me!?”
Eydis vanished from the apartment.
She sat alone in the basement cellar near the burning furnace until Rynn walked down the steps to care for the unconscious princess.
Eydis’s fingernails clawed grooves in the paved floor as she drew her hands into fists.
The impact of her fist into the floor left a fractured indent.
“I want to kill every last one of the police!”
Rynn approached meekly and rested her arms around Eydis’s neck.
“Will you?”
“Then my life here would truly be over.
Information spreads fast in this world.” Eydis hugged Rynn in return.
“Until something is done about Jethro, I feel the guards will not leave me alone.”
Her eyes fell upon the unconscious princess.
Maybe I should give her to Jethro.
Maybe then I will be free.

The very thought of giving Jethro, the one who fed Rynn to slavery and abuse, what he wanted swelled a storm of anger in Eydis that threatened to lash out indiscriminately at the nearest available target.
Rynn sensed her rage and held Eydis tighter, nuzzling the side of Eydis’s head with her cheek.
Eydis resisted her anger and fought to calm down.
Only Rynn, the princess, or she could be the target of her rage.
She had no choice but to suppress it.
The surging frustration and anger took long to subside, but Rynn held Eydis through it.
“Thank you.”
Eydis brushed Rynn’s hair behind her ear and rested her hand on the girl’s cheek.
“I should return.”
Rynn nodded and stood up.
After one final embrace, Eydis tore open a portal to her room and stepped through.
On the desk, her smartphone was buzzing.
Eydis picked it up and slid the green circle on the bottom to the right to answer the phone, something that she had learned from watching Sammy and Justin.
“Eydis!
Finally you pick up.
What happened?
Sean called and said something was wrong with you.”
Eydis had only just calmed down and now struggled to keep her anger from resurfacing.
“Everything is fine.
I only sent away a police that Sean let in the apartment.”
“Sean told me you sent him into the river.”
“It was shallow where I sent him,” she replied.
She was not in the mood to be chastised by Justin after already being yelled at by Sean.
“Sean said that they could legally arrest you for that, but I guess they couldn’t hold you no matter what they tried.” Justin paused for a moment.
“Should I come back,” he asked in a soft tone.
Justin’s earnest concern helped calm Eydis’s anger.
She sat down on her bed and grew a faint smile.
“No.
I am fine.
You have your work to do, so do not worry yourself.”
“As long as you are sure.
Call me if anything else happens.”
“I will.”
Eydis pressed the red circle to end the call and then lay back on her bed.
Sean is starting to doubt me.
I need to be more careful.
At least I have Sammy and Justin on my side.
That evening, Sammy arrived before Justin.
Justin had sent a text message stating that he was going to run a few errands, including shopping, and asked if Eydis wanted to join, but Eydis declined.
Sammy then volunteered to keep her company.
Eydis told Sammy about the events earlier that day which caused Sammy to break into a fit of laughter.
“Serves them right!”
Eydis was happy to have an ally in Sammy.
They continued talking throughout the afternoon and the topic of Sammy’s relationship with Justin came up.

From what Eydis could glean from the broken stories and assumptions about what Sammy had already told the princess in the past and thus left out of her current retelling, Sammy was Justin’s first woman, and the princess was his second.
This further frustrated Eydis because this meant that even after meeting the princess, he still sought out two more women despite not having the ability to house and care for the two he already had.
Sammy left out any mention of her and Justin’s love life, and most of the stories were complaints.
Eydis found it hard to believe that such a relationship was thriving, but within all the complaints was something subtle.
While talking of Justin, Sammy always smiled, even if faint during her complaints.
When some of the more endearing stories came up, Sammy’s heartrate increased and her body warmed.
The womanly scent on her grew slightly more prevalent.
There was no doubt that Sammy cared deeply for Justin.
No matter how much Sammy tried to hide it behind snide remarks, sarcasm, and insults, her body could not lie to Eydis’s keen senses.
If Justin could muster such fidelity in a woman despite the number of flaws she openly pronounced about him, maybe he was not such a bad male.
“So, what about you?”
Sammy’s question caught Eydis off guard.
“I have been holding back asking you, but after all this, you owe me a little.
What do you think of him?
You’ve been living with him for almost half a year now.”
Eydis remained silent.
This was a conversation that she feared.
She knew nothing of Justin and the princess’s relationship outside of what little she could see during her time observing them.
“I… I do not want to answer.”
A mischievous grin grew on Sammy’s face.
“Come on.
Spill it.
I mean, I can already piece most of it together from how I see you two act, but I want to hear it from you.”
How would the princess respond?
She tried to kill me to keep me from him, so she clearly cares for him.
His scent is all over her bed, but I do not know the extent of their relationship.
Sammy never told any stories about sex, so she is probably not looking for those at least.
No, what if the three of them had sex together?
Then she would know the princess and Justin’s relationship far more intimately.
If I say something wrong, then she would know I am not the princess.
But if Sammy knows the relationship between Justin and the princess intimately, then why is she asking?
Unless the princess is not one to openly express her personal feelings?
I cannot make any assumptions about that either…
Eydis’s mind circled around concern after concern.
There was no way for her to answer without fear of bringing suspicion upon herself.
“I am sorry, but please do not ask me,” Eydis said in the end.
Sammy’s face grew an exaggerated pout but she did not press further.
She immediately changed the subject.
Now that doubt stirred in Eydis’s mind, she grew cautious over anything she said or answer she gave.

When the topic moved to Sammy’s swim class and lecture of some unknown biological subject that was far beyond what Eydis’s English comprehension could follow, she closed up like a clam hiding from the breaking waves of Sammy’s discourse.
The more Sammy spoke, the more Eydis could no longer reply.
She could play no other role than a wall for Sammy to speak at.
The gap in her knowledge of the princess’s past was never more apparent than it was now.
Pain grew inside Eydis’s chest when she realized that she could not get close to Sammy without bridging that knowledge gap--an impossible task.
The ally that she thought she had was now beyond arm’s reach.
Sammy noticed the growing depression in Eydis’s demeanor and ended her rambling.

She thanked Eydis for spending time together and a promised to come visit again before leaving the room to go talk with Justin who had long since returned but was kept out of the room by Sammy’s orders.
Sammy left the apartment after a few kind parting words.
Eydis was then left alone on the bed.
What am I to do?
I can no longer go to the university with Justin.
Sean thinks I am not acting as the princess would act.
And now, I can no longer talk with Sammy.
Justin entered the room and sat back against the side of the bed.
He said nothing, only grasping Eydis’s hand to reassure her that everything was alright, but she could find no comfort in it.
What if I say something that makes Justin doubt me as well?

Chapter 8
Justin
“A School of Combat Magic”
“We need to get Eydis outside.
Staying inside for this long is not healthy.”
Sammy sat next to Justin across from Chloe and Miriam at a table in the commons of the student center on campus.
Justin’s eyebrows furrowed in frustration.
“I’ve tried, but she barely even talks to me anymore.”
“She won’t even talk to us at all.”
Miriam placed her hand on Chloe’s shoulder, and Chloe nodded slowly.
“She probably feels bad about all the people who died, but it wasn’t her fault.”
Sammy shook her head.
“While that might be part of it, she was going out with us before, right?
She only became a recluse after the police started pestering us constantly.
Maybe she doesn’t want to get us involved in her problems.”
“None of this is her fault,” Justin grumbled, “but knowing her, she’s blaming herself for it anyway.”
Chloe and Miriam looked crestfallen at the center of the table in unison.
“Then we just need to find something to get her mind off it.
What about another trip to the mall?
Or we could go out and eat at the diner?”
Sammy liked Chloe’s suggestion, but Justin shot it down.
“I already suggested that.
She turned it down.
She didn’t give a reason, but think about it.
When do we go to the diner?”
“For celebrations…”
Chloe’s shoulders slumped after realizing what Justin was hinting.
“If she feels that she is at fault for any of this, she would obviously be against treating herself.”
Miriam tapped her fingers on the table pensively.
“Then maybe take it from another direction.
We just need to get her out and active again, right?
I feel kind of bad about suggesting this, but we can rely on that guilt to have her follow through with the plan to teach us combat magic.”
“Miriam, that’s terrible…”
Chloe stared at Miriam with mild disgust.
“No, no, no.
I’m not saying guilt trip her into it.
That would be heartless.
If we ask her to teach us now, she is bound to agree.
She cares for us more than anything, right?
She’s probably worrying about us and our safety now that people from her world finally arrived.
Sammy even said this might be because we are being pulled into her problems.
She tried to get us to cut ties with her for our own safety, but we wouldn’t.
Now she is the one trying to stay away from us.
Teaching us to defend ourselves on even grounds against them might put her at ease a little.
It could only help.”
The table went silent.
“Let’s do it.”
““Justin!”” Both Sammy and Chloe complained in unison.
“I’ll ask her.
I don’t agree with relying on her guilt or worry to force her, but I also don’t want any of you to be hurt either.
I feel responsible for what has happened, and I want each of you to be able to defend yourself.”
“Says the weakest one here.” Sammy nudged Justin with her shoulder.
“We’ll leave it to you to convince Eydis.”
That evening, Eydis sat at the kitchen table eating the dinner Justin prepared while he worked on his homework beside her.
He had tried to initiate a conversation, but Eydis completely ignored it and only said three words, “I am hungry”, so he made her dinner.
Her lack of appetite over the past two days prompted the worried discussion at the university, so Justin was glad Eydis finally ate.
They sat in deafening silence listening to the scraping of Eydis’s fork on the plate and the tapping of Justin’s laptop keyboard.
Eydis was the first to break the silence when she stood up to place her plate and fork in the sink.
“Thank you.” Eydis then proceeded to walk past Justin to the hallway.
“Eydis, hold on please.
I have something to ask you.”
Justin’s words stopped her mid step.
She looked over her shoulder almost suspicious about what Justin might say.
“The girls and I have been talking…”
Worry replaced suspicion, and she averted her gaze.
Justin took a breath and beckoned Eydis to come sit back down.
She hesitated but complied.
“Back when we all met in Dr. Shuman’s office, conversation came up about--”
Eydis stood and tried to walk away, but Justin clasped her hand gently.
He was sure now that she was worried about what happened and that she wanted to avoid talking about anything related to it.
That day, many people died, and she firmly believed that the police confined her.
“Eydis, please.”
“…I will listen.”
Eydis sat back in her chair and looked down at the table.
Justin never let go of her hand and grasped it with his other as well.
“You tried to convince Miriam, Chloe, and Sammy to stop associating with you in order to protect them.
They are worried about you because you have refused to contact them or pick up your phone when they call.
You turned Sammy away when she came to visit yesterday.
But, I understand why you would want to protect them.”
Justin’s grip tightened ever so slightly to reassure Eydis that he was not accusing her of anything.
“Chloe brought up the idea of you teaching them how to fight using magic.”
Eydis’s hand balled into a fist in his grasp.
“I will not teach any of you how to fight.
I cannot--”
“No, that’s not it,” Justin interrupted and shook his head.
“I am not asking this so that we can fight Jethro.
To be honest, I hope we never hear about him again let alone meet one of his assassins.
I am asking in the off chance that one of us do happen to encounter one of the people after you.
I am scared, not for myself, but for Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam.
I am sure you are as well.”
Eydis’s eyes shifted to her hand being cradled in Justin’s grasp.
“You want them to be safe.”
“I want us all to be safe, and if teaching them how to defend against magic will help them, of course I want them to learn.”
“What about you?”
Justin only shook his head with a self-depreciating smirk.
“You know better than anyone how hopeless I am at magic.
I am asking for their sake.”
Eydis sat in silence as the minutes ticked by.
In the end she shook her head.
“Please, Eydis.”
Justin could not let Eydis turn down his plea, for her sake just as much as for his friends.
“You really do care for those girls…” Again, Eydis thought in silence.
“I cannot answer you now.
Can you give me a day to think on it?”
This was the best reply Justin felt he was going to get.
“Of course.”
The next evening, Eydis avoided bringing the topic up, and when Justin bridged the topic, she diverted it immediately.
This continued for another couple days.
Justin realized that Eydis’s request for time was not to give the offer consideration but to hope that Justin would forget or drop the suggestion.
If she decided not to, she could tell him, and he would accept that answer.
He wanted to push but felt guilty doing so.
If she really did not feel like teaching them, nothing could be done.
“Eydis.” Justin knocked on her bedroom door.
Every evening at the same approximate time, Justin brought up the suggestion again, asking if Eydis had made her decision.
She knew what he came to ask.
“You want an answer.”
Eydis spoke through the closed door, so Justin opened it and found Eydis sitting on her bed, back against the wall and book in hand, one of Sean’s.
In her self-imposed confinement, Sean’s books were her only source of entertainment.
“If you do not want to teach them, just say so.
But I do think that it would be the best for all of us.
They know I asked you and are also waiting eagerly for your answer.
They want to learn.”
“You told them before I answered?”
Eydis set her book down in frustration, not marking her page.
“They were the ones who brought up the idea initially.” Justin sat on the bed beside Eydis.
“How about this?
If you hold one lesson, I will treat you to something.”
Eydis looked at Justin quizzically.
“A reward?”
“Of sorts.
Just a bit of an incentive.
I am the one asking, so it only makes sense that I would compensate you, right?”
A faint smile grew on Eydis’s face, the first smile Justin had seen in days.
“I… I will try, but I will let you decide where to hold the lessons.
We surely cannot do them here.”
“Or Miriam’s apartment.”
Eydis’s eyes widened a little and she took a quick breath.
“Of course not at her apartment either.”
Was asking me to find a place to hold the lessons just another attempt to stall?
Justin grumbled.
Having seen the photos of the devastation of the field where Eydis and Jethro’s men fought, he needed to find a place that could handle the damage that combat magic could cause.
But it’s not like they will be able to do that much damage from the start.
His pillow grew uncomfortably warm, so Justin flipped it over and readjusted his blanket.
The clock on the living room wall showed half past midnight.
He had spent the past two days thinking about where to hold the lessons and investigating the possibilities.
Calling Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam also gave no leads, but they each promised to think about it.

Even if he could find a location that could handle the damage of magic amateurs, he also needed the place to be secret, or at least somewhere that those who should not know about magic would not see them or find out.
An abandoned building or warehouse would be ideal, but landing on such a prime location was nothing but fiction.

Even if such a place existed somewhere in the city, Justin did not know how he could locate one let alone be able to use it without the original owner of the property finding out or someone noticing something and calling the police on them while they practiced.
“The police.” Justin threw off the blanket and ran down the hallway to Sean’s room.
“Sean, you awake?”
The door cracked open, and Sean stood at the door still dressed in jeans and a white polo shirt.
“You realize what time it is?”
“Just a quick question.
Do you think the police would be able to provide a location for Eydis to teach magic?”
“You aren’t thinking straight.
What reason would the police have to provide it?
Beyond that, what is the police’s current opinion of Eydis?”
Sean was about to close the door, but Justin placed his hand on it.
“What if there was something that Eydis could offer the police that would be beneficial to them?
They have never fought against magic before, so being able to witness it and learn from it would help them just as much as it would help us.”
Sean’s left eyebrow twitched in annoyance.
“Again, what is Eydis’s current opinion of the police?
She’s not leaving the house because of the trouble they caused.
Do you really think she would want to help them?
Go to sleep.
Your mind will be clearer after some rest.”
Justin was left staring at the closed door, and he could hear Sean return to his desk to continue typing on his computer.
This was still the best option.
Back in the living room, Justin sat on the couch to think more on the idea.
The police could not turn down this proposal.
They already lost multiple officers to fire magic, and all the police in the city were likely informed of the existence of magic by now.
Eydis, Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam were the only ones in the city that they would be able to ask to teach them about magic.
Each of them also had affinities to different elements.

If they could become practiced in combat magic, the police would be able to observe the offensive capabilities of each element, potentially saving the lives of the officers who might encounter Jethro’s men.
It was a win-win.
The only obstacle then was Eydis, but Justin also felt that she would agree to it.

Sure, she was avoiding the police, but Eydis had jumped at the idea of teaching people before, and she had finally agreed to teach combat magic for the sake of everyone’s safety, so Justin was confident that with the goal of saving lives in mind, she would agree to working with the police despite her aversion to them.
It might also improve her relationship with them and show them that she was not a threat.
Another win-win.
“I will ask her first thing in the morning.”
“I refuse.” Eydis’s reply was curt.
Justin’s hand froze while lifting a slice of French toast to his mouth.
He had prepared it for breakfast, including apricot preserves, fresh mint leaves, and whipped cream, with the hope of improving Eydis’s mood.
Although she seemed to enjoy it more than usual, her favorite breakfast did nothing to sway her.
“You won’t do it?”
“Those police see me as an enemy.”
“This is the best way for the police to view you in a better light.
I’m sure they don’t consider you the same as the men who are after you.
They are probably just wary because magic is not supposed to exist.
Familiarizing them with magic will make them less cautious of you.”
Eydis set her fork and knife down on her cleared plate and popped a tiny mint leaf in her mouth.
Her cheeks flushed lightly.
“Or it will make them fear me more.”
“Instead of fear, what if they were grateful to you?
That one minum proved that Jethro’s men are not afraid to take the lives of both police and civilians.
The entire purpose of these lessons is to prevent more people from dying.
I am worried about Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam just as much as the police are worried about the city’s safety.
What you teach us could save lives.”
Eydis froze in thought after picking up the last mint leaf from her plate.
She did not appear as if she would move any time soon, so Justin cleared their plates from the table and washed them in the sink.
He then returned the preserves, whipped cream, and mint sprigs to the fridge.
When he sat back down, Eydis had not moved from her contemplation even a millimeter.
“If anything, could you do it for me?”
Eydis’s eyes closed and a faint smile grew.
“A personal favor now, is it?”
Justin flashed the most endearing grin he could muster, but it only served to make Eydis chuckle.
She sighed.
“You care little for yourself and ask only for the safety of others.”
Eydis shook her head and said, “What have I gotten myself into choosing to live with such a man?” under her breath.
“If you are so worried, I will work with the police, but will they agree?
You have not asked them yet, right?”
“I will go to the station today and ask.
If they say no, there is nothing we can do.”

* * *
Major Wickenny readily agreed to find a suitable location when Justin brought up the possibility of witnessing combat magic firsthand.
The following day, Justin received the call stating that they would use an outdoor firing range in the mountains about an hour out of the city.
The range had been inactive for a few years, so it was the perfect location for secrecy.
Currently, the dirt road to it was closed, but the police would be able to grant access.
Eydis waited at the police station with uneased fingers gripping nervously at the bottom hem of her coat.
Sammy, Chloe, Miriam, and Sean were also present.
Major Wickenny arrived and led them out back to the parking lot where they were met by two officers and Agent Botteger.
With five people per truck, they drove out of the city to the mountains.
Each passing mile, Eydis’s nerves only worsened.
“You okay?” Justin held Eydis’s hand firmly.
“I am fine.”
Eydis continued looking out the thin window of the truck’s back seat.
She was trying to feign composure, but Justin knew she was troubled and that he was the cause.
“Sorry for asking you to do this,” he said.
Eydis shook her head.
“You had good reason to ask.
I could not turn you down.
I trust you will make my reward worth my trouble.”
“You bribed her?”
Sammy glared at Justin.
“She wouldn’t budge.
It was the only thing I could think of at the time.”
“If this goes well, we will compensate her too,” Major Wickenny chimed in from the driver’s seat.
“It was not the reward.
Justin was concerned for your safety, Sammy.
We do not know when or where more of those terrorists will appear.
I do not want you to come to harm either.”
Sammy leaned against Justin’s shoulder and reached across to grasp his and Eydis’s interlocked hands.
“Thanks,” she said with a bright smile.
Once off the highway, Major Wickenny followed a mountain road still lined with a foot of snow.
It wound through a shallow valley with deep banks on either side.

The snow on the road had melted making the trip easy, but after another fifteen minutes, they pulled off onto a gravel road and immediately met a simple orange bar acting as a barrier against vehicle entry.
The other officer in Major Wickenny’s truck exited and unlocked the barrier to let both trucks through.
Snow covered the remaining road, having been shaded from the sun by the slopes and ridges the road wove through.

Justin felt that they would get stuck in the one- or two-foot drifts, but Major Wickenny skillfully maneuvered the path until they reached a large clearing that looked like the hill behind it had been carved out to make the entire range level and give a solid earth backdrop.
Most of the clearing had little more than a few inches of remaining snow due to being in direct sunlight but at a high enough elevation to be too cold to fully melt yet.
A small shack sat in the corner by the entrance.
Both trucks pulled in next to it and let everyone out.
“It’s much cooler up here,” Miriam said while rubbing her hands.
Chloe hopped out of the truck and almost slipped on the snow.
“My shoes aren’t meant for this.”
Sean walked beside Major Wickenny to the shack and went inside.
Justin and Sammy followed.
It contained two couches, a table in the center, and a large variety of targets and stands in the back.
Major Wickenny shuffled through some of the targets and stood up a wooden stand to show Justin.
“Anything here that can be of use?”
“Is it alright if we use them?
They might get destroyed.”
From what Justin understood, this used to be a private business, so weren’t the targets someone’s property?
Major Wickenny promptly answered Justin’s unspoken concerns.
“Don’t worry about that.
The police of Gullivan and other nearby towns were given permission to use the range as needed after it closed.
Everything here was supplied by the station.
Use it freely.”
“Awesome.
Then it just depends on what Eydis needs.”
Justin looked behind him.
Eydis had not followed.
He left the shack and returned to the field.
The two police and Agent Botteger eyed the clearing with slack-jawed faces.
Much of the snow on the shack side of the clearing was gone, having been blown to the side by Eydis’s wind magic.
“Is this better?” Eydis asked.
“Thank you!” Chloe cheered.
Eydis noticed Chloe’s lack of proper footwear and cleared the snow from the area everyone would be practicing.

“Amazing, isn’t it?” Miriam boasted in front of the officers with wide gestures full of finesse almost as if she had been the one who cleared the field, but Chloe quickly stepped in to let the officers know their reaction was normal.
“This is the first time we’ve seen magic used to this extent, so it’s just as surprising for us to be honest.”
Justin walked over to Eydis in the center of the cleared dirt and gravel.
“There are targets inside the shack.
You want to take a look to see what you can use?”
“I do not think we will be needing targets yet.
Maybe… Bring out one or two.”
Eydis did not sound confident in her decision, almost as if she did not have a lesson plan ready.
Justin knew she would be fine and wished that she would have more confidence in herself.
This should be no different than teaching the self-defense class or her regular magic lessons.
Only the nature of the combat and magic changed.
In any case, he knew that demonstrations were what the police were here to see, so targets would be necessary.
He ran back to the shack and helped Sean and Major Wickenny carry out two of the cheaper looking wooden stands and paper targets.
Everyone gathered adjacent to the shack on the edge of the area Eydis cleared.
The police stood off to the side near the trucks to observe.
Justin expected Sean to join them, but he stood on the opposite side of the group of women from Justin.

Sean’s reasoning was that because he lived with Eydis, the possibility of him getting involved with Jethro’s men was higher, so he wanted to stand in on the lesson to learn what he could even if he could not use magic.
If anything, ven control could be practiced even without magic ability.
Eydis stood silent to gather her thoughts.
You can do this, Justin assured her in his mind.
It’s no different than teaching your self-defense class.
Eydis had no reason to be nervous or worried, but she also knew that the police were expecting this to be worth their time.
Justin doubted that they would judge Eydis’s every action, but there was no guarantee that Eydis wouldn’t feel she was being judged by them.
You can do this.
After a deep breath, Eydis finally spoke.
“Magic comes from energy inside your body called ven.
Ven is present in everything from the ground under you to the sky above you, but it is found most in things with life, like you, me, and even plants and animals.”
Why is she starting from the basics, Justin thought, but then realized that neither Sean nor the police had heard any of this before.
The others did not seem confused by Eydis’s review.
Surely they realized this as well.
“Each person that can use magic is able to use one or more of eight different types.
For example, I can use wind magic, Sammy can use water, Chloe can use fire, and Miriam can use earth.”
“What are the other four elements,” Agent Botteger asked.
“Life, space, time, and gravity,” Sammy replied.
“So they aren’t really elements in the traditional sense.
Eydis also can use life and spatial magic, and Justin has an affinity to time, but he can’t really do anything with it.”
After the interruption, Eydis fell silent.
“Oh, sorry Eydis!
You can continue.”
Sammy quickly apologized, and the police who asked the question followed.
“You are fine.
If you can answer any of their questions, please do.”
Eydis flashed a weary smile and fell silent again.
No one spoke up to ask a question or help move the lesson forward.
Awkward tension spread throughout the group.
Justin knew something was wrong.
He had never seen Eydis act like this.
This tension was felt by those most familiar with Eydis as they exchanged confused glances at each other.
“You are here to learn about combat magic, so I should start there,” she finally said.
Everyone returned their attention.
“Each element is different when it comes to combat.
I feel life magic might be the deadliest, but you need to touch the person to do any harm.
I was almost killed by life magic without even realizing it.
The only way to survive it is to use life magic to stop it.”
Justin’s heart skipped a beat.
When did that happen?
Was it before Eydis came to this world or after?
Was it when she was captured?
This was the first he had heard of it.
The others were just as concerned, but for the spectators, the concern was not directed towards Eydis.
“Are you saying that the only way to protect yourself from being killed by life magic is to be able to use life magic,” Agent Botteger asked.
Eydis nodded.
“You must be more skilled than your opponent or you will die.”
The spectators whispered among themselves.
This had to be the worst news for them to hear.
There was no way to protect against it.
“Life magic is rare.
Do not get touched, and you will be fine.
After life magic, the next deadliest might be fire magic.
You saw what fire could do when you let the Minum escape.
Ice is also very powerful, so water magic is strong.” Eydis paused.
“And so is wind.
In my fight against the terrorists, my wind magic made the long scar across the ground.”
“So they are all strong in combat?” Sean asked.
“By the skill of the user, yes.”
Major Wickenny raised his hand.
“Could you give us a demonstration of your wind magic?
Not clearing the field, but something used in combat?”
Eydis nodded and turned toward the two targets on the far end of the field.
Justin was glad he brought them out.
“Wind magic is hard to see, so I will increase its strength.”
Excitement grew on the faces of everyone present.
As far as Justin knew, no one here had seen combat magic.
He certainly had not.
His heart thundered in anticipation, and he looked on at Eydis and the target over fifty yards from her.
Eydis extended her arm diagonally downward to her side.
Her pants, coat, and hair billowed in a breeze that no one else could feel.
At the palm on her hand, the air distorted and blurred.
The blur stretched about five feet long into what looked like a swirling rod.
As it grew in intensity, Justin could feel the wind if only faintly from his position far behind her.
The spear disappeared from her hand with a swift forward swipe of her arm.
The near-transparent object flew at incredible speed and impacted the wooden target at the end of the cleared snow.
It bored through, disintegrating the paper target fastened to the front, and picked up the wooden stand.
The stand shredded into splinters as the wind spear carried it into the ridge another fifty yards back.
What was left of the stand blew apart as the wind of the spear dispersed on impact.
Everyone froze speechless, but to Justin’s surprise, so did Eydis.
She stared at the small crater in the ridge created by the spear.
“Eydis?”
Justin jogged over to Eydis and placed his hand on her arm.
She was breathing heavily from the wind conversion that must have been required for the spell.
“That was the strongest spear I have ever made.
I did not think that was possible.”
Her voice was so quiet that Justin was the only person to hear her.
A small smile grew on her face.
“I must be getting closer.”
“Closer?”
Eydis looked down at Justin and shook her head.
“It is nothing.”
She turned around, and immediately Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam swarmed her.
“That was amazing!”
“I’ve never seen anything like that!”
“Are we going to get that strong with enough training?”
The police did not see the same excitement on their faces.
There was only fear.
Justin could tell exactly what they were thinking.
How could anyone defend against such an attack?
Any person hit with it would be killed instantly.
It even had the possibility of killing multiple people at once.
Worst of all, no physical weapon was needed.
Eydis did this with her power alone.
Her earlier concern rang warning bells in Justin’s mind.
“It will make them fear me more.”
“Eydis!
Is there a way to defend against this?
Is there a way?”
Everyone looked at Justin a little bewildered by his sudden panicked question.
Their excitement died as they also realized what Justin was saying.
Sammy spoke everyone’s thoughts.
“If any of us were up against that, what could we do?”
Eydis placed her hands on Sammy’s shoulders and tried to reassure her with a smile.
“This magic is stronger than what you can handle now, but you are still learning.
Practice and get better, and something like this will be nothing to you.”
Whether this was true or not, Justin did not know, but Sammy seemed pleased with Eydis’s words of confidence.
“Ms. FeAmel.”
Major Wickenny approached the group after having discussed something with the other officers.
His expression was stern and still carried in it the lingering fear of what he had witnessed.
Justin stepped back to make room.
“You just said that Ms. Thompson would be able to do what you did or equivalent with enough practice.
Is that correct?”
Eydis looked at Sammy with concern and then back at Major Wickenny.
“You are worried that Sammy will become dangerous?
Are these lessons not so they can defend against the terrorists as equals?”
“You seem to be mistaking our purpose here.
We want to know how to protect people from them, not create more people with the same destructive power.”
“Is that not the same?
You were too weak to stop only one of them with your weapons.
If Sammy can do better than all the police you lost, should she not learn?
I fail to understand--”
One of the police that had ridden in the other truck, Officer Beynard, brushed Justin aside and glared at Eydis.
“My brother lost his life fighting that terrorist even you could not kill.
I will not let you insult him.”
“Larry, that’s enough.”
Major Wickenny placed his hand on Officer Beynard’s shoulder to turn him away.
“Yes, in a many against one battle, I did not have the luxury to make certain all were dead, but your people not only helped him, your brother could not even defeat an injured enemy.”
“Eydis!” Sammy moved in front of Eydis and pleaded with her eyes for Eydis to stop.
Officer Beynard turned around to confront Eydis again, but Justin blocked him.
Something was wrong with Eydis.
Justin had never seen her act like this, but he also did not want the officer to do anything to her.
Major Wickenny pushed Officer Beynard back to the trucks.
Sammy clung to the sleeves of Eydis’s coat.
“What’s the matter with you?”
Eydis’s gaze fell away dejectedly.
“I only wanted them to realize what they were up against.
Everything I said was true.
If your city police cannot fight Jethro’s men, teaching you how to fight them is the only way I can keep you safe.”
“That doesn’t mean you can insult someone’s dead brother.”
Eydis’s shoulders slumped, and she struggled to speak her next words.
“I… I have no desire to be kind to them.
I may have brought a war to this city, and the sooner they realize this, the better…
If they do not understand their own weakness, they will not become stronger.”
Major Wickenny returned alone.
“And that is precisely why we made arrangements to take you out of the city where you could be better protected.”
“And I already told you that removing me will not help you.
My goal is to make sure Sammy and the others are safe, and I will teach them if it will help.
The best you can do is watch and hope you learn a way to fight it.”
“I’m sorry, but we have already decided that no more combat lessons will be held after today.
None of your friends here have had proper combat training, so I cannot permit teaching them something that is as dangerous as what you have shown us.
I have a few more requests for you today, but after that, we will be finished here.”
“If you will not let me help my friends, then I have nothing more to show you.
I now know of this location, so we can come here whenever we want with my teleportation.
We no longer have need of you.”
Sammy cut in.
“Eydis, it’s fine.
They are only trying to protect the people who live in Gullivan.
You said it yourself, right?
They need to know what they are up against.”
Eydis looked long at Sammy’s pleading eyes, and slowly the tension in Eydis’s melted away.
Justin felt that if Sammy had been the one to personally request combat magic lessons, Eydis would have complied immediately.
A mild feeling of inferiority rose within him, but it was overshadowed by the joy that Eydis had such a dear friend.
“What requests do you have of me?
Let us finish with them and be done,” Eydis ordered.
Major Wickenny nodded and then took out a small notepad from his coat pocket.
“First is to know what weapons or firearms would be useful against your magic.”
“I know nothing of your weapons.
Did you bring any with you?”
“Only a handgun.”
Major Wickenny flashed the firearm at his waist.
“Seeing only one weapon, I cannot answer your question, but I doubt something that small would have any effect.”
“That is fine.

Next was for you to show us how to defend against the fire magic that killed so many people, but you are not able to use fire magic, so this request might not be possible, but… I will change the question.
You used a projectile style magic earlier.
The man who killed so many people used a different type of magic.
From the camera footage, fire shot up from below their feet.
To me, it looks like there is no way to defend against this.
Do you know a way?
He is still out there, so this is very important.”
Eydis did not answer.
She looked at her hand while deep in thought.
Her fingers moved as if trying to feel the shape of an invisible object.
“Everyone, stand back,” she ordered.
Major Wickenny moved back to his fellow police by the trucks, and Justin followed Sammy and everyone else back to where they had been standing at the beginning of the lesson.
Eydis motioned with her arm, hand, and fingers as if trying to use magic, but nothing happened.
The longer this continued, minute signs of frustration began to appear in Eydis’s movements.
Justin noticed that in random places in the clearing, dirt or snow shifted around.
His eyes followed them, and the more it happened, the more worried he became.
He looked over at the others, and no one else seemed to have noticed, or they had noticed but thought nothing of it.
When a large amount of dirt kicked up between Eydis and the group, Justin knew something was wrong.
“Eydis, stop!” The warning came from Miriam.
Eydis turned around.
At the same time spiraling wind erupted from a location in the center between where Eydis, the police, Justin, and the others were standing.
Near-invisible crescent arcs of wind flew out in all directions from the whirlwind.
One arc approached Justin at incredible speed but slowed down to a crawl when it neared.
Justin flung himself backward to avoid it but did not notice the smaller arc just behind it that was now heading for his left arm.
He moved his arm upwards as the slow arc passed and nearly avoided it by a few inches.
When he landed on his back, the world returned to its normal speed.
He gasped for breath from the impact on his back.

His arm stung terribly from where the smaller arc passed, but when he looked at the tear in his sleeve, the injury appeared no worse than having something thin whipped across it--a pink line with only the top layer of skin torn.
No doubt a terrible bruise would form later.
This was the damage caused by avoiding the arc by inches.
If it had hit, he knew the damage would have been far worse.
Fear struck like lightning.
He jumped up and looked at Eydis.
Her arm was extended towards Sammy who was unharmed.
Chloe next to Sammy was on her back bleeding from cuts on her left leg and arm.
Sean was on his back with Miriam on top of him.
Her back had a long slash across it that cut clean through her coat and shirt and exposed her lower back.
A thick pink welt line spread completely across her back, but she was otherwise unharmed.
Eydis ran over in a panic.
“No!
I am so sorry!
That was not supposed to happen!
I… Chloe!”
Eydis ran to Chloe and quickly slid her hands over the lacerations.
“I’m okay.
I’m okay.”
Chloe forced a pained smile.
Blood soaked her pant leg and sleeve.
The cuts could not have been light.
Justin scanned everyone and was relieved that no one else was badly injured.
He then looked over at the police.
“E-Eydis!
The police!”
Justin grabbed Eydis’s hand and ran to the trucks.
Major Wickenny was bleeding from his left shoulder.
Agent Botteger and one of the other officers were unharmed, but Officer Beynard lay on the ground bleeding profusely from his side.
The uninjured officer drew his gun and aimed it at Eydis.
“Don’t move!”
Major Wickenny ignored his injury and rushed to the side of Officer Beynard.
Meanwhile, Agent Botteger pulled out his phone.
“Put your gun down!
Eydis can help him!”
Justin pleaded with the officer, but the gun remained raised.
“He cannot hurt us.”
Eydis ignored the weapon aimed at her and ran with Justin to Major Wickenny.
The officer hesitated but lowered his firearm.
“Major Wickenny, let Eydis help.
She can heal--” Justin’s words caught in his throat.
His head grew light, and his vision wavered like agitated water.
The damage done to the downed officer was far worse than what he had seen from a distance.
The cut had severed clean through Officer Beynard’s side about four inches deep or more.
If not treated fast, it would be fatal.
“Move aside!”
Eydis immediately ran her hand through the cut.
Major Wickenny was about to pull her away, but the flow of blood from the wound stemmed.
She slid her hand in the deep wound and worked to repair the damaged tissue, but her face quickly grew strained.
“Justin, hold my hand.”
Justin held Eydis’s outstretched, bloody hand while she worked.
“Roll up my sleeve and yours.
Wrap your arms around mine.
The more skin contact, the better.”
Justin obeyed the odd request without question and clasped Eydis’s forearm between both of his.
“It is not enough.
I am almost out of ven.
He is stable for now.
I will return quickly.”
Eydis let go of Justin and ran a few yards away.
She vanished with the sound of a loud snap using a form of teleportation that Justin had never seen.
Sammy, Chloe, Miriam, and Sean arrived and were shocked at the severity of Officer Beynard’s wounds.
Major Wickenny kept pressure on the wound to keep it closed to prevent further bleeding even though the bleeding had completely stopped.
At least Officer Beynard was still breathing.
“A life flight helicopter is on its way,” Agent Botteger announced.
“I can’t believe that witch attacked us!
We should have locked her up when we had the chance.”
The officer who drew his gun on Eydis was fuming.
Justin understood why he was angry, but he could not ignore any insult to Eydis.
“Anyone could see that was an accident!”
“Accident?
You all are unharmed, but the one of us who confronted her ends up nearly killed?
I find that hard to believe.”
