Justin wanted to say Chloe was injured--she was in the back of the group, so her injuries were not visible to the officer--but Miriam cut in before Justin could.
“It was an accident.
Don’t let your fear make you stupid.
Eydis would never attack you.
She’s just been off since she was captured.
I’m positive she never meant any harm.
If she did, she wouldn’t be trying so hard to save him.”
“But still, this is unlike Eydis…”
Once Chloe voiced her worry, Sammy could not deny it either.
“Yah.
I haven’t seen her this distressed since Justin tried to kick her out of his apartment.”
Justin wanted to retort, but he knew that Sammy was right.
Eydis was not in her right mind.
“It’s almost like she is a different person,” Miriam sighed.
“Miriam, would you be the same?
She fought for her life and then was imprisoned for a week waiting to be taken somewhere where she would probably be executed or worse.
She…” Justin’s own words sank in his chest.
Painful anxiety grew.
Executed or worse…

Eydis’s startling warning to Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam about what could happen to them if they were captured by Jethro’s men brought a painful understanding of what might have happened during the week she was captured.
Her sudden shout was unlike her usual outbursts caused by misunderstanding or wrongful accusation.
There was a real terror and pain that seeped out through her cry.
Justin could not imagine that such a painful cry could come without having experienced the same pain she was warning the girls against.
“But it’s true, isn’t it?
We all realize it,” Miriam said.
“You can’t deny it either, right?”
Justin staggered back as the ignorant conversation continued around him.
If Eydis was assaulted in captivity, of course her emotional state would weaken or change.
Of course she would be distressed and afraid.
Of course she would not want to be taken away by soldiers somewhere far from her friends.
Those were human soldiers, the same as those who attacked her.
“Could you all stop already?!”
Justin shouted.
“You have no idea what kind of--”
“Move out of the way.”
Eydis nudged Justin aside.
At some point in the conversation, she had returned.
Miriam clamped shut and stepped back with a guilty countenance.
Eydis knelt at the side of Officer Beynard.
The wound healed quickly, and in a few minutes’ time, she was sealing the skin back together.
The fresh pink skin showed little sign that the injury had ever existed.
When finished, Eydis placed her hand on Officer Beynard’s forehead, and his eyes shot open.
Dread grew on his face from the visage of the one looking down on him, and before anyone could stop him, he drew his handgun and fired.
The bullet embedded itself in the dirt next to Officer Beynard’s head, having been deflected by Eydis’s barrier.
Major Wickenny rushed to subdue and disarm his fellow officer, which was easy after how much blood Officer Beynard lost.
“I told you it would have no effect.”
Eydis turned away from the man she saved.
Anger welled up inside Justin.
Ignoring that the officer had been lethally injured just moments before, he raised his foot but was quickly pulled back by Sean before he could stomp the downed officer.
Justin pushed Sean away and hurried to Eydis where Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam surrounded her in collective panic.
Eydis brushed everyone away and approached Major Wickenny while he was holding down Officer Beynard.
She placed her hand on his shoulder and immediately healed his shallow cut.
She then walked away from the group.
Sammy tried to follow, but Eydis stopped her.
“I want to be alone.”
Ignoring Eydis’s plea for solitude, Justin hurried to her side.
She did not reject his company, for which he was grateful.
Once separated from the group, Justin worked up the courage to speak.
He did not know what to say and struggled in his heart to think of how to comfort the dejected and defeated woman beside him.
What words could he say that could ease her troubled heart, especially after what very well could have happened to her?
Coming up empty but then realizing no one had expressed their gratitude, he had something to say.
“Thank you for saving him.”
Eydis stopped walking and peered down at the frosted dirt and gravel a short distance in front of her.
“It was my fault that he was injured… And thank you for defending me.
You were the one I was most worried about, but you are the one who has trusted me the most…”
Worried about me?
Was she scared that I would shun her if I knew what happened to her?
Despite his internal anguish, Justin could not find the courage to bring up the topic to Eydis.
However, he could offer his support should she ever decide to talk about it.
“Whatever is going on, you can talk with me.
I am here for you.”
“I just need some time alone.
Tell Major Wickenny that he need not compensate me.
You also have no need to reward me.”
Eydis opened a portal to her room and gently pushed Justin away before backing in and closing it behind her.
Justin was left with an empty feeling in his heart.
He urged her to hold this training session, and everything went horrifically wrong.
He knew Eydis was not well, and yet he still coerced her into it completely ignorant of the signs that she was hurting inside.
People were injured.
Her relationship with the police worsened.
She overheard her own friends talking about her behind her back at her most vulnerable moment.
All this was his fault.
He walked back to the group with an unbearable weight of guilt born over his shoulders that he struggled to keep from crushing him.
All he could do now was apologize to those still present.
“I’m sorry for all of this.
I’m the one who pushed her into it despite knowing that she was under a lot of stress.
Please don’t blame her,” Justin said.
“It would have been best if you took that into consideration beforehand, but what has happened has happened.,” Major Wickenny replied.
“Thanks to her magic, we are all fine.”
Officer Beynard had calmed down, so Major Wickenny was free to talk with everyone about what just occurred.
Now that the group spread out in a circle, everyone’s individual injuries or lack thereof was visible.
Chloe’s in particular caught Major Wickenny’s attention.
Blood soaked the sleeve of her jacket from her first cut, and blood had run down her thigh soaking her pant leg from her second.
She was proof that this had just been a terrible accident.
Justin felt that he understood why the magic went awry and that it was his duty to give an explanation now that Eydis left.
“I have seen Eydis cast magic many times before.
When you asked her how to defend against magic that shot up from the ground, I don’t think she knew how to do it.
She was trying to figure it out.”
“She should have said so.
I would have accepted that.
We would be no worse off without knowing,” Major Wickenny said.
“True, but Eydis is someone who always wants to help when she can.
We can’t fault her for that.”
Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam nodded in agreement.
Major Wickenny glanced over at everyone’s injuries and stopped at Miriam.
“What I do not understand is how you all avoided injury in that blast.
Jason and Murphy only avoided it because they were standing behind Larry and me.
Those blades even cut into the siding of the truck.”
Justin looked to Miriam and Sammy.
Chloe was the only one of their group unable to avoid injury, but she was the first to reply.
“I’d probably be dead if not for my magic.”
Everyone turned to Chloe with varying expressions of surprise and disbelief.
No one had seen Chloe use any magic, and fire magic was not easy to hide.
Noticing everyone’s confusion, she hurried to explain.
“A large wind blade, or whatever you could call it, headed straight for me.
I panicked and tried to block it with my hands.
I channeled a lot of fire ven into my hands and heated the air in front of me the hottest I could.
I don’t understand the physics behind it, but the blade dispersed and only cut me a little.”
Your injuries were more than just a little, Justin thought, but he remained silent.
Her cuts could be seen as small given the alternative and what had happened to Officer Beynard.
Miriam followed next and removed a pocketknife from her jeans pocket.
She held out her hand and ran the knife edge forcefully across the palm of her hand.
Major Wickenny blinked twice as if he did not believe the information his eyes transferred to his brain.
There was no cut.
“Earth magic can be used to protect from cuts.
I coated my body with it to protect myself and shield the closest person to me.”
She glanced at Sean who smiled and nodded his head lightly in an expression of gratitude.
Sammy explained next.
“Eydis saved me with a barrier.
She probably realized that I couldn’t have protected myself even if I wanted to.
I don’t know any way to stop that with water magic.
Ice might have done something, but I’ve tried making ice and can’t.”
The only explanation remaining was Justin’s, but he did not feel his was anything special.
“All I did was dodge them.”
Sammy walked up to him with a stern expression.
“Don’t lie.
We all know your special power.”
Sammy swung her arm to the side and patted Justin’s chest forcefully.
“Justin here can slow time, so dodging things is really easy for him, but that’s about all he can do.”
The few remaining threads of reason that held Major Wickenny’s sanity finally snapped.
“What kind of fantasy have I found myself in?”
He wiped his face and began pacing in a circle but stopped abruptly.
He looked over at Justin, Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam.
“You are all amateurs.
You cannot do anything close to what Ms. FeAmel can.”
Sammy shook her head.
“Nowhere close.”
“We were absolutely powerless to protect ourselves.
Ms. FeAmel even deflected a bullet.
That air explosion she did looked far more powerful than the projectile she threw before and yet you were able to protect yourselves.”
Everyone looked around at each other.
No one knew what Major Wickenny meant.
“You can tell Ms. FeAmel that this has been rather informative.
We wanted to know how to protect ourselves from magic, and now we know that we can’t, at least as we are now.
It is very clear that only magic can defend properly against magic.”
“She was right,” Agent Botteger said, joining the circle after finishing another phone call.
“Teaching you all is the only way to keep you safe against it.

Justin, please tell Ms. FeAmel that we can continue the lessons, but the Department of Defense will be supervising it in place of the Gullivan Police Department, and we have a huge request if Ms. FeAmel is willing.”

* * *
Justin returned with Sean from the combat magic lesson.
He requested Sean to make a quick stop before they arrived home and now carried a small white cardboard box in his left hand.
It contained two slices of German chocolate cake from Eydis’s favorite diner, a dessert Eydis had not tried.

While Sean sat on the couch and immediately picked up the book he had been reading before they departed for the magic lesson, turning to the exact page he had left off on without having marked it, Justin grabbed two forks from the kitchen.
He walked down the hall in slow nervous steps to Eydis’s room.
His heart was laced with worry.
Worry about how much anguish Eydis was in.
Worry about what he was going to say to her.
Worry about how he was going to apologize.
With his trembling hand raised to the door, he even hesitated to knock.
“If you are going to come in, come in.”
Eydis’s sullen voice was muffled by more than just the door between them.
Justin opened the door to find her sitting on the floor in the corner by the desk with the down feather comforter he gave her for Christmas wrapped around her.
Her face was buried in the soft fabric with some of her hair messily bunched up into loops as she pulled the comforter tight against the back of her head.

All that was visible was her hair on the top of her head, her fingers gripping the fabric, and her toes poking out from beneath with a tiny bit of her light green fleece sweatpants showing on top of them.
She had changed into the most comfortable clothing she owned and bundled herself up in her most comfortable blanket.
Justin could not see or hear her crying, but from how she continually readjusted her trembling fingers to re-grip the fabric, he knew she was, even if only on the inside.
Staring down at her did nothing to help, so Justin slowly sat cross-legged beside her close enough to brush against the comforter and placed the small white box and utensils beside him.
Not knowing what to say, he gently leaned over until his shoulder rested against hers to at least let her know he was there for her.
There they sat in silence as the minutes passed on.
“I am trying…”
Eydis’s trembling voice broke the silence.
When she did not continue, Justin felt that she was waiting for him to reply.
He leaned ever so lightly further into her shoulder.
“You can’t blame yourself for what happened today.
It was an accident.”
“I never wanted to do that lesson!”
Eydis pulled her knees in closer to her chest and the comforter tighter around her, causing it to slip up over her head dragging a bunch of hair with it.
Somehow, her tone sounded more self-depreciating than accusatory against Justin.
He knew this was his fault, and after all that had happened, he felt worse that Eydis was far too kind to blame him for any of it.

She probably felt that she should have been able to teach that lesson as she had countless times in the past, and she was smart enough to realize that she wasn’t up for the task after what had happened to her, but her kindness made her hold the lesson anyway for the sake of those she cared about most.
“I did it because it is what everyone expects of me.
I thought if I did something that was normal for… for me to do, then things would return to how they were before.
I hate it.
I hate it!
I do not want to be trapped inside this apartment.
I feel like a prisoner again…”
“You are the only one forcing yourself to stay in here.”
“Do you think I do not know that?!”
Eydis’s face shot up from the comforter at Justin, but she promptly buried it again.
Justin thought he saw that her eyes were turning more of a burnt orange than their usual scattering of green and blue.
“Do you think I do not know that,” Eydis repeated again, but with a strain that sounded as if she would break into sobbing at the slightest provocation.
“I was foolish to think that I could come here and live my life like nothing would be different.
Nobody trusts me.
Even Sammy doubts me…”
Eydis pulled the comforter tighter so that it covered her entire head aside from a few loops of hair sticking out.
“I want to give up.
I want to end it all.”
“Eydis!” Justin slid in front of her with his hand gripped tightly on her shoulder.
“Stop that line of thinking right now.”
“But, I cannot continue like this.
Would you not…” Eydis’s voice trailed off.
She shivered like the abandoned puppy he had always envisioned her as in the past only now caught alone in the frigid rain.
Her next words were so quiet that Justin could barely hear them.
“Would you not be happier if… if the old me was here instead?”
Something terrible had happened to her.
Eydis’s words confirmed it without a doubt in Justin’s mind.
He knew something was different about her.
Her emotions were more pronounced and unstable.
She was actively suppressing her excitement as if she felt that she no longer deserved to be happy.
The way she interacted with others was submissive and repressed as if she feared what everyone would say to her or what they would think about her.
Even now, she was choosing her words carefully to hide what happened to her.
Jethro and his men did something terrible to Eydis that could not be undone.
If only I knew about this sooner.
“Part of the problem is that you have been keeping all these pent-up feelings to yourself.
The more you hold them in, the more they will hurt you.
If you talk to me more, talk to your friends more, we will better understand you and be able to help you.
We will support you and help you through it.”
“You would never understand.
You could never understand.
If I told you, you would hate me, and my life here would be over!”
Eydis’s head sank deeper between her legs, showing surprising flexibility.
“No, you don’t understand.
We have all been worried sick over you.
Ever since you came back to us, we have watched you spiral into depression and shut yourself off from those who love you.
We do not know what happened to you when you were captured.
What you heard from Sammy and Chloe and Miriam at the range was just them voicing their worries.
They don’t doubt you, and they have not lost their trust in you.
You should talk with them.”
Eydis’s head rose slightly, but only enough that her forehead could rest on her knees.
“But, there is too much that… I am afraid that…”
“You are talking to me, aren’t you?
How is that any different?”
“But you are my man…
If I cannot talk with you, who can I talk to?”
Justin retracted his hand in shock.
His thoughts drowned in the blood that rushed to his face, unable to make sense of the words that had entered his ears.
Eydis’s head rose slowly like a child peeking out from under the covers after hiding from thunder in the dark.
Her terror was realized when she saw the shocked face of the one to whom she had spilled the troubled contents of her heart.
That fear seeped into her expression, and she slid back into the wall behind her as if to distance herself from it.
“No… I was wrong?
Are you… are we not…?
All this time I thought… I have made a terrible mistake.
I… I can no longer stay here.
No… I…”
Eydis’s words became incoherent Elven rambling, and in her dismay, she sprung to her feet to either run out of the room or create distance so she could safely teleport away.
When her leg brushed Justin’s arm, his senses returned, and he clasped Eydis’s fleeing hand.
“Wait!”
Justin pulled her light frame down to her side and caught her in an embrace.
The side of her face pressed against his chest, crinkling the soft cartilage of her ear.
He rested his cheek against the top of her head.
“No, you weren’t wrong.
I love you.
I always have.
So please, don’t go.”
When Justin spoke those words, Eydis shuddered.
He felt light moisture through his shirt where her face rested.
She gripped his shirt and slowly lifted herself off him.
He saw pain in her tear-filled eyes.
“Why?
The first man to show me such kindness, and it hurts.
The first man to say he loves me and it… it is a lie.”
A lie?
Eydis’s pained eyes cut his heart like poisoned daggers spreading doubt through his veins.
He loved her, or at least he thought he did.
He had become utterly distressed and inconsolable when she disappeared.
When he realized what might have happened to her when she was captured, his heart ached deeply for her.
But what if he was misinterpreting his feelings of sympathy as love?
What if Eydis had some way to tell if he was not sincere in his declaration?

The longer Justin looked at the tears building in Eydis’s eyes, the stronger he wanted to hold her, the more he longed for the return of her radiant smile like the sun after a light summer shower, reflecting its light off all it touched.
That smile had been tarnished by sorrow and regret.
He hated Jethro for hurting Eydis, for making her like this.
He wanted her to smile again.
He wanted all that tormented her to be swept away in a flood of laughter.
All these feelings he had, all these desires for the happiness of the crying woman in his arms, if that was not love, what was it?
“I am not lying.
I will say it as many times as I need to.
I love you.”
The building tears fell from Eydis’s eyes.
The grip of her hands on his shirt tightened, and she buried her face in his chest.
“No… No… No… No… No…”
The words Justin spoke to quell her worries only caused greater pain.
He froze, not knowing what to do.
Should he hold her?
Should he say something else?
He looked around for something, anything, when his eyes fell upon the small bump beneath the discarded comforter.
He lifted the still sobbing girl off his chest and looked into her bloodshot and tear-soaked eyes.
“Want some cake?”
Eydis looked up at Justin with her mouth slightly ajar and her eyebrows raised lightly in confusion above her pained eyes.
After wiping a tear from her eye with his thumb, he stood and gathered the comforter, wrapping it gently around Eydis’s bare shoulders.
He then retrieved the white box and forks.
He leaned against the wall and extended his hand towards Eydis.
She was another two feet away, so he let her decide whether to take it.
She hesitated, but her outstretched hand clasped his.
He pulled her in, leaning her against him between his legs so that her head rested just beside his and readjusted the comforter so that it wrapped snuggly around her but kept one arm free.
Justin opened the white box in her lap to reveal two slices of moist dark chocolate cake with coconut frosting.
Justin grabbed a fork and broke off a piece with both the frosting and the chocolate and coconut buttercream separating the two layers of cake.
The fork hovered near Eydis’s mouth until she succumbed to the sweet aroma and took a bite.
“How is it?”
Eydis grabbed the hand Justin had wrapped around her waist and tapped her feet in delight.
Fresh tears fell from her eyes.
She fought to hold back the faint coughing chuckles that escaped her mouth.
“Want another?”
Eydis wiped her tears and nodded, so Justin cut another piece and brought it to Eydis’s mouth.
Once again she smiled and tapped her feet.
“Eat as much as you like,” Justin said, handing the fork to Eydis.
“You said you did not need a reward, but that is exactly what this is.
It’s a reward for coming back to us.
Thank you for coming back.
Thank you for surviving.
I’ll give you this and more.
After all, I love you more than anything.”
Eydis set the fork Justin handed her back into the box.
Eydis’s head hung low, but after a few light nods, she set the box beside them and knelt forward facing Justin in the gap between his legs.
Eydis looked down at him with a soft smile on her tear-stained face.
She leaned into him and placed her forehead against his.
“I will stay.”
He could feel the warmth radiating from her face and the faint breath of her words tickling his lips.
His heart raced faster for every second she held him close.
She brought her face to his, and after a moment’s hesitation, her soft and smooth lips pressed against the corner of his mouth.
The touch was brief, but it left Justin breathless.
After pressing her forehead against his once more, Eydis stood up and placed the comforter on the bed.
“Thank you for caring for me so.
I need a moment to myself, so I will take a bath.”
Eydis exited the room, and Justin was left alone staring at the door in panic and amazement.

He promised himself after his year with Sammy that he would never enter another relationship, but if the choice was between keeping that promise to himself and losing Eydis, it was not a choice at all.
He loved Eydis; that much was certain.

His heart continued to race from the lingering touch of Eydis’s lips, and his romance-starved mind kept worming its way into thoughts about sex, but he had to remind himself that sex was not an option.
It could never be an option.
He loved her far too much to hurt her.

After a breath of relief to calm the carnal man inside, his mind cleared enough for the anxiety pricking his heart to surface, anxiety caused by something he had noticed recently but was now far more profound during the kiss.
Eydis’s breath smelled of blood.

Chapter 9
“Confused Feelings”
Eydis
Eydis closed the door to the bathroom and opened the tub faucet.
Without stopping the drain, she stared at the water as it pooled and spiraled down.
She ran her cupped hand under the water and brought it to her mouth to wash it clean from the kiss she had given Justin.
Was returning his feelings the correct choice?
Did she have a choice after claiming he was her man?
What would have happened if she rejected him then?
What would the princess have done?
With both hands cupped under the faucet, she splashed her tearstained face and stared once more at the water that spiraled down the drain.
“What am I doing?” she moaned in a tired whisper.
In a moment of weakness caused by the days of fear and anxiety from trying to avoid all risks of her identity as an imposter being revealed, she had spilled her heart to the princess’s man.
Even after stating every trouble that plagued her, he did not shy away.
He did not doubt her.
He never questioned that she was not his princess.
How blind is he?
Does he love her so much that there is no room for doubt?
Eydis’s hands gripped the edge of the tub hard enough for the strange material to creak.
She only let go for fear of it breaking.
Eydis pulled the tab on the faucet to let the water rain from the showerhead and opened a portal to the cellar of Rynn’s house.
The cellar was dark, lit only by the faint orange glow of the furnace that Rynn kept stoked.
The body on the floor across from her lay motionless.
Despite the warm but faint glow of the furnace, the princess’s skin appeared ghostly pale.

In Eydis’s rush to save the police officer’s life in a desperate attempt to salvage what little relationship she had with the city’s guards and the princess’s friends, she fed for a second time that day.
Ignoring the princess’s miserable and deathly pallor, Eydis eyed her with loathing.
“Why…” Eydis took one step closer to the body.
“Why?
Why?
Why?!
Why?!
WHY?!”
Her foot swung into the princess’s stomach, and the body flew back.
The chains binding it caught on the stake in the ground and stopped her before she collided with the shelves against the wall.
“Why did you have everything?!”
Eydis fell to her knees and hunched over, cradling her arms under her.
“Why was your life so much better than mine?
Are we not the same?”
Tears fell from Eydis’s eyes, but she did not try to stop them.
She only stared at the small wet marks they made in the cement floor.
Every drop she saw, her rage grew stronger.
It bubbled up until it erupted through her wailing screams.
“You are the crowned princess!
A genius who is the pride of the entire empire!
You wanted for nothing.
You had family and friends.
You had loyal retainers.
You had a mother who loved you.
You were destined to rule the empire and bask in the praise and support of your subjects.
Even when your family was assassinated, you miraculously survived!
You came to a new world with new friends like Sammy and even found a man who loves you so unconditionally that he is blind!
And you never accepted that love?
Was it not good enough for you?
Were you too perfect for him having lived such a perfect life?”
The tears became an unbroken stream down her cheeks, dripping off her chin.
“I was never shown love even once my entire life… I was created only to be used.
I am not a person.
I never was.
I was a tool for you to sacrifice.
I was a tool for Jethro to find you.
The only people to ever show me any kindness are your humans, and only because they think I am you.
The only man to ever say he loves me is Justin, and only because he thinks I am you…”
Eydis grabbed one of the chains and pulled the princess closer.
She held the princess’s head in her hands and caressed the princess’s slightly sunken cheek.
“I look like you.
I sound like you.
But, now more than ever I know… I am not you!”
Eydis threw the princess away.
The princess’s head made an audible crack when it hit the hard floor.
“I cannot be you!
I can look more like you.
I can sound more like you.
I can use magic more like you.
But I am not you…
Why cannot someone love me for being me?”
Eydis sat up and tried to wipe her tears, but they kept flowing.
She forced herself to smile and chuckled.
“That is not possible, is it… After all, we are not truly the same.
I am a Lurr, a monster, right?
You said it yourself.
And nobody can love a monster.”
As small figure stepped into the corner of Eydis’s vision.
Rynn stood at the bottom of the stairway.
Tears fell from her cheeks onto her yellow, flower print dress.
She ran to Eydis and wrapped her arms around her neck.
She pressed her cheek as hard as she could into Eydis’s.
That is right… Rynn knows me as I am.
But, would she be as attached if she had never been through what was done to her, if I never had to save her?
Would she treat me as a monster or just think of me as the princess’s tool?
“Would you still love a monster like me if we met under better conditions?”
Rynn hugged Eydis even tighter.
“You are not a monster.”
Rynn shifted to kneel in front of Eydis and placed her forehead against Eydis’s.
She wiped away Eydis’s tears and rested her hand on Eydis’s cheek.
“I am the second daughter of the royal Master Chef.
Princess Eydis was my future empress, nothing more.
You saved me when I was dead.
You gave me life again.
You are not Princess Eydis.
You are something more.
You are my world.
Stop trying to be less than what you are.”
Rynn had never been so vocal.
Her words sounded like a lie in Eydis’s ears, but she knew Rynn had not lied.
Her acute senses heard nothing but loving care.
Fresh tears flowed down Eydis’s cheeks, and she sobbed.
Rynn pulled Eydis down into her chest and cradled her head, brushing her hair with her fingers as Eydis had always done to her.
“You are not a monster.
You are not Princess Eydis.”
Rynn’s soft hands and calm, reassuring voice helped soothe the pain threatening to tear Eydis’s heart apart.
I am not Eydis?
I am not a monster?
Eydis was a Lurr.
Lurr were monsters that became what they preyed on.
Eydis preyed solely on the princess and was becoming more and more like her.
If I am neither, then… what am I?
The pain in Eydis’s heart lessened but was only replaced by the empty void of confusion.
The tears streaming down her cheeks slowed.
She sat motionless in Rynn’s arms unable to think any longer.
She was tired, mentally, physically, and emotionally.
Rynn led Eydis to her feet and up the steps.
She was about to lead Eydis to the bedroom to rest, but after looking at Eydis’s face stained with tears, she led her to the bathroom.
Only then Eydis remembered that she was supposed to be bathing.
Rynn removed her dress and undressed Eydis.
She ran the water and began washing Eydis.
Eydis did not resist and let Rynn’s gentle, yet meticulous hands wash away her tears.
Rynn even took attention to the dried blood still remaining under Eydis’s fingernails, never asking where it came from.
When finished, Rynn sat at the far end of the tub and leaned Eydis back so that her head rested on Rynn’s belly.
Once more, Rynn ran her fingers through Eydis’s hair and brushed Eydis’s cheek like a mother consoling a troubled child.
Eydis’s body relaxed.
She was falling into the comfort of the small girl.
When her heavy eyes threatened to close, her senses woke with the fresh smell of blood.
Rynn’s caressing ceased when a warm droplet fell onto Eydis’s forehead.
Eydis’s eyes shot open and looked up at the young girl to find that the tip of her left horn was bleeding.
Rynn touched it and stared at the red stain on her finger.
After righting herself, Eydis was about to touch the raw skin at the tip of Rynn’s horn to stop the bleeding, but Rynn shielded her horn with her hand.
“Let it peel.”
Forrest Elf youth were considered adults once the skin on their horns fully peeled, and letting the skin peel naturally was a long-held tradition in most Forrest Elf households.

The natural pattern or shape of the remaining skin on the horn once it finished pealing was seen as another facet of a Forrest Elf woman’s facial beauty, and tampering with the pealing even to help the process could have a negative effect on the final appearance.
Boys’ antlers grew long and fast, so peeling finished quickly, but the process was much longer for girls, lasting half a year at most, and was oftentimes painful.
In rare cases, the bleeding would continue throughout the entire process, leaving the girl weak and anemic until the peeling finished.
Infection of the skin was also a possibility, but that was rare.
The early days of peeling were always the worst until the skin encasing the horns died.
Rynn spent most her time alone, so Eydis wanted to help the process in any way she could, but once again Rynn stopped her.
“Do not worry.” Rynn grew a faint smile, the first smile Eydis had seen, but it felt forced.
This was a joyous occasion for any young Forrest Elf, and Eydis understood that Rynn wanted her to be happy as well.
Once the peeling finished, Rynn would be an adult and free to love and start a family if she pleased, but that truth twisted a knot of regret in Eydis’s heart.
Rynn was given as a slave to a man for pleasure, but if Rynn had put that past behind her and was looking forward to her own future, Eydis should as well.
Eydis forced a smile in return and kissed Rynn’s cheek to not touch her horns when pressing their foreheads together.
“Congratulations.”
A genuine grin spread across Rynn’s face.
It was small, but to Eydis it glowed brighter than the noonday sun.
Eydis found a small hand towel in the hallway closet to wrap under the base of Rynn’s horns to catch any dripping blood.
Having lost track of time, Eydis knew she had to return or Justin would worry.
“I need to go, but I will be back to celebrate.”
Rynn nodded, and the faint smile returned.
Back in the bathroom of Justin’s apartment, Eydis found that the water of the shower had been turned off.
She opened the bathroom door slowly, expecting Justin to be waiting angrily because of her unannounced disappearance, but she did not find anyone.
She walked to her room and found Justin sitting on the floor where he had been when she left.
“I am sorry.
I just needed some time to myself, so I…”
Justin smiled and shook his head.
“I’m not mad.
I knew something was up because you never use the shower.
Remember what I said before?
Just talk to me.
I won’t understand anything unless you say it.”
Eydis felt that was a lie, because Justin almost had a sixth sense for detecting when she was nervous, worried, or troubled.
The events preceding her escape to Rynn’s house flooded back.
I accepted Justin as my lover.
What am I to do?
Her face grew hot, and she could not find any words to say to him.
She knelt in front of him with her head lowered, submissive, because she did not know how else to approach him now.
“Eydis.”
“Yes?” Eydis startled and replied by reflex.
“While you were gone, I was thinking about everything you said.
You are probably thinking that things cannot go back to how they were before, and you are probably right.”
Justin grasped Eydis’s hand and gently caressed her knuckles with his thumb.
He pulled her over to sit next to him as they were before.
“I don’t know what Jethro and his men did to you, but whatever happened does not define who you are.”
He turned his head and locked eyes with Eydis, his deep blue eyes like polished sapphires exuding confidence.
“This sounds a bit cliché, but you decide who you are.”
He broke eye contact with a smile and looked forward into nowhere.
“You are worried that everyone will judge you because of what happened, but I certainly won’t.
I can’t speak for Sammy or anyone else, but I don’t think they will either.
If you are still worried, there is a simple answer.
Just be yourself.
Don’t try to overcompensate for anything.
Don’t try to hide your feelings or hold back.
Just be yourself.”
Be myself?
Rynn’s words echoed in Eydis’s mind.
“You are not a monster.
You are not Princess Eydis.”
“I do not think I can be the Eydis you knew…”
I do not even know who I am anymore.
Justin’s chuckle surprised Eydis, cutting her doubtful thoughts short.
He wrapped his arm around her shoulder and pulled her closer to rest his head against hers.
“The Eydis I know, huh?
The Eydis I know gets excited about simple and seemingly pointless things, but after you escaped Jethro, any time you start to grow excited about something, you hold back and grow depressed.
It’s okay to be happy.
That excitement is you.”
Justin interlocked his fingers with hers and gripped her hand lightly.
“You tried to push Chloe, Miriam, and Sammy away in order to protect them.
That concern you have for the safety of those you care about is you.
Growing frustrated with the police enough to teleport one of them into the river is also you.
I can imagine that there were one or two times you wanted to do that to me as well.”
Justin chuckled again.
“The tapping you do with your feet when you eat something delicious is also you, a part of you I absolutely adore by the way.
Hell, even your outbursts are just as much a part of you as anything else.”
Eydis felt her face grow hot, and she lowered it in bashful embarrassment.
She had not even realized she tapped her feet when eating.
Justin lifted their entwined hands and kissed the back of Eydis’s hand.
“When your magic went awry at the range, you immediately shielded Sammy, your closest friend, faster than anyone else could have reacted.
You then rushed to Chloe to heal her.
You even expended every effort to save the life of the officer that accused you despite how much you hate the police.
You have such a large capacity for kindness, larger than anyone I have ever known.
Your heart is what defines who you are, and despite all that has happened, your heart has not changed.”
Did you not just list a bunch of things that the princess used to do and that I only do because I am her copy, Eydis thought to herself, wanting to doubt Justin’s honest praise.
“I don’t expect things to go back to how they were before Jethro’s men showed up.
We just want you to be yourself again, even if that ‘you’ is a little different after all that has happened.”
No, What if being similar to the princess is just part of who I am?
“I was in love with you before you were captured just as I am in love with you now.”
I am similar to the princess, but I am not the princess.
I am different.
A tear ran down Eydis’s cheek.
Justin loves the princess, but he also loves this different Eydis that is not the princess?
Does that mean he really does love me?
“I think I understand now…” Eydis spoke softly.
I understand why the princess loves you.
Eydis wiped away her tear and nuzzled her head against Justin’s.
“Thank you.”
She still felt uneasy, but perhaps this could work to her favor.
Maybe this was her chance to finally join with the humans of this world and pursue a better life for her and for Rynn.
Justin was kind, and perhaps, just perhaps, she could accept that kindness, even if he was human.
The room fell silent.
The minutes passed, and they let the light contact of their heads, shoulders, and interlocked hands speak all that was more to be said.
I should not keep Rynn waiting.
“Today has been tiring, so I want to sleep now.”
Justin nodded and planted a light kiss on Eydis’s cheek before standing up.
The sentiment startled Eydis, but what surprised her most was that she was not averse to it like when she had kissed him.
“If there is anything you need, remember to just ask,” Justin said.
“Actually, there is something.
Do you still have the cake?
I would like to eat it before I sleep.”
Justin laughed.
“I’ll go get it.”
Justin returned with the white box and a fork and handed them to Eydis.
He was about to leave the room but stopped.
“If anything is ever troubling you again, please talk to me.
I will listen.”
He wished Eydis goodnight and left the room.
Eydis locked the door and opened a portal back to where Rynn was waiting.
Together they shared the chocolate cake to celebrate.

Chapter 10
“Beware those who always seem happy.”
Jethro
A splintered quill scratched ink across a tattered sheet of parchment.
The written letters and sigils were so misshapen that they could only be understood by their author, but even he was having difficulty making out what he wrote.
The lines of ink blurred and faded, ebbed and flowed.
Jethro rubbed his sleep-drunk eyes, smearing even more ink on his face.
“This would be so much easier with a sigil draft…”
Using pen and paper to work out incredibly complicated spells was an act of futility.

Jethro had to commend Emer for his level of skill in spatial magic despite not only the limited magical technology of this world but also their use of lengthy strings of glyphs to express spells on paper instead of condensed sigils.
If Jethro was forced to conduct the research of his youth on paper, he would have given up the profession then and there.
Now, he had no other choice.
At least he could draw the sigils when working on his own.
Unable to bear the exhaustion any longer, Jethro sat the broken quill back in the ink well and slouch back in the unstable wooden chair.
The light from the brazier in the small room had long grown dim, only adding to the weight of sleep in his eyes.
Keeya had succumbed to slumber, and so Emer was forced as her host to sleep as well, but Jethro did not mind.
He had been working with Emer consistently for days to continue modifying his transmission magic to be used to teleport to the other world.
Earlier that evening, they had finalized the formula.
Jethro was only combing it over for errors they may have missed and simplifying it where able to reduce the ven expenditure further.
The level of difficulty of this magic was far beyond what Jethro had expected.

Given the complexity of the original trans-world teleportation trace he retrieved from Emer, he had steeled himself for the daunting task in front of him, but what he originally believe was an overestimation of the time and effort required proved to be nothing more than a minute fraction of the actual workload.
Emer’s trans-world teleportation was incredibly complicated, and Jethro’s self-developed transmission magic was no less complicated.
Fusing them together created an abomination that Jethro would have never imagined during his days as a young researcher.
But, the fruits of his efforts would pay off.
For what Jethro had planned, this transmission was crucial.
All that remained was to test it.
“Tomorrow…”
Jethro used regular teleportation to return to his room back in Tolmyur in order to not disturb the already sleeping kissiae and half-elf.
The following day, Jethro brought Emer back to the Amelian Palace.
The sight of crude human soldiers patrolling the noble elven hallways would have distressed Emer, but his emotions were overtaken by the kissiae controlling him.
Keeya’s face beamed with excitement not only from her first visit to Amel, but also being able to personally see the interior of the grand Amelian Palace.
She rushed Emer from the exquisite tapestries to the crystalline windows.
She even took time to admire the fine craftsmanship of each individual door handle.
“Can you do something about her?” Emer’s face pressed into a door so that Keeya could get a better look at the door handle over Emer’s shoulder.
“Each different?” Keeya rushed even faster from door to door to admire the uniqueness of each handle.
Emer’s face slammed into one door after another.
“This is something you will need to get used to, I guess.
You and Keeya are one and the same now.”
“She could at least learn some body awarene-fmf…” Emer’s face collided with another door.
“That will come with time, I assume.
Keeya, you are falling behind.”
Keeya leaned her head back to look at Jethro who was two doors further down the hallway.
She moved Emer to a trot to catch back up but was then immediately distracted again by an intricate cerulean vase with gold engravings between two nearby windows.
At least Emer’s face was not pressed into anything while she admired it up close.
“I’m beginning to wonder if she is myopic,” Emer grumbled.
“Doubt it,” Jethro replied.
“Eye defects are trivial to cure with life magic.
She is a type of dryad, after all.
Keeya, over here.”
Jethro stopped in front of a single large door near the end of the hall.
He opened it and was immediately greeted by a female High Elf.
“Is Fect here?
I assume his recovery is finished.”
The High Elf bowed her head.
“He is not present, my Lord.
I would assume he is training in the central courtyard.”
The High Elf bowed deeply as Jethro closed the door.
“Can we teleport to the courtyard?” Emer asked.
“And waste precious ven?
We are only going to get a few attempts at this before both of us are out.
We need to save what we can.”
Jethro only saw Emer’s dejected face for a moment before Keeya whisked him away to admire the vases set between the windows that she had ignored due to her obsession with the door handles.
“Each different too!
This birds… They are Habha?
And this flowers!”
Keeya’s face glowed with excitement, and Jethro could not help but smile at the ancient dryad’s oddly childish demeanor.

In the central courtyard a grizzled minum with stripes of white in his beard and along the sides of his head above the ears was engaged in a heated duel against a much younger minum who looked no different than a human child.
“They’re at it again.” Jethro leaned on the railing of the walkway surrounding the outer perimeter of the central courtyard to watch Fect and Captain Byurk’s duel.
None of the spectators noticed his presence, so he was able view the fight without someone calling everyone to attention.
“From the look of it, it will be over soon.”
Emer jumped up onto the railing and nearly lost his balance.
He held onto the nearby pillar and leaned out so that Keeya could get a better view above the heads of the crowd.
Keeya did not want to miss the action, and her eyes lit up when a deafening explosion rang out in the center of the courtyard.
“Fect is becoming desperate,” Jethro commentated to himself.
Fect stood panting in the corner of the square arena.
His clothes were drenched and he was splattered with mud from head to toe.
The earth beneath him shook, and in the split second it took him to dive to the side, a stone spike shot up from beneath.
Fect was barely able to right himself before the stone liquidated into mud and shot like a spear in his direction.
In desperation, Fect triggered an explosion from his hands to blow away the mud.
The explosion threatened to catch some of the spectators in the blast.
The force pushed Fect back, but he was able to roll to a crouch.
Without missing a beat, he focused his eyes on the feet of his opponent.
The ground beneath Byurk heated.
Before the pillar of fire could form, the man lifted his pointer and middle fingers, causing a short wall no higher than his waist to grow.
The ground at his feet cooled now that the line of sight broke, and the pillar of fire shot out horizontally from the side of the wall back at Fect, but Fect would not be harmed by his own flame.
Using his other hand, Byurk swiped an upward arch and then pulled his hand down as if pressing something into the ground.
An inverted geyser pinned Fect to the ground from above.
Exerting all his efforts, Fect faced both his hands the same direction and expelled a torrent of wind that pushed him out from underneath the high-pressure water.
He tumbled from the force of his own attack towards the center of the arena and landed on his back.
Before Fect could stand back up, a stone spear pointed at his neck.
“It has been decided.” Jethro hopped the railing and walked towards the group of spectators.
“Commanding General present!”
All the soldiers immediately stood at attention aside from Fect and Byurk in the center of the arena.
Jethro waved his hand.
“At ease, everyone.”
Emer followed Jethro close behind.
The dirt around the edges of the arena was in all sorts of disarray.
Only the center where Byurk stood had little to no damage.
Even without watching from the beginning, the progression of the fight was obvious.
Fect was on defense from the start, and his opponent never moved a step from the center.
“Captain Byurk, ruthless as always.”
“You flatter me, Jethro.”
“You do realize Fect was almost killed not that long ago.”
Byurk extended his hand to the winded minum.
“Boy, your father was one of the best fire mages I had the pleasure to fight beside.
Your offense is relentless just like his, but once you lose your initiative and are forced to defend, you crumble.
If you are looking for where to improve, I would begin there.”
Fect wiped the mud from his face and grabbed Byurk’s hand.
“Yes sir.”
“I have business with Fect.
Do you mind?”
Jethro could easily order Byurk, but his relationship with the minum was not one of commander and officer but of longstanding friends.
If Byurk still had business with Fect, Jethro could wait.
Mentoring Fect was also important for the future.
Byurk exchanged glances between Jethro and Emer, and his eyes widened when he saw the kissiae attached to him.
His body involuntarily shook the longer his eyes lingered on the kissiae.
She had an overwhelming aura that few seemed to notice.
“Of course not,” Byurk answered quickly.
He rotated his arms in a large circle and encased Fect in a sphere of water.
All the dirt on Fect was removed when he passed through the sphere.
Fect then closed his eyes and concentrated.
Steam erupted from his clothes, and he was dry in an instant.
“Do you need any medical attention before we leave?” Jethro asked.
Fect shook his head.
“Then we will be off.
Byurk, I know you are recovering from a major injury as well, but the sooner you can return to your pursuit of the wife in Vallen, the better.
From what I hear, Lieutenant Soppet is having some trouble with the fairy resistance in your absence.
We are losing men at a far quicker pace than when you were in command.”
“Understood.” Byurk placed his right fist over his heart and began bowing but stopped halfway.
“Sir, about the Vallen campaign…”
“What is it?”
Byurk raised his head and looked around at the many men watching his interaction with Jethro.
“It is nothing,” he said and then finished his bow.
Jethro smirked and then walked away.
He knew Byurk disliked leading the campaign, but there was no one he trusted more to accomplish such an extensive campaign with limited troops and resources.
The rapid increase in casualties on their side in Byurk’s absence was undeniable evidence that Jethro could not give the responsibility to another.
Fect stared back at Captain Byurk in disbelief as he followed Jethro out of the courtyard.
He had been overpowered by not only an elderly soldier but an injured one.
Noticing this, Jethro placed his hand on Fect’s head.
“Do not let the loss bother you.
Byurk sees too much of your father in you.
You are not a frontline fighter like him.
Your skills are better suited for covert operations.”
“That does not change the fact that if I do get into a fight, I need to be able to scrap on equal ground.”
“While that may be true, evasion and escape is always a viable option.
Where I came from, fights where you meet your opponent head on are nonexistent.
Only attack if you can get the kill.
If you fail, escape and hide until another opportunity presents itself.”
“That sounds awfully cowardly.”
Jethro patted Fect’s head and smiled.
“Ah, but it is the cowards that survive.
If a war can be won by a handful of cowards, is that not better than throwing away thousands of valiant lives?
We would not even be walking in this palace if not for our cowardly assassinations.”
“I see.
I will practice being more… cowardly.”
Jethro laughed.
“I admit, when you say it like that, it does sound rather pathetic.”
Fect sighed and shook his head.
The walk to the grand council chamber was long in no small part due to Keeya’s meandering.
Fect joined in Emer’s annoyance, asking Jethro to order her to stop wasting time.
After the fourth request, Jethro gave in and ordered Keeya to stop.
She was immediately heartbroken, so he promised that Emer would give her a full tour of the palace later.
Emer’s distraught cries were drowned out by Keeya’s gleeful laughter.
“Her cooperation is of utmost importance.
Research has progressed at breakneck pace since I began treating her better,” Jethro explained.
“But it is my neck that is breaking.” Emer’s head hung low as if his neck had indeed been broken.
At the throne in the grand council chamber, Jethro removed the stack of parchment containing the completed transmission spell.
“Am I to be the test subject?” Concern seeped from Fect.
“No.
We will need to find a suitable location for the destination, and having someone familiar with the city will expedite the process.
Once one is found, we will use those coordinates for the transmission.”
Fect exhaled his relief and stood poised to perform his task.
Jethro tore open the abyssal black portal to the other world, and Fect stepped through, but his return was quick.
“Close it!”
Jethro obeyed with haste.
“No good.
Very populated.
Many eyes were on me when I emerged.”
“Now that they are aware of us, we cannot let any see our portals.
We will be unable to use them once the city guard receives word, and the princess will know where to avoid and when to go into hiding.”
Jethro realized that Emer’s population restriction from the original escape formula was still active.
The portal would open somewhere where people were present, such as on a road, in the city, or in someone’s home.
Adding or removing randomization was as trivial as flipping a switch, but adding and removing randomization restrictions for such a complicated spell was not.

Jethro sat on the throne and worked out the restriction for limiting the population density near the randomized destination to zero while keeping the location of the destination close to the original, hopefully still within or near the city.
During this time, Emer found his way up to the balconies where Keeya admired the unique council chairs.
When Jethro finished, he called Keeya back down and opened another portal.
“This should be better.”
Fect stepped through with Jethro’s assurance.
He took his time before returning.
“I scouted the area, and it looks promising.”
This just proves how important destination restrictions are, Jethro reminded himself.
“It is a wooded area on the edge of the city.
There are some houses not too far away, but from the foliage growth and ground cover, no one travels through here.
So long as we keep the portal small, I do not believe anyone will notice when it appears, especially because most the properties are surrounded by high wood-plank fences or tall shrubs.”
“The location sounds ideal, but will sound be an issue?”
Fect grew confused.
Jethro realized that he may be unfamiliar with transmission.
To use the least amount of ven as possible, Jethro transmitted himself from the throne to just beside it.
Fect realized what he meant, the loud snap and flash of light.
“Will this be an issue at the destination?” Jethro asked again.
“The sound shouldn’t be an issue at the distance the exit is from the houses,” Fect mused, “but the flash will if used at night.
We will need to be careful when using it at night.”
“Their days are almost exactly half of ours.
It should still be early afternoon, correct?”
“From the sun, closer to late morning or midday.”
“So a little longer than half.
Odd… The original reports stated they were shorter.
Unless the days change in length throughout the year.
What would cause that?
Perhaps it is only a change in daylight.
That would be easier to explain.”
Fect and Emer stared confusedly at Jethro.
“I will keep that in mind.
It is not important for now.
Go back and await the transmission.
Return with whoever comes through.”
Fect did as ordered and stepped back into the black portal.
“Here is the destination.
You will be first to cast.”
Jethro touched the Kissiae’s hand attached to Emer’s head and sent the destination via the magic’s trace.
“Am I to send myself?”
Emer’s tone did not reject the idea outright.
“You are far too valuable.
Sending a soldier would likewise be a waste.
With Austin missing, I guess this would be the best option.
They are no longer needed.”
Emer opened a portal and reached his arm in.
“I thought you said we should not waste any unneeded ven,” Emer complained.
“With the destination set, we know the exact number of times we can cast it.
I can afford this much.”
Jethro simply enjoyed watching Keeya run Emer around the palace, but he kept that to himself.
Jethro pulled out a fairy woman from the portal.
She yelped in surprise seeing Emer’s grotesque form and almost fell backwards.
Jethro yanked her arm to force her to stand.
“Use her.”
Jethro threw the woman in front of Emer who extended his hand towards her.
Not knowing what would follow, the woman gazed up at the grotesque body with fear and pleading.
A loud snap, and she vanished.
Small pieces of flesh that had failed to travel remained on the marble floor.
Fect returned dragging a limp and bloody body through the black portal.
The fairy’s limbs were not only broken in many places, but she was also covered in lacerations, one of which cut deep into her neck.
The transmission was fatal.
“Move the body to the side.
We will clean them up later,” Jethro ordered.
Fect looked despairingly at the mutilated woman only slightly taller than him.
Just as High Elves closely resembled humans, fairies resembled minums.
Only small differences in their appearance set them apart.
The mild remorse for the perfectly wasted woman was only countered by the relief that he was not the test subject.
“What do you make of it?” Jethro asked Emer.
Emer stared at the body with remorse.
He did not expect such a gruesome end for the poor woman.
But, he had seen these types of injuries before, many times.
“The stability function did not last for the duration of the transmission.”
“I concur.
We will need to revise it a little.”
Emer and Jethro scanned through the parchment where the stability function was written.
Emer noticed something almost immediately.
“Did you make modifications?”
“I only made a few simplifications to reduce ven expenditure.
The resulting spell should be the same.”
Emer shook his head and pointed to a string of glyphs.
“This appears to have the same functionality on the outside, but the underlying workings are different.”
He then pointed to another line of glyphs further up the parchment.
“What you have written below causes distortion over distance with this passage.
If this were a normal teleportation, the distortion would be negligible, but we do not know just how far the other world is from ours.
As the subject travels, the distortion grows.
This could cause the stability to collapse.”
Jethro removed a quill and corked ink-vial from his robe.
He flipped the parchment over and worked out the stability sigils for the unmodified version and his simplified version.
The two sigils looked identical.
There was no difference.
Maybe this world’s glyphs are far more accurate than I thought.
This level of spatial magic is unknown in my world, so this minor of a distinction might have never been noticed.
“Let us return to the original.

Your knowledge of spatial magic has once again proven superior to mine.” Jethro had to remind himself that even though Emer looked half his age, Emer was four or five times older, and that meant over five times the experience he had in spatial magic.
Fect was sent back to the other world, and Jethro pulled out the next test subject.
The High Elf was frightened by Emer’s appearance just as the fairy was, but then she covered her mouth and her eyes welled with tears.
“Emer?”
“Dyas?”
Emer extended his palm towards her out of no control of his own.
The High Elf noticed the mutilated fairy on the cold marble floor beside her.
She shook her head in fear, too scared to speak.
“Jethro, please stop Keeya!” Emer tried to resist with all his will but couldn’t stop.
With a loud crack, she vanished.
“Someone you know?” Jethro asked after waiting for Emer to send her off to the other world.
Emer gritted his teeth.
His extended hand fell limp to his side.
“Dyas… She was my personal maid.
I’ve known her since she was a young girl in training.
She was in charge of my office and personal quarters and would often help me with my research in her spare time.
Her mind is brilliant.
She could have been better use to us than this.”
“You should have spoken up quicker.”
“I did, but you only stood there!
Do you take me for a fool?!
She never cared about my position or the differences in our status.
From a young age, she would always joke that one day I would take her to wife.”
Emer’s face contorted in anguish but immediately calmed.
“Thank you, Keeya.
In that state, he probably would not have been able to concentrate enough to continue.
Let us hope she survived then.”
Fect appeared from the black portal dragging a limp body behind him.
Unlike the fairy, there was no visible damage.
“This is an improvement.
Emer, check her vitals,” Jethro ordered.
Fect spoke up before Emer could.
“She’s dead.
Her heart has stopped.”
Emer ignored Fect and knelt next to the body.
He placed his hand on her forehead and then on her chest.
When he began using life magic in a desperate attempt to revive her, Jethro stopped him.
“I would rather you save your ven.”
“Please.
We do not need to do all the testing today.”
“The longer we wait, the more time the princess has to prepare as well.
You have one chance.
After that, we move on.”
Now with Jethro’s permission, Emer began his struggle to save the woman’s life.
His emotions were still repressed by Keeya, but the trembling of his hands showed his desperation.
Life magic had no effect.
Emer placed his hand on her chest and released an intense shock that caused the body to jolt.
He repeated twice more and then placed his hand on her mouth to force air into her lungs.
After two more shocks, Jethro ordered him to stop, and Fect dragged the body next to the Fairy’s.
“Wait.
Can you please ask Keeya to try?
I beg you.”
Jethro shook his head.
Emer could only stare at the floor unable to express sorrow or rage.
The corner of Jethro’s lips curled upwards.
“Sorry about your loss, but such is the nature of experimentation.
Let us look over the spell.
Stability does not appear to be the issue this time.”
Emer resisted answering.
He wanted nothing more to do with the experiment, but Keeya was the one in control.
“Stability is still the issue,” he was forced to say.
“While not visible on the outside, Dyas’s body showed signs of significant internal trauma.
I healed it, but that wasn’t enough.
The magic is still placing too much strain on the body.”
“Can you identify the cause from the formula?”
Emer scanned over the parchment and shook his head.
“I see…” Jethro created another portal and pulled out a Forrest Elf woman by her arm.
“Instead of healing this one, I want you to investigate the damage done to help us determine the cause of the trauma.”
The Forrest Elf cowered from Jethro’s ominous words.
She noticed the mutilated fairy and dead High Elf.
The strength of her legs gave out.
“Please… no… I’ll do anything.”
Jethro ignored the woman’s plea.
“How many more times can you cast it?”
“I just have enough for three more attempts.”
“Perfect.”
Emer extended his palm toward the terrified woman, and she vanished.
Fect stepped through his black portal to retrieve the body on the other side.
He returned with the woman in the same condition as the High Elf.
“Investigate thoroughly,” Jethro ordered.
Emer placed his hand on the woman’s forehead.
He remained silent for a long time, but Jethro waited patiently.
Without healing the damage like Emer had before, faint bruising slowly appeared all over the woman’s body.
Seeing this, Jethro knelt down and inspected the bruising skin of her arm.
“I don’t understand,” Emer finally spoke.
The trauma, it is as if she was hit with some incredible force evenly all over her body, yet there is no physical damage on the outside.”
“What is the damage to the inner ear and lungs?”
“Her ears are ruptured to a degree I have never seen before.
The damage is severe enough that the blood is pooling in the inner ear instead of running out.
The lungs have severe tissue damage and are flooded with blood.
Both arteries and bronchial tubes have ruptured.”
“Of course!
There is little chance anyone here would know these symptoms.
Overpressure.”
Emer looked to Jethro for an explanation.
“When you are near an explosion caused by fire magic, you feel a force pushing you back, but it is comparatively weak.
When an explosion is produced chemically, the force from those blasts can be much, much greater depending on the reaction.
When atomic, the blast is greater still.
Where I am from, we have weapons capable of not only killing with the force alone but also destroying entire cities if needed.”
Emer’s eyes grew wide.
“She died from a blast injury cause by overpressure, that wave of force.
Fect, was there any large explosion at the exit when she appeared?”
“None, just a flash of light and a little noise.
It was actually more silent than the transmission you demonstrated to me.”
“The greatest noise only happens at the origin after all.” Tired of kneeling, Jethro sat on the ground and folded his arms.
“At what point was the force felt?
When going through the regular portal, do you feel any pressure or force?”
“None, but there is a small bit of resistance, almost as if wading through mud.
It wraps around you.
I cannot describe it well.
I have never felt anything like it outside of that portal.”
“Perhaps similar to a weakened teleportation barrier?”
“I wouldn’t know.”
“Resistance… What if all that resistance was placed on the body at once and compounded due to the near instantaneous nature of transmission?
It is just a theory, but this problem may not be something we can solve through modifying the spell.”
“Then we will be ending the experiment?” Emer asked.
“Hardly.
I have an idea.” Jethro stood and created another portal.
He reached in and pulled out a Mountain Elf.
She looked at Emer, the dead bodies, and then at Jethro.
“Jethro, what is the meaning of this?” she demanded.
“Just running a few experiments, and you are the next subject.”
Fect entered his portal.
“Jil, Dyas, Wian, what did you do to them?!
Emer!
Even Dyas?
What did you do?!”
Emer’s face remained emotionless due to Keeya’s emotional repression.
He could only shake his head and offer a heartless apology.
“I am sorry, Symra.”
A stone blade grew instantly in Symra’s hand.
She swung her arm with quick and practiced motion towards Jethro’s neck.
Jethro stepped back in mild surprise.
The stone shattered against his barrier.
“If I am to die here, I will at least take you with me!”
The Mountain Elf struck her palm into Jethro’s barrier, and when her stance locked, the barrier shattered to Jethro’s surprise.
The ven in her strike disrupted the ven of his barrier, forcing recoil that numbed his arms.
Jethro extended his hand before a second stone blade could reach his throat.
The space in front of him rejected Symra, launching her back into one of the pillars of the council balcony.
It cracked on impact.
Symra fell to the marble floor but staggered back to her feet, two new blades in her hands.
She did not shred apart from Jethro’s attack as he expected.
She was not even as broken as when he used it on the princess’s doppelganger.
She was more resilient than a Lurr.
Reinforcement magic.
She was an earth mage.
Jethro’s new magic did have a weakness it seemed.
The Mountain Elf’s little rebellion proved quite educational.
Symra’s steps were slow.
She coughed up blood and fell to one knee, stabbing one of her blades into the marble floor for support.
Perhaps her internal damage was greater.
Jethro locked her in a barrier and drug her over.
“You will not kill me so easily,” she seethed.
She glared at the man who caused the deaths of the women she had suffered with through humiliation and torment to protect others from the same fate.
“The whole point of this experiment is for you to survive, so your cooperation is much appreciated,” Jethro said with a smile.
“Keeya, heal her.”
“You are allowing Keeya to heal Symra but not Dyas?”
Even though Emer showed no emotion, Jethro knew he was raving inside.
Or perhaps Emer couldn’t feel any anger.
Jethro did not fully understand how Keeya’s emotional suppression worked.
A small smile grew on Jethro’s lips.
“This is different.
How could we tell the damage the transmission caused if she is already injured?”
Emer placed his hand on various locations on Symra’s body while she struggled to break her arms and legs free from the barrier that bound her.
Keeya healed her through Emer, using his body as a conduit for her life magic.
The barrier locking Symra’s arms and legs warped and condensed tight around her entire body.
“For your sake, I hope this works,” Jethro said.
Emer extended his hand, and Symra vanished.
After a moment, Fect returned through the portal pulling Symra with his arms hooked under her rigid shoulders.
She remained frozen in the pose the barrier locked her.
Her eyes found Jethro and glared at him.
She was alive.
“Perfect!” Jethro spun in place and pumped his fist.
“Emer, check her condition.”
Emer placed his hand on her chest but could not make contact.
“The barrier.”
“Of course.”
Jethro removed the barrier, and Symra collapsed to the ground from the odd angle Fect held her.
She shoved Fect away sending him sliding across the smooth marble but then found her arms and legs restrained again before she could attack.
Emer placed his hand on her back.
“No damage.
It was a success.”
“To think that a simple barrier to protect against the force, or in this case resistance, was all that was needed.
But we must make sure it always works.
We may have just gotten lucky.
We shall continue until we are out of ven.”
The invisible force binding Symra pulled her up to stand and then encased her body.
Emer sent her back to the other world two more times to finish draining his ven.
Jethro estimated he would be able to send her fifteen times.
The black portal began to waver, so Jethro recreated it to ensure Fect’s safety.
“I guess I only have seven more attempts now.” This drastic difference in ven expenditure was the sole reason Jethro needed the new transmission formula.
Fect returned to the other world, and Symra followed by transmission.
She continued returning unharmed for the fourth and fifth attempt, building Jethro’s confidence in the safety of the formula and his remedy against the overpressure.
On the sixth attempt, Fect flew out the black rift and tumbled to a stop at Jethro’s feet.
He had a large red abrasion on his face, and his nose bled.
“That troll got away!” Fect dove back through the portal.
After a long wait, he returned emptyhanded.
“Did you find her?” Jethro asked.
“No, sir.
I couldn’t find a trace, not even footprints.
She must have jumped from tree to tree.”
“How did she attack you?” “The last time you sent her, she appeared injured.
She was not restrained in your barrier.”
Jethro patted himself lightly on the forehead.
“I was careless.
Of course the overpressure would damage the barrier and weaken it over time.
I should have renewed the barrier after each attempt.
But then, I would have lost the last attempt or so anyway.
No matter.
I would call this an astounding success.
One more elfkind over there will not cause us any trouble.
Now all that remains is a bit of information on our enemy.” Jethro removed the handgun from his belt.
“Fect, I need you to learn just how effective the weapons from that world are against our magic.
I should finish my preparations in ten days.
I expect a full report then.
I cannot risk anyone inexperienced to go to that world right now with them on high alert, so you will be on your own.
Can you manage this?”
Fect wiped the blood from his nose.
“Yes sir.”
“Also, if you encounter the doppelganger, try not to kill her.
She may still be of use to us.
Of course, your own life takes priority over hers.”
Jethro created a small portal and pulled out a bag of provisions to give Fect.
Once Fect was through the portal, Jethro closed it.
He stretched his arms behind his back and then shook them to loosen up.
They still felt numb from the troll destroying his barrier.
“I would say that went quite well, would you?”
Emer stared at the three dead bodies, and his eyes lingered on the High Elf, Dyas.
“How about that palace tour now?” Jethro announced.
Keeya’s eyes perked up, and Emer quickly ran to Jethro’s side.
“Why are you doing this…?” Emer asked with a mournful voice.
“The tour?
Did we not promise Keeya we would?”
Emer gritted his teeth in anger.
Keeya was no longer controlling his emotions, having forgotten to do so after Jethro mentioned the tour.
“What purpose do you have in continuing to target that world?
Why are you still trying to kill Princess Eydis?
You already won the war!
All the races within the Amelian Empire have surrendered themselves to you!
Can you not leave her be in that world?
She has no means to come back.”
Jethro stopped walking.
He turned back to look down at Emer’s angry face.
“For one who lives so long, your mind is too focused on the short term.
I will only live another three to four years by your world’s time, maybe less.
What happens then?
If I choose a successor, he will only live another three to four years after that.
You elves live for eighty or more years.
If I am not thorough in dousing the remaining embers of this empire, in just two or three human generations, all my work here could be undone while you are still in the prime of your life.”
Jethro placed his hand on Emer’s shoulder and burned holes into Emer’s eyes with his glare.
Keeya turned her head away, trying to distance herself from Jethro’s rebuke of Emer.
Emer shook, and Jethro could not tell whether this was due to Keeya’s fear or Emer’s.
He hoped it was both.
His next words applied equally to both of them.
“Having been in a position of power, I am sure you know the true history between the humans and the elves.
Eliminating the royal family is only the beginning of the elves’ suffering.
As for the princess, I have personal reasons to make her suffer.
The Coastal War is one, but the other…”
The fury in Jethro’s eyes grew until Emer feared he would run him through that instant.
Jethro’s anger was far greater talking about the princess than when he mentioned the elves’ betrayal of the humans in ancient past.
Jethro flashed a smile and walked out of the grand council chamber.
Neither Keeya nor Emer could move.
“Come, Keeya.
Let us begin our tour,” Jethro called.
Keeya hurried Emer to catch up but kept a full five paces behind him, at least until something caught her attention and sent Emer running around again.

Chapter 11
Eydis
“A Moment of Clarity”
This is bad…
Eydis knelt next to the unconscious elf in the floor of the cellar.
The body was dangerously warm and would not cool no matter what life magic Eydis tried.
In Eydis’s anger, she had abused the already weak elf and even threw her head into the solid pavement floor.
The princess’s skull fractured, and there was internal bleeding in both her stomach and head.
When Eydis discovered the princess’s condition the morning after her violent tirade, she addressed it to the best of her ability and continued tending to the princess over the past week.
The damage healed, but the body did not recover.
It reacted adversely and broke out into a terrible fever.
The princess’s body was not replenishing its blood supply at an adequate rate.
Her breath was weak, and her heart rate was weaker.

Her body began converting all its ven to the life element in order to keep itself alive, but her ven recovery was already slow from her feeble condition, and she was not recovering enough to support her body’s self-preservation.
She could not rise above critical ven levels.
The princess was dying.
What am I supposed to do?
I am not complete yet.
If I knew how to transfer my own ven into her, that could help, but…
Eydis was about to place her hand on the body to try and give it ven, but hesitated.
If I touch her, I will only take more ven from her.
Every attempt to supply the princess with ven had failed, leaving the princess with less ven than before.
“Is she beyond help?” Rynn crouched next to Eydis.
The skin on the tip of her other horn was now peeling like the first.
The rag around her forehead at the base of her horns was already stained brown from the dried blood that had dripped onto it throughout the morning.
Eydis could not answer.
She did not know.
“I will watch her,” Rynn said.
“You must go.
They are waiting for you.”
Justin had informed Eydis that the FBI understood the events of the last combat magic lesson and gave permission for its continuation.
Today was the day of that lesson.
“I have no choice but to leave her to you.
I cannot even touch her.”
“I will try and keep her cool,” Rynn promised.
Eydis opened a portal and returned to the small bathroom of Justin’s apartment.
After a brief apology for the long wait, she, Justin, and Sean left for the police station.
Sammy, Chloe, and Miriam met them there.
Major Wickenny greeted everyone beside Agent Botteger and two police who were not present at the last lesson.
One of them was Officer Hellings, appearing less smug than Eydis remembered.
Perhaps her irritation from her mistaken confinement soured her initial impressions of the policewoman.
What surprised everyone but Justin and Eydis was the presence of three more people who were not police or FBI.
Eydis had talked to them over the phone, but this was their first meeting.
She had seen other humans like him in the city, but she was surprised by just how dark the man’s skin was.
Human breeds in Whinhlem were distinguishable by their stature and build, but human breeds on Earth seemed to differentiate by hair and skin color.
Agent Botteger introduced the new additions.
“This is Colonel Richards, Post Commander of Fort Samper.
The Army will be accompanying us with Eydis’s permission.”
“I’m surprised you agreed to do another one of these,” Sammy said, “but you are even letting the military watch?”
Eydis smiled and placed her hand on Sammy’s shoulder with a light pat.
“I want you to be as prepared as possible in case you run into Jethro’s men.
This was part of the agreement to let us continue using the range.”
“As long as you are up to it.”
“We can stop at any time if you no longer feel confident,” Major Wickenny assured, and Agent Botteger agreed.
“A mistake like before will not happen again.”
Eydis’s confidence raised the morale of everyone present.
She had to reserve her ven with the princess in such a state, so large-scale spells were prohibited.
So long as she did not use too much ven, she could stay in contact with Justin to recover what she used.
Justin’s regeneration rate was astounding, so she relied heavily on him to replenish her supply, unknown to him.
Thankfully he never seemed to notice the syphoning of his ven.
The setup for the training took longer than before.
Large glass screens were placed out for the spectators, and those involved with the actual training were required to wear thick black vests, helmets, and eye protection.
Eydis eyed them with suspicion.
“Is that glass strong enough to protect them if something goes wrong?”
Justin shrugged.
“It stops bullets similar to your barrier before, so it should help.”
“What about those vests?”
“My guess is that these are Kevlar.
They stop bullets as well, so they should provide some protection.”
One of the police handed Eydis a vest and helmet.
She inspected the vest but thought that it would be weaker than armor because she could not feel any metal.
Agent Botteger then handed Eydis the strange eye protection.
“Part of what we planned for today is testing just how protective these are against magic,” he explained.
“And that will be my job while the others practice?”
“If you would.”
This may be difficult depending on how much they want me to test, but they did say that I can stop when I feel like it.
“Gladly.”
Justin, Sammy, Miriam, and Chloe stood in line at the edge of the range.
This time, Sean stood with the spectators behind the glass screens.
The appearance of everyone in their protective gear gave the feel of actual military training, although Eydis had never witnessed any personally.
