Eydis cleared her throat, took a breath, and then bowed her head.
“I must apologize.”
Only the cold wind could be heard across the range.
Eydis slowly lifted her head, hoping everyone would react reasonably to what she was about to say.
“I cannot teach you how to fight using your elements.”
Whispers grew from among the spectators, but Justin and the others remained silent.
“I cannot teach you because I cannot use those elements.
I have never trained with them in combat.
I have only fought against them.
What I can do is give you direction as you discover how to fight using your own individual elements.”
A smile grew across Justin’s face.
He had given her some advice after their conversation a week ago.
“If you don’t know how to do something, just say so.
We will respect that.”
Eydis smiled back at Justin.
He must have suspected that I would not be able to teach them.
But, that does not mean I have nothing to offer.
“First, I want you to tell me everything you can do with your element, even if I already know it.
I suspect you all have been practicing on your own.
I will be better able to direct you after that.
“Justin first.”
Justin shook his head, but his smile never faded.
“Still useless.
I’ve been meditating to feel my ven, but all I can do is slow time by reflex.”
“Sammy?”
Sammy flashed a guilty smile.
“You already know I’ve been practicing while swimming, but other than that, I can produce more water than before.”
Sammy held both hands in front of her like she was holding a small ball.
As she spread her hands apart, a sphere of water grew between her hands until it became about the size of her head.
Once it grew bigger than that, it lost its form and fell to the ground.
Sammy jumped back so that her clothes would not get wet from the splash.
Whispers grew from the military--their first witness of magic.
“Miriam?”
“I have been practicing trying to change the shape of the rocks I can produce, but it’s not easy.”
Miriam held out her hand.
A misshapen cube grew from small granules.
She then tossed the cube out into the range.
It flew over the length of the range, hit the embankment on the far side, and imbedded itself into the dirt.
Justin, Sammy, and Chloe stared at Miriam in amazement.
It was a throw much stronger than what should have been possible for any human.
“I also found out that if I concentrate ven on one side of it like you taught me on my hand, I can make the ven shoot out and launch the rock.”
“Incredible.
You discovered that on your own?
That is the same principle behind throwing the wind spear you saw before.”
“Oh, and I can coat earth ven over my entire body now, and I’ve been working on making it stronger because that wind attack that hit me still hurt like a bitch.”
“Miriam! We promised not to talk about that!”
Miriam waved her hands apologetically at Chloe.
“It is fine,” Eydis said, unperturbed.
“It was my mistake after all.
Now, what about you, Chloe?”
Chloe grew silent.
She fidgeted in embarrassment.
After seeing Miriam’s improvement, Eydis understood being nervous.
“You do not have to worry if you have not been practicing on your own.
Fire is dangerous.”
Chloe shook her head.
After a deep breath, she removed her protective gear, coat, and pulled off her shirt.
All she wore on her upper body was a tight black sleeveless top that exposed her stomach and some of her cleavage.
Eydis guessed that its purpose was to contain her large breasts to prevent them from moving too much when active.
“Chloe?
What are you doing?” Even Sammy grew concerned.
Chloe walked away from the group and passed Eydis.
Once she was twice the distance from Eydis as Eydis was from the others, she turned her side to everyone and took what looked like a melee combat stance with elbows locked in and fists raised.
All at once, her arms from her hands up to just past her elbows grew flames.
Eydis immediately recalled the fire mage she fought the night she captured the princess.
It cannot be.
There is no way an amateur could sustain hand-to-hand combat while controlling her fire.
Chloe shot a quick blade-handed jab with her left followed by a straight punch with her right.
When her right hand fully extended, the fire shot out in a line about two times the length of her arm.
She was not controlling the flame.
The cycle of jabs and punches continued.
Some of the jabs started creating minor bursts of fire, and the distance the fire flew from the punches grew as Chloe moved.
When she turned and swung her elbow, the fire grew in a large arc out to her side.
The fire on her arms grew larger and larger, and Eydis grew worried.
If she did not stop, Eydis feared her fire would grow out of control.
Eydis was about to create a barrier to cut off the air to Chloe’s arms to starve the flames, but Chloe planted her feet firmly on the ground with her right foot forward.
She swung both her hands wide and brought them together in a clap.
The growing fire on her arms concentrated at the tips of her fingers and generated an explosion that blasted outward.
It shook the ground and blew away the rock and dirt in front of her.
It had incredible power.
Eydis was dumbstruck.
Her mind could not even process what she saw enough to think of a response.
Everyone who witnessed it was equally stunned silent.
Chloe walked back to her shirt and coat but did not place them on.
Her body radiated visible heat, distorting the air around her.
She was sweating profusely and looked terribly exhausted.
Only once she finally sat on the cold ground could Eydis work out something to say.
“Are you really an amateur?”
“Chloe!” Sammy ran over to Chloe but could not get too close.
“She’s way too hot!
Here, some water.”
Sammy produced water and tried to hold it close.
“Drop it on me,” Chloe ordered.
Sammy held the head-sized sphere of water higher and dropped it on top of Chloe.
Steam erupted in all directions, clouding the air.
After a few more spheres of water, the steam stopped, and Chloe cooled down.
The cold air now chilled her, so she pulled back on her coat despite being wet.
“What was that?” Eydis called.
“When did you find the time to practice it?
WHERE did you practice it?” She walked up to the group, still stunned by Chloe’s performance.
Chloe leaned her head back and shook it lightly.
“I didn’t practice it.
Well… not physically.”
“What do you mean,” Eydis asked after reaching Chloe.
How can one do that without practice?
She even knew when her own fire was growing too large and how to expel it.
“Who are you?”
Chloe chuckled.
“A while ago I was watching anime and saw something called image training where you practice things in your mind that you cannot practice otherwise.
You taught me how to fight, and I learned to coat myself with fire from how you taught Miriam how to coat her body with earth ven.
I just practiced putting them together in my head.
This was the first time I actually used it, though.”
Is this girl some magic genius?
How is that even possible?
“How did you know your fire was growing too big and how to disperse that built up energy?”
“I kind of just felt it?
My body was getting too hot, and even though I was controlling the fire away from my clothes, I was afraid they would catch fire.
I got the idea to focus all the ven to the tips of my fingers and then expel it like Miriam’s explanation on how she threw the rock that far.
You were ready to step in in case it didn’t work, so, well… I thought I might as well try.”
This girl was not only gifted with magic, but she also had the combat sense to be aware of her surroundings enough to realize that Eydis was about to intervene.
And in all that, she was concentrating enough to keep the heat off her clothes.
Chloe’s final attack was powerful enough to compete with the princess magically.
A tinge of panic struck Eydis’s back as if someone shot her from behind.
The police were afraid when she used powerful magic, and now a human of their world used magic even stronger than her.
Eydis looked behind her to the glass screens.
By agreement, the spectators were not to leave from behind their cover until Eydis gave them permission.
Colonel Richards looked directly at Eydis and motioned with his hand for Eydis to go to them.
“Chloe, head over to the military.
I will follow shortly.”
The chatter between Chloe and the others ceased.
She nodded and walked over.
Worry grew on everyone’s faces.
“I will not let them do anything to her.
But for now…”
What should I have them do?
“Miriam, create a stone.”
Miriam complied.
Eydis grabbed it and squeezed.
The pressure she applied was excessive, and the rock broke into powder.
The ease of how it broke startled Miriam.
“Too weak.
For now, focus on making the stone harder.
They will be useless if they break so easily.
Sammy.” Eydis did not even know how Sammy could fight if she could not conjure ice.
“You need to find a way to use your water to attack; something that fits you.
I cannot give you much direction until you figure that out.”
Last was Justin.
He had a rare affinity but was unskilled with it.
How was he spending his time in all the training sessions before?
Not coming to any answer, Eydis shook her head.
“Just do what you usually do.”
Justin grew a smile.
“Figured as much.”
Was that normal?
Was the princess also at a loss with him?
“Looks like we’re back to normal lessons.”
Sammy laughed, and Justin and Miriam joined in.
Relieved that they accepted her instructions, Eydis hurried over to where the military was talking with Chloe.
“…Interesting.
And how long have you been training your fire magic?” Colonel Richards was already questioning Chloe, but his tone was not antagonistic.
He almost sounded excited albeit suppressed to maintain the appearance of a ranking military officer.
Or so Eydis assumed.
“Only a few months.”
“And have the others had the same amount of practice?” Chloe nodded.
Eydis placed her hand on Chloe’s shoulder.
She was still rather hot to the touch.
“Her rate of growth is not normal.
I was surprised by what Miriam accomplished and would even consider her growth exceptional.”
Perhaps the princess is a far better instructor than I realized.
Either that or these women have inborn talent.
Sammy’s level of growth seems normal, though.
And rare elements are very difficult to grasp without a proper instructor, so Justin’s lack of ability could be explained.
Colonel Richards spoke Eydis’s name to break her out of her internal dialogue.
“As you are aware, we will help track down and combat the terrorists that are targeting you.
After what I have seen, there is another service we can provide.
I do not intend to monitor or restrict Chloe’s actions, and there is no training or licensing for use of magic.
I would like to volunteer our time to train your students, especially Chloe, in combat safety.
Would it be permissible for me to take time at the end of your lessons to instruct them?”
He did not want unintended casualties, and Chloe’s lack of restraint over her fire still worried Eydis.
“You may have as much time as needed.”
“Much appreciated.”
“No. Thank you for being reasonable.
I do not want Chloe to be a danger to others.”
“I’ll do my best to be careful…”
Chloe had at some point in the conversation removed a bar from her coat pocket and was snacking on it.
When she finished with it, she pocketed the wrapper and removed another.
“Chloe, for your practice, I want you to try and increase and decrease the intensity of the fire on your arms.
Keep the heat low.
Learn how to keep it under control so that you do not have to expel it all at once.”
“Okay.” Chloe pushed the rest of the bar into her mouth and trotted over to where the others were practicing.
“Make sure to keep your distance from them!”
“Okay!”
“This is going much better than last time,” Major Wickenny stated while watching the group practice in the distance.
“I was not in my right mind then.
With all that has happened, my thoughts were elsewhere worrying about everything.
Justin gave me a stern lecture, and we argued a bit, but he helped me realize many things.”
“That is the benefit of having a good partner.”
Eydis’s face grew warm, and she involuntarily smiled.
“Miss FeAmel, now that your students are practicing, do you mind helping us,” Agent Botteger asked.
“Of course not.
They should be fine without supervision, and I can teleport to them in an emergency.
This is the least I can do after declining your request to increase the number of students I am teaching.
As I am right now, I am incapable of teaching your soldiers.”
Eydis hopped in the truck with Agent Botteger, Colonel Richards, Officer Hellings, and one of the military personnel.
Sean stayed with the remaining police and military to observe his friends’ magic practice.
At the far side of the range, they set up various targets from the glass pane to three vests similar to the one she was wearing but more armored with a tan pattern.
There was even a tall black shield with what looked like a thin window near the top.
A selection of odd weapons was laid out on a table beside the truck.
They were similar in form to the small hand-held weapon that major Wickenny showed her in the last lesson and that was fired at her.
“From what I hear, you can use three types of magic?” Colonel Richards asked.
“Yes, but life magic cannot be demonstrated on targets like these.
I would need a live target you would not mind killing in order to demonstrate it for you.
If you have a prisoner or criminal you can bring, multiple would be best, then I can demonstrate it at that time.”
Agent Botteger and Colonel Richards looked at each other unsure of how to respond.
Did I say something odd?
Agent Botteger rubbed his eyebrows with his thumb and forefinger.
“I’m sorry, but in this country, such forms of execution are not allowed.”
Eydis thought the military at least would relish the opportunity.
Perhaps they were not at war and had no war prisoners or criminals to execute.
“Then we must settle with wind and spatial magic.”
The military set up the vests first.
Eydis channeled wind into her hand and swiped her arm through the air at each vest.
A thin blade shot out and impacted the vests.
The fabric tore, but it did not cut through.
Eydis increased the power, but the attack still did not break them.
For her last attack, she created a spear and added a little more force to the propulsion to make up for its small size.
The spear penetrated the first vest easily.
The second was penetrated as well but not deep.
The spear lost all its power and dispersed.
On the last, the impact was even weaker than the blade even though Eydis was sure it would pierce it as well.
The spear did nothing to it but damage the fabric.
“What is that middle vest?”
“That is our standard IOTV,” Colonel Richards replied.
“IOTV?
What about the last?
It’s stronger than metal.”
“It’s a rejected concept called Dragon Skin.
It couldn’t stand up to combat tests despite its outward strength.
I still had one on hand at Fort Samper and decided on whim to bring it.”
They have dragons in this world too?
“That is surprising,” Eydis said.
“Indeed.
We may need to consider further development for use against magic.”
Eydis was frustrated that she could not break it.
If it was dragon scales, it would be resistant to elemental magic, so she changed to spatial.
With a quick swipe of her hand, a thin planar projectile flew at the armor and split all three simultaneously.
Against Jethro’s magic, the armor might as well have not been there.
The police and military stared at the split vests in astonishment.
“Did you see what hit it?”
“No, you?”
“Not at all.”
“Did anyone?”
They all shook their heads.
Eydis continued testing both wind and spatial magic on the other targets.
The glass cracked with the wind blade, and the spear penetrated it but lost all its power, like the IOTV.
The shield withstood both types of wind attacks.
However, the spatial magic cut through both as easily as it had the armor.
The faces of the police and military personnel were grim.
Colonel Richard approached Eydis.
“What magic did you use just then?”
“That was spatial magic,” she replied.
“Can anyone able to use spatial magic do this?”
“Spatial magic is rare, and only one other person I know can use spatial magic this strong, and that is the man searching for me.
I doubt he will show himself, but if he does, I do not believe anyone can fight him.”
“Even you?
You defeated all those men who attacked you from what I heard.”
Eydis recalled the one time she tried to attack Jethro.
He did not even use this attack.
She was not sure what he did, but she was blown back through a wall terribly injured and unable to move.
“I would not be hiding from him if I could kill him.
I do not believe anyone could rival him.
Your only choice would be to flee, but even that might not be possible because he can teleport as I can.”
Eydis’s words were a terrible revelation, but Colonel Richards nodded in understanding, as grim as his expression may have been.
“Do you have a description of the man,” Agent Botteger asked.
When asked during her questioning at the police station whether she could describe her captors, she never even thought of giving them Jethro’s description.
She did not know if he would become involved personally, but Jethro was the single person the city needed to be wary of most.
If his face was sent out to the public, then they would know if he ever showed.
“He is shorter than me and of a thin body.” Eydis held her hand at the level of her nose to show them his height.
“He is middle-aged but has black hair with no grey and is trimmed short but always looks unkempt.
His eyes are a strong green.
His voice is not that deep, but it is also not that high.
He always appears unfocused, but he had enough skill to conquer my city in a single day.”
“Anything specific about his face?”
“It is also thin.
His nose is short.
His eyebrows are thin but straight.
His lips are thin too.
Altogether, he is not very masculine and does not appear strong, but that deception might be one of his strengths.”
“Thank you for that important piece of information,” Major Wickenny said.
We will make sure this description is sent out.
If you have time later, we could have you help create a facial composite at the station.”
“What is that?”
“It is like a drawing of someone’s face, but we will do it on a computer with your input to make it as accurate as possible.”
“I can help after we are finished with today’s lesson.”
Eydis arranged with Officer Hellings to remain at the station after the lessons.
The Army moved on to testing their weaponry.
Eydis already experienced the small handheld weapon of the police, but the others were much larger.
“How should I test these?”
“I heard you could create barriers.
We would like to test these weapons to see if they are effective,” Colonel Richards explained.
“Can you create a barrier away from you?”
“That is not difficult, but the last time I was attack with such a weapon, it bounced off and almost hit the man who attacked me.” Officer Hellings offered a suggestion.
“Can you angle it so that the ricochet hits the ground?
The penetrating force will be weaker, but it will drastically reduce the danger.
Can you regulate the strength of your barrier?”
“Of course.”
“Then angle the barrier forty-five degrees, and decrease the strength by… I think about thirty percent.
That should make the penetrating force about the same as if it hit directly.”
Forty-five degrees?
Thirty percent?
Seeing Eydis’s confusion, Officer Hellings removed a notepad and pen from her pocket and drew out a simple diagram.
Eydis understood with a little more explanation.
“Can you do this?” she asked again.
“Easily.”
Everyone donned ear protection.
Eydis set her barrier across the range as far as she was able on the opposite side of where the others still practiced.
One of the military personnel fired the smallest of the weapons no larger than what the police carried.
Its make was different, so Eydis guessed there was some difference between the two.
This was an Army weapon, not a city guard weapon, or so she assumed.
It might have been more powerful, but as Eydis expected, the projectile bounced off her barrier and embedded itself directly below into the dirt.
She did not feel much recoil.
The weapons gradually increased in size and power.
Eydis had to create new barriers as the former waned from abuse.
She found these bizarre weapons fascinating.
Unlike bows that required exceptional skill to perfect the archery, these far more powerful firearms appeared usable by anyone.
The projectiles flew straight and fast.
An amateur only needed to point it at a target to hit it.
The next weapon broke the barrier on the first shot, but the bullet still ricocheted into the ground.
The following weapon did the same.
The final was so long that the man firing had to lie down.
Just watching the man ready his aim made Eydis anxious.
The projectile demolished the barrier and continued onward.
The penetrating power was so forceful the ven recoil not only numbed Eydis’s arms but also her shoulders and back.
Eydis walked over to the man who shot the last weapon while rubbing her arms.
“What was that?”
He did not hear her, so he removed his ear protection, and Eydis repeated her question.
“That last round was a black tip fifty-cal.
Armor penetration.
Looks like a seven-six-two or above is effective.”
“Let me try that fifty…cal?
That last one again.” Eydis donned her ear protection and created another barrier.
This was about pride.
She increased the barrier as strong as she could.
The draw on her ven was drastic enough to be felt physically.
Eydis nodded to say she was ready.
The man took aim and fired.
The impact caused Eydis’s whole body to lock up from the recoil, almost dropping her, but the barrier held solid.
She immediately dispersed the barrier and hobbled over, her joints popping when they first moved.
“That was the strongest barrier I could make.”
“I’m surprised it held,” the soldier who attacked the barrier replied.
He clearly had confidence in his weaponry and was disappointed that it was ineffective.
“Can we assume that no one else could create a barrier like that,” Colonel Richards asked.
“Using a barrier that strong would be foolish in a fight unless you knew an attack that powerful was coming.
It used far too much ven.”
Nothing remained to test.
They gathered up their weapons and broken targets into the truck.
On their way back to the other side of the field, Colonel Richards discussed the possibility of taking Eydis to a location they could test explosives against her barriers.
He also considered having Chloe join to test her power against their protective gear since she was the only one of Eydis’s students whose power was combat ready.
Justin and the others had exhausted themselves from practice and were idly chatting when Eydis returned.
“How did it go?” she asked the group.
“As usual, nothing on my end,” Justin sighed.
“I tried a bunch of things, but I don’t think I can do much until I can generate more water,” Sammy said, feigning disappointment, “so I’ve been practicing that.
Chloe made a good target.” Sammy giggled at Chloe who was drenched.
Steam rose from her body as her residual heat dried her.
“I still can’t control it that well,” Chloe confessed.
“Once I heat up too much, my fire would not go down.
I needed Sammy to put me out over and over again.”
Miriam tossed a rock to Eydis.
It was almost spherical in shape and a slightly different tone than her usual stones, more grey than tan.
“Try breaking that one,” she challenged.
Eydis gripped it.
She found her arms tired from the ven recoil, but the stone still crumbled in her hand.
It was not reduced to powder, so this was certainly an improvement.
“Still not good enough.”
“You are really strong.
I tried to break it but couldn’t even crack it.”
“I am using more than arm strength to break it,” Eydis lied to hide her Lurr strength.
“I do not expect you all to make major progress immediately.
Keep trying and you will succeed.”
“Can I make a request?” Miriam asked.
“Request?”
“Next lesson, if you are testing firearms again, can I join?
I saw one I haven’t fired before.
I really want to.” A light glistened in Miriam’s eyes.
To Eydis, Miriam never appeared a weapons enthusiast.
Was she not a witch, one of this world’s ancient magic users?
“I am fine with it, but you need Colonel Richards’ permission.”
“Sweet!
Are we done then?”
“Colonel Richards wants to teach you all combat safety, so he will speak to you before we leave.
He will do the same after every lesson from here on.”
Eydis invited Colonel Richards over.
The police and military personnel joined as well as Sean who sat down next to Miriam.
Once the hour-long lecture finished, the lesson came to an end, and everyone returned to the police station.
Justin grabbed Eydis’s hand and pulled her over to the other truck where Chloe, Sean, and Miriam were standing.
Sammy followed close behind.
“We talked about it while you were still with the Colonel, but we were wondering if you wanted to hit the diner on the way back.
My treat.”
Eydis immediately recalled that was where Justin bought the cake.
“Yes!
I would love to!
But, I promised to help the police with something first.
I do not know how long it will take.”
And I still have to help Rynn with the princess…
“Then how about tomorrow evening?
We want to thank you for today.”
A wide smile grew on Eydis’s face.
Her heart quickened with excitement.
“Tomorrow then!”
Sammy and Chloe clapped hands together and Miriam gave Eydis a thumbs-up.
Sean also looked pleased and said he would join them.
Justin lingered behind after the goodbyes and the others headed towards their cars.
“Seriously, thank you for today.
I know you did not want to do the lesson before, but this is really going to help everyone.”
Eydis smiled and shook her head, almost bashful.
“No.
I did it this time because I wanted to.
You are the one who taught me what is important and to be true to who I am.”
“You give me too much credit, but thanks.
Do you want me to stay until you finish?”
“No. I will be fine.
I can teleport back to the apartment when I am done.”
“Okay.”
Justin motioned Eydis to lean down.
When her face was level with his, he rested his fingers under her chin and placed his lips against hers.
Eydis did not recoil but almost returned the kiss, much to her surprise.
“I’ll see you at home.”
Justin jogged off to catch up to the group.
Sammy grinned mischievously.
“What was that?
Justin!
Spill it!
When did this happen?!”
Sammy’s interrogation continued as the group walked away, but Justin never replied.
Eydis could only chuckle to herself.
Miriam and Chloe were not Justin’s women as she had supposed, but Sammy certainly was.
Sammy would demand answers, but Eydis didn’t worry.
They were friends, and so she did not doubt that Sammy would be willing to share Justin.
Share Justin?
Without even noticing, Eydis’s apprehensions about accepting Justin as her lover had vanished.
How could that have happened?
This realization scared her.
He was a human, same as Jethro and his men, but the more her thoughts lingered on him, the greater the warmth in her chest grew.
Justin accepted her, and while he was still oblivious to the fact that she was not the princess, he still cared for her and never minded the differences.
Eydis touched the lingering feeling on her lips and found them fixed into a smile.

Instead of feeling like Justin was her key to acceptance and a life with the humans of this world, she now felt she could be honest with her feelings, that she was actually excited about being with Justin, the first man who had shown her true kindness.
Her feet felt light as she pranced over to the station.

* * *
The facial composite took longer than Eydis anticipated.
Multiple faces were provided on a computer screen according to Eydis’s description, and those faces could be combined and modified as needed to mimic Jethro’s actual face.

A female officer trained in making these composites worked the machine for Eydis, but even then, Eydis had trouble knowing exactly what type of information she needed to give, especially when all the faces initially looked nothing like Jethro.
Eventually Eydis was satisfied with the appearance.
The specialist thanked her, and Eydis headed out of the station.
Major Wickenny waved her down by the exit.
“I know that your relationship with the police has not been the best.
We cannot fully comprehend your situation or what you have been through, and we have only added to your troubles.
I just want to say personally and on behalf of all of us that we are extremely grateful for all the help you have provided so far.”
Eydis stared at Major Wickenny, unable to find the words to respond to his honest, truthful gratitude.
She was sure that they still thought of her as a threat and would prefer she leave the city, but now he was thanking her.
If she had not rebelled against Jethro, none of the police or civilians at the hospital would have died.
She was the one prolonging this war.
“If there is anything you need from us, please feel free to ask.
As for your compensation for the information on the terrorist and magic, we can pay you or provide other forms of repayment if desired.”
“I… I have no use for money.
So long as Justin and Sammy and everyone are safe, that is all I care about.
So…”
First Justin and now the police?
Have I done anything worthy of gratitude?
The smile returned to Eydis’s face.
It came with a peaceful warmth in her chest that was not unlike what she felt when she thought of Justin after their kiss outside the station.
This new feeling confused her, and she could not find an emotion to describe it.
It felt good.
“Your thanks are payment enough,” she said.
“If you ever change your mind, please tell us.
I look forward to next week’s lesson.”
Eydis left the police department in high spirits.
She walked around to the side of the station and stood behind a pillar where no one would see her.
The smile on her face never faded.
“I actually did well today.”
Justin and Sammy, even Major Wickenny, they all looked so happy.
Eydis placed her hand on her chest as if to feel the pulsating warmth that radiated within and lightly stamped her feet in excitement.
It felt really good.
After confirming that no one was near, she transmitted back to the cellar of Rynn’s house.
Rynn was kneeling beside the princess to wipe off the fever sweat.
Multiple blankets had been brought from the bedroom and set aside, and some form of mat was placed beneath the princess to insulate her from the cold floor.
Rynn finished wiping the sweat and acknowledged Eydis before heading upstairs with the sweat-soiled towel.
The princess lay bare before Eydis.
The large bruises on the princess’s stomach and face that still had not faded were glaring evidence of Eydis’s anger-filled abuse.
The princess’s sunken face.
Her deathly pallor.
The scars on her neck and shoulder.
The many injuries.
The chains.
For the first time, Eydis saw the princess not with contempt and loathing, but with pity.
Eydis’s breath grew short.
The warmth in her chest became a cold knife that cut a deep wound which threatened to suck her heart inward.
She sat on the floor and placed her hand over her chest to hold the wound together.
Once more she looked upon the princess.
Once more the form she saw was one of misery and sadness and deserving of help and compassion.
Eydis vigorously shook her head.
She does not deserve pity!
She created me as a tool to sacrifice in her place!
The pangs of the wound in her chest answered.
But she gave you life, and without her, you would not be.
She abandoned her people.
She was living happily while everyone suffered, especially Rynn!
But she was sent here against her will before the fall of the empire.
She had no way to know and no way to return.
She hurt Rynn!
Rynn could have died when she attacked me!
But you were her target.
You attacked her first, captured her, and threatened to harm Justin.
She never accepted Justin.
He is willing to do anything, give anything, just to make her happy.
But she is a royal, purebred High Elf and princess of the Amelian Empire which is at war with the humans.
What if she wanted to accept his love but knew she could not?
Eydis leaned forward until her forehead rested on the cold cement floor.
Her hands balled into fists, and she slammed them down.
The cement fractured out like a spider’s web.
No!
She does not deserve pity!
I HATE HER!
The wound in Eydis’s heart sucked in her anger, and for a moment her mind had clarity.
She raised her head to look at the pitiful frame that was barely breathing and even now was fighting a losing battle to live.
Eydis blinked once, then twice.
“Why do I hate her?”
The wound in her heart festered and oozed out fear, fear of what she had done, fear of what she was.
Jethro’s painful lesson rang louder in Eydis’s mind than it had ever before.
Doppelgangers were a unique form of Lurr created from feeding solely on one individual.
While looking identical to and exhibiting heightened traits of the original, they also held natural animosity towards them.
If given the chance, a doppelganger will kill and replace the original.
Eydis’s body shook.
Her eyes grew wide and trembled.
Why did I not see it before?
“I am no different than that Alukah.
I am no different than that giant.
I am a monster.”
“You are not a monster!”
Eydis’s eyes fell upon the base of the staircase.
Rynn stood there holding a pitcher of water.

For the first time, Eydis saw anger in Rynn’s eyes, but where she should have been surprise, the festering wound in Eydis’s heart ruptured and bled out the anger it had sucked in, anger now directed selfward.
“I am a monster!
Everything Jethro said about me is true!
I thought I was fighting him, but I am doing everything he said I would!
Everything he said a doppelganger would…”
Eydis gritted her teeth hard enough for one of her back molars to crack.
“I AM a monster!”
A loud slap echoed in the small room.
Eydis’s eyes grew wide, and she felt a light sting on her cheek.
Rynn’s open palm was extended, and tears ran down from her anger-filled eyes.
“Stop.
If you keep calling yourself a monster, you will become one.”
“But, I only hate Eydis… I only did all this to her because I am a doppelganger.”
Rynn knelt in front of Eydis.
Her bleeding horns and large scar set between an anger-filled stare gave Rynn an overpowering presence.
Eydis’s anger dried up leaving shame, and she could no longer look into Rynn’s eyes.
Her voice only came out in a whisper.
“We had the chance to run when we came to this world.
I could have taken you away from all this.
But because I am a doppelganger, I decided to stay and capture Eydis.
I wanted to become Eydis, and you got hurt because of that.”
Rynn shook her head.
“I got hurt because I chose to save you, not because you wanted to capture the princess.
It was my choice.”
“But, Eydis is only in this world because she has no way to return.
Jethro killed her family.
I knew that, but I still captured her, took her friends, took the man she loves.”
A horrifying idea crept into Eydis’s mind.
“What if, what if my feelings for Justin are only because I feed on her?
I even stole her love and emotions.
I took what little she had left because I am a doppelganger.”
Tears welled up in Eydis’s eyes.
“I would not even be if she had not created me, and now she is dying because of me.”
The welling tears fell, and Eydis clutched her aching chest.
“It hurts.
All this time, I have caused so much pain.
Eydis did not deserve any of it.”
Rynn’s expression softened, and she looked at Eydis like a loving parent who just finished scolding her child.
She grasped Eydis’s hand and placed it on Eydis’s heart.
“No monster would feel this pain.
You have proven to yourself that you are not a monster.
A monster would not feel remorse.”
Rynn pulled Eydis into a gentle embrace and held her in silence until her tears dried.
“I promised to take care of you, but you are always the one taking care of me,” Eydis spoke with a weak voice.
“Thank you.”
Warmth returned to Eydis’s chest, but it did not replace the guilt.
The wound in her heart still hurt in direct contrast to that wonderful feeling she felt before, but it no longer festered, and it no longer bled.
It was healing, and Eydis knew that the healing would take time and only if she helped it heal.
I must right this wrong.
“Rynn, we will leave this city.”
Rynn pulled herself off Eydis and looked at her with endearment.
“When?”
“Justin and Sammy have been so kind to me.
I have lied to them all this time.
I am not the Eydis they love.
I do not want to hurt them, so they must never know.”
Rynn looked over at the dying princess.
“Yes.
We will do everything we can to save her.
Once she regains consciousness, I will apologize and explain everything.
She can then take my place as the true Eydis once again.
If she wants to tell them then, I will not stop her.
I cannot stop her.”
Eydis’s head hung low.
“This is for the best.”

Chapter 12
“The Methods of a Coward”
Fect
“That feeling again…”
Fect sat in the woods near the new portal location wearing the clothes he took from the child the day of his escape from the medical facility.

Jethro tasked him with discovering how well this world’s weapons worked against magic, so wearing suitable clothing from this world helped him blend in and walk freely through the city, but he had made no progress, especially because he had to be cautious of the city guard.
Each day, he returned to the forest to both hide and rest, wasting precious time he could have spent in his investigation.
The more time he spent in the forest, the more he felt a strange sensation from the direction of the houses.
It would only happen at certain times during the day, usually in the morning and again in the evening.
Some days the strange feeling occurred more frequently.
Today, Fect chose to stay in the forest to investigate the sensation instead of heading into the city.
The sun had yet to rise over the ridgeline, but the dim morning light filtered through the trees.
If this day was like the others, the sensation would appear around the time the sun peeked over the mountains.
So Fect waited.
He cleared his mind and focused solely on what he felt.
The first rays of sunlight scattered through the spring-green leaves of the trees.
Soon…
“There!”
The feeling was faint, but now that Fect focused on it, he could more specifically tell the direction.
He placed a long branch pointing in the general direction of the sensation.
However, one direction was not enough.
Each time the sensation came, another shortly followed.
Fect ran as fast as he could through the forest for another angle.
The greater the distance from the first, the more accurate of an intersection he could create.
When Fect felt that he had gone far enough, he quickly cut another low branch of a tree and returned his focus to feeling the sensation.
This time it came quickly.
If he had decided to go further, he may have been too distracted while running or breaking off a branch to feel it.
He laid the branch pointing in the direction of the sensation.
Fect found two trees in the line projected by the branch and brought the branch to the first tree, laying it down pointing in the direction of the second.
In this way, he reasoned that he could bring the two branches together to pinpoint where the lines met.
He ran back to the first branch and repeated the same steps.

After going back and forth between the two branches jumping them forward from target to target while staying in the general line, he reached the edge of the residential district that the forest bordered.
About ten houses sat along the dead-end road.

Due to the inaccurate way Fect found the intersection of the two directions, he was unsure the specific location of the sensation, only that the estimated intersection was near the edge of the district, not deep within.
His best option was to wait for it to occur again.
Now that he was closer, it would be stronger.
The next occurrence should be in the evening.
Again he waited.
Fect chewed on a piece of bark to stave his hunger.
Occasionally, a Human from one of the houses sauntered out into their yard or peered out a window, so Fect hid in the shrubs.
He kept his actions simple and kept his mind clear to not miss the direction.
Unlike in the morning, the time the sensation came in the evening was always different.
He could not afford to miss it.
He was running out of time to complete Jethro’s mission, and if he came up empty after wasting time on this sensation, Jethro would surely punish him.
The sun set, and the only light that penetrated the forest came from the windows of the houses.
The sensation had yet to reappear.
The randomness of the evening occurrence meant that there was always the chance it would not happen, but it always happened in the morning without fail, so there was little worry in Fect’s mind.
After waiting late into the night, Fect was about to turn back.
Sleeping so close to civilization would be dangerous.
He started walking away, but then he felt it.
“Strong!”

The sensation was not unlike standing in the same room as Jethro as he cast his teleportation magic or during his futile attempt to observe the doppelganger’s actions when she teleported away each day she searched for the princess.
It did not come from the houses closest to him but more in the far corner of the district.
He was further from the actual location than he had anticipated.
Fect moved as quietly as possible but could not risk missing the second occurrence.
He stopped near the backyards of three houses at the end of an adjacent street to his initial estimate.
Fect waited, but this time with anticipation gripping his chest.
His heart thundered.
It came again from the house to his right.
The overgrown shrubbery had overtaken the fence that bordered it.
It stood alone in the corner of the residential district more separated from the houses beside it than any other neighboring houses were from each other.
Fect found his target, and he could hardly contain his excitement.
Having felt it close for the second time, he confirmed that the sensation originated from spatial magic and specifically teleportation magic.
There were only two people in this world Fect knew who could possibly use teleportation magic: the elven princess and her doppelganger.
For now, Fect was tired and hungry.
Attempting to investigate the house in this condition would be foolish.
He returned to his stash of rations deeper in the forest and slept uneasily from excitement.
If he could not complete his mission, discovering the location of the princess was a far greater achievement.
Even if it was the doppelganger, that should be adequate consolation for failing his original mission.
He had to complete everything the next day before Jethro reopened the portal.

* * *
The longest period between uses of teleportation magic was between morning and evening.

There were two possibilities: first, the user was always at the house both night and day except for the moments in the morning and evening where they briefly teleported away, or second, the user was always gone and only came to the house for those two brief moments during the day.
Fect hoped it was the latter, but in case it was the former, he needed to use as much caution as was possible.
Fect investigated the shrubs on the forest side of the fence for a break or opening.
The overgrown plants suggested a high probability of disrepair.
Finding two neighboring rotten planks took little time.
He pulled them from their nails at the base and slid them away from each other to create enough room to slip through.
This was another time Fect was thankful for his small stature, even compared to other minums.
The shrubs were far more overgrown on the inside of the fence than on the outside.
Maneuvering through them proved difficult, especially because Fect was trying his utmost to keep the plants from shaking and giving away his position.
Eventually he found a low opening beneath the shrubs that he could crawl through.
Fect slid on his stomach until he could see out into the yard.
The grass was untrimmed and half his height with many long stalks that would tower above him.
Even if invisible, walking through would leave a trail, and the grass might wilt from the heat of his invisibility magic.
Fect crawled on his stomach under the shrubs along the grass-line.
The grass stood tall enough to conceal him and the light shaking of the lower branches.
He worked his way around the edge of the yard to the house and snuck along the siding to the back door.
Now he needed his invisibility.
Fect coated himself with heat and distorted the light around him.
He propped his arms and legs against the doorframe and spidered up until he could peer into the window.
The curtain was closed, but there was enough of a gap for him to see a little inside.
Bread?
He almost let slip the word spoken in his confused mind.
Many stacks of dried flatbread sat atop the kitchen table.
There was far more bread than what any one person could eat, but upon closer inspection, the bases of some of the stacks had been nibbled on, likely by some rodent or other pest.
The kitchen looked used, and some of the cupboards were open, so the bread had probably been ignored and not eaten or at least eaten very slowly.
There was a lot of bread, and Fect continually found himself drawn to the absurdity of the stacks as he peered in.
Fect saw no resident in the house.
The second possibility seemed likely.
The user of the teleportation magic might not be here.
The doorknob was unlocked.
He slowly opened the door, but it caught on a small chain latch.
Cutting through it with fire magic was trivial, but in case he had to leave, Fect could not risk leaving behind evidence.
He worked his small hand through the thin opening between the door and doorframe and pulled the chain hook from its latch.
Fect inspected the kitchen and living room with his invisibility magic still active.
The kitchen was clean of dust, but the living room had a layer of grey dust on everything, even the upholstery.
The front doorknob also had dust.
The resident never opened the door.
Obviously, they teleport in and out, but it’s strange… Didn’t the princess live with some young human man in this world somewhere along the river?
I am sure I heard the doppelganger and Austin talking about that.
And this does not look like the home of some young man.
Fect inspected the portraits on the wall.
Many depicted elderly persons.
Some were clearly the same person at different ages of their long life.
Whether that person was still the current resident or not was uncertain.
What if the princess removed the former resident and secured this location as an additional hiding spot?
That assumption felt wrong.
From how the elves in the palace spoke of the princess, she would not be the type to do such things.
The princess would not take a home from someone.

If she was sharing it with the owner, that would be more understandable, but no man or woman of the age shown in the paintings would be away from home; they couldn’t, at least for any long stretch of time.
If that was so, then where was the elderly resident?
There was only one teleportation user who would not feel bad killing someone or stealing a house to use as a base.
There was a monster in this world, the doppelganger.
Fect could not make any hasty conclusions.
There were still rooms he had not searched.
The elderly resident could be bedridden, and the princess was taking care of him or her.
The man she lived with somewhere along the river could be the grandchild of the resident.
Fect tried to convince himself, but the thought that this house might actually be a Lurr’s den made him anxious.
Fect turned back down the entryway to the hall.
A young Forest Elf stood before him.
The girl’s face bore a long scar, possible signs of abuse.
Lines of dried blood fell from the tips of her horns into a stained rag tied around her forehead.
The doppelganger had a spriggan with her, Rynn.
This was the doppelganger’s den!
The young elf froze in place.
Fect’s invisibility magic remained active, but because he was moving when he entered the hallway, there would have been a slight blur for a moment.
If Rynn was close enough, she might be able to feel the heat radiating from his magic.
Fect did not move or breathe.
Rynn did not move or breathe.
Her eyes searched the hallway and kitchen.
Slowly she took a step back, then another.
She moved backwards until her back bumped into the open door of what appeared to be a closet full of boxes and clothes.
Without removing her eyes from the hallway, Rynn retreated step by step until the door closed and her back pressed against it.
There was fear in her eyes.
Fect pondered his options during their invisible standoff.
Killing Rynn right here would be easy.
He could then explore the house uninhibited.
Or, he could capture her and use her as a hostage against the doppelganger to get information on the princess’s location.
She was awfully protective of her pet spriggan.
That’s the better option.
Fect stepped forward, and immediately Rynn’s eyes were on him.
She thrust her palm forward, and a small sphere of water shot towards his face.
He dodged to the left, but a second was ready and hit him in the chest.
Fect feared that it might have been offensive magic, but it was plain water.
It was not corrosive or acidic nor did it carry any force.
It only served to break through his invisibility at the point of impact, but the light quickly bent around him once more.
Fect was now discovered, so he no longer needed invisibility.
He dropped his magic and smiled.
Fear evolved into terror in the spriggan’s expression.
“You must be that monster’s pet.
Where did she go?”
Rynn did not answer.
Her trembling eyes glanced quickly towards the doorway to Fect’s left and then the doorway to his right.
Both were open.
She was searching for a way out.
“No answer?
Well then, how about the location of the Amelian Princess?
Do you know where she is?”
Rynn remained silent.
“Loyal, aren’t you?
Or are you more afraid of that monster than you are of me?”
Her expression changed slightly.
While she still trembled in fear, her lips formed a light scowl.
“Either way, I need you to come with me.”
Fect took a step forward, and Rynn reached her hand for the doorknob without taking her eyes off Fect.
“That is nothing but a storeroom.
You can’t escape there.” Fect produced a small flame in his hand.
“And locking yourself inside will not help you.
Make this easy on both of us.
If you come with me, I promise not to hurt you.
That may be a better deal than what you get with that monster.”
A cold mist rose from both Rynn’s hands.
While keeping one hand on the doorknob, she thrust the other at Fect’s feet.
He jumped to avoid the ray of frost.
A thin sheet of ice coated the floor.
When Fect landed, he lost his footing for but a moment until his feet froze to it.
Rynn used this opening to dive towards the open door to Fect’s right.
He flash-heated the floor to remove the ice and pursued the girl.
She jumped onto the bed and braced her head with her arms.
With a strong kick off the other side, the spriggan broke through the window.
“Accursed agile sprigs!”
Fect climbed onto the bed and dove out the window after her.
Due to his small stature, he easily avoided the broken glass on the edges.
He rolled to a stop on the front lawn and looked around.
The rag that was wrapped around her forehead sat on the grass in front of him.
Rynn ran down the road with a limp in her left leg.
Her left foot was bleeding as was her right arm near the shoulder, but neither appeared too serious.
They only impeded her flight.
Fect was grateful.
He had no hope catching a fleeing spriggan otherwise.
The road was almost barren of people.
One dark-skinned man in a fluffy yellow robe stood in his yard holding what looked like a rolled-up paper in a transparent bag.
He saw the bleeding girl with horns and froze.
He could use this.
Fect focused his gaze at the man’s feet.
A pillar of fire engulfed him.
Only a charred silhouette remained.
Rynn saw this and yelped.
Her pace increased, almost tripping over her injured leg.
A woman ran out of the house, her eyes frozen to the remains of the man who was likely her husband.
Her body trembled, and she fell to her knees unable to comprehend what she saw.
“Oh, Lord Jesus…”
Fect yelled at the woman in the highest, childlike voice he could, pointing at the fleeing Elf.
“That!
That!”
Hearing Fect’s shout, Rynn glanced behind her.
The woman saw the scarred face and bloody horns.
“Demon!” She screamed and fled back inside her house in a fit of panic.
This early in the morning, the number of people outside their homes were few, but anyone Rynn looked at, Fect disposed of in like manner.
The body count grew to five when Fect chased Rynn out of the residential district.
The main road was far busier.
Many of the metal carriages swerved or stopped upon seeing Rynn.
She ran across an intersecting road and was nearly hit by a carriage that tipped onto two tires as it swerved to avoid her.
It spun to a stop leaving black streaks on the road.
When she looked back at the large, unknown object that nearly struck her, Fect lit an intense fire beneath it.
To his surprise, the vehicle exploded in a fireball that rivaled powerful fire magic.
Pandemonium ensued.
Screams erupted from those on the streets when they saw the explosion and the girl with horns.
Fect ignited a second carriage which also exploded like the last.
It was not happenstance.
The carriages were combustible.
People fled in every direction in a raving panic.
Those in carriages abandoned them and fled on foot.
Rynn spun, not knowing where to flee.
Fect lit anyone along her line of sight on fire, being too far to accurately conjure pillars of flame at their feet.
She ran, avoiding the street, and weaved between buildings so no one would see her.
Fect cursed under his winded breath.
She caught on to his ploy.
No matter.
The devastation should be sufficient by now.
He followed close to not lose her and to make her aware that he was still pursuing.
His plan would be ruined if he lost her or she decided to hide out of sight.
The loud sirens of the city guards echoed in the distance.
Fect chased Rynn into a light commerce district with shops lining the streets.
She fled along the back alleys of the buildings where few people would see her, but every so often someone noticed her and met the same fiery demise.
The sirens grew closer.
Now was the time.
Fect lit a wall of fire with his gaze in front of the spriggan to impede her flight.
She turned back, but Fect cut in front of her.
“I think this is enough running,” Fect sneered, or as close to a sneer as he could manage while breathing heavily.
A thin alley stretched to Fect’s right and led to the road.
He slowly approached Rynn, and she slowly limped backwards.
As Fect rotated to the right, so did she.
When her back was facing the alley, Fect moved forward, and Rynn backpedaled into the alley.
“I need you to put on a show for me, but some might pity a girl in a pretty dress.”
Fect focused on various locations on the flower-print dress.
Fire sprouted, and Rynn fought to pat out the flames, but the number grew faster than she could extinguish them.
She drenched her dress in desperation, but the water only boiled under Fect’s gaze, scalding her skin.
She pulled the dress off from over her head and tossed it away.
Only a loose silken undergarment hung from her shoulders.
It extended past her waist and stopped halfway down her thighs.
Her long tail twitched irritably behind her digitigrade legs.
Bloody horns, pointed ears, scarred face, long tail, and inhuman legs.
“Now, dance for me.”
Fect lit a fire in front of Rynn.
When she jumped back to avoid it, Fect extinguished it with a wave of his hand and lit another.
He pushed her further and further through the alley until he forced her out onto the walkway lining the road.
Confusion spread among those who saw her and the flames.
Fect remained at the edge of the alley.
This street was far busier than the previous, like the morning of a market when merchants were prepping to open shop.
The number of people was few, but the passing carriages were many.
Rynn searched around frantically trying to find where she should run.
One brave woman worked up the courage to approach her.
“Are you okay?”
Rynn shouted at the woman in terror.
“Get away from me!
Run!”
The woman could not understand Rynn’s desperate warning.
She spoke in Elven and did not seem to know any English.
The foolish doppelganger never taught her.
The woman reached out a caring hand towards the quivering spriggan.
Fect set the woman on fire by heating her directly like he had Rynn’s clothes.
He already showed his pillar of fire to the city guards.
It was his signature.
This time needed to be different.
The woman screamed and flailed as the fire quickly rose in intensity.
Rynn conjured water, then ice, but both evaporated, powerless against Fect’s superior flame in his unbroken gaze on the woman.
She could only stare in horror as the woman crumbled to the ground.
Her eyes met Fect’s a short distance away.
“Put on a show,” Fect mouthed back in Elven.
Rynn ran across the street.
Fect ignited an intense fire beneath a carriage in front of her.
The force of the explosion blew her to her back on the road.
The traffic stopped.
The drivers of the carriages all ran.
No one remained.
She looked around to find a direction she could run, but the road was soon cut off.
The flashing blue and red flares of the city guards arrived.
Fect used Rynn’s moment of confusion to quickly climb up a pipe on the side of the building onto a small ledge on the second floor.
He lay down to get a clear aerial view of the road.
Amid the loud sirens, thunderous flapping could also be heard.
The flying carriage arrived.
Fect enshrouded himself with his invisibility magic while Rynn looked up at him in terror.
He could not risk the flying enemy spotting him.
The first of the city guards swung open their doors and crouched behind them.
They aimed the small handheld weapon that Fect was familiar with at the girl, but they did not immediately fire.
“On the ground,” the guards shouted from behind their metal cover.
Cowards.
These small weapons were not what Fect wanted to see.
He already knew their effectiveness.
His only choice was to antagonize the guards but not enough for them to outright kill Rynn.
Fect ignited a carriage near the guards but not close enough that they would be injured in the explosion.
The guards dove behind their carriage.
Neither dared show their heads.
Instead, they removed an object from their belt and yelled into it.
“Suspect on Juniper using fire magic.
We are pinned down.”
Rynn tried to use this time to escape.
Fect ignited an abandoned carriage in front of her to force her back into the center of the street.
Her arms and legs shook in fear as she searched in desperation for a way out of her cage.
The more she panicked--the more the guards panicked--the happier Fect became.
Another city guard carriage arrived on the other side of the girl from the first, and a third arrived close behind.
They parked their carriages perpendicular to the road to create a barrier between themselves and the girl.
Perfect.
One of the guards held a much larger weapon that Fect had seen at the medical facility.
He propped it on the front of the carriage with his body safely behind.
“Dance for me,” Fect whispered, not at the spriggan but at the city guard.
They were reacting exactly as he had hoped.
Fect ignited a vehicle near them.
All the guards hid behind their carriages once again.
He needed more or his luck here would go to waste.
He only had one more carriage at his disposal within his range aside from the city guard, but he was not against using theirs.
He only feared that if he attacked them directly, they would shoot Rynn before he could witness the steady increase of their firepower.
Both sides of the street were blocked, and the only alley Rynn could use as an exit was guarded by Fect.
The cage was complete.
There was no escape.
Rynn curled up on the street and covered her head, trying to show she was not a threat.
“Eydis!” she cried through sobs.
One of the city guards peeked out from behind the carriage.
She flagged those near her to lower their weapons.
“Hold!
I don’t think she’s an enemy.”
Rynn certainly looked terrified, and Fect did not take into consideration that her terror would sway the guards.
“What is happening here,” the guard called.
“Do you know Eydis FeAmel?”
Fect could not let the aggression die.
How could he spin this to his favor?
If fear was such strong evidence of Rynn’s innocence, he needed to turn that evidence into a greater threat to the guard.
An idea popped into his mind immediately.
What better way could there be than to make the guard think that Rynn’s fire magic was spiraling out of control?
The crying girl lifted her terrified gaze to the guard who called out to her and was now leaving the cover of her carriage.
The moment their eyes met, Fect set the female guard on fire.
Those close to her pulled her back behind cover and fought to suffocate the flames with their coats.
The guard was badly burned, but she would survive.
Many of the guards aimed their weapons at the girl out of fear of their own.
“It’s not me!
I didn’t do it!” Tears streamed down Rynn’s face, but no one could understand her cries.
“He’s over there!”

Rynn stood and swung her arm to point at where Fect hid, but the moment her extended hand crossed the direction of the guards in front of her, multiple gunshots thundered across the street from a single city guardsman.
The girl jolted from the numerous impacts of the high-speed projectiles, and she collapsed to the ground.
“Stupid girl… Now I can’t use her,” Fect grumbled.
He was about to retreat when a flash of light appeared near the downed spriggan.
The elf scanned the guards with their weapons drawn and then found the girl bleeding out on the road.
The princess?
No, that was Jethro’s magic, so that must be the doppelganger!
The doppelganger ignored the guards and dropped to Rynn’s side.
She removed Rynn’s undergarment and immediately stemmed the bleeding.
Another gunshot.
The impact knocked the doppelganger’s head aside, but there was no damage.
The projectile was deflected by a barrier.
The doppelganger looked in the direction of the attack to the terrified guardsman who shot Rynn and now shot at the doppelganger.
Her eyes glowed with vehement crimson.
“Beynard!
Did you do this?!”
She stood and confronted the guards.
“Did you attack this child!?”
Fect chuckled to himself as his grin steadily grew wider.
The weapon was blocked easily by spatial magic.
Soon, they would bring larger and more powerful weapons.
This is what he wanted to see.
Dance for me.

Chapter 13
“Choices Made in Desperation”
Eydis
It began as an average morning.
Eydis woke up before Justin as usual on the days Justin could sleep in.
She teleported over to check on the princess who remained in poor condition.
Instead of continuing her attempts to provide the princess ven, Eydis had been using her life magic to ease fatigue and nourish the body.
Through both Eydis’s and Rynn’s efforts, the high fever was breaking.
The ven the princess’s body was expending to preserve her life now nearly matched its recovery speed.

The princess would no longer weaken, and unless there was a sudden change, she would not die, but Eydis could not tell how long the princess would take to recover enough for Eydis to apologize and confess everything, if she would recover at all.
After spending a moment with Rynn, Eydis returned to Justin’s apartment to begin breakfast.
She was limited in her selection of recipes, but if it was the egg and cheese dish Justin served her when she first arrived, she was more than capable.
She was quite proud that she could cook it better than him and even asked Rynn what spices would best elevate the flavor.
Her omelets became an immediate favorite for Justin.
“Breakfast is ready.”
Justin stirred but did not wake.
Eydis walked over and planted a light kiss on his cheek.
“Breakfast is ready.
Eat before it grows cold.”
She grabbed Justin’s hand and pulled him off the couch.

Part of her thought it odd that Justin still insisted on sleeping on the couch instead of sharing her bed now that she was one of his women, but she also felt that she did not deserve to share a bed with him.
After all, she was not the princess.
Eydis also felt that she was not ready for that level of intimacy yet.
Eydis’s face flushed lightly, and she suppressed the thought.
They ate together and spent the morning uneventfully.
Justin worked on his studies while Eydis sat on the couch reading another book she borrowed from Sean, a dramatized account of a female ruler from the history of this world, Cleopatra.
She found reading a wonderful study aid to further improve her English.
This was the twelfth book she read this week alone.
By the next week, she will have not only finished Sean’s bookcase but also the two boxes of books he stored under his bed.
The rate she devoured books surprised him.
Apparently, the princess only read about a book a week and had yet to finish Justin’s small collection he rarely touched.
Through careful conversation, she learned which books of Justin’s the princess had already read and completed them in secret while reading Sean’s collection.
Sean offered to accompany her to the library to obtain a library card next week so she could keep reading.
While Eydis read, a faint buzzing reached her ear, but she thought little of it.
It passed in time only to reappear a minute later.
Again, she ignored it.
Once Justin’s ringtone played on the table, Eydis closed her book, tired of the annoyances, and decided to investigate the buzzing.
It was very faint, so quiet that Justin could not have heard it, and it came from down the hall.
It was her phone.
She left it in her room.
Eydis quickly rushed down the hall as Justin picked up his phone in the kitchen.
She did not reach hers in time to catch the call, but Major Wickenny’s name displayed on the screen, missed four times.
“Eydis,” Justin called in a panic from the kitchen.
Eydis rushed back into the kitchen to find Justin on his phone staring at the local news on the television.
The voice she heard over Justin’s phone belonged to Colonel Richards.
The news showed areal footage of a road with burning vehicles where the police were in a standoff against a small figure.
Eydis’s heart sank into despair.
She knew the small girl.
“Where is this?!”
“The southeast side of the city.
The old town.
I’m not familiar with it.”
“Tell Colonel Richards that girl is not an enemy!”
Eydis recalled the transmission formula she thought she had forgotten long ago and teleported to the top of the tallest building in the city.
Small wisps of smoke rose from the southeast.
Eydis strung together a transmission formula and activated it.
Due to the inaccuracy of the destination, she fell twenty feet to the roof of another building, but from her location, she could just see the road where the standoff was taking place.
Another transmission formula emerged in her mind at a startling speed, and with a crack and flash of light, Eydis appeared on the street.
Rynn was bleeding out on the road.
She was too late.
Eydis tore the gown off Rynn and ran her hands over the many bullet holes to stem the bleeding.
Rynn had severe internal damage.
She could not move Rynn for fear of sudden motion killing her.
She could not teleport Rynn away in this condition.
Using life magic, she suppressed the shock in the body and stabilized the girl to prevent her heart and other organs from failing.
Before she could treat the damage, her adept ears picked up on the small tick of a firearm, a sound she recognized from her demonstrations with the police and military.
She erected a quick barrier but was not fast enough to strengthen it.
The impact of the bullet knocked her head back and caused some pain, but the bullet was deflected.
Rage burned in her, her eyes glowing red.
She stood and stared down the police.
Although all the police had their firearms raised, only one showed open animosity, Officer Beynard.
“Beynard!
Did you do this?!”
She stood.
“Did you attack this child!?”
“I knew you were a demon!” Beynard shouted.
“Look at her ears!”
Eydis did not have time to care about the police.
If she did not act fast, Rynn would die despite Eydis’s life-support magic.
She focused on the worst injuries first, starting with the bullet that penetrated Rynn’s back.
It lodged itself in Rynn’s left lung.
The lung was filling fast with blood.
Eydis expelled the bullet with wind focused in the bullet wound and sealed the hole in the lung.
She then expelled the blood in the lungs using wind once again.
Rynn’s breathing improved, but that alone took far too much of Eydis’s ven.
She was already low due to aiding the princess’s recovery.
Eydis’s fury grew stronger.
“Do not let her revive that demon or more of us will be burned like Joyce.”
“The Major is ordering us to stand down,” an officer called from the far side.
“The girl is not an enemy.”
Another officer from that same side approached cautiously with his firearm lowered but still in hand for protection.
“Stay back,” Eydis growled at him, her crimson glare burning.
The officer frightened and fired.
The shot ricocheted off Eydis’s weak barrier, hitting Rynn’s extended ankle.
“We cannot arrest her.
She can kill us if we touch her,” Officer Beynard warned, ignoring Major Wickenny’s order.
“You’ve read the reports.
Her barrier will break with enough force.”
Everything she taught the police they were using against her.
Eydis seethed internally.
She only managed to stop the bleeding of the new wound.
Her life magic was having less and less effect.
Eydis could not risk continuing in her ven-starved state without the threat of her treatment accidently killing Rynn.
The cold shivers of ven exhaustion informed her that she could no longer teleport away.
She lacked the ven to use transmission to send Rynn to safety.
Even if she could, she might not be able to reach the house in time to treat Rynn, and the police would follow her there.
Using her Lurr strength to flee somewhere else with Rynn would worsen the already fatal injuries.
The police would likely attack if she tried to flee, and her ven was too low to hold a barrier against them.
“If we don’t kill her now, there is no telling how many more people will die!”
Officer Beynard continued inciting his fellow police.
The police could not be reasoned with; they were too quick to act on fear.
Fleeing was impossible.
Eydis had only one option.
“You killed her,” Eydis lied, but if she did not act fast, that lie would become truth.
With what dregs of ven that remained, she created a barrier around Rynn, but she doubted it would hold back a single bullet.
“You killed her!”
The anger she felt towards the police raged into an inferno.
Eydis dove.
The force of her takeoff ripped away the soles from her shoes and fired pieces of asphalt out in her wake.
The gap between her and Officer Beynard closed in an instant.
She grabbed his collar with her momentum and threw him.
The man flew over fifty yards before hitting pavement and bouncing into a car.
Eydis did not care if he lived or died.
She saved his life once, so she had no qualms about taking it again.
Now openly hostile, the nearby police had reason to retaliate.
Eydis swerved to the right to avoid a gunshot.
She grabbed the attacker’s arm and swung him into the other officer.
His arm broke from the torque, and both police tumbled to the sidewalk unconscious.
To the side, Eydis saw a badly burnt body.
She knew her, Officer Hellings.
Fire magic was being used, but not by Rynn.
This was a setup.
Two barbs struck Eydis’s back, and the surge of electricity through her body constricted her muscles, but the effect only slowed her a little.
She already attacked the police, so she needed to eliminate the immediate threat first.
Eydis grabbed the cords and tore the weapon she had not seen before from the officer’s grip.
She kicked him in the side and felt his ribs buckle on impact.
He flew through a store window, showering glass onto the sidewalk.
Eydis tore out the barbs by the wires and searched for the next hostile target among the police cars on the other side of Rynn.
The remaining police fled.
In their place two large, armored vehicles similar in color to the tan uniforms worn by the army personal weaved through the abandoned cars.
No fewer than ten soldiers exited.
They wore the IOTV that had resisted her wind magic and brandished weapons that broke her barriers in the demonstrations.
Eydis’s heart sank into fear.
“I have created my own demise.”
The soldiers pointed their weapons at Eydis and advanced slowly.
Instead of fighting, Eydis ran back to Rynn and shielded the small girl with her body.
The weak barrier that she left behind had already dispersed.
“I surrender!
I will not fight you!”
The soldiers hurried to check the status of the downed police.
Only three of the soldiers approached Eydis.
Two of them kept their aim on Eydis, having seen her assault on the police.
A third reached down and grabbed her arm.
“We were ordered by Colonel Richards to retrieve you and have you explained the situation.
Medics are on the way to treat the girl.”
Eydis shook off the soldier’s grasp but did not attack.
A second soldier attempted to help the first in securing Eydis, but they were no match for her strength.
“No!” Eydis released herself and returned to cover Rynn.
“Please. I must save her.”
The soldiers could only guard Eydis.
“What is the status of the police,” one of the soldiers asked from further away.
“None are dead, but many are in critical condition.
One officer further from here has a broken neck.
We cannot risk moving him until EMTs arrive.”
The soldiers continued talking and aiding the injured.
Eydis did not leave Rynn.
She was recovering a little ven from her contact but not enough to teleport away or heal Rynn.
In Rynn’s state, Eydis did not know if the young girl could even recover ven, so the longer she remained in contact with her, the more ven Rynn lost.
Draining Rynn’s ven only weakened her further.
Even now, Rynn could pass at any moment.
Eydis gritted her teeth and pressed her head harder into the asphalt as she held Rynn under her.
With what little ven she recovered, she periodically checked Rynn’s weakening vitals.
If Rynn dies, I will kill them all.
I will kill every last one of them!
Eydis was ready to become the monster that everyone feared she was.
She came to this world for Rynn, and if Earth rejected the girl as Whinhlem had, she would end it herself.
Thorough and indiscriminate, until not one human remained.
“Eydis!”
Eydis’s heart constricted painfully in her chest, choking out a whimper.
She knew that voice.
Justin ran behind Major Wickenny.
The soldiers guarding Eydis made room.
“What happened?
Are you okay?” Justin placed his arm on Eydis’s trembling shoulder to lift her.
His grip retracted when he saw the condition of the young, horned girl Eydis covered.
“The police… they hurt Rynn… She’s dying…” Eydis cried.
“You can’t heal her?
Are you out of ven?” Justin removed his jacket.
He lightly embraced Eydis and held their arms together.
“The more contact, the better, right?”
Tears of gratitude fell down Eydis’s cheeks.
Justin’s ven recovery was exceptional.
Elf ven recovery rate should be higher than a human’s, and other humans like Sammy were as low as what Eydis expected, but for some reason Justin was different.
This made her all the more grateful that he came.
A medic arrived and reached for Rynn.
“Do not touch her!” Eydis swatted the medic’s hand away.
She felt the bones in his hand break, and he cried out in pain, cursing at Eydis.
“He is trying to help.”
“Do not touch her.
Nobody touch her.”
Justin held Eydis tighter.
If she did not trust anyone else, giving her ven was all he could do.
“How much longer before you can help her?”
Eydis shook her head.
Even though her ven was recovering, contact was still the slowest method.
Rynn’s injuries need a substantial amount of ven, and fast.
She needed to return to the house on the edge of the city.
One of the armored vehicles exploded.
The soldiers raised their weapons, some of them pointing at Eydis.
“It was not us!
We cannot use fire magic!” Eydis cried.
“It’s not Eydis,” Justin shouted.
“Someone else is here!”
“Eyes on the buildings!”
The soldiers looked around, firearms raised.
No one could be found.
Eydis lifted herself off Rynn and held her carefully in her arms.
“Do you have enough ven?” Justin asked.
“No. But I can get more now.”
Eydis worked out a simple teleportation formula using the ven that Justin provided.
When she tore open the portal, the ground beneath the soldier beside them heated.
Justin kicked the soldier away and used the force to pull Eydis and Rynn through the portal before the billowing flame erupted.
They landed on the carpet of a small bedroom.
The portal collapsed almost immediately before the flames could enter, barely giving them time to exit.
It was formulated for two, not three.
She never imagined Justin would pull them through.
His timing reacting to that attack was far too perfect.
She felt the peculiar sensation of his time magic at work.
If he did not act, they may have been caught in the fire, and that soldier would have certainly died.
Eydis took a few long breaths to calm down and lifted Rynn onto the bed.
“Was that…” Justin began, breathing quickly in his panic.
“Yes, one of Jethro’s men was trying to make the police target Rynn to get to me.”
“Who is Rynn and where is this?”
“Rynn…”
How should I answer…?
I was planning on introducing Rynn to Justin and Sammy eventually, but not this soon.
I have not thought of an excuse.
Eydis’s mind raced to find something to tell Justin, but she could not think of anything.
The truth was all she had.
“When Jethro had me prisoner, his men were using this girl as their… she was their slave.
When I escaped, I took her with me and found this house.
She distrusts humans because of everything that happened to her.
I planned to introduce her to you eventually once she opened up more and I was certain she would be accepted.”
“Of course she would be accepted.
I accepted you, didn’t I?”
A pain pricked Eydis’s heart.
“You did.
You did.”
I should have brought Rynn with me to Justin.
I should have given an excuse then and there.
If I did that, then Jethro’s men never would have found her.
She never would have gotten hurt!
But then, there would have been no one to take care of Eydis.
Eydis’s chest hurt.
The emotional wound in her heart was burning once again.
“Justin, can you wait here for a moment?”
If I feed on Eydis in her current condition, I will have enough ven to keep Rynn alive, but Eydis will die.
To save Rynn, I will sacrifice the princess.
I am sorry Justin.
I cannot return her to you.
Eydis walked into the hallway.
Her hand rose to her mouth.
The door to the closet was not only closed, but a thick layer of melting ice also covered the doorknob and latch.
The events that led to Rynn running through the city became clear.
One of Jethro’s men discovered this house, and Rynn used herself as a decoy so that the princess would not be found.
Eydis fell to her knees.
“Eydis?” Justin rushed over to her, but she ignored him.
She only stared at the frozen door.
Rynn risked her life to save Eydis.
Why?
Was it because I said I would save Eydis’s life?
If I kill Eydis now to save Rynn, I would destroy the sacrifice Rynn made to save her.
Rynn would have been injured for nothing!
No… Rynn became injured because of my own selfishness.
I should have run.
I should have left with her and escaped Amel.
I never should have helped Jethro!
Rynn would have been safe!
Justin would have never lost his princess.
