Sammy would have never lost her dearest friend.
“Eydis, are you okay?”
I can still get ven another way.
Eydis grabbed Justin’s arm and pulled him back into the room.
“What’s wrong?” Justin held nothing but loving concern in his eyes.
Eydis’s heart pounded in her chest.
“Lie with me.”
“What?”
“I need ven.
Lie with me.
Sex is the only way I can restore ven now,” Eydis protested.
“Please!”
A shadow fell across Justin’s countenance not unlike what Eydis often saw in Rynn.
There was something dark in Justin’s past that Eydis did not know.
“We can’t.
I can’t,” Justin said as he struggled to voice some hidden torment the suggestion stirred inside him.
“Just take my ven.
You have expelled my ven and given me ven before.”
“I don’t know how!”
Eydis did not have the time for argument.
Rynn was dying on the bed beside them.
“Please!”
In Justin’s fearful silence, she steeled herself against what she felt was necessary.
Justin’s troubled gaze widened in surprise when Eydis removed her clothes.
“Eydis?
Don’t do this.”
Justin’s eyes scanned her naked body, but instead of lust, his fear deepened.
Eydis’s hand caressed her tail.
Her chest tightened.
“Justin… I am sorry.”
She grabbed Justin by his shirt and forced him to the floor.
He resisted, but a human’s strength could not compete.
“Please!
Eydis!
Let’s talk through this!”
I want to talk!
I want to tell you everything.
I want to tell you who I am, WHAT I am.
I want you to love me for being me.
I want to talk, but…
“I do not have time!”
Eydis pulled down Justin’s pants and was grateful that he was aroused despite his fear and confusion.
“Eydis!
Stop!”
She shut out Justin’s voice from her mind.
He complained, but Eydis did not listen.
She held him firm, and a stinging pain tore inward, but the amount of ven she was recovering was no different than regular contact.
She grabbed Justin’s shirt amid his struggling and removed it too to increase contact so the siphoning of ven would also increase.
“Eydis, if you love me, please stop.”
Even though Justin’s voice was not a scream, even though she tried to shut him out, his words rang louder in her mind and heart than any former plea.
Eydis stopped.
She leaned over his body.
Tears fell from her eyes onto Justin’s confused and frightened face.
Justin wrapped his arms around her and pleaded in her ear.
“Eydis, please.
I don’t want to hurt you.”
“Rynn will die,” Eydis cried.
“Is… Is there no other way?” Justin asked, his voice trembling.
“No…” No matter what choice she could have made, she would hurt Justin.
“…Okay,” Justin said.
He no longer resisted, but that did not mean he wanted this.
Justin wrapped his arms around her and trembled.
He was afraid.
He had some unknown trauma, a deep wound that Eydis was carving open.
Even though he gave his consent, she knew she was hurting him.
He did not want this, and neither did she, not in this way.
There was no going back to the love they had before, even if it was a lie.
Deep down, Eydis wanted love.
She wanted a fulfilling relationship with a loving partner with whom she could share her most intimate self.
She had never known love, only abuse, only lies and deceit.
She had hope in Justin.
He was the first man to ever show her affection.
He helped piece her heart back together and guide her from the wrong path she followed, even if he did not know it.
If there was a man she wanted to share a pure and intimate love with, he was that man, but with each second and each movement of her body, she tore that dream apart piece by piece.
There was no going back.
Eydis held Justin tight but gently.
She apologized to him over and over in her heart.
Her body grew tense.
The flow of ven grew rapidly.
And then Eydis could see it.
Justin’s ven was like a vast reservoir of murky water.
Her movements chipped away at the dam holding it back until all at once the dam breached.
The murky water spilled over into the small, empty vessel inside Eydis.
Justin’s ven capacity was enormous.
This level was inhuman.
It was inelven.
It was far beyond any elfkind.
It flowed and flowed and would not stop.
She wanted to push away but couldn’t.
Her Lurr nature thirsted for the ven and drew out all he would offer until her capacity stretched like a balloon about to burst.
Finally, she let go and the flow of ven stopped.
Justin distanced himself.
He shuffled back and collapsed against the closed closet door.
He said nothing, only burying his head in his arms.
She had done something unforgivable to Justin and knew their relationship ended here.
Eydis remained on her back.
The pressure of the ven throughout her body was uncomfortable, almost painful.
Her head and all the way to her extremities throbbed with an unfamiliar ache.
Her ven was restored, far more than drinking blood ever could.
She needed a moment to recover but could not spare that moment.
Eydis bit her inner cheek.
She grabbed onto the bedsheets and pulled herself up.
After crawling onto the bed, she checked Rynn’s condition.
Thankfully, Rynn was still alive, but just barely.
She immediately began healing the damage.

* * *
Treating Rynn took hours and was not completed until the day was far spent.
Treatment used only a fraction of Eydis’s ven, but the longer the treatment continued, the more ill Eydis felt.
Her body was in physical pain when she finished, but her relief was far stronger.
Rynn slept peacefully.
She lost a lot of blood, but she would recover.
“How is she?”
Justin remained naked on the floor against the closet.
He never moved for the hours Eydis meticulously worked.
She was sure that Justin hated her now, and yet he stayed.
“Rynn is fine.
She will live.”
Relief showed on Justin’s face.
“I’m glad.”
What can I say to him?
“Th… thank you…”
“I don’t want your gratitude.
I want an explanation!”
Justin looked Eydis in the eyes, but she could not look back, averting her gaze to the floor.
“I’ve been thinking these past hours.
The difference in personality.
The blood I kept smelling on your breath.
Your red eyes.
Your strength.
Your lack of knowledge about magic.
The way you speak.
This other house.
Rynn.
Your knowledge about Jethro.
Your violence towards others.
And this…” Justin shook his head slowly.
“I had assumed everything was due to you being assaulted when you were captured or some similar reason causing you to be under a lot of stress or in a lot of pain.
I was worried about you.
I was so worried about you!”
Justin gritted his teeth.
“I want to know the truth.”
Eydis’s face contorted in anguish.
This was her punishment.
“Get dressed.
There is something I must show you.”

Chapter 14
“A Plea for Forgiveness”
Eydis
Eydis tucked Rynn into the covers of the bed.
Her fingers lightly traced the young girl’s pale cheek.
She was cold, almost as if dead, but the small girl’s weak breathing showed she was alive.
That did not remove the fear in Eydis’s heart.
She scanned Rynn’s vitals once again, and a nauseating ache wracked her body from the simple use of life magic, but Eydis paid it no mind.
Her body ached anyway, and she felt it was a meager punishment for what Rynn had to endure and for what she did to Justin, but the scale could not be balanced.
Rynn had endured so much pain, and because of Eydis’s selfish desires, Rynn continued getting hurt.
Justin was innocent like Rynn, but Eydis hurt him too.
She glanced behind at him as he dressed.
Her face flushed warm, but it was not from the embarrassment that followed a maiden’s first passionate love.
Her heart burned in guilty anguish.
She loved Justin, but because of what she had done, he would never love her.
Especially after she showed him the truth.
Eydis dressed, and Justin followed her out the room to the closet.
The ice Rynn placed on the door to prevent it from being opened had melted.
Eydis led Justin through the closet and down the dark steps.
“The light is broken, so I will stoke the furnace.”
“Is someone down there?”
Scant light from the hallway filtered into the cellar from the closet, but even in the dark, an occupied bed of blankets could be seen from the stairs.
Eydis walked over to the furnace and inserted dry wood.
She lit the tinder with a packet of matches set nearby, but before the flames could take life, Justin realized who slept in the blankets.
“It can’t be.” Justin rushed to the princess’s side.
His hand rested against her cheek, trembling.
He looked back at Eydis.
His eyes betrayed confusion, doubt, and a plea for explanation.
Eydis felt a suffocating, tight pain in her heart.
It constricted her voice to silence the words she was about to speak.
The anguish was unbearable, and breathing felt impossible.
She was terrified.
Suppressing her fears and suffocating guilt, she squeezed out the confession stuck in her throat.
“That… that is the true Eydis FeAmel, First Princess of the Amelian Empire.”
Justin’s face froze in disbelief.
Slowly the realization of what he just heard seeped into his mind.
His hand returned to her cheek and then her forehead.
She had a fever.
Her cheeks were sunken, and her lips were cracked.
Dark rings shadowed her eyes.
She appeared dead if not for the warmth.
He shook her lightly.
“Eydis.”
He shook her harder.
“Eydis!”
The chains binding the princess jingled, their sound a warning siren blaring in Eydis’s ears.
She never removed the chains for fear that the princess would wake and flee at the first opportunity before Eydis could apologize and explain herself.
She wanted to stop Justin from removing the blanket, but her body would not move.
Her guilt paralyzed her.
Justin saw the princess’s naked and emaciated body chained to a stake.
His hands reached for her but did not touch.
They shook as if trying to resist the reality lying before him.
He turned to Eydis with pure terror.
“What did you do to her?
Who are you…?”
Justin’s terrified eyes caused even greater anguish.
She did not want Justin to look at her like this.
He could hate her.
Eydis was prepared for that.
He could be angry at her.
Eydis was prepared for that.
But more than anything, she did not want him to fear her.
Anger may have come from what she did, but his fear came from what she was, a monster.
Eydis’s heart shattered.
She sobbed in her hands, and no matter how she tried, she could not voice an answer.
The world around her drowned in her pain and sorrow.
Her hands fell to her lap lacking the strength to even hide the shame on her anguished face.
Her voice wailed out, but no one would be there to hear it.
No comfort would come.
She was alone.
A firm hand gripped Eydis’s shoulder.
She grasped out, and her hands found fabric.
She buried her face in the warmth it covered.
Her wailing continued as the scent that had once brought her comfort now only increased the aching of her heart.
A second hand grasped her other shoulder to push her off, but she held fast to the warmth begging and pleading through her tears for the comfort to return.
“Stop!
Stop crying.”
The hands gripping Eydis’s shoulders shook.
“I can’t…” The voice trembled.
“I can’t stand seeing someone with Eydis’s face crying like this.”
The voice fell silent.
His hands gripped tighter and tighter as Eydis’s unceasing tears drenched his shirt until finally the grip eased.
A hesitant arm wrapped around Eydis’s shoulder, and it held her close to the warmth.
“I… I don’t know what drove you to do this to Eydis.”
The arms held Eydis tighter.
“I can’t… I don’t believe that the care, the kindness you’ve… The way you protected Sammy and healed Chloe.
The way you worked with the police to help save lives and fight those from your world.
I can’t believe that was all an act.
I don’t know why you did this to Eydis, but I don’t think that someone who feels this bad over what they’ve done can be that evil.”
Rynn’s words floated in Eydis’s mind.
“No monster would feel this pain.
A monster would not feel remorse.”
“I can’t forgive you, but I can at least try to understand you.”
Eydis’s hoarse wailing reduced to sobs, but she still held firm to Justin, fearing that he would disappear if she let go, leaving her alone.
She fought to stifle her cries, but it only made her choke.
“Please.
Talk to me.
I told you that I would listen.”
“Sorry…” Eydis’s voice escaped in a hoarse whisper.
She wrapped her arms around Justin.
“I am so sorry… sorry… sorry…”
Justin gently lifted Eydis off him.
“I said I don’t want your apologies.”
Eydis’s head hung low.
“Eydis.”
She looked up at Justin.
He was no longer afraid.
His face was rigid from suppressed anger, but his deep blue eyes expressed honest concern.
“Talk to me.”
Eydis nodded slowly.
She wiped the tears from her eyes, but more fell.
With a hoarse voice, Eydis told her story.
“Princess Eydis created me almost a year ago, maybe ten years in your time…”
She explained how she was raised to believe she was the Amelian Princess in order to be a body-double for use in emergencies.
She told of the fall of the Amelian Empire, of Jethro, and with bitterness and pain, she recounted her struggle with the Alukah and how she found out what she was.
She continued with her reluctant agreement to help Jethro, recounting with anger how she met and saved Rynn from Austin, and how she came to Justin’s world.

Her heart choked out painful tears as she hid nothing from Justin about capturing the princess, her abuse, and how because of her nature as a doppelganger, she pushed the princess near death, that the princess was going to die.
“But… because of Rynn, Sammy, and you, I realized that was not who I am.
I wanted to make everything right, but I was scared.
I did not want you and Sammy to find out what I was.
I did not want you to fear me, so I decided to do everything I could to save Eydis.
I planned to tell her everything and then let her go back where she belongs.
I would then leave the city with Rynn.
You and Sammy would never know about me.”
Eydis gazed at Justin with yearning in her red and swollen eyes.
“I love you, but I cannot lie to myself.
I can never be with you.
Not after everything I have done.”
Justin sat silent with his head hung low.
Eydis could not see his expression.
Her tale overwhelmed him.
She slid next to the true Eydis.
“I cannot recover my own ven like she does, so I could not help her much, but because of you, I have plenty.
I will use it all to try and help her.
I should, after what I did to you.
It is your ven, not mine.
She will recover after that.
I hope.
She is already recovering slowly, and this should help.
I will let you take her, but please… please do not tell Sammy about me.
I do not want her to hurt because of me…”
Eydis placed her hand on the princess’s forehead.
She used life magic to help boost the princess’s natural healing, the magic now far more potent than her previous treatments over the past few days due to her excess of ven obtained from Justin.
With this, Eydis hoped that the princess’s body would stop converting its vital ven to sustain itself and allow the princess to slowly leave the critical levels, making her healthier.
She was only able to heal a little before sharp pain wracked her nerves far stronger than the constant ache.
Her stomach grew nauseous.
Eydis quickly turned aside and vomited.
Justin rushed to the princess’s side, not caring for Eydis’s sickness.
“What happened?”
Eydis recalled when the princess nearly killed her with life magic.
Did Eydis attack me?
Is she conscious enough?
No, this is different.
Eydis placed her hand on the princess’s forehead and attempted to read her vitals.
Intense pain and nausea returned stronger than before, causing Eydis to wretch.
Impossible.
“I… I cannot use magic.”
“Did I just hear you can’t use magic?
My English is quite bad.”
A minum looked down at them from between the wooden beams at the top of the steps.
“Is that a minum?” .
Justin quickly covered the princess when fear replaced his surprise
“Of course, I couldn’t use it anymore either because I spent too much in that little experiment with your pet sprig.
Had to sit and rest a bit.
I’m surprised you didn’t evacuate this place while I was gone.”
How could I be so foolish?!
This place was discovered, and I came back here!
Eydis rose to one knee, but the minum waved his hand.
“Don’t get any ideas.
From where I am standing, I can just see into the bedroom where your sprig is sleeping.
My fire magic works by sight.
I can burn that room to ash in an instant.”
Eydis gritted her teeth.
“What do you want?”
“A trade.
How about the sleeping Forrest Elf for the sleeping High Elf?”
Justin’s lack of reaction showed that the princess had not taught him Elven.
He did not understand the conversation.
I just promised to give Eydis back to Justin.
What am I to do?
Even if his magic works by sight, he is looking at me.
If I charge him, he might have time to go to the room and kill Rynn directly.
If I can kill him with Jethro’s barrier magic, even if he sets fire to the bedroom, I should be able to get there before Rynn is hurt.
Eydis tried to channel spatial magic into her hand, but the excruciating pain returned.
She lurched over and her body throbbed.
Sweat streamed off her from the shock.
She could only stare at the floor that rapidly heated beneath her, unable to move or think.
The floor soon cooled, and no fire appeared.
“Scared me for a moment.
Looks like I heard right.
Spent all your ven healing your pet?
No more tricks.
You… umm…” The minum rubbed his forehead.
“That… girl?
To me.
Give me.”
He pointed at the princess and gestured for Justin to bring her to him.
Justin understood and pulled the princess closer.
“Like hell I’m giving her to you!”
The minum pointed out the cellar and lit a flame in his hand.
“That girl.
You give me!”
Justin realized Rynn was now a hostage.
The girl that Eydis cared for more than anything was being held in return for the princess.
He looked around the room for anything that could diffuse or delay the situation.
He held the princess close, and the chains binding her ran taut.
Justin grabbed the chains and shook them.
“These chains!
I can’t move Eydis with these chains!”
The minum shook his head.
“Monster!
If you don’t want your pet to die, unchain the princess.”
Eydis looked over at the princess.
Phlegm that regurgitated from nausea dripped from her lips.
The worst of the pain subsided, but the severity had been debilitating to the point of paralysis.
She feared to move.
She could barely think.
Only her eyes wandered over to a small, rusted metal box sitting on the middle shelf lining the wall.
It was the sole box amid many jars of preserved food.
Justin’s eyes followed Eydis’s gaze to the same location.
The minum also took notice.
“You!
That!” he ordered.
Justin set the princess gently on the blankets and retrieved the box.
He pulled out an incredibly thin, three-toothed key made of the same metal as the chains.
One by one, he inserted the key into tiny holes that ran across each shackle.
The shackles separated from the princess’s ankles, wrists, and the chain itself.
She was free.
“To me.
Give girl.”
Justin supported the princess’s body with one arm hooked under her legs and held her close to his chest with his other.
Her head rested limp on his shoulder.
Slowly he ascended the steps, and Eydis could do nothing but watch.
Justin,  I am sorry.
“No say.
Walk.” The minum waited until Justin passed before turning to follow.
“You should have never betrayed Jethro’s trust.
Consider yourself fortunate that he still has interest in you, otherwise you would be dead.”
After that parting warning, he vanished from sight.
I chose Rynn over Justin.
I chose her over my promise to him.
Eydis wanted to cry, but no more tears fell.
They had run dry.
The sound of a struggle and crash came from the closet.
“Eydis!
He set fire to the bedroom!”
In a burst of adrenaline, Eydis shot up the steps and through the closet.
Justin leaned against the wall in the hallway in front of the bedroom door.
He was in pain.
A charred and blistering burn covered his shin where the fabric of his pant leg burned away.
The minum clung to a toppled chair in the kitchen to pull himself off the floor.
An ear-splitting alarm rang to Eydis’s left.
The bedroom glowed orange.
Eydis ran inside to find the bed in flames.
She tore off the burning blankets and grabbed Rynn.
The thick covers insulated Rynn from the heat.
If Justin had not kicked the minum away, Eydis knew Rynn would have died.
“Stupid human!”
Justin dove into the bedroom onto his back with the princess in his arms.
A pillar of fire erupted from the floor where he was standing.
The hallway caught fire, and the billowing heat made Justin groan through his teeth from the burn on his leg.
Their escape was cut off.
The burning bed and blanket filled the room with smoke.
Justin held his shirt over the princess’s mouth and nose and searched for a way out.
He kicked Eydis to the other side of the bed and dove with the princess into the closet door.
Another pillar of flame shot from the floor where Eydis had been standing.
Justin had incredible timing and reflexes from his time magic.
A sudden realization came to Eydis.
The minum’s magic worked by sight.
He was in the room.
Eydis hooked her arm under the heavy wooden frame of the bed and flung it at the door.
Justin limped to Eydis’s side and to the broken window.
Still holding the princess with one arm, he unlatched the window and pulled it up, but it would not hold on its own.
He held it open and nudged Eydis with his knee.
“Go!”
Eydis climbed through and pulled Rynn through after her.
Justin lifted the princess’s legs, and Eydis pulled her the rest of the way.
“Justin, hurry!” Eydis screamed.
Justin lifted his injured leg to the window but dove away.
A fiery explosion blew out the window knocking Eydis to her back.
“Justin!”
Eydis left Rynn and the princess in the yard and jumped through the window, breaking the frame.
Justin lay on the floor struggling to lift himself.
Burns marked his arms and face.
She could not see the minum.
She grabbed him and was about to jump through the window again, but an explosion erupted right in front of her.
She jumped backwards by reflex with all her strength.
The wall behind her buckled from the force of her impact, and she rolled onto the gravel path on the side of the house while cradling Justin.
Even without magic, she was still strong.
For the first time, Eydis was grateful to be a Lurr.
Eydis called Justin’s name while carrying him over to Rynn and the princess.
He was mildly disoriented, but he found focus after she patted him on the cheek a few times.
A crowd of people gathered at the edge of the property.
There were panicked voices and strange accusations from those who saw the fire and that the girls were not human.
Eydis ignored them and called out.
“Please!
Someone help them!”
“Eydis, I’m okay.”
Justin separated himself from Eydis and picked up the princess.
He hissed through his teeth from the burns and nearly fell again from his injured leg.
Two men and a woman ran over to help.
The woman placed her coat over Rynn and picked her up.
She showed no fear of Rynn’s appearance.
Justin pulled Eydis away.
Fire shot up from the ground.
The crowd screamed and fled in panic.
He dove into Eydis and knocked her to the ground.
A second pillar of fire shot up.
“Take those two and run,” he shouted to the crowd.
The two cowering men listened to Justin and grabbed Rynn from the woman and the princess from the yard.
“You go too!
You are hurt!” Eydis ordered.
“You can’t use magic anymore.
I can still help!”
Justin tried to pull Eydis to the side, but his injured leg slipped on the slick grass.
Eydis kicked back and flung Justin into the air.
They barely avoided the fire.
She caught Justin in her arms and then pushed him towards the crowd.
He stumbled over his injured leg and fell.
“Sammy was right.
All you can do is dodge!
Go with them.
Make sure those two are safe, and do not let anyone touch Rynn’s horns.
Unlike you, I can still fight without magic.” Eydis’s eyes glowed red.
They were no longer the burning crimson embers of a monster but the radiant glow of a polished ruby.
“After all, I am a Lurr.”
Justin grimaced and hobbled toward the crowd.
“It’s dangerous here!
Everyone Evacuate.”
A man offered Justin his shoulder, and they followed the two carrying Rynn and the princess down the road.
Why am I not being attacked?
Eydis looked around, and her keen Lurr eyes noticed a strange blur moving in the dark along the edge of the property in the direction of the fleeing crowd.
The minum can turn invisible.
That’s why she never saw him in the assault.
Eydis grabbed a disc-shaped cement slab from the garden bed lining the front of the house and flung it at the blur.
Her aim was off, but it hit the ground and shot out dirt and debris.
The minum’s invisibility magic dispersed in the spray of dirt that knocked him to the ground.
Eydis ran at full speed to catch him before he could recover.
She grabbed his ankle and was about to tear him apart, but his leg grew an intense flame.
She flung him away towards the house to avoid getting caught in the fire and to separate him from Justin and the fleeing crowd.
He bounced off the roof and into the back yard.
The damage would not be fatal because of the minum’s incredibly light weight in this world, but hopefully he had a broken bone or two.
“I hate those wretched Lurr,” the minum shouted from the back yard.
Eydis jumped the overgrown shrubbery lining the back fence but was blown back by an explosion that destroyed the side of the house.
The windows of the neighboring homes shattered, and scattering flames set the neighboring houses ablaze.
The power was unlike the human mage she fought before.
This was the proper strength of the minum breed that could compete with the elfkind as equals in magic.
Her body ached, but she was not injured.
The pain could not compare to her attempts to use magic.
She only felt it for a moment until it was drowned out in her incessant, agonizing nausea.
Eydis ran back to the yard and found it empty.
She ignored the noise of the fire and focused on anything else that might give away the minum’s location.
The rustling of grass and leaves.
A snapping twig.
“The forest!”
The minum ran as fast as his small legs could carry him.
There was no way he could compete against a Lurr’s strength, and his ven was likely running low.
Eydis counted on this and pursued.
She saw him in the distance before long.
She picked up a large fallen branch and broke it into smaller pieces as she ran.
She tossed each one, but like the cement slab before, her aim was terrible.
The first shattered against a tree.
The other two flew the correct direction but far overshot her target.
There she saw it, the black portal that devoured all light entering it like a deep cavern in the night air.
She could not let him escape back to Jethro.
Eydis picked up speed and ran with all her might.
The uneven ground made movement difficult.
Her foot slipped on a patch of mud and sent her tumbling over the dirt and brush into a tree that shook heavily from the impact.
Air expelled from her lungs and would not return, but she couldn’t stop.
The portal was close, and the minum was nearly upon it.
Eydis ran once more despite her suffocation.
She aimed for the portal.
The minum glanced behind him in terror.
When she was almost close enough to grab him, the minum jumped in.
Eydis kicked off the ground to avoid the portal and crashed through the branches of a nearby tree.
She could not risk entering the portal.
It was made for the minum and him alone.
If she tried to go through, the portal may have collapsed and killed her.
Even if she survived, Jethro would be waiting on the other side.
She could not catch the minum.
Eydis wiped the mud and leaves from her face and looked back.
The portal was gone.

Chapter 15
“The End of Preparation. The Beginning of Action.”
“Close the portal now!”
Jethro immediately obeyed but did not show any concern.
“Are all your missions going to end like this?
At least you look far better than last time.
Care to explain?”
Fect brushed himself off and rubbed the large bruise on his cheek from bouncing off the roof of the house.
He felt justified by his aches.
“Mission successful, sir,” he announced with a wide grin.

* * *
Sammy was a nervous wreck.
While watching the morning news from a small-time local station during breakfast in her dorm lounge, she saw the reports of a demon setting people on fire.
Anyone else would have questioned the validity of such an absurd report, but she knew better.
Jethro’s men returned.
The news report cut to the helicopter feed of a police stand-off against what looked like a child with horns.
She immediately called Justin, but he wouldn’t pick up.
The child was shot on live television just before Eydis appeared on the scene.
The helicopter feed then cut out leaving both the newscaster and Sammy stunned.
Justin called back in not too long, stating that he was with Major Wickenny on his way to the location, but that was the last she heard from him.
For the rest of the day, Sammy called Justin over and over, but he never answered or called her back.
She tried calling Sean, Chloe, and Miriam, but neither of them had heard anything.
She did not have Major Wickenny’s phone number either.
Any attempt to contact the police station was met with a denial of information.
She could only wait.
She skipped classes and stayed tuned to the news and internet as reports trickled in on the aftereffects.
Seventeen civilians confirmed dead with eleven more injured.
Five police in critical condition.
The military was called in to intervene and suppress the threat.
All the while, Sammy could not contact Eydis or Justin.
Finally, she received a call from Sean.
He was en route to pick her up.
Justin and Eydis were admitted to the hospital.
Justin was hurt and Eydis was ill and unresponsive.
“Have you heard anything else?” Sammy asked.
Sean shook his head.
“Major Wickenny did not know much, only what the dispatch and ambulance told him.”
Sammy fiddled with the zipper on her coat in a futile attempt to calm her nerves.
“We’ll be able to hear everything from Justin when we get there.”
The hospital was still in operation.
There was no other hospital for miles, and the hospital itself was rather large, servicing the surrounding farmlands and neighboring cities.
All the fire damage from the minum was secluded to the lobby and top floor of a single wing of one building in the hospital’s complex.
Sean pulled up to the emergency entrance and dropped Sammy off at the curb before parking.
Sammy ran inside and to the reception desk.
“Justin Hapfeld and Eydis FeAmel.
What rooms are they in?”
The receptionist looked up the names.
Her eyes narrowed.
“That’s the… I’m sorry, but no one is allowed to visit by orders of the police.”
“I know Major Wickenny!
I’m a part of all this!”
Sammy struggled to keep her tears of worry from falling.
The receptionist grew troubled but picked up the office phone.
“Just a moment.”
Sammy sat in the lobby and waited.
The receptionist called a second number and then a third.
With each new call, Sammy’s anxiety worsened.
Sean walked in and sat down next to her.
The anticipation and anxiety ate at Sammy as the minutes ticked on.
She continued fiddling with her zipper until it broke off the bottom of her jacket.
“Goddamn it!”
She threw the zipper across the room and buried her face in her hands.
Sean placed his hand on her shoulder to comfort her, but Sammy swatted it away.
“Don’t let Miriam see you doing that.”
Sean could only sigh.
“Sammy,” a voice called.
Sammy dashed to the reception desk.
“I have received permission to let you see them.
Is that Sean with you?”
“Yes it is.
What room number?”
The receptionist handed Sammy a slip of paper and pressed a button that unlocked the door beside the counter.
Sammy grabbed the sleeve of Sean’s jacket and yanked him through the door.
Sammy grew more and more frustrated with each wrong turn.
“Why do they make these places so confusing?!”
“Keep your voice down,” Sean whispered.
“It’s early morning.
Patients could be sleeping.
We could ask someone.”
“Do you see anyone to ask?”

They continued walking through the halls of the hospital trying to follow the numbers on the doors, but the hall they walked down reached a dead end before the door numbers increased to match what they needed.
Sammy fumed.
She crumpled the paper in her hand and walked back down the other direction.
At the opening to the hallway, a nurse waved them down.
“Are you Sammy and Sean?”
Sammy ran over to the nurse.
“Where is room 146?”
“It’s at the end of the next hallway down.”
“But those numbers are decreasing!”
“There was a remodel some years ago.
About halfway down the hall, the numbers jump up and continue from where this hallway ends.
Sorry for the confusion.
Make sure to tell the guards your names or they won’t let you in.”
Sammy thanked the nurse and pulled Sean around the corner.
She took the next right and hurried down the hall to a small waiting area with blue, padded benches.
A single door sat to the side.
Two fully armed military personnel stood guard on both sides of the door.
They not only wore their combat helmet and tactical vest, they were even holding some large rifle that Sammy did not recognize.
They looked ready for combat at a moment’s notice.
“We are Sammy and Sean.”
Sammy gave a haphazard salute and pulled Sean through the door after one of the soldiers nodded.
The large room contained three full-sized hospital beds and had room for a fourth.
The two beds on the left had their curtains drawn shut.
Justin sat up alone on the bed on the right.
Aside from a bandaged leg and some burns that did not look too severe, he appeared alright.
A rush of relief overcame Sammy.
He acknowledged Sammy and Sean but then returned his stare to the curtain across from him.
Sammy ran over and spoke in a loud whisper.
“What happened?” Her eyes scanned his wrapped shin and the oiled burns on his face and arms.
“I’m fine.
It’s only a burn.
I don’t need a graft.”
“A graft,” Sammy repeated in panic, staring at his bound leg.
Justin would not have brought up a graft unless it was serious enough to be considered by the doctors.
“How bad is it?”
“I’m fine,” Justin repeated.
“I just have the burns and a concussion.”
“And Eydis?”
Justin nodded towards the bed across from him.
Sammy peeked behind the curtain.
Her hand rose to her mouth.
Her gut sank, and her breath grew short.
“What happened?
She looks terrible!”
Justin’s head hung low.
Sammy ran back to his side and grabbed his arm.
“Tell me everything!”
“Sammy…” Sean pulled Sammy away from Justin.
“Is it something you can’t tell?”
“I don’t give a damn.
I need to know!”
Sammy’s eyes welled with tears.
“She’s my friend too!”
Justin’s hands balled into fists.
“It was life magic,” he finally said.
Justin explained how Jethro’s men had sent an innocent girl to this world in order to frame her as an enemy and get the police and military to attack.
Their goal was to draw Eydis out of hiding.
Eydis fought back against the police in order to save the girl’s life but was forced to surrender once the military arrived.
Jethro’s men were still there but hidden, so Eydis used a random teleport to bring them to some empty house in the city.
Eydis used all her ven to heal the injured girl, but a minum that could use both life and fire magic found them.
“Eydis was at a disadvantage because she had to protect all of us without her ven.
The fight was noticed by the neighbors.
I don’t think that Jethro’s men want to be found because the minum fled once the crowd grew too large.
By then, Eydis had collapsed.
It was probably magic to make her too weak to resist capture.
I couldn’t carry both Eydis and the girl, so the neighbors helped us evacuate the area.”
“Is that bed over there…?” Sammy began.
“Yah, that’s the girl.
I think she might be a different kind of elf than Eydis, but Eydis never told me what she was.”
Sammy peeked around the curtain.
“She looks twelve.
How could they use a child as bait?
Is she okay?”
“I don’t know when she’ll wake, but I trust Eydis’s healing abilities.”
“Sammy, can I speak with Justin in private for a moment?”
Sean looked serious, so Sammy found it hard to argue despite not wanting to be left out of the discussion.
Sean and Justin knew each other far longer than Sammy, and as men, there may have been things that only they could discuss together.
Reluctantly, she left the room.
“Make it quick!”
Sean pulled up a chair next to Justin and spoke with a soft yet serious tone.
“What you told Sammy was a lie.
I was with Major Wickenny as the reports came in after you and Eydis disappeared.
Those that saw the fight said there were two people who matched Eydis’s description.
Tell me the truth.”
Justin was not surprised.
“Major Wickenny and Colonel Richards already spoke with me.
They have the general idea of what happened, but they agreed to keep it a secret within the police and military at my request.
What I told Sammy, can you treat that as the truth, please?”
Sean looked at Justin’s pained expression.
This was a conversation that he could not press too far, but he had to make sure.
“The one that has been with us since Eydis disappeared was an imposter, wasn’t it.
So much could be explained if that was the case.”
Justin did not answer, but Sean took his silence as affirmation.
“I don’t know why you want to keep it a secret, especially from Sammy, and I hope it’s more than to hide your shame or protect your ego, but I will trust you.
However, you need to tell her eventually.
She might already suspect it as Miriam and I did.”
Sean called Sammy back into the room, and their visitation continued, but Justin did not contribute much to the conversations.
Just before sunrise, Sean suggested they leave.
Sammy wanted to stay, but Sean convinced her to give Justin some peace so he could rest.
Sammy argued but eventually agreed and promised to be back later that day.
Justin was left alone once more unable to sleep and spent his waking hours staring at the curtain around Eydis’s bed.

* * *
Later that morning, the nurse gave Justin permission to sleep, but he was awoken only a couple hours later by the screaming of a girl.
The curtains had been drawn from the young elf’s bed, and two nurses tried to comfort the child.
None of the nurses could understand the words the girl cried, but Justin recognized it as Elven and was able to pick out a name from her screams.
“Rynn wants Eydis.”
One of the nurses heard and pulled the curtain around Eydis’s bed to the side to show Rynn, but Rynn only screamed louder.
She wanted the other Eydis, but he could not tell them.
Justin did not know what happened to the other Eydis after he fled the fight.
He did not even know if she was still alive or if she was captured or lying injured somewhere unable to recover if she still could not use magic.
He sat feeling helpless as he watched the poor girl cry.
“Wait… Stop!”
One of the nurses held gauze in her hands.
The left horn on Rynn’s head was bleeding.
“Don’t touch her horns!”
Justin stumbled out of bed and grabbed the nurse’s arm.
“Don’t touch her horns,” he repeated.
The nurse stepped back in shock, fearing that she might have done something terribly wrong or dangerous.
“We were trying to stop the bleeding.
Her blood levels are already dangerously low.
We can’t give her a transfusion because her blood is different.
We don’t know how her body will react.
She can’t risk losing any more.”
“Eydis is more knowledgeable about elves than any of us.
She told me to not let anyone touch her horns.
If the bleeding was an issue, she never would have said that.”
Rynn stared at Justin.
She was terrified.
Justin racked his brain to piece together the little Elven that Eydis had taught him.
She told him to focus on one thing at a time, feeling and expelling his toxic ven first, so the Elven he could convince her to teach him was limited.
Justin’s mouth hung open.
“That’s what was wrong!”
The nurses started in surprise at his sudden shout.
Rynn cowered, her budding tears about to fall.
“Sorry.
I just realized something unrelated.”
He returned to piecing together something in Elven and looked at Rynn with the most comforting smile he could.
“It is fine.
You are fine.”
Tears fell from Rynn’s eyes.
“Eydis…”
“Eydis is fine,” Justin repeated.
Rynn shook her head, pointed at Eydis in the bed next to her, and cried something in Elven that Justin could not understand, but he was sure he knew what she meant.
He stood between Rynn’s pointed finger and Eydis’s bed and shook his head.
“No.
Eydis.
Eydis is fine.”
There was a chance that the words he spoke were a lie.
All he could do was attempt to comfort the scared girl.
Rynn calmed down and nodded her head.
She understood.
She then collapsed back on her bed thoroughly exhausted.
Having lost so much blood, she could not have had much energy, especially not enough to fight against two nurses, being so small and light.
“What should we do about the bleeding?” one nurse asked.
“Can we wrap something around her forehead to at least catch the blood?”
The two nurses still looked concerned.
“I’ll do it,” Justin offered.
“I might have better luck than you.”
The nurses agreed and handed Justin a long strip of gauze and a rolled-up bandage.
When he approached Rynn’s bedside, she grew afraid once again.
“No.
It is fine.”
Justin unrolled the bandage and wrapped it around his forehead to hold the gauze in place, showing her what he planned to do.
Rynn watched intently.
“It is fine.
You?”
Justin pointed to Rynn, and she winced by reflex.
She struggled to sit up and nodded hesitantly.
A nurse handed Justin a new packaged bandage and a new strip of gauze.
When Justin reached over to Rynn, she cowered again.
She did not resist his aid, but she trembled with fear while Justin wrapped the bandage around her head as if even his proximity to her was painful.
He then requested more gauze, slid it carefully behind her horns, and wrapped it in place as well.
One of the nurses then leaned over and taped the bandages down.
Tears fell from the girl’s eyes when he finished, and Justin knew they were not of gratitude.
She was terrified.
Justin stepped back away from the bed hoping that would help calm her fears.
After Justin distanced himself, the young elf calmed.
Rynn felt her bandages and then wiped the tears off her cheeks, but she continued staring at Justin warily.
When the nurses helped lay Rynn back into her bed, they did not elicit the same terrified reaction.
Perhaps she was scared of him, and placing the bandages on was even more terrifying for her.
He should have let the nurses do it.
His cursed his arrogance in thinking that because he was associated with the fake Eydis, he would be better for the task.
Not wanting to trouble the girl further, Justin returned to his own bed.
He was still exhausted, and it was the nurse’s job to help her anyway.
“Can we check your bandages before you go back to sleep?” a nurse asked.
Justin sighed but agreed.
There was bleeding, and the burns stung through his painkillers, especially when exposed to open air, but the damage was far less than what could have been.
He kicked a minum in the face while that minum used sight-based fire magic.
He could have lost his leg or caught fire.
Seeing Rynn alive and resting in the bed across the room from him, he was glad he did it.
Once the nurse finished, Justin went back to sleep and slept through Sammy’s visit later that afternoon.
Someone shook Justin’s shoulder.
He turned to his side and ignored it.
The shaking continued.
“Justin.”
That voice.
Justin shot up and nearly hit the owner of the voice with his head.
The room was dark.
No nurses or doctors were present.
“You usually have a harder time waking up than that.
I do not have food to bribe you with this time, so I was a little worried.” The voice laughed dryly.
“Eydis?”
The fake Eydis sat at his bedside.
Her red eyes shined with a subdued glow.
Justin was filled with mixed emotions of relief, which surprised him, and sorrow that she was not the real Eydis.
“What happened with the minum?
How did you get in here?” he asked.
“Can I hold your hand?
I need to recover ven.”
“You can use magic again?”
She shook her head.
“But you couldn’t have gotten in otherwise.”
“Even though my ven is almost full, I cannot use it without a lot of pain.
If I can recover the tiny bit that remains empty, I can use magic with only a little pain.
Even now, I feel rather ill.” Her face in the dark looked as one who was in the worst throes of a terrible flu.
Eydis held out her hand, but Justin hesitated.
She retracted it and looked dejected as if she expected he would not help her.
“I think I know what is wrong with you,” Justin explained.
“You are not the first person this happened to.”
“You mean…” Eydis looked over at the sleeping princess.
Justin quickly corrected himself.
“No, two others, years ago.
They got sick just like you.”
The dark trauma of his past haunted his expression once again.
“That… that’s why I tried to stop you.
I didn’t want to hurt you.
After what Eydis--the other Eydis--has taught me and seeing what happened to you after you…”
Justin hesitated to vocalize her assault on him.
“Anyway, I think my ven is the problem.”
Eydis pleaded silently to Justin for an explanation.
“You have ven poisoning.
When my body recovers ven, some of it turns toxic.
It even harms me when too much builds up.
Every day or so Eydis would force the toxic ven out of me.
After she disappeared, and even when you took her place, the toxic ven was never removed.
It never even occurred to me to ask you to do it.”
“If you had, you would have found out fast that I was a fake,” Eydis replied.
“You can’t do it either?”
Eydis shook her head.
“If I could, I would be able to fix myself right now.
The control a Lurr has over its ven is severely limited.
I can convert it in order to use it just fine, but I cannot recover it or manipulate it.
As much as I tried, I could not give it to Eydis to help her recover.
I tried over and over again.”
“That means the only way to remove it would be…”
Eydis bit her inner cheek.
“I have to use it…”
Her body shivered at the prospect.
Justin knew how much his migraines hurt, but from how Eydis reacted when she tried to use magic against the minum, toxic ven was far worse.
Even the true Eydis had told him that using the toxic ven was “very, very painful” whereas extracting it was “much less painful.”
When she forced out all his toxic ven the night he had the migraine, he felt like he was dying.
It was the most painful experience of his life.
He could not imagine a pain that was much worse.
“That’s why I don’t think you should get your ven from me.”
Eydis smiled weakly.
“No, it should be fine.
I have been holding you and touching you all this time without any problems.
I only take a small part of what you are currently regenerating.”
“Then, you won’t take the ven that becomes poisoned by me.
Eydis said that good ven is always used first.”
Eydis held out her hand in pleading.
Justin hesitated but grasped it.
Her smile widened ever so slightly.
“I also wanted to hold your hand one last time,” she confessed.
Something sunk in Justin’s chest.
He unconsciously gripped her hand a little tighter.
“That means you are leaving the city?”
“No. One of the reasons I came here was to tell you that the minum got away.
There was a portal back to my world waiting nearby in the forest.
I am sure that is how they found Rynn.
It was so close to where we were hiding.
I will remain in Gullivan for now and look out for Jethro’s soldiers, but you will not see me.
Now that Princess Eydis is back, I… I no longer have a place with you.”
Justin wanted to tell her different, but deep down he had not forgiven her for what she did even knowing the circumstances that led her to take such harrowing actions.
He doubted that Sammy or anyone else would either.
“I should tell you this at least.
The police and military know you exist.
Sean also came to that conclusion himself.
Maybe Miriam too.”
“I thought Sean might.
He questions everything.
What about Sammy?”
“I haven’t told her.
I also asked Sean and anyone who knew to keep it a secret.
It all depends on what Eydis does when she wakes.
I will talk to her, but the choice is hers.”
Eydis looked across the room to the other Eydis’s bed.
She let go of Justin and placed her hand on the sickly elf’s forehead.
After wincing from pain, she returned and grabbed Justin’s hand again.
“Her ven levels are finally rising.
She is not out of danger yet, but she is recovering.
She is amazing.
I do not think a human could have survived what I put her through.
High Elves have incredible vitality, and she’s not even a Lurr.”
“Because of their life affinity.” Justin smirked.
“That’s what she says, so it has to be true.”
“Her life magic was the only thing keeping her alive.”
Awkward silence filled the room.
Part of Justin wanted to go back to when he believed this Eydis was the true Eydis.
He was happy in his ignorance, especially when his feelings for Eydis were returned by this fake Eydis.
But now that he knew the truth, he loathed his past self.
He was happy while the true Eydis suffered abuse at the hands of the one who shared in that happiness.
The part of him that was happy in his ignorance was also happy that this Eydis was back and holding his hand, but that feeling filled his heart with anguish.
He wanted her to stay but also wanted her to leave and to never see her again.
She hurt the woman he loved.
She forced herself on him without a care for his feelings.

If she had only given him the chance to tell her why he was so afraid, the trauma of his past… that he would hurt her too, he might have accepted whatever choice she made if she was willing to take the risk for Rynn’s sake.
No, he knew she would have taken the risk anyway.
That much was obvious.
His own trauma was the only barrier stopping him from willingly consenting after Eydis explained that she needed sex to recover ven quickly.
He was still angry, but he also felt guilty, part of him thinking that he was also at fault.
All this confusion was because he knew deep down that despite what Eydis had done, she was not a bad person, just misguided, confused, and desperate.
This tumult of feelings made his head spin and tied his stomach in knots.
He could not stand being in the same room as her, but not because he hated her.
He hated himself because part of him could not hate her.
“You said that telling me about the minum was one of the reasons you came,” he said to distract himself from his own conflicting feelings.
“I assume Rynn is the other?”
Eydis exhaled weakly.
“Yes.
I will take her with me, but I also wanted to heal you.
You got hurt protecting her.
I could not live with myself if I did nothing to thank you.”
She ran her hand over the burns on Justin’s arms and forehead.
When she touched his cheek, her fingers lingered briefly past the ebbing of the sting.
Justin pulled away the blanket and turned his left leg towards Eydis.
She unbound it and eyed the burn with sorrow.
She ran her other hand over his leg.
Her face contorted in pain while she worked on the severe burn and soon had to stop to recover more ven before her pain grew unbearable.
His skin healed and peeled, then healed and peeled again.
After a second break to recover ven, Eydis slid her hand over his leg one final time.
Fresh, pink, hairless skin that looked far healthier than the skin surrounding it covered his shin.
“It should look like the rest of your leg in a few days, but I don’t know if the hair will grow back.”
Justin was about to thank Eydis but stopped himself.
She did this to thank him or as an apology.
The awkward silence returned.
Justin understood that Eydis would need to hold his hand longer to recover enough ven to leave, but he also knew there was more she wanted to say but was not saying it.
Justin felt like he had to break the silence before it choked him, but he was saved by the rustling of a bed.
He pointed across the room.
Their talking woke Rynn.
Her quivering mouth opened, but Eydis spoke a single word in Elven that made her cover her mouth.
She cried in silence.
Eydis walked over and hugged the young girl.
Justin was relieved to have a respite from interacting with Eydis.
He laid back in his bed while the two talked silently in Elven.
He wanted to go back to sleep and let this dream or nightmare, which ever it was he was not sure, to end.
Only when Eydis sat back in the chair beside his bed did Justin reluctantly sit back up.
Rynn sat in Eydis’s lap, and the difference in their height with Rynn wrapping her arms around Eydis made Rynn appear even younger.
While in Eydis’s arms, Rynn did not exhibit the same fear of Justin she had before.
“I know it is a little late for this, but let me finally introduce you to Rynn.
She is a Forest Elf and the youngest daughter of the Amelian Palace’s master chef.”
Eydis whispered something in Rynn’s ears.
“Nais doo… meed… yuu,” Rynn repeated.
Her pronunciation was terrible, but that only made Justin smile wider.
Traditional Elven had no hard consonants, so the T’s might have been hard for her to pronounce.
“Nice to meet you, too.”
He searched his mind for an Elven greeting.
“Hanem-si-Justin-valeim.”
Eydis snickered.
“Too formal.
I did not know you spoke Elven.”
Even though Eydis laughed at him, Justin did not mind.
“Eydis taught me a few basics but nothing more.
If you don’t mind me asking, why did you warn me not to let anyone touch Rynn’s horns?
Is there something dangerous about them?”
Eydis’s fingers caressed the base of Rynn’s right horn, and Rynn quickly pulled Eydis’s hand away.
“The way a Forest Elf’s horn looks after it peels naturally is seen as beautiful.
Interfering with them while they peel can ruin the final appearance.
She does not want anyone to touch them, and I also want her to grow into a beautiful adult.
Once they finish peeling, she will be considered a fully grown adult woman in Forest Elf society.
She is two and a half years old.
If I compare her to a human girl in this world’s years, she would be about thirteen or fourteen years old and the horns will finish peeling when she is fifteen or sixteen, maybe?
She’s actually older than me,” Eydis chuckled.
Sammy guessed that Rynn was twelve.
With Rynn sitting in Eydis’s lap, Justin had the impression that she was closer to ten.
He never imagined that she was equivalent to a teenager.
“She will then be able to find herself a man and start a family.”
That last remark took Justin by surprise.
He had a bad feeling.
Eydis’s eyes glistened.
“We plan on staying in this world, so Rynn will eventually choose a man from among the humans of this world.
I have done too much that is… unforgivable, but Rynn is innocent of everything.
I know you already have Sammy and Eydis, but once Rynn comes of age, I cannot think of a better man for her than you.
You are not only kind, brave, and thoughtful, but you are also very accepting of our kind.”
Justin was at a loss for words.

“She is incredible with housework, has a water affinity which helps even more, and because she is the daughter of the master chef of the palace, she will be incredible at cooking, too, once she grows accustomed to the food of this world.
She is already very skilled with what supplies she had at that house.
She also has a really long tail, but I guess you already saw it.
Do human males in this world even have tail preferences?
And if you do not like the scar, I might be able to talk her into letting me heal it if it will give her a better chance at a happy life.”
Eydis was like a mother trying to arrange a marriage for her beloved daughter.
Rynn on the other hand looked confused as she switched glances between Eydis and Justin.
It was clear to Justin that they had not discussed this beforehand and that Rynn had no idea what Eydis was talking to him about.
“Hold on.
Hold on.
You are moving way too fast.
A year of age for elves is like ten or more for humans, right?
That’s still a long way off.
And have you even talked with her about it?”
“Elves mature faster when young, so she may be ready in four or five of your years.
I know I might be rushing this, but I want what is best for her more than anything and everything.
I am begging you to please at least consider the possibility of taking her as one of your future wives.”

Legality and social stigma against polygamy aside, Justin had long promised himself to never be in another relationship, and he felt even more committed to that promise knowing that he broke it by starting a relationship with the imposter of the woman he loved.
Now that same imposter was pushing Rynn on him.
How do I even respond?
Eydis did not wait for a reply.
She lifted Rynn off her and stood.
Her formerly glowing face when talking about Rynn grew solemn, almost remorseful.
“I have said everything that I came here to say.
I will keep watch out for Jethro.”
Justin’s bed shook.
Eydis hunched over and used the bed as a support.
Sweat beaded and dripped from her face.
Rynn grew concerned and spoke some words in Elven.
Once Justin was certain Eydis would collapse and almost reached over to grab her, she tore open a portal in the air at the end of Justin’s bed.
He could see the nearly empty hospital parking garage.
After a few breaths, Eydis recovered, but the pain of creating the portal remained on Eydis’s already anguished face.
“Making… a portal…for two… was harder than I… expected,” she said through haggard breaths.
Eydis righted herself but hesitated to walk through the portal.
Justin grew tired of her reservation.
“There is something else you want to say.
What is it?”
Eydis froze.
“Eydis.”
“Do you like my eyes?
It is a bit tiring, but I am keeping them red.
They are the only part of me that is different from Eydis, after all.”
Justin grew annoyed.
That’s not it.
“And there is something else I regret.
I feel I need to confess it to finally have peace.
Tell the police to check the freezer in the basement of that house.”
Annoyance turned to anger.
That’s not it!
“You said that you did not want my apology.
You wanted an explanation.
Now that I have told you everything, I can finally say this.” Eydis gripped her hand over her heart and bowed herself low enough that her forehead touched Justin’s feet.
“I am so, so sorry for everything I have done to you and Eydis and everyone.”
Justin thought that her apology might have been the source of her reservation, but when Eydis raised her head, an even greater sadness and deeper darkness lingered.
He wanted to tell her to speak her mind.
I told you to talk to me…
Eydis forced a smile.
“Goodbye…”
Eydis walked through the portal with Rynn and closed it behind her.
She ached from the void in her heart.
The emotional pain was more agonizing than her ven poisoning.
She wanted to beg Justin to let her stay.
She wanted him to tell her not to go.
But, she knew that would never happen.
It could not happen, and she knew she had no right to ask that of him.
Eydis fell to her knees and cried.

* * *
Fect stood in a chair set at the head of a large table of a meeting room on the second floor of the palace.
Dim morning light glistened between the half-drawn curtains of the crystalline windows.
Flecks of rainbow danced on a large fabric map pinned in the corners of the table by four knives.
The map depicted the city of the other world to the best detail that Fect could remember.
Fect did not draw the map himself.
The work was done by a professional High Elf cartographer under Fect’s direction.
Those attending the strategy meeting marveled at the detail produced in less than a day by a craftsman who had spent many times the lifespan of a human to perfect his craft.

In attendance were Jethro, Fect, and five veteran generals nearing or past retirement who volunteered for what they believed may be their last mission: General Vard, a noble-born human; General Hattn, an eleventh-generation human military officer; General Makstev, a dwarf who worked his way up from a nameless foot soldier; General Teppo, a minum and magical prodigy; and General Oyak, a fifth-generation human military officer and the only female officer in Tolmyur.
Jethro placed his hand on Fect’s shoulder.
“Let us begin.”
Fect jumped onto the table and walked across the large map on his bare feet.
He held a black, red, and blue stone in his hand.
One by one, he drew three X marks on the map with the powdery blue stone.
The first was located further north of the city.
The second was on the road leading up the mountains to the east.
The final mark was in the forest on the southeast edge of the city.
“These are the three teleportation coordinates that Jethro has memorized.”
Angry voices whispered to each other due to the informal way Fect referred to their Commanding General.
Fect did not hold a military rank and was no more than an expendable foot soldier who was attending the meeting only to relay information.
Jethro raised his hands to silence the room.
Unfazed, Fect continued.
“As you can see, these three locations are on the east side of the river bisecting the city.
The highest probability is that our target is located here.”
Fect walked over to the other side of the map and thrust down a very thin dagger designed for use as a marker for locations of importance on maps.
The dagger was sharp at the tip but rounded on the edge.
On the small spherical pommel was etched a symbol meaning “primary.”
“And that is?”
“A medical facility, General Makstev.”
The dwarven general stroked his beard.
“And you are certain that the princess will be there?”
“It is the most probable location.
To my knowledge, this is the only medical facility in the city.
The size would suggest there is no need for another and that it services other regions outside the city as well.
The population of the city is not so ill that it would warrant a medical facility of that size.
The doppelganger that Jethro sent over succeeded in severely weakening our target.
To my eyes, she was no different than a corpse.
She was given into the hands of the humans, and the medical capabilities of that world are very limited, much like our own back in Tolmyur.
I expect her to be there recovering for a prolonged time.”
“If the princess was before you, why did you not capture her?!”
Accusatory voices sounded around the table.
“With all due respect, General Teppo, I tried.

Even with your three elemental affinities, how would you fare in combat against a doppelganger of the genius princess who is capable of using magic taught her by Jethro while simultaneously trying to take that Lurr’s prey?”
The minum grew silent as did the other generals.
“And the other possible locations?” General Oyak asked.
Fect stabbed another dagger into the center of a complex of large and spaced structures.
The symbol on the pommel read “secondary”.
“This is an educational complex.
The princess worked as an instructor here and taught both combat and possibly magic.
If she has recovered, we may find her there.
The final location is more troublesome.”
Fect grabbed five daggers that read “tertiary” from the side of the table and thrust them into locations along the river.

“When I was secretly monitoring the doppelganger’s movements while she was working with us, I heard from her discussions with Austin that the princess lived with a man along the river, but I never discovered where.
She ignored orders and teleported around the city, so I could not follow her.
These five daggers represent the five residential districts bordering the river.
Four of them are quite large.”
“Then the plan is to send our strongest forces to the medical facility and a secondary force to the school.
We can then handle the residential districts the same as we did here in Amel and the early fairy cities.”
Fect shook his head.
“Jethro is unable to do that.”
“Who are you to say what is and is not possible for our Great Commanding General!
Know your place!” General Makstev drew his sword, and angry voices berated Fect.
Jethro raised his hand once more to silence the generals.
“Fect is correct.
I was personally involved with the Amel invasion and many of the fairy cities at the beginning of the Vallen campaign.
However, I cannot accurately send someone to a location unless I have personally been there or have otherwise seen it.
Take a look at this.”
Jethro removed a sheet of parchment from his robe and slid it across the table.
The generals were amazed by not only the quality of the parchment but also the painting on it.
The face looked nearly identical to Jethro with other smaller faces on the bottom displaying modified hairstyles and beards.
“Fect returned with this from his latest mission.
The city knows who I am.
If I go to that world to assess the precise locations to teleport our soldiers, I would likely be spotted.
The city would go on high alert and the princess would be hidden or removed.
The matter could change if I arrive with you in the city and then sent you from there, but for now, that is not possible.”
“So, my Lord will not be taking part in the siege?”
“No, General Hattn.”
The generals grew silent, so Fect continued the meeting.

“Because our three known teleportation locations are on one side of the river and there are only three bridges across the river to our primary and secondary targets, our movements from that side are limited.
With Jethro’s help, I will find two more locations on the other side of the city for us to use.
Due to randomization, I cannot tell you the exact location these coordinates will be, but we will try to set them here and here.”
Fect drew two large circles with the blue stone in the northwest and southwest.
There were five generals and five locations marked in blue.
The generals quickly understood the plan.
Fect then drew four X’s on the map using black charcoal.
“These are the tallest buildings in the city.
No matter where you are, you can see them and use them to orient yourself.
As you can see, the topmost building is at the educational complex, making it easy to locate.”
“What of the city’s forces?
Do we know a number or makeup?”
Fect removed a string with a loop tied on one end and then tied the other end to the waxy red stone.
“We cannot use our concept of military and force when thinking about this world.
From what I have seen, they are few in number but are individually powerful.
This is mainly due to their weaponry.”

Jethro produced the small handgun and set it on the table while Fect explained the fighting strength of the weaponry he saw as well as the weakness to fire that all the carriages had, including those used by the military.
“Due to their small numbers and lack of organized patrols within the city, there is a delay in their response.
I can only estimate this time from the speed I have seen their carriages move on their fastest highways, but it gives us a range of action something like this.”
Fect looped the string around the handle of the dagger pinned into the medical facility.
He then wound the string around the red stone until it held the proper length and drew a large red arc.
The wax slid smoothly along the fabric to create a distinct line.
“From the time I first attacked someone at the medical facility until the large majority of city guards arrived, I would place their initial location somewhere near the edge of this circle.”
Fect then repeated drawing another large arc in the southeast side of the city using a longer string length.
“When I attacked here, the response time was longer, making me think the large part of their force was about this far away.”
There was a location where both arcs neared each other.
Fect pinned a dagger with a red pommel at that spot.
“Two reference points are not enough to be certain, but if I had to guess, the main body of the city guard is stationed somewhere near here.
As you can see, it is closer to the medical complex than the educational complex or river.”
“In all your time in that world, you were unable to locate the headquarters of the city guard?
What was the scout team doing,” General Vard asked, rather exasperated.
“I saw their distinct carriages from time to time, but I had no idea those were guards and did not learn until my escape from the medical facility.
The culture of the other world is far too different from ours.”
“Now that you know, can you remember any location where these carriages were stored?” General Makstev followed.
“It would be quite substantial to hold the numbers stated in your reports.”
“Most of the buildings are large, and the city has both aboveground and underground mass storage locations for their carriages.
I never saw one with the police carriages inside, so its entrance must be sealed or secluded.”
“If the general public had access to them, that would be problematic for the guard,” General Vard thought vocally.
“I understand.”
“Then this ends my briefing of the other world, but I am able to answer any further questions you have.”
Fect walked off the table and sat back down at the head while Jethro stood beside him.
This unnerved the generals, but they continued the strategy meeting in a professional manner.
The planning took most of the day, and Fect was thoroughly exhausted by its conclusion.
Jethro dismissed the generals and left the room with Fect.
He looked down at Fect and saw him shaking.
“A bit much for you?”
“No sir.
I am just not used to it,” Fect replied honestly.
“You should know that their outward hostility towards you was all an act.
You did well not to lose face or yield to them.
They will remember your composure and be more accepting of you.
And you will become more accustomed to these sorts once your promotion to Captain becomes finalized.
I would have liked to give you a higher position for the work you have accomplished, but I need you to stay active in the field and behind enemy lines, at least for now.”
“No. It is an honor I am unworthy of.
How long until you know if you can join us in the siege?”
“That depends on Emer.
Inverting the coordinates of the origin and destination is far more complicated than just swapping the two.
It is more akin to turning a person inside out and expecting them to continue living as if nothing changed.
Creating a new formula from the destination to return to the origin is far easier, but we still do not know where our world is in relation to that one, so that option is impossible.
I cannot go to another world until I am certain I can return this time.”
“Why not wait until Emer finishes?”
“Why would you think not waiting is best?”
Fect stopped walking to think.
Having come to an answer, he continued after Jethro.
“We do not know when the princess will recover or if they will move her out of the city.
The sooner we act the better.”
“Precisely.”
“Is there anything you need me to do in preparation for my mission?”
“I trust you enough to be able to prepare what is needed.
However…” Jethro gazed out the window at the palace courtyard and Temple of the Gods glistening golden red in the sunset.
“If you feel you need assistance, talk with Penk and get him up to speed.
If he can learn everything about the other world as well as you know it, feel free to take him with as security.
I cannot risk losing someone of your potential.
It will take me two days to prepare the soldiers.
You have until then.”

Chapter 16
“Invasion”
“You can’t stay cooped up in here forever.”
Justin sat in a chair next to Eydis’s bed with a textbook in his hands and a notebook lying on the bed next to him.
The bags under his eye were the telling signs that he had been forgoing sleep.
“I want to be here when Eydis wakes up.”
Sammy folded her arms and looked up at Sean and Miriam to say something as well.
“Besides, this is the only place that the reporters won’t bother me.”
Rumors about Eydis being involved in something dangerous had spread around the university to the point that it became common knowledge to all the students.
When Eydis appeared on the news for a few seconds before the feed cut, gossip among the students exploded.

The news footage was seen by everyone within two days, and despite the police’s attempts to keep witnesses quiet, Justin’s involvement in the standoff and the fires in the southeast edge of town where Eydis was reportedly seen had reached the various news outlets.
Everyone wanted to know who Eydis and the demon girl were, how Justin was involved, and what actually happened that made the police and military want to silence it so desperately.
After a leak by the nurses that the demon girl disappeared mysteriously at night without the guards or Justin knowing, the press was in full force.
They waited at the university for Justin to arrive, and some even found his address.

Sammy, Chloe, Miriam, and Sean were accosted by the press at first, but once they explained that they were not involved in the incident and only knew what the news and police had already reported, they left them alone.
Only occasionally would someone new approach them and ask a few questions about Justin and Eydis.
“You will have to leave eventually.
I can stay and watch Eydis too.
You don’t need to shoulder everything yourself,” Sammy said.
“But she’s like this because of me.”
Because I didn’t recognize that other Eydis was a fake.
“He will need to leave soon anyway,” Sean said.
“He has a final in two hours.”
“Two hours?”
Justin looked up at the clock across the room.
He had lost track of time.
“That settles it.” Sammy pulled Justin up by his arm.
“Sean I am borrowing your car.
Can you and Miriam watch over Eydis?”
“Of course,” Miriam replied, elated.
“And I know there are extra beds in here, but try to keep control of yourselves.
You don’t know when a nurse might pop in.”
“Was that supposed to be a joke?
Who do you take me for?”
Sean shook his head lightly as he tossed Sammy his car key.
Miriam only smiled and waved off Sammy and Justin.
Justin raised the hood of his hoodie and tightened the strings to conceal most of his face.
It was a hot April day, and Sammy knew he would be sweltering in his thick hoodie.
She only wore a single layer.
Like her, Justin always felt warmer than most.
The hospital gave him permission to use a service exit instead of the main entrance to avoid any press who might be lurking around the hospital.
He stayed silent during the drive over to the university, and they arrived with an hour and a half to spare.
“I didn’t need to arrive this early,” Justin complained.
“Yes you did,” Sammy shot back.
Justin expected that Sammy wanted to account for possible students and reporters who might spot him, but that was not the case.
The campus had few students wandering the pathways due to finals week in session.
Sammy skillfully led Justin around less used routes, and they only crossed one student.
Sammy held a finger to her mouth, and the girl nodded and acted like she never saw Justin or Sammy.
Sammy led Justin into a building on the older side of campus and up a floor to a rarely traversed foyer.
“Wait here.”
Sammy ran off down the hallway.
Justin hunched over on the couch to hide his face from anyone who might walk by, but he was sure no one would.
It was a foyer that he and Sammy knew well, the same foyer where they first met.
This was also the foyer where he instructed Eydis to wait after her first English class at the university, where Eydis also first met Sammy.
Ten minutes later, Sammy returned with two cups of coffee and handed the larger of the two to Justin.
“There are a couple more shots of espresso in it.
Take this hour to relax and wake up so you don’t fail your test.
I know it will be hard, but I forbid you to think about Eydis until your final is over.
This is your only final because your other was a paper, right?
And knowing you, you probably need to get at least a B on it to pass the class.”
“B-minus.”
“See? So take a deep breath and caffeinate yourself.”
Justin took a sip of the coffee.
It was a tad too bitter.
Sammy tended to be a little abrasive, but she was soft-hearted and had always been rather considerate when needed.
Times like today made Justin miss the year they had been dating.
“I know you already have others like Sammy.”
Had… Justin corrected the fake Eydis in his mind.
Sammy backhanded Justin’s arm.
“You were thinking about Eydis just then.
Stop.
If you need to take a quick caffeine nap to clear your mind, I can wake you up in a half hour.
Feel free to use my lap if you need to.”
Justin downed half the cup and set it on the floor.
“A nap is probably a good idea, but please spare me having to use your lap.”
Justin slouched down in the couch so that he could rest his head against the back cushion.
Once his eyes were closed, he fell asleep before even realizing it.
“Wake up.
You have fifteen minutes before you need to be in line for your test.” Sammy pulled Justin up off the couch.
Once he stood, the sleep left him rather quickly.
He felt like he had a bit more energy.
“Caffeine nap, huh?”
Justin followed Sammy to the testing center.
There were plenty of students in line who shot glances and tried to strike conversation, but he ignored them.
Once inside the door, no one could bother him.
Sammy sat on one of the many benches outside and waited.
After two hours passed, Sammy received a phone call from Dr. Shuman.
She looked to the northeast and saw whiffs of smoke.
Their greatest fear had become a reality.

* * *
Jethro walked down the central hallway of the Amelian Palace beside Emer and Keeya with an entourage of over two hundred High Elves following behind him.
The grand palace door opened to a crowd of soldiers standing in rank and file below the steps.
An eerie silence enveloped the crowd.
For such a large gathering, the breaths or coughs of the few should have been audible.
The small shifts in position should have created sound as the soldier’s armor rubbed.
But no, despite the one thousand soldiers packed together on the proportionately narrow walkway of the palace’s main courtyard, not a sound was made.
Five generals stood at the top of the steps beside an elevated platform.
General Makstev saluted Jethro and approached.
“The men have been briefed on their missions with their individual roles explained by their generals before assembling.
Many of them are still nervous due to being sent to an unknown world.
A few words of encouragement from you should ease them.”
“I know my soldiers’ mettle.
What you see as nerves is only the excitement of war.
Besides, I have never been one to speak before crowds.
I trust your words were sufficient.
Your ability to rally the soldiers is why I have given you command of the largest platoon and the key role of the siege.”
“Yes, sir.
I am honored to lay down my life for our cause.”
“Do not go assuming you will die yet.”
If even General Makstev believed he would die, perhaps the soldiers truly were nervous.
Jethro reconsidered.
“A word will not hurt.”
Jethro stepped up onto the platform, and General Teppo stood beside him to broadcast Jethro’s voice using wind magic.

The army of one thousand included several of his army’s most skilled magicians and fighters pulled from their former positions in the occupation of Amel, the campaign against the fairies in Vallen, and even from back in Tolmyur.
Jethro created this very small but powerful force because he could not risk failure here.
“Grand soldiers of our proud Tolmyur Kingdom!
The mission you are about to undertake is of the greatest importance in our destruction of our eternal enemy, the Amelian Empire.
The Tyrant Princess has fled to a new world where she believed we could not reach her.
Now she is hiding within the protection of the humans of that world.
Yes, your enemies today are your fellow brothers and sisters, but they have been corrupted by the lies of the elves, the same lies that labeled us as enemies of our world.
Make no mistake; the humans of that world will try with all their might to kill you.
Do not feel remorse, give them no quarter, and return with Princess Eydis FeAmel so that she can pay for her crimes and the crimes of her empire!”
Shouts echoed like the beat of a drum.
Jethro’s words marked the beginning of a battle that bridged worlds.
