“As masterful as to be expected of our Great Commanding General.” General Makstev and the other four generals genuflected with their left fist thrust at the ground beside them and their right fist across their chest.
It was not a salute but a posture used by military to show reverence to the king.
For a military officer to perform such an act to one other than the King of Tolmyur was the highest form of treason, but for Jethro it was the highest form of respect.
To many, Jethro was their king.
Jethro brought Emer to the head of the steps and called General Makstev.
“Bring your troops.
The mission starts now.”
General Makstev raised his sword, and 500 of the soldiers advanced up the steps.
A High Elf from Jethro’s entourage placed his hand on Keeya’s back.
Other High Elves grasped the arms of the first High Elf, and the elves behind grasped the arms of the ones before.

All the High Elves’ ven connected through each other to Emer while the kissiae shaman, Keeya, acted as a filter to prevent any intended harm to Emer from the comparatively weaker life magic of the High Elves.
The army of five hundred arrived at the top of the steps with General Makstev at the head.
“To victory!”
Jethro surrounded General Makstev with a barrier, and Emer sent the general to the other world.

* * *
General Makstev stepped off the empty cement foundation of what had once been a house used as a base for Jethro’s men.
Behind him, soldiers appeared in a flash of light one by one.
“Keep moving and do not hesitate.
If you remain at the portal exit, you will die when the next soldier arrives.”
A lieutenant remained at the exit to give instructions to the soldiers as they arrived and move them forward.
Makstev continued walking along the gravel road leading away from the house.
He could see the large city in the distance without a wall.
There were no towers or any external fortifications visible on the perimeter.
“Pure foolishness.
This is no siege.
Their lack of preparation will be their undoing.”
The sky spread clear and blue and a faint chill from the mountains followed the wind over the plains to ease the mild heat of the sun.
“Even the Gods of this world have given favor to our battle.”
Makstev turned to watch the remaining soldiers arrive.
They stood in rank and file at the front of the property, fifty to a squad and ten squads in total.
Each squad was led by a lieutenant for individual action when needed.
No captains were present whose role would have been to lead the men into battle while the general strategized and controlled from the rear.
This was an unknown world with many unknown dangers.
His final task was to lead them through the unknown as one of the most senior and seasoned of all Tolmyur, to fight and die with them.
He was proud of his men.
They did not show fear or surprise at the unfamiliar view before them.
Their faces were hardened.
“To our deaths!
March!”
Jethro had expressed his confidence in Makstev’s ability to not only provide for their victory but also survive; however, Makstev knew the truth of the mission given to him and his men.

In a battle where the strength of their opponent was still not fully measured, they were the sacrifices, decoys to lead the way for the other generals to fulfil their mission of finding and capturing the Tyrant Princess.
The army of five hundred marched at full pace.
Hiding was impossible among the fields.
The enemy would see their advance.
Show us what power your city holds.
Meet us in honorable battle!
What met General Makstev was not an army.
“Do they mock us?”
The march halted still distant from the edge of the city.
On the road ahead sat three of the armored carriages Fect had mentioned in the briefing.
No more than twenty men in speckled tan and black uniforms stood guard.
“No armor but helmets and fabric.
There is no honor in this.”
To Makstev, this would be another massacre like all the others.
For those who thirsted for battle, the Amelian Empire had fallen too easily.
But he still had a mission to perform.
Makstev faced his army.
“This city underestimates us!
Show them true fear!
The princess is ours for the taking!”
The thundering chord of gauntlet, spear, and shield sounded from the army, and the humans of the city responded not with weapons but with sound.
A voice echoed over the field, but neither Makstev nor his men could understand it.
“Earth mages to the vanguard!
Raise the walls!”
A line of minums, dwarves, and a few humans marched to the front.
They thrust their hand onto the ground in perfect unison and raised a wall of hardened earth that covered the entire breadth of the army.
“March!”
The line of earth mages split into two alternating groups.
Every other mage sustained and hardened the earthen wall while the next pushed it forward.
“Archers, ready!
Fire!”
A volley of arrows flew into the sky from the back lines, but they far over-shot their targets.
“Adjust aim!
Arrows carry further in this world!”
Under the direction of their lieutenants, second and third volleys were fired.
Rapid cracks and popping reached Makstev’s ears.
A minum signaler at the front signed that the wall was being attacked but the damage was insignificant.
The information on this world’s weaponry from the new minum captain was indeed vital, and Makstev began to understand why the Commanding General thought so highly of the boy.
The small projectiles fired from this world’s weaponry could not penetrate the thick wall of earth.
This mobile wall was the boy’s machination.
Earth mages were often employed for defensive walls in battle but never on this scale and never to lead a charge offensively.
This was a mark of genius.
“Your weapons mean nothing.
Mourn your misfortune of being born without magic.”
A faint white smoke wafted over the walls.
The signaler coughed and shielded his eyes.
The earth mages soon showed similar symptoms.
A burning object spewing smoke flew over the wall and landed near the front lines.
A second followed.
Any who ingested the smoke likewise fell into a fit of coughing.
The smoke was a heavy irritant.
“Clear the air quickly before it spreads!”
The few wind mages at Makstev’s command blew the smoke upward and away from his soldiers while the nearby earth mages buried the small sources of the smoke deep in the ground.
Captain Fect never mentioned smoke weaponry, but he expected his knowledge to be incomplete.
It was only one of the many unknowns he knew he would encounter.
In a world without magic, perhaps smoke weaponry might be effective, but such weak tactics served no greater purpose than to inconvenience his men.
His men recovered their composure quickly, showing it was not toxic.
A signaler on the wall unaffected by the smoke held up his hand and signed that the enemy was retreating.
“March! Double speed!”
The earthen walls thinned for ease of movement, and the soldiers picked up pace.
The speed prevented the archers from volleying their arrows, but they were now in range of the first structures.
Arrows were useless against brick and stone.
“Fire mages!
Draw those cowards out!”
Countless fireballs soared through the air and over the wall in trails of grey smoke.
Buildings burst into flame.
The screams of the populace wailed from the city.
Jethro, in his wisdom, placed the greatest number and most skilled fire mages under Makstev’s command.
Widespread destruction would draw the enemy from wherever they hid if they wanted to save their city from crumbling into a ruin of char and ash.
The Minum raised his hand and signaled.
Enemy reinforcements, double the number.
“Still too few.”
The army’s advance reached the first enflamed buildings.
Makstev was confident that no enemy could be hiding in them.
The walls became a hindrance in the narrow streets, but they had fulfilled their purpose in helping the army approach the city unharmed.
“We have reached the city!
Remember the words of your Great Commanding General!
Show no mercy!
Draw these cowards out of hiding.”
A small object flew over the wall and landed in the center of a squad.
The resulting explosion killed or injured a fifth of the squad.
Two more similar objects flew into the soldiers with the same destructive force.
“Wind mages!
Send them back!”
Although Makstev gave the order, no more objects flew over.
Instead, the minum signaled that the enemy was retreating.
From what General Makstev could see, about ten of his men had died with many more severely wounded, but no deaths were confirmed yet from the enemy.
Their opponent did have power.
“Hahaha!
Much better!
Now we have a fight!
Listen to your lieutenants.
Purge the streets!”
Fire mages rained a large barrage of explosive fire over the wall to create suppressive cover for the earth mages to drop the walls.
The soldiers flooded unhindered into the streets and alleys killing all in sight.

* * *
“That was the eighth carriage to leave.
How many do we wait for?” Penk asked Fect.
“We no longer wait.
General Makstev is attacking.
We must cut off their communication before the other generals arrive.”
Fect and Penk monitored what they believed to be the station of the city guard.
Jethro sent them a day early to scout it out, and as Fect predicted, it was located not much further north from his estimation.
He expected their mission to involve eliminating the enemy’s commander before they could gather forced and retaliate but was surprised when Jethro gave a different goal.

With the technological advancement of this world, the city guard could communicate orders to their forces and quickly respond to threats across the city; a tactic of which Jethro’s army was incapable.
Having seen the power of the communication devices and how rapidly the city guard responded when Fect escaped the medical facility, he understood the importance of this mission far more than Penk.
Information was the greatest weapon in war.
The two minums activated their invisibility magic and split up.
Penk headed to what they assumed was the headquarters or administration building, and Fect targeted what he believed to be the underground storage location for the carriages.
Penk waited by an entryway for someone to either enter or exit the locked backdoor.
It opened, and a hurried guard ran out, across the paved lot, and past Fect to the carriage storage.
Once Fect was sure Penk entered, he followed the former guard.
The stable for the carriages was just as Fect expected.
The entrance was small, but once inside, it grew larger than the lot above it.
Although he thought it a stable, a dock would be a more accurate label.
The machines were evenly spaced along the cement walls like boats at port.

Three thick-armored carriages were parked near the back, and about ten to fifteen of the carriages with the red and blue flares affixed on top, their lights dead, were scattered among the remaining lots.
Fect waited to give time for Penk to begin his attack.
He did not want the dock swarmed with guards.
Once enough time passed, he conjured pillars of fire from beneath the three armored carriages.
They exploded in a grand fireball.
One by one, he continued with the other carriages.
Two city guards appeared from a door to the horror of their vehicles’ destruction, and Fect engulfed them in fire before running through the door.
This was far too easy.
A guard with his handgun drawn in the narrow hallway noticed the blur of Fect’s invisibility magic in motion and fired.
Fect anticipated the attack and dropped to the ground.
An intense and concentrated ray of heat shot from his eyes into the guard’s eye, roasting the inside of the guard’s head instantly.
The guard collapsed, liquid fat and mucus draining from his nose and mouth.
Only two more guards remained in the structure holed up defensively in one of the back rooms.
Fect eliminated them without issue by setting the entire room on fire and ran for the headquarters.
He trusted that Penk had already finished.
Penk specialized in silent anti-personnel magic that became even stronger inside structures and other enclosed spaces.
A small fireball blew out the back door to the headquarters, and Fect rushed in.
He ran past two dead bodies and entered a large open office.
There was no sign of Penk--he already moved on to the upper floors--but the aftermath of his magic permeated the office.
Fect used wind magic to filter out the immense humidity near his head in order to breathe, and if not for his fire affinity, the heat of the air would have killed him near-instantly.
The skin of the people on the ground boiled and peeled right off their bodies.
Everything that could not stand the heat and moisture dissolved and crumbled, including the wall coating and ceiling tiles.
Penk was first and foremost a water mage, but he further increased its power with his aptitude for fire magic.
This was a level of silent lethality that Fect felt he could never match.
Fect ran for the stairwell door that had been blown open.
The second floor was in a similar state to the first.
One man clung to life and tried to crawl for the stairwell.
His eyes boiled and spewed out diluted blood.
Fect stabbed the man in the heart through his back to prevent him from sending out an alarm even if the probability of doing so was low.
He continued to the third floor where he found Penk standing over a body in one of the smaller offices.
“From the difference in his badge, I would say he was the Captain of the Guard.
Mission complete.” Penk handed Fect the badge that read Major P. Wickenny.
“This should slow any response time against the remaining generals.
Now we must determine if the princess is still at the medical facility,” Fect ordered.
“If she is not, we will send up the signal.”
Fect and Penk ran down the stairs and out of the station with their invisibility magic leaving a blurred outline around them.
A hand faster than Fect could see grabbed Penk’s head from behind and ground it into the paved walkway as the hand’s owner slid to a stop.
The High Elf looked at the red line of gore that was once half of Penk’s face.
She then lifted and inspected the intact side of Penk’s head.
“Not the one I was hoping to kill.”
Fect stared in horror at the red-eyed monster before him.

* * *
General Makstev’s assault on the northern side of the city began effecting the citizens.

The city was large, so much of the population was unaware of the dangers at first, but there were some who leaned on the side of caution, having seen the smoke rising from the northeast, and decided to evacuate, or at least travel to the Gullivan City Viewpoint in the mountains where they could better see what was happening.
The road to the east up the mountain gradually increased in traffic.
In a flash of light, an elderly woman with waist-length, silver hair tied back in a ponytail and wearing a studded leather tunic appeared on the mountain road.
A horn from an approaching metal carriage blared.

With a step to the side and a twist of her waist, General Oyak drew her bow with her shaking left arm and fired a wind-enhanced arrow at the side window of the carriage as it passed by close enough for her to feel the draft.
The arrow broke through the window unobstructed and passed through the heads of both driver and passenger.
The carriage swerved and collided with a metal railing bordering the mountain’s slope on the side of the road.
Oyak removed two arrows from the left quiver on her hip and fired them in quick succession at two more oncoming carriages.
Each arrow broke through the glass with the aid of wind magic and hit their mark.
The first carriage continued forward past Oyak, but the second swerved to the left and collided with another.
The clash of grinding metal roared from behind.
The carriage that had passed her collided with a much larger carriage, or perhaps what may be considered a wagon in this world.
The large vehicle jackknifed and slid downhill perpendicular to the road.
She ran at the vehicle and slid feet first underneath.
The large vehicle tipped over and stopped, blocking both lanes of the roadway.
No more traffic approached from either direction.
Panicked people left their vehicles and ran towards the wreckage to aid those caught in it.
Oyak staggered in her gait as she returned to the location the transmission sent her, making sure to stay a few feet clear.
One concerned man called out to Oyak.
She drew her bow to kill him, but a white flash of light blew away half the man in an explosion of gore.
A bearded giant wearing thin plated chainmail and brandishing a halberd stood in his place.
Those who witnessed the gruesome scene fled screaming.
“Lieutenant Borgrum, move from that spot unless you want to become like him.
Make certain the others who appear do so as well.”
General Oyak walked over to the large metal crate of the wagon and used wind magic to lift herself on top.
She looked down at the bizarre yet beautiful city that glimmered in the sunlight and at the smoke rising from the northeast side of the city.
“Tis a pity that this great land has fallen prey to the Tyrant Princess’s deceit.
I wonder if they can still be saved.” She looked back at her arriving soldiers.
“No, the city will be lost.
The greatest salvation we can give the humans of this world is to quell the elven corruption here before it can spread.”
The small force of fifty soldiers finished gathering.
General Oyak once again used wind magic to aid her aged body in jumping down from the metal crate.
When she landed, her head grew faint, and she fell backwards.
A large hand supported her back and helped her stand.
“Thank you, Lieutenant Borgrum.
The air is far too thin here.”
“Do not force yourself.
You are nearing six years old.
I should have been the one to clear the exit.”
“As strong as you are, you could not have stopped these carriages without magic.
My health matters little.
So long as our mission is accomplished, our lives are but a small price to pay.”
Oyak faced her single squad of soldiers made primarily of human elemental archers and giant spearmen wielding square tower shields the size of a full-grown man.
“We march!
By our Great Commanding General’s orders, kill all those in your path!
Purge this city!”

* * *
One-hundred and forty-eight soldiers stood on an evacuated road on the northwest side of the city.
Demolished vehicles and dead bodies littered the ground.
The destruction happened in an instant.
General Teppo and his men had appeared within the city on an intersection of two large roads only a short distance from the northernmost tower located at his target, the school.
Only two of their men were lost from collision with the metal carriages.
“We have been blessed by our Great Commanding General!
Only kill those who oppose us until we reach the school!
We march for the tower!”

* * *
General Hattn viewed his surroundings, slightly awestruck by the peculiar architecture.
Vast warehouses filled with wood, metal, and many unknown items and material surrounded them on all sides.
This warehouse district was vastly different than the structures towering in the distance.
The map of the city drawn from the young Minum’s memory was surprisingly accurate, at least to the positions of the towering structures.

He and his 250 men had appeared on the southwest edge of the city, and the tall buildings, which he had originally assumed to be watchtowers due to the young captain’s description of their height, stretched as if reaching the sky in the exact positions his mental map had set them.
The tallest of the structures even put the Amelian Palace to shame.
Hattn could see the smoke from General Makstev’s assault on the other side of the city.
He wished that he had been given the role of leading the assault.

Having come from a long line of generals, he thirsted for the glory that would come from dying in battle in a foreign world; however, he also knew that no one else could perform the vital role that his Commanding General entrusted him.
He was provided the second largest army and was given the task of searching the primary location, the medical facility.
He and his men could not afford to lose their lives.
Searching for the princess required him and his men to live while becoming a distraction required General Makstev and his men to die.
Hattn turned to his men who had just finished exiting the portal and now stood in formation.
“We have received the choice position from our Great Commanding General!
We march for the medical facility!
Earth mages, break up all streets as we march!
We cannot let them flee with the Tyrant Princess!”
The soldiers marched at a jogging pace through the warehouse complex and onto the open road.
Any vehicles that approached were flung to the side by earth mages upheaving the pavement or detonated by fire mages igniting the combustible fuel inside the carriages.
All the civilians who saw the carnage fled for cover, except one.
Hattn saw one man kneeling on the ground in shock.
In front of him, a tossed vehicle sat inverted with a large slab of pavement crushing it into the ground.
Beneath the pavement and metal was a woman.
Hattn ignored the civilian, but in the man’s anger, he removed an object from his hip.
Multiple loud pops echoed out, and Hattn watched six of his men crumble to the ground.
The civilians were armed!
“Archers!”
In an instant, five arrows impaled the man’s chest, neck, and head.
When the man was confirmed dead, an archer ran over to reclaim the usable arrows, but he was shot down from an unknown direction.
“In the window!”
One of Hattn’s scouts pointed to a window, and a fire mage blew up the side of the brick structure.
No more attacks followed.
One civilian killed six of his men.
If his scout had not seen the secluded attacker, no one could have followed the path of the invisible projectile.
Was that the strength of this city?
Was that why they felt no need for walls?
If every man he saw was armed as such, they would not survive until they reached their target.
This was vital information that the young Captain neglected to tell them, or perhaps the boy did not know.
The ranged weapons of this world were small despite their lethality and could easily be concealed.
He could have spent all his time in this city and not learned that the citizens were armed.
Normally, arming villagers or other civilians was an incredible waste of resources.
The thought had never even crossed Hattn’s mind.
It was impractical.

But with the quality of the architecture of this city, with the advanced machinery and weaponry these people possessed, the humans of this world could very well have the spare resources to arm the populous.
How many people were in this city?
More?
If he assumed a tenth of the city was armed, even at the smallest estimate, that was still ten times the number of soldiers his Commanding General sent to this world.
If one hundredth the city was armed, ignoring the city guard and military, that number still matched the strength of their armies.
The massacres in the Amelian Empire would not, could not, be repeated here.
“Assume all civilians are armed militia!
Be preemptive and kill anything that moves!
We must survive until our mission is complete!”

* * *
General Vard pressed his hand tight to his side.
His head felt light, and his body was quickly growing cold.
Behind him, numerous houses burned, the sign of their progress, but in the streets were the bodies of over half his 50 men.
“How could we be so… underprepared?”
The thunder of the weapons held by the citizens reverberated in his ears.
Another three of his men fell.
“Sir!
We must retreat!”
General Vard’s vision grew blurry.
The light was fading.
“Lieutenant, you have command now.
I underestimated our enemy…
That is my shame to bear… and I will take it with me to death.
This is where… that minum attacked.
I should have known… they would be prepared.
I should have expected a militia…”
The lieutenant’s face split in a mist of red from another unseen attack.
“We are done…
Forgive me… Lord Jethro, I have failed you…”
May I find myself once more in your care in my next life.
General Vard struggled to his feet using his sword as a crutch.
With one final call to rally his remaining men, he charged into the streets.
Fire, arrows, and ice flew over his head at the doors and windows of the houses.
A shot to his shoulder wrenched his back, and he twisted to the ground.
In his dark eyes he watched as one by one his men fell until all light left him.

Chapter 17
“Fear and Panic”
“Gullivan is under attack,” Dr. Shuman announced to Sammy over the phone in a panic.
“A large army is attacking from the north.”
The rising smoke on the northeast of the city that Sammy had taken no notice of earlier became a terrifying alarm.
She watched it with shaking hands, ignoring whatever else Dr. Shuman was saying.
The other students in line outside the testing center chatted among themselves completely oblivious to the dangers.

Perhaps some of them were worried as they looked at their phones, and a few pointed out the smoke rising far in the distance out of curiosity, but their anxiety could very well be due to their approaching exam, not an invasion.
None of them knew what was happening, or they would be fleeing.
Sammy hung up her phone.
“Everyone!
The city is under attack!
You need to evacuate!”
The line stared at her in disbelief.
A few students grew more nervous, but they kept their vital place in line.
They were not Sammy’s problem.
She gave her warning.
The one person whom she did care about was still in the testing center, oblivious to what was happening in the outside world.
She pushed her way through the line into the testing center to the check-in counter.
“What room is Justin Hapfeld in?!
This is an emergency!”
One of the campus security assigned to the testing center approached.
Before he could speak, she grabbed his arm.
“Put the campus into lockdown immediately.
Better yet, evacuate the campus.
Dr. Ryan Shuman will vouch for me.”
Those who heard Sammy talked worriedly among themselves, and a few students left their lines.
“Justin is in testing room six,” the receptionist answered, slightly flustered.
Sammy ran through the door, and the security officer chased after her.
“Is there a gunman on campus?”
“Worse.
The city is under attack.”
“This isn’t a time for jokes.”
Sammy turned to face the officer and pounded her index finger into his chest.
“I wouldn’t joke about something like this!
Think about when those people died about a week ago but much, much bigger!”
She then ran to the sixth door down the hall and opened it.
“Justin!
Jethro’s army is invading the city!”
Justin shot up from his desk with enough force to knock over the empty desk behind him and push the rim of his desk into the back of the woman in front of him.
He ran to Sammy ignoring the complaints from the proctor and the profanity spewed at him by the woman, and she pulled him down the hallway.
The Security officer was radioing in Sammy’s message, and she nearly jumped when the lockdown alarms roared in the hallway.
“Dr. Shuman told me over the phone,” Sammy explained.
“How did he find out?”
Sammy and Justin pushed past the scared students and exited the testing center.
“I don’t know.
We can see the smoke from here, so maybe he saw it from his office.”
Justin pulled out his phone and dialed a number while Sammy watched the student’s scatter.

The university never had lockdown drills, so there was confusion on whether the students should enter the buildings to hide in the classrooms like they learned in grade school or escape campus to somewhere else.
“Major Wickenny is not picking up,” Justin said.
“Of course not, you idiot!
He’d be swamped right now!
I thought you were calling Sean or something!”

In the brief time Sammy had been inside the testing center, the few plumes of grey smoke had grown into large dark funnels that billowed into the sky showing that the attack had grown immensely and would only worsen.
“This is bad…”
What do I do?
What do I do?
Sammy’s mind grew blank from unease and panic.
“Ah!” The vibration of Sammy’s jeans pocket made her jump.
The name on her phone read Chloe.
“Chloe! Jethro’s attacking the city!”
“I’m on campus.
Where are you?” Chloe asked.
“We’re here too.
Outside the testing center.”
“On my way!”
While Sammy explained to Chloe where they were, Justin searched his contacts for the number she had admonished him for not calling.
“Sean.
Jethro is attacking.
There is a lot of smoke on the north side of the city.
Inform the hospital and see if they can increase security.
We are on our way there… No, I don’t know when.
We are still on campus, and I think Chloe is going to meet us.
I can’t get in contact with Major Wickenny either… Yes, thank you.
We will.”
“Chloe!” Sammy pulled Justin over to Chloe, and he nearly dropped his phone, juggling it while she pulled him backwards.
“It’s bad,” Chloe said with a shaking jaw.
“There is smoke coming from west of campus too.
They’re close.”
Sammy saw the fresh black plumes rising above the campus buildings.
It was so close that she could see every bulging detail as it billowed into the sky.
It wasn’t there a minute ago.
How did they get here so fast?
Two large fireballs flew over the campus and collided with the side of the humanities building.
The small explosions sent glass and debris falling onto the campus grounds.
Screams erupted all over campus.
“They’re here…” Sammy cried.
“Sammy!
Justin!
Where did you park?” Chloe’s shout brough back Sammy and Justin’s attention.
Justin looked towards the direction of the smoke and screams.
“On the west side of campus.”
“We need to get out of here.”
Sammy grabbed Justin and Chloe’s wrists, but she could not hold onto Chloe.
Just touching her almost burnt her hand.
Steam wafted from Chloe’s clothing.
Unable to pull her friend along, Chloe followed Sammy close as they ran.
“Why are you so hot?” Sammy asked.
“I don’t know.
When you said Jethro was attacking, my body just heated up.”
The three ran south across campus through the pandemonium.
The few students who were there to study or take their finals fled in every direction.
As they neared the humanities building, Sammy saw a few injured students who had been caught in the falling debris ignored on the ground.
Then they appeared; a mob of medieval- or pre-medieval-armored soldiers ran through the campus.
They shot arrows and magic at anyone who moved.
The skirmishers drove their swords and spears through anyone they could catch.
The soldiers seemed impossibly nimble on their feet despite the weaponry and armor they carried.
No one could outrun them.
“Faster,” Sammy cried to herself and her friends.
From the corner of Sammy’s eyes, a man and woman running from the soldiers were engulfed in a fireball and crumbled to the ground.
“This can’t be happening!
God, no!”
“Sammy!” Justin pulled Sammy’s arm.
Something flew by her face close enough for her to feel it brush her bangs.
They stumbled together and fell to the ground.
Sammy looked to her left and saw an arrow protruding from the ground about twenty feet away.
Sweat beaded and fell from her forehead.
A group of five soldiers grew closer.
One of them hurled a fireball at them, the same that had killed the two students just before.
Sammy could not move.
She only stared at the death that rapidly approached.
Chloe jumped in front of them, and her sleeves burst into flames.
She lunged forward and clapped her hands in front of her.
An explosion of fire weaker than what she had produced in her demonstration during training erupted out front.
It caught the fireball and detonated it.
The heat of the explosion washed over them, but the force blew out sideways like a wedge had been driven between it.
“Hurry!
I can’t pull you up with my arms like this!” Chloe screamed.
Justin grabbed Sammy’s wrist and pulled.
Wasting no movement, they broke into a sprint with Chloe following close behind.
The group of five called more soldiers over to help pursue.
Two of them nocked arrows into their bows and fired.
Justin let go of Sammy and pushed Chloe to the side.
One arrow overshot, but the other traveled right past where Chloe’s back would have been, nearly hitting Justin’s outstretched arms.
Neither of them lost their footing and continued running.
Another fireball approached.
Chloe swung her arm out to release an arch of fire.
It had little force but traveled far enough to catch the fireball and detonate it in the air.
Unlike the wedge before, the explosion erupted towards them and knocked Justin and Chloe to the ground.
Sammy looked back at her downed friends and the eight soldiers who were quickly gaining on them.
Her body shook in fear.
In the deep reaches of her mind, something told her to run, to leave them behind.
They would be okay.
Justin could dodge attacks.
Chloe could fight.
But Sammy, she had no combat potential.
She could barely even hold a sphere of water steady.
All I can do is create water and swim and make things waterproof.
I can’t fight them.
I will just slow Chloe and Justin down.
I will get them killed!
Sammy took a step back, then another.
“Run!
We’ll catch up!”
Justin’s eyes pleaded for Sammy to flee.
Her heart sank.
She knew that if she fled, she would be the only one to survive, or perhaps with how fast the soldiers were, they would catch her anyway.
All her body told her was that she had to move.
Sammy’s legs broke into a sprint before she realized.
A firm ball of water grew in her hands.

She leapt over Justin and brought her arm back to toss the ball at their attackers knowing full well that it would be useless, but before she could release it or even touch ground, Justin grabbed her ankle and pulled down.
She lurched forward and fell face-first into the grass.
Two arrows nearly missed her head.
“What do you think you are doing,” Justin yelled.
“I can’t fight!” Sammy screamed back at him, her nose bleeding lightly.
“I can at least buy time for you two to get away!”
“Too late…” Chloe looked ahead, and she extinguished her arms.
Six of the soldiers surrounded Justin, Sammy, and Chloe.
They knew that at least Sammy and Chloe could use magic.
“Eydis where?!”
Sammy could not believe what she heard.
The soldier pointing his sword at her spoke in English.
“Eydis where?!”
In a world with no magic, only those who could use it would be connected to Eydis.
Both she and Chloe realized this far too late.
They could no longer hope to escape in the panic while the soldiers killed someone else.
The moment they used magic, they became priority targets.
Sammy looked at the tip of the sword with fear.
Words would not leave her mouth, and the hand that held the sword grew impatient in her silence.
He thrust the sword at her, but a tug on her hair wrenched her neck to the side.
The blade of the sword nicked her ear.
Justin then batted the flat end of the sword away with the side of his fist.
“No Eydis here,” Justin shouted back.
Sammy recognized the poor Elven that Justin spoke from what little she had learned.
The man smiled.
He held up his bloodstained hands in the shape of a red cross.
“Eydis here,” the man replied in English, a pleased grin spreading over his blood-speckled face.
He knew Eydis was at the hospital.
The other soldiers did not seem to understand the soldier’s epiphany.
Sammy lunged at the man before he could inform the others of his discovery.
If she was going to die anyway, if she could take down this soldier, then she could prevent this information from spreading and at least save Eydis and Miriam’s life.
He braced against the impact, but Sammy’s weight pushed the oddly light man back.
The two soldiers beside him grabbed Sammy and threw her back to the ground in the center of the tight circle.
A sword swung and a spear thrust.
Justin grabbed the spear with impossible reflexes and yanked it into the path of the sword, deflecting them away from Sammy.
The remaining soldiers brought their weapons down for the execution.
“Duck!” Chloe shouted.
Justin pulled Sammy to the grass.
Chloe’s upper body erupted in flames that exploded outwards in a powerful blast.
The six soldiers encircling them caught fire and flailed in burning torment.
Justin broke free of the group, grabbed a dropped sword as he passed, and thrust it into the stomach of the startled bowman who was about to send a warning flare into the sky.
The second bowman next to him nocked an arrow and fired.
Justin only had time to lift the sword into the path of the arrow.
The arrow nicked off the edge of the sword and cut along his shoulder close to his neck.
Before another arrow could be nocked, Justin ran and swung the sword, but an orange glow approached from the corner of his eyes.
He jumped back before a fireball engulfed the bowman, the fire clinging like oil.
Sammy sat stunned.
All eight soldiers had been defeated in an instant.
She then noticed the raging fireball beside her.
Chloe’s fire was not dying.
It completely engulfed Chloe’s upper body.
Chloe dropped to her knees and hunched over.
“Chloe!” Sammy produced water ball after water ball and tossed it on Chloe.
Each ball had little effect.
The heat was too intense.
Chloe began to scream.
She needed more water.
Using all the ven Sammy could gather into her hands, she forced it to condense and create water.
When she produced water, she channeled more ven into it.
It grew from a trickle to a spout, but it wasn’t enough.
She forced more and more ven until her arms ached.
The spout became a constant stream, and steam rose from Chloe’s bare back.
The fire weakened and the intense heat abated.
The flames died revealing light pink burns covering Chloe’s back, arms, and face, but they were no worse than a bad sunburn.
“Chloe, are you okay?!” Sammy asked.
Chloe shivered from fear and cried.
“I… I could not control it.
It was getting too hot.
I couldn’t stop it.
I thought I was going to die…”
The burns did not look severe, but Sammy knew that Chloe would have been terribly hurt if she had not doused the fire quickly, even with Chloe’s incredible resistance to heat.
Justin removed his hoodie and handed it to Sammy to help cover Chloe.
The hoodie was a loose fit on Justin from back when he was heavier, so it fit Chloe well enough, but she winced from the pain of the fabric sliding across her skin as Sammy helped her slip it on.
“We need to hurry.”
Justin pulled Chloe to her feet, and they ran off campus, Sammy leading while holding Justin’s other hand.
Sammy continually checked behind her out of fear that other soldiers might follow, and the longer she watched, the more smoke rose from the campus.
More people Sammy knew would be killed, but there was nothing they could do.
Her body shook, and it was then she noticed that the hand she held trembled far stronger than hers.
“I… I killed someone.”
It was not Justin but Chloe who spoke.
A cold feeling sunk into Sammy’s chest.
Both Justin and Chloe just killed multiple people.
Justin released Sammy’s hand and held his mouth.
He stopped walking.
A moment later he lurched over and vomited on the sidewalk.
Chloe grabbed her chest.
Her legs grew weak, and she fell to her knees.
Now that the adrenaline of their fight was wearing off, the emotional trauma of what had just transpired surfaced in both her friends.
Sammy looked at their struggle to cope with what they had done.
She was the only one unaffected, because she was the only one too weak to fight back.
Guilt ate at her and knotted her stomach.
She wanted to throw up just like Justin, but she needed to be the strong one.
She needed to help them through this.
Sammy gripped both their hands and pulled them to a run.
“You didn’t have a choice!
It was self-defense.
If you didn’t kill them, they would have killed us.
We have a long way to go until we get to the hospital.
We might run into more of Jethro’s army.
We might have to kill more of them!
If you are this troubled after that, we won’t be able to save Eydis!”
Justin coughed and spat out the sick in his mouth.
He wiped his face with his shirt and nodded.
“You’re right…
We can’t let them take her.”
Justin trembled despite his declaration.
He pulled out his phone and dialed Sean.
“The army arrived on campus.
We made it out but don’t have a car.
They know the hospital is one of the places that Eydis could be at.
You need to get her out of there.”
Sammy heard gunfire from Justin’s phone.
“Sean!
Are they there?!
Sean!” Justin shouted, but no answer came.
Sean’s phone cut out.

* * *
Pain.
Intense burning pain that felt as if Symra’s insides were torn to shreds.
Each breath gurgled from the blood filling her lungs.
Each cough shot out a spray of red mist.
The faster she ran, the harder she breathed, and the harder she breathed, the more she coughed up blood.
But she was alive, at least for now.
The vile human to whom she and her sisters in torment had been given never returned.
They lost their usefulness.
Jethro systematically killed them one by one in a teleportation experiment, and had she not taken the slim sliver of hope that presented itself when Jethro’s barrier broke, she too would have died.
So, she fled.
She fled until the pain and exhaustion broke her spirit and sent her collapsing to the ground unconscious.
An unknown amount of time passed in unconscious darkness without even a thought or dream.
Symra’s weary eyes opened and saw a majestic cerulean sky.
A small, almost translucent body fluttered above her and then disappeared letting the bright rays of the sun assault her eyes.
One arm rose to shield her eyes from the blinding light, but the small movement sent snaking pangs throughout her body.
Her muscles were tense and ached, her mind was clouded, and her body temperature was high.
Anyone else would assume they were ill, but for a Mountain Elf these symptoms came from a physiological safety mechanism unique to them.
“I… hibernated?”
When a Mountain Elf’s body came under extreme physical trauma, it was forced into hibernation to recover.
The length of the hibernation changed depending on the amount of damage and strain on the body.
Even if an inch from death, hibernation could preserve the life of a Mountain Elf.
This ability developed due to the near-inhospitable habitats of the ancient Mountain Elves; arid lands and treacherous mountains where food was scarce and the physical toll on the body was high.
Symra sat up.
Sharp rocks stuck to her back where they had slowly dug impressions over time.
She brushed off the rocks one by one while she gazed at the otherworldly scene before her.
She sat inside a rocky crag between two spindly bushes.
Outside, a vast and majestic city spread out from the base of the mountain on whose slope she sat.
Golden sunlight reflected off glass and metal buildings that stretched up as if desiring to reach the mountain’s heights.
The scene would have been breathtaking if not for the smoke rising from the four corners of the city.
This was the city Jethro targeted.
This was the city where Her Highness was hiding.
Jethro was here with his armies.
This was an invasion.
No matter her injuries, she had to act.
The largest concentration of smoke rose from the north side of the city.
Fires were plentiful, and as she watched, new fires grew.
The largest force was located there.
A diversion.
In a search operation, the attackers drew most of the city’s forces as far from the suspected location of their target as they could.
The only question then was which of the other forces was the primary force.
A battle unfolded on the highway leading up the mountain a fair distance from where Symra sat.
A small force of soldiers fought their way into the city.
The army was far too small.
A supplementary force.
The fires to the left on the mountain side of the river were few and did not appear to grow.
The damage almost looked like it was being suppressed.
In her cloudy memory, Symra felt that she had fled to the mountain from that direction.
Jethro must have used the same coordinates for an attack, but there were likely no more soldiers there.
A supplementary force that failed.
On the opposite side of the city, the second largest concentration of smoke rose into the sky.
The number of soldiers there would be high, but something felt off.
That was too close to the diversion force.
If that was where they believed Her Highness was located, they would have sent their diversion force to the failed location.
And given the damage, they had not located Her Highness yet.
She was not there.
The final location on the far side of the city had little to no smoke, the level of which would not look all that peculiar rising from a large city, at least in her world.
However, the small wisps of smoke grew in a line.
As Symra watched, another new plume rose.
The other locations were fighting where they were, but this army of unknown number was traveling fast.
If they were at half march or even full march, Symra was confident that she could still intercept them from this distance.
From her elevation, Symra memorized the lay of the roads to plan an intercept route to what she believed was the main army.
She coated her feet in earth ven to reinforce them and sprinted down the mountain with all haste.
Forest Elves were faster and more agile, but none of the elfkind could compete against Mountain Elves in strength, and only the dryads beat them in endurance.
On top of this, her earth magic gave her a speed boost across land.
Every step she took, flat earth pushed up against her feet and propelled her legs forward.
Her light weight in this world further increased the distance of each stride.
She reached the city at a breakneck pace.
Continual kicks off the ground shot stone pillars up from her feet that launched Symra over building after building until she reached the first road on her mental map.
The shawl hanging from her shoulders billowed in the wind and kept pressing against her face, so she tore it off.
The humans watched in confusion, amazement, and fear as a woman with a tail ran faster than the vehicles down the road leaving demolished pavement and wreckage in her wake.
Turn after turn, she followed her mental map.
By Symra’s estimates, she was nearing her targets.
She chanced a glance up to see the smoke not too far off in the distance but nearly collided with one of the strange automatic metal carriages of this world in the process.
After another turn that set Symra on the road to her target, the same semi-translucent body she saw when she woke floated in front of her eyes.
It was feminine and beckoned Symra to follow.
Somehow, it was able to keep pace and even moved faster than her.
She knew the identity of the figure.
It was a wind sprite, an elemental being from her world.
Something inside Symra told her she should follow.
The sprite turned sharp down a road that led Symra away from the enemy army.
If she did not focus hard on keeping sight of her, she knew she would lose the small figure.
Turn after turn, road after road, she followed until the sprite led her up a sloped road to a complex of large buildings.
There she slowed down and led Symra to a set of large glass doors that opened automatically when she approached.
The figure floated above a woman behind a counter before vanishing.
The woman behind the counter stared at Symra in dumbstruck astonishment.
She lifted some black object to her ear and spoke into it.
What do I do here?
Symra’s legs faltered, and she leaned against the counter.
The exhaustion of her sprint caught up with her.
Pain assaulted her body.
Her chest burned and pleaded for air, and she coughed hard into her forearm.
Blood sprayed both the counter and the woman.
She was not healed.
The sprite woke her from hibernation, and that should have been impossible.
Mountain Elf hibernation was known as the sleep of death.
Even severe trauma to the body would not wake a hibernating Mountain Elf.
Mountain Elves passed on cautionary tales of those who had collapsed into hibernation in the wild and were discovered half eaten by beasts and yet still slept.
Only healing and treatment could wake them.
Somehow the sprite cut Symra’s hibernation short and then led her here.
“Call a doctor and bring a stretcher,” another behind the counter ordered to someone unseen in back.
Two men rushed beside Symra, but she pushed them away and found them strangely heavy.
Symra knew she no longer had the strength to intercept Jethro’s army and find where they were headed.
Now that she was aware just how injured she remained, attacking the army on her own would be suicide, even though she was confident she could still trim their numbers a little.
In a last desperate attempt to find meaning in being led here, she spoke a single name.
“Eydis FeAmel.”
Another woman behind the counter reacted.
She looked at Symra’s long, drooping ears and then into Symra’s deep orange eyes.
“She’s a type of elf.
She must be connected to Eydis,” she said to the other receptionist who was wiping Symra’s spray of blood off her face.
These humans knew Princess Eydis.
Maybe she was here.
Renewed determination welled up in Symra.
She leaped over the desk and ran down the hall, pushing her pain to the back of her mind.
“Eydis!
Eydis!”
She called out, hoping for a reply.
The blinding white hallways were a maze, and Symra had no direction where to go.
The sprite returned.
It fluttered left and then right towards the end of a hallway.
Sprites were citizens of the Amelian Empire.
Symra knew where she led.
A guard wielding a weapon that Symra had never seen stepped out into the end of the hallway.
He waved to the side, and a second guard appeared.
“Don’t move!” they shouted as they pointed their weapons at her.
From the feeling beneath Symra’s feet, she knew stone hid beneath the glossy floor.
She kicked the ground, and jagged pavement jutted up knocking both men to their back.
One fell unconscious from the impact, but the other pointed his weapon and fired.
Symra had no time to react.
She knew the loud roar of the weapon announced her death, but the sprite appeared before her.
The air rippled like water.
Small metal objects fell to the ground at Symra’s feet.
Not wasting the opportunity, she conjured a stone baton in her hand and beat the man across the face.
Symra opened the guarded door and met a man and woman.
She lunged at the man and swung her baton before they had time to attack.
The man dodged right, but the baton shattered the small rectangular object in his hand.
In the bed to the side, Symra saw her.
Princess Eydis lay asleep and very sickly.
“What did you do to her!?”
She once again targeted the man, but the woman with him grabbed her arm.
She felt the ven in her body lock up, and with a step and twist of her hip and arms, the woman sent Symra flying over her shoulder back to the ground.
Sharp stones appeared in the woman’s hands and one by one they shot out at Symra.
This was an earth mage like her.
Symra swung her baton, and the two projectiles exploded into powder on contact.
They were weak.
This was a novice.
She energized the ven wellpoints in her body, and her ven began flowing again.
The baton in her hand molded and changed shape to a curved blade.
In Symra’s other hand, she conjured a second identical blade.
Now that she looked at the two, the man was thin and ill-suited for combat, but the woman was fit, toned, and held a practiced stance.
She would not mistake her true opponent again.
She felt insulted to call herself the instructor of the palace guard having been caught off her guard and thrown in such a humiliating manner.
Pavement shot out below Symra’s feet to propel her forward.
Both swords swung down faster than the woman could defend against.
They hit the woman’s shoulders and cut down across her chest.
The woman’s clothing sliced open, but there was no blood.
Impossible, Symra mouthed in shock.
Earth ven could be used to protect the body, but Symra had created the strongest and sharpest blades within her power.
Symra would not have been able to protect herself to this level.
But even if there was no visible damage, the force of the hit still knocked the woman to her butt.
Even if the body could be protected, places like the eyes were still vulnerable because hardening the eyes led to temporary blindness, so any practiced earth mage avoided it.
One of her swords re-shaped into a thin spike that she thrust forward.
The sprite appeared in front of the woman’s face.
The air rippled like before, and the spike shattered.
Symra looked at the sprite with her mouth agape.
It flew over and fluttered above Princess Eydis and then above the woman.
“Do not fight them,” spoke a feminine voice in her mind.
Symra realized the first attack the woman performed that locked her ven was the same that she taught the palace guard and royal family.
It was a beginner skill for the lowest rank of bem in the art Symra both practiced and instructed, the first that taught how to temporarily block the flow of an opponent’s ven.
These were not enemies.
She stepped back and looked over to Eydis’s bed, but the man moved and blocked her.
Fear enveloped him.
He did not want to confront Symra, but something inside him drove him to do so nonetheless.
“You… you are protecting her,” Symra spoke in English.
Symra’s adrenaline abated, and her pain and exhaustion caught up.
She sat back into the metal siding of the bed beside her.
The man and woman looked at each other.
Their hostility and fear vanished.
Footsteps came from the door.
The guard who had first fallen unconscious entered the room with his gun pointed at Symra.
“Stop! She’s not an enemy!”
The woman shouted at the guard and moved quickly to cover Symra while the man hurried to confront the guard and speak with him.
Symra looked up at the woman.
The sprite sat on the woman’s shoulder and patted it, but the woman did not notice.
“You, you led me to them, to Her Highness.”
The woman smiled and knelt in front of Symra.
“We are Eydis’s friends.”
“Friend Eydis,” she repeated in broken Elven.

* * *
Of all the people Fect wanted to avoid, his worst fear stood before him holding the bloody corpse of his partner.
“I know you are there, coward.
I can smell you.”
Fect had delighted in Jethro’s suggestion to bring Penk along on this mission solely for the chance that he may encounter the Doppelganger again.
Jethro stated that Penk would be extra security, and true enough, if Penk had not been there, Fect would be in the clenches of this monster with half his head carved away from the pavement.
Penk’s presence had saved Fect’s life, but not in the manner he intended.
He hoped to kill the monster should he and Penk encounter her.
He did not understand Jethro’s attachment to her.
Now Fect stood alone against the monster once more.
Cold sweat ran down his back.
He fought to keep his racing heart calm.
So long as he did not move, he would not give away his position, but no matter what he did, he knew the monster would find him eventually.
She no longer needed to protect her prey or pet or mate.
She could fight unhindered.
There was only one chance for Fect to survive.
“Your offense is relentless, but once you lose your initiative, you crumble.”
Captain Byurk had spoken such words to Fect.
If he could strike the monster down before she could target him, he could win.
But if it failed, he would lose to her merciless onslaught.
The only advantage Fect had against the monster was his sight-based magic.
He did not need to move.
His flame pillars were silent and invisible, but she was fast enough to avoid the attack if she noticed the cement at her feet heat rapidly.
His heat ray was his swiftest magic, acting almost instantly, but if he did not kill her, his position would be revealed.
The condensed fire ven was visible, but if not used at full power, it might remain unnoticed.
Eydis gazed around at the sidewalk in front of the police station.
The minum’s scent wafted into her nose, and she could faintly hear his racing heart.
Thankfully, her gruesome execution of the first minum cleared any people in the nearby street, but the few passing cars still made listening difficult.
Her target was somewhere in front of her, but so long as he stayed immobile, she could not see him.
She channeled wind ven into her hands causing an intense pain to burn through her body.
Before she could gather enough, the pain grew so intense that her body rejected the ven and stopped.

A wide blade of wind would have forced the minum to move, but she had already used ven to teleport to the police station when she saw the fire from her perch on top the tallest building in the center of the city.
She lacked enough clean ven to use combat magic, and the dead minum in her hands would not supply her any.
She regretted not knocking him out instead of killing him.
The shirt on Eydis’s chest heated.
She moved the minum in her grip in front of her, and the minum caught fire.
The heat grew rapidly until the minum burst into a charred fireball.
She released him.
Eydis jumped back, but the pavement beneath her heated.
A pillar of fire shot up the moment Eydis dove to the side only to have a second come up from where she landed.
The flames caught her side, singeing her and burning her clothes.
A wall of fire grew along her right.
When she moved to the left, a second wall grew.
It stretched behind her and filled in close.
Once the walls met both in back and front, she was trapped in a small room of flame only two meters wide.
The heat made her drip with sweat.
Eydis was about to jump out, but the instant her feet were about to spring, the front corner of the fire wall detonated, blowing her back.
She collided with one of the stone pillars in front of the police station.
Another explosion in front of her sent her through the side of the stone pillar.
The metal reinforcement inside the pillar cut her arm.
Eydis’s vision grew red with the blood running into her eyes.
Her chest would not expand to allow her lungs to take in air.
The attacks came one after the other without pause.
If she did not move, she knew she would be killed.
… But then, nothing happened.
Fect breathed deep.
His assault had worked, but in his haste, he blew the monster outside his line of sight.
He did not know how much damage she took or if he could escape.
Should he finish her off?
But what if she could still fight?
If he moved, she might see him.
Plus, Jethro still wanted her alive, but after everything the monster had done, Fect felt that she was too great a danger and risk to let live.
Jethro would understand.
Keeping his eyes on the direction the monster landed, Fect slowly crept closer to the police station for a better position.
When he rounded the pillars, he could not see the doppelganger.
A large chunk of the pillar flew into Fect’s field of vision.
He focused his eyes on it with all his might.
The chunk of pillar heated and then exploded from the ray sending molten and red-hot rock in all directions.
“Found you!” Eydis charged.
A wall of fire rose from the ground in front of the minum.
Eydis kicked the ground with her heel using her Lurr strength and the momentum of her charge.
Cement shards shot through the fire unabated, and a voice cried out on the other side.
She jumped over the wall of flame, but before she could land another immense explosion on the outer wall of the police station sent her soaring through the air to the empty street.
Eydis bounced and rolled onto the sidewalk.
The bloody minum glared down at her from the steps across the street leading up to the police station.
“You are strong, but you know nothing of combat.
You never should have crossed Jethro.
If you would have given us the princess, you could have avoided all this.”
“I know that already,” Eydis coughed, half smiling.
She was long past any regret.
A thin line of heat shot from the minum’s dazed eyes.
Unfocussed, it split and pierced through Eydis’s left arm and into her side.
The burning pain charred through her ribs and lung, exiting through her back.
The other hit her left leg and bored into the sidewalk.
Eydis glared at the minum.
She would not let him see her cry in pain nor plead for mercy.
The pain from the burn was weaker than the pain of using the toxic ven plaguing her body.
She could tolerate it.
She rolled to her elbow and smirked confidently at the minum.
A second beam fractured worse than the first.
Four rays hit the sidewalk and the building behind her, all missing.
The blood draining from his forehead showed some of the cement she kicked up had struck him near the eyes.
The minum never approached for better aim.
She knew he feared her.
The minum grew more and more frustrated.
“Once I am through with you, I will join the assault on the medical facility.
I will have your prey and kill all those who protect her.”
Eydis knew Justin had been staying in the hospital room every day.
Even though she kept her distance, she tried to monitor his actions to protect him.
If she died here, then Justin would die in the assault on the hospital.
That much was certain.
She had no time to feign confidence.
She still had one spell that used very little ven.
She removed the bloat in the transmission formula that she had always questioned, not knowing whether it was needed.
She did not care about stability.
This reduced the ven cost a staggering amount, almost to a hundredth of what it was formerly.
Her body screamed out in pain and agony worse than the burns on her skin or the charred lines through her chest and leg, but with a rush a relief, the spell finished.
Eydis extended her hand.
An explosion hit the sidewalk beside her, sending her through the window of the building behind her, but amid the deafening sound, her keen Lurr ears picked up the distinct snap of transmission.
She coughed and spat up blood, pulling herself to her feet and relying on her Lurr resilience to endure the pain.
Across the street, the minum was gone.
Her left leg struggled to support her, and her chest burned with each breath, but because there was no hole despite the pain she felt, she could still breathe well enough.
Forcing the pain to the back of her mind, Eydis limped out of the building and in the direction of the hospital until her leg steadied enough to hold a jogging pace.
In her heart she prayed that she would reach Justin in time, and that the minum could not swim.

Chapter 18
“Resistance”
Miriam helped a nurse treat the unknown, injured elf while Sean worked to deescalate the panic in the hallway.
Every few breaths, the elf coughed out blood into her forearm.
From what she could hear from the hallway, the elf broke a guard’s nose, a few teeth, and dislocated his jaw.

Once Sean explained that it had been a misunderstanding by an acquaintance of Eydis that could use magic, it appeased some of their worry, but they were still furious about the attack and the damage to the hallway.
The hospital was already overworked due to the sudden influx of patients from the fighting all over the city, most arriving in their own vehicles after escaping the assaulted areas.
“Here, you should cover yourself.”
Miriam handed the elf a hospital gown provided by the nurse.
The elf inspected it and pulled it over her head.
It fit loose up top but restricted leg movement, and she did not seem pleased.
She moved her legs, but the fabric caught in odd ways depending on her movements.
After she tore a slit up the side to her hip to give her legs more freedom, she grew content.
“What’s your name,” Miriam asked.
“Symra,” the elf responded, understanding Miriam’s question.
“How do you know Eydis?”
“I taught Princess Eydis to fight, same as she taught you.”
Symra’s reply further surprised Miriam.
It was perfectly grammatical with only a light slur in the accent.
“Your English is excellent.
Where did you learn?”
“I learned English as a slave to a man Jethro brought from your world.
I begged him to teach me to give the other girls a chance to rest.”
Miriam immediately understood the situation Symra was in before arriving on earth.
She must have escaped just before or during the attack on Gullivan.
“We have no time.”
Symra grabbed Miriam’s arm and pulled her to the hallway where the nurses were treating the downed soldier.
The other soldier stood guard and held both rifles.
She grabbed the second and pulled it away amidst the shouts of the soldier and the screams of the medical staff.
“What are you doing!?”
Miriam tried to pull Symra away from the soldier but found the gun thrust into her hands.
“Jethro’s soldiers are on their way.”
Symra noticed and grabbed the tactical vest of the downed soldier that had been set aside.
She almost handed the vest to Miriam but then donned it herself, simply pulling it over her shoulders without strapping it around her chest.
Two stone blades appeared in Symra’s hands.
The nurses screamed, and the soldier pointed his rifle at the Elf.
“Follow her.”
A faint feminine voice that was not Miriam’s spoke inside Miriam’s mind.
Sean hurried to Miriam’s side.
“Just before she broke my phone, Justin said that Jethro’s men knew Eydis was here.”
Miriam checked her pocket for her phone.
“Shit!
I left my phone in the car.”
“Call for whatever reinforcements you can,” Sean ordered the soldier.
“An enemy army is on its way here to the hospital.
We need to evacuate everyone.”
Miriam ran after Symra who waited at the end of the hall, and Sean followed, but she stopped him.
“No, you stay with Eydis and make sure everyone gets out.
I’ll find you and Eydis later.”
Sean did not question Miriam’s order.
“Here, take this.”
He removed his coat and handed it to Miriam.
Without embarrassment, Miriam removed her torn coat, shirt, and bra that was only hanging by a single shoulder strap and donned Sean’s coat.
“Thanks.”
Sean pulled Miriam in and kissed her.
Warmth grew from where their lips met and spread downward to dwell within her chest.
“Be careful.
Please,” he begged.
“I will.
I’m tough, remember?”
After radioing in Sean’s information about the approaching army, the soldier met Miriam and Symra and helped Symra strap on the tactical vest.
He then noticed how Miriam held the assault rifle with proper form and trigger discipline.
“Do you know how to use it?”
“My father is a gun nut.
I was practically born with a gun in my hands.
I have fired a SCAR before.”
Now that she thought about it, he probably wanted her interests to be as far from witchcraft and magic as possible.
If only he knew.
Miriam chuckled wryly, which created a small grimace of concern on the soldier’s face.
The soldier removed earplugs from his pocket and handed them to Miriam.
“If you absolutely plan on fighting, you should also use my IOTV.”
Miriam accepted the ear plugs but rejected the vest.
“My body is strengthened with magic.
My skin is probably harder than your vest.”
“I’m jealous.”
Instead of his vest, the soldier handed Miriam two spare clips.
“Thank you.
What’s your name?” she asked.
“Nathan Karls.”
“Miriam Schruder.”
The three rushed out of the hospital.
Light smoke rose above the buildings about two miles to the south.
“They’re closer than I hoped,” Miriam whispered.
There was not enough time to evacuate everyone.
“How long until reinforcements come?”
Nathan shook his head.
“The few of us who were stationed in the city are already engaged with the terrorists.
Mark and I were ordered to stay here at the hospital.”
He turned to look up at the greying sky from the ever-growing fires on the far side of the city.
“Damn it.
We should have taken that elf from the city before this happened.”
Miriam recalled her earlier premonition when that same suggestion was brought up in their meeting with Dr. Shuman the day after the fake Eydis appeared.
That time as well, a feminine voice spoke in her mind telling her not to remove Eydis from the city.
“Doing so would lead to a greater catastrophe,” Miriam repeated the words of the voice.
Was this the voice that her grandmother heard?
Was this the source of her premonitions and predictions?
The city was under siege.
No doubt many people had already died.
What disaster could be worse than what was happening now?
Did she do something wrong?
Was there more to the premonition that she was not connected or attuned enough to hear?
Fear bubbled in her stomach and constricted her chest the more she dwelt on these worries.
Miriam claimed to be a witch, but the truth was that her parents kept her away from her grandmother as much as was possible.
What training she gained was little more than stories and a trust of things spiritual and natural.
She could only maintain steady contact after she moved away from home.
Just before her grandmother’s passing, she said Miriam would grow to be a wonderful witch, and Miriam believed it, joyful to claim the title.
Now, she did not know.
She only practiced fake spiritualism in her spare time.
She had no way to learn how to be the great witch her grandmother was.
Have I failed her expectations?
An army of about 200 soldiers in crude armor marched into view at the intersection down the long declining road leading to the hospital.
One van that tried to turn and speed away met a fiery demise.
Miriam took a deep breath.
“Protect the hospital.
Protect Sean.
Protect Eydis.
Here we go.”
The road leading to the hospital rose at a three-degree incline.
It was not steep enough to slow the march of the army, but it gave Miriam and Nathan a higher vantage point.
Symra nodded at Miriam and walked out to the center of the road, standing at the top of the incline brandishing her swords.
She was in view of the army.
A few overeager arrows attempted to fly the distance but missed their mark.
Symra only moved to strike down a lucky arrow midflight but returned to her menacing stance.
“I am here.
I will not let you pass,” her posture announced.
“This way.” Nathan led Miriam back up the road out of sight of the army so they could move unnoticed.
They snuck along the side of the road to the perimeter ledge of the hospital to remain hidden and find a vantage point with cover.
No cars were parked on the slope or near the top.
There were no buildings close to the road.
The shrubs and trees planted for aesthetics provided the only weak cover.
The trees were not thick enough to hide behind, but the shrubs were just tall enough that one could kneel or crouch and stay completely obscured, however they provided no protection.
“Stay here and wait for my signal.”
Nathan continued further down the side of the road.
The brick hospital sign was another fifty yards ahead, but there was a large gap in the shrubbery.
As Miriam worried that he might try to make for the sign, Nathan stopped at the largest shrub before the gap.
He was within arrow range of the army, but they did not notice him.
The army was focused on the sole elf standing menacingly in the middle of the road.
Miriam had to wonder if Symra knew the nature of the ranged weaponry she and Nathan held.
By using herself as a decoy, she would leave the army open to a surprise attack.
The army continued their march and neared where Nathan hid.
The first fireball flew from the backline towards Symra.
She remained rooted, unyielding.
She kicked the ground with her heel forcing the asphalt to rise into a wall.
The fireball exploded with no damage to her.
She kicked the wall down and continued glaring at the army.
She would not let this be a long-ranged fight, at least from their end.
Symra shouted in a language other than Elven, and the army responded with a cacophony of shouts and banging metal.
Miriam saw in the back of the army an elderly man standing poised.
He lifted his hand and shouted orders to the army.
She raised her SCAR and aimed.
Max effective range should be somewhere around 300 yards, and he is probably about 200 away…
Miriam’s heart pounded in her chest.
Her entire life from childhood, she had only shot at targets.
She had never even hunted before.
Not once had she taken a life with a gun.
Her breath became ragged.
Should I shoot?
She looked over at Nathan but could not see him well from his obscured position.
He remained motionless and waited.
Miriam peered back down her sights at who she believed to be the commander.
She slowed her breaths and focused on the rhythm to calm her heart and clear her head.
The safety was off.
The general was down the sights and compensated for distance.
At the end of a long and full exhale, her finger felt the trigger, but she hesitated.
“Shoot,” spoke the feminine voice.
One shot.
After a split-second pause to readjust aim, a second shot followed.
Miriam inhaled.
Her body shook from adrenaline.
At the back of the formation, Miriam could not see the commander standing.
Nathan opened fire.
Chaos erupted from the army as the few mages attacked indiscriminately in all directions and rangers scouted to search for the origin of the gunshots that were dropping soldier after soldier.
Taking advantage of the chaos, Symra charged.
Miriam’s shot signaled the start of battle.
Symra erected a wall on her left to protect her as she attacked the soldiers on her right.
Her quick and precise slashes with her curved stone swords showed a well-practiced mastery of the weapon.
Each cut avoided the studded leather or thin plate and aimed for joints made of simple fabric or leather that the peculiar stone could cut easily.
Through the struggle, Symra would cough, and slowly blood trickled from her mouth.
Miriam remembered how Symra collapsed in the room after realizing that she and Sean were not hostile.
Symra was badly injured or sick.
Miriam originally planned to target the archers and mages but instead switched to supporting Symra hoping that Nathan would remove the ranged combatants.
She lined her sights and pulled the trigger.
A spearman who jumped around the small wall to attack from behind crumbled to the ground with a red spray from his face.
Another swordsman took advantage of the death of two of his comrades to attack while Symra’s swords were still in them.
Miriam fired, and the bullet hit the swordsman’s side, but it was not enough to take him down.
The soldier forced Symra to release her blades, but she was not defenseless.
Symra struck the soldier in the chest with a weak-formed strike from the back of her wrist, but the form appeared similar to one of the closed-fisted strikes Eydis taught in her self-defense classes.
The only difference was the shape of her hand and positioning of her arm.
When Symra rotated her elbow thirty degrees, her posture locked, and the soldier collapsed to the ground spewing blood from his mouth and nose.
Symra claimed to be Eydis’s combat instructor, and perhaps Miriam was now witnessing advanced forms of the art that either Eydis did not know or did not feel safe teaching her students.
Symra caught the falling soldier and used his corpse as a shield while she conjured another curved saber.
She left her back open, so another spearman closed in to strike her down.
Symra did not react, so Miriam shot the soldier twice, dropping him.
Symra knew Miriam now covered her flank and focused on those in front of her.
Miriam shivered with excitement and adrenaline.
A small grin curled up on the corners of her mouth.
It scared her to realize this, but she was having fun.
Killing should not come natural to anyone, but for her it was so easy.
Miriam continued focusing on the one-versus-many melee while Nathan picked off the ranged fighters and scouts as she had hoped.
They only had three on their side, so the survival of their single vanguard was top priority in Miriam’s mind.
Ten, twenty, thirty, soldier after soldier dropped between her and Nathan’s assault, and Miriam was forced to swap out her magazine.
Only one spare remained.

Lacking their general, some of the more confident soldiers became desperate and broke formation to take out the single vanguard or make a run for the hospital, but there were three or four who called them back and continued giving orders.
Of course there would be more leaders than a single commander.
After waiting for an opening where Symra could survive without support fire for a few seconds, Miriam targeted one of the men shouting orders.
Three shots later, he dropped.
This enraged the group under his control, but they were seasoned soldiers.
Even without command, they continued working together to fish out their enemies who were picking them off from a distance.
The search passed the sign and was nearing Nathan and her position.
In the corner of Miriam’s eye, a lucky fireball landed in the bushes where Nathan hid.
The subsequent explosion knocked him back into the metal fencing along the edge of the slope.
They found their target.
Nathan patted out the flames on his body and quickly ran for more cover.
Miriam could see charred burns on his face.
Arrows and near invisible wind projectiles flew his direction.
Nathan barely had time to dive out of the way before another explosion sent him tumbling to his back.
The soldiers who had only focused on Symra now divided their forces to attack Nathan.
Symra hurried after them.
If she could reach him, the earlier melee could continue with Nathan as support.
An arrow that blustered with visible wind current shot through the air at such an incredible speed that gravity could not pull it into an arch.
The arrow embedded itself up to the fletching into the center of Nathan’s vest.
A sole archer stood on the shoulders of a giant in the back of the army.
He knocked another arrow and fired again.
Once more the arrow flew and penetrated through Nathan’s stomach.
“Damn it!” Miriam cursed under her breath.
She aimed at the archer and giant.
One bullet took down the archer with two more killing the giant.
She had outlasted Nathan, not by her skill or reinforcement magic but by the roulette of the battlefield.
Certainly, that same arrow would have killed her just as easily as it killed him.
This realization extinguished any sense of thrill in Miriam’s mind.
They were pre-medieval soldiers fighting modern firearms, but they had magic that could compete.
This was war, a life-and-death, kill-or-be-killed struggle.
In Miriam’s hesitation after seeing the death of Nathan, she had forgotten to cover Symra.
Symra had multiple bleeding cuts on her body from fighting off her overwhelming attackers.
The cuts were not deep, showing that Symra might have reinforcement magic, but Symra was already fighting injured.
The toll was visible in the steadily increasingly lethargy of her curved blade.
Unlike before, the soldiers now parried them with relative ease.
An involuntary and intense cough dropped Symra to one knee.
No less than ten weapons rose against the fallen elf.
Miriam pulled the trigger as fast as she could while attempting with all her might to hold the SCAR steady.
Soldier after soldier dropped to the ground giving Symra time to pull back and retreat.
A sharp pain hit Miriam’s right temple and caused her head to twist to the side.
The arrow that hit her head skidded across the road.
Her cover was blown.
A second and third arrow followed and narrowly missed her.
A fourth hit her shoulder and bounced off.
The pain was intense, her magic only preventing it from penetrating.
She tried firing amid the rain of arrows but was forced to run when a fireball flew her direction.
She was far enough from the explosion to stay standing, but the pressure knocked the wind out of her.
Symra retreated after Miriam.
They no longer had their surprise advantage, and most the army still remained.
Miriam fought to ignore the pain of the arrows hitting her and wondered how long her ven would last.
Symra propelled herself back to avoid a fireball and landed two yards to Miriam’s left.
When their eyes met, they knew they needed to retreat and find another strategic location.
Together they broke into a sprint and trusted their reinforcement magic to keep them alive.
Miriam glanced back as she ran and saw four large fireballs flying their direction.
The fireballs converged midflight and created a massive burning sphere that radiated heat so strong that Miriam could feel it.
There was no way she could defend against that.
Symra noticed the heat and turned back to erect and emergency wall as thick as possible in the short time she had.
