The burning sphere struck the back of the wall with incredible force and erupted into an explosion that shook the entire hospital complex.
The heat was suffocating, and Miriam’s ears rang despite her earplugs and the reinforcement magic she applied, but she and Symra survived.
They pulled each other out of the rubble of the wall and continued running while Miriam shot at who she could.
From their position, Miriam could see the evacuation of the hospital in full force.
The soldiers also noticed, and two platoons broke off to break up the evacuation.
Miriam fired at them but could not stop the fifty or more soldiers.
There was nothing she could do.

Only a small feeling of relief came from the knowledge that Sean and Eydis were not in that direction; however, if the army continued pushing her down the road, she would arrive at that wing of the hospital where Sean and Eydis resided.
The remaining army continued their pursuit after Miriam and Symra.
The number of soldiers slowly dropped with every shot of the SCAR, but the final magazine eventually ran dry.
Miriam created a sharp spike of stone with her ven and threw it at the soldiers in desperation.
The ven placed on the back propelled it forward at incredible speed, but it shattered against a soldier’s shield without making so much of a dent.
The words from the fake Eydis’s training echoed in Miriam’s mind.
“Still not good enough.”
Miriam did not know who the fake was or her purpose in training them, but just like the true Eydis, her instruction was designed to hone in on Miriam’s weaknesses.
Miriam’s rocks were hard but far too brittle to be used as weapons.
The martial training taught her by the true Eydis would also do little against such large numbers.
Without a gun, she was defenseless.
Once again, four fireballs approached and converged into one.
Symra tried to erect another wall, but she was panting too hard and her stance was weak.
The wall that jutted from the street was thin.
She turned to Miriam and shouted, “Build a wall!”
“I can’t… I don’t know how.”
They both knew the magnitude of the danger that rapidly approached and that they had no way to prevent it from hitting them with full force.
Miriam and Symra braced themselves behind the thin wall.
With all the ven she could gather, Miriam coated her body and strengthened it to the extent of her ability.
The blazing sphere exploded, and everything went dark.

* * *
“We have thirteen in this wing, seven requiring special care and transport.
How many ambulances are available?”
“Only five.
The rest have already been dispatched.”
“Radio them and tell them not to return if they have injured.
If they don’t need the extra wheels, we do.
All incoming urgent care patients are to head to the 27th Street clinic until they are stable enough to travel.
All others who can handle the 50 miles are to head north.”
“I just got word nine busses are on their way.
They will be here in ten minutes depending on traffic.
We still have our vans available as well.”
Doctors, nurses, and administrators ran about the halls of the hospital like an army of ants whose anthill had been stepped on.
Their first priority was to ensure safe travel for critical patients to the nearest hospital just over fifty miles away.
Local clinics in the city would temporarily house patients within their medical specialty where feasible until it was safe to return to the hospital or they needed to head north as well.
Sean helped where he could amid the chaos, but not knowing the hospital’s evacuation plan, he was mostly getting in the way of the practiced professionals.
“Do not stand in the hallways.”
A sweating male nurse pushed a heavyset man on a gurney past Sean.
The sound of an explosion shook the walls of the hospital.
A few feminine yelps and masculine cries echoed in the halls, but the fear only increased the urgency of the evacuation.
The receptionist at the counter hastily made phone call after phone call.
A female nurse looking behind her as she ran bumped shoulders with Sean as she passed.
A man in a suit jogged in Sean’s direction, but like everyone else, he paid Sean no attention.
Sean rushed to the man’s side.
“Is there anything I can help with?”
“Get rid of that damned elf!”
The man sneered and continued running down the hallway.
Sean stood frozen, unsure how to reply.
Eydis was the reason the hospital needed to evacuate.
Her presence placed everyone in danger.
“Don’t stand in the hall!” Another gurney pushed past, the eleventh from Sean’s count.
Sean was just in the way.
He returned down the hallway outside Eydis’s room.
No one came.
He heard that there were thirteen patients in this wing, but when the twelfth passed the end of the hall, his worry grew.
They would come for Eydis next.
A door halfway down the hall opened, and an elderly woman on a gurney passed.
“Wait!
Hold on!”
The nurse did not listen to Sean and continued evacuating his patient.
Sean ran back down the hall and jumped over the upturned cement floor.
He had to make sure he did not somehow miss Eydis’s evacuation.
Inside the room, Eydis slept in her bed.
“Damn it.”
Sean grabbed the first person he could find back down the hall.
“There is still a patient back here.”
“I was informed that she was the last one.”
The nurse thumbed to the gurney that turned the corner out of sight.
“Eydis is still back there!”
A hand rested on Sean’s shoulder.
Feeling that the suited man would help Sean, the nurse hurried after the final gurney.
“We will not be taking the elf with us.
The people attacking the city are after her.
If we bring her, they will follow and place us all in danger.
This is a decision made by the hospital.”
Sean prided himself on being levelheaded and remaining calm under pressure, but his chest burned with anger.
This was blatant injustice.
His hands balled into fists, and he struck the man across the face.
The man staggered back a little and rubbed his jaw.
The punch was embarrassingly weak.
“You keep calling her elf, elf.
Are you doing that to say that Eydis is inhuman and not worth helping?
What about your oath as a doctor?!”
“Our job is to save lives, and that is what we are doing.
I must prioritize the many over the one in this case.
Sorry.” The man’s tone was anything but apologetic.
He was the one who made the decision, not the hospital.
“If you want to evacuate her, take her away in your own car.”
Sean did not voice his building rage but instead ran down the hall back to Eydis’s room.
Escaping with Eydis in his car was not possible.
He had arrived with Miriam and Sammy, and then Sammy left with Justin in his car for Justin’s final.
Sean inspected Eydis’s bed and then the door.
The bed was far too large to fit through the door, and even if it could, the destroyed floor of the hallway would not let the bed pass.
He rushed out of the room and opened door after door hoping to find a smaller bed or gurney.
“Is there anyone still here?!”
The hallway was silent.
The main hall of the wing was the same.
“Is anyone here!?”
Sean continued checking rooms until he finally found one with a thinner bed.
He unplugged the power cord, tossed the control pad on it, and pulled.
It didn’t budge.
After a deep breath to calm down, he unlocked the wheels and maneuvered the bed out the door and down the hall.
The upturned floor was as close as he could push the bed.
He removed Eydis’s IV using the methods he had seen many times before when giving blood, removed her catheter with no small amount of trouble, and carried her to the bed.
He pulled the bed down the hallway to the door by the main reception counter.
No one remained in the lobby.
The hospital was efficient in its evacuation, but he knew that the other buildings and wings with multiple floors would still be working hard to evacuate all the other patients.
If he could take Eydis to one of the evacuating groups from a different wing, they should take her, he hoped.
Sean pulled the bed out the switch-activated double doors to the lobby.
A loud explosion rattled the glass doors and Sean instinctively crouched down for cover.
On the road just past the emergency drop-off roundabout, Miriam flew into view about ten feet off the ground and rolled onto the pavement.
The rifle she held flung out of her hands and bounced away from her.
She struggled to stand.
A fireball flew over her and landed twenty feet behind her.
The explosion knocked her back to the pavement.
“Miriam!”
Blood drained from Sean’s face.
He forgot the task he was engaged in and ran out the doors to pull her to safety.
Another explosion shook the lobby.
The florescent lights on the ceiling flickered.
Two fingers on the bed twitched and then slid across the dim blue mat.
Water welled in weary eyes that had not opened for weeks and then fell like dew from a pale leaf.
Eyes too hazy to make shape or form of the light gazed upwards at the ceiling.
A broken and raspy whimper disturbed the empty lobby.
“Justin…”

* * *
“I apologize for interrupting the work I gave you.
The invasion took priority.
But it looks like you were able to get back on track without too much trouble.”
Jethro sat across a grand redwood table from Emer inside a massive, redwood-accented, white-marble banquet hall.
Emer’s hand raced over a piece of parchment to write the spell he had been working on since the success of the transmission experiment.
“If you wanted to take part in the invasion, you could have waited another day.”
“I had no idea how far you were, and this wasn’t something I could delay.
To think you had just about finished when I stopped you.”
“The break in focus made this take longer than it would have otherwise.”
“Oh, I understand that.”
The quill stopped moving.
One by one, Emer lifted the parchment and scanned it over for errors.

He wanted with all his heart and soul to slip in an error, some fatal flaw that would kill Jethro, but the kissiae entangled with his body prevented him from even penning such a betrayal against the one who was her master.
Even if the kissiae knew nothing of spatial magic, she could perceive his thoughts and understood his will even better than he did.
No instinct or unconscious action could deceive her.
He was under her complete control.
The spell had no errors as written.
He slid the parchment over to Jethro who also scanned it over and inscribed it to memory.
“Peculiar.
Even though the formula looks nothing like the original in structure, I can see all the vital elements that make it the original’s perfect partner.
How were you able to finish the coordinate reversal so quickly and elegantly?”
“Practice,” Emer said flatly.
Jethro slouched in his chair.
“I cannot even imagine what would be possible for me if my lifespan was as great as yours.
You elves are truly a blessed race.”
The words that would normally sound like praise or complement rang in Emer’s ears as those of a madman hiding pure malice and rancor behind a smiling façade.
“No other spatial mage aside from you or I could manage such a spell, so unlike last time, you must be my test subject.
Pray that this works the first time.”
“I am confident it will.”
“Good.
Keeya, make certain he returns immediately to this room once he arrives in the other world.
We have no time to waste.”
Keeya nodded.
Emer stood from his chair and moved a short distance from the table.
Without even a breath to concentrate, he encased himself in a barrier and activated the inter-world transmission spell.
The redwood-accented marble dining hall vanished and was replaced with a graying sky and open field.
Emer stood on the cement foundation of some demolished structure.
The thin wind caressed his face.
In the distance, a grand city rose from the fields at the foot of a mountain.
Smoke rose as a black mist from the city.
In Emer’s mind, he could almost hear the screams of the citizens who were thrust into a war with an enemy they never knew existed.
It pained his heart that he was the cause of their strife.
If he had not made a mistake in his formula to help the First Princess escape, she would have been placed in the care of another nation of their world.
The people of this city would have been able to continue their lives in whatever peaceful manner they pleased.
Emer’s jaw quivered.
“I am so sorry.”
“Must return.”
A simple command wormed its way into Jethro’s mind.
Without any intent or control on his part, Keeya activated the newly designed transmission spell through him.
“I see you are in one piece.
Any pain or fatal injuries?”
Jethro’s lighthearted tone was sickening.
Emer remembered the faces of the innocent women who died in the last experiment, their tears and pleas for mercy.
Dyas…
“Are there any complications with Emer’s body?”
Keeya shook her head.
“Wonderful!
I guess it is time I take a look at this grand, new world.”
Jethro vanished leaving Emer alone in a hall too large for one person.
He collapsed to his knees on the floor and pounded it with his fist over and over.
He increased the force of each consecutive hit with gritted teeth.
Suddenly his hand would no longer move.
“You are hurting us.”
“I don’t care!”
“We do care.”
“After everything I did to save her, after she tried her hardest to live a life away from all this conflict, I handed Jethro the weapon to hunt her down.
You made me place a knife at Eydis’s neck!”
Emer grabbed a vine digging into his stomach, but Keeya would not let him pull at it.
As often as he tried to tear the kissiae off him, he never could.
“Why?!
Why do you obey Jethro when you know he is an enemy to all elfkind, to all dryads?!
Why do you let him kill your own empress who has done nothing but love and care for the people of her empire?”
“A small price for survival of kissiae.”
“Are the elves truly alone in their struggle?”
Keeya ignored Emer’s dejected mumble and smiled.
“Let’s explore palace until Jethro return!”
Emer could not even voice his disproval as Keeya whisked him away out of the dining hall.

* * *
“Still no contact from the police.
Assume communication has been compromised.”
“Fifth Humvee is down.
All wheels on site are inoperable.”
Colonel Richards wiped his hand down his face.
“Do we still not have a number on how many are out there?”
“Aside from the estimated four to five hundred north of the city, reports are still coming in about hostiles throughout the city.
The Southeast has been neutralized by the civilians, but fighting continues at the university.”
The screen to Colonel Richard’s left showed areal footage from a news helicopter.
About two square miles of the northwestern corner of the city burned.
Buildings along the east highway leaving the city billowed smoke, but the damage did not seem to be spreading.
The university campus in the distance was not even visible through the volume of its smoke.
Major Wickenny said it was a handful of terrorists, not a fucking army.
“Sir!
Gullivan Central Hospital has sent out an urgent request for aid.”
“How long ago?”
“Not long.
Five minutes.
They claim to be a direct target of the attacks and are evacuating.
The enemy is on top of them.”
“Anyone in the area?”
“Aside from the two positioned there, none.”
“They are after Ms. FeAmel.
Where are the nearest ground forces?”
“All we could contact are engaged elsewhere.
Radio silence from those at the police station.”
This was a precisely planned attack.
The enemy knew the police were the central contact with the military and somehow broke that line of communication.
The number of Army personnel stationed in the city was meant as reinforcements for the police in the event of a terrorist attack.
There were not enough to stop an army assaulting four or five separate locations.
The initial request for additional reinforcements arrived an hour and a half ago after the first contact with hostiles on the northern edge of the city.
Ground and air forces were dispatched, but nearly three hundred miles was a long distance to cover.
Police from nearby cities were contacted and should have arrived, but with the central communication between law enforcement in the city cut, organizing them would be difficult.
This was proven by the sole fact that none of the additional police had contacted him yet.
“Contact all police departments of the neighboring cities and link them with us.
If that is not possible, I want every cell-phone number of every officer you can find.
ETA on air support at the city?”
“Three eggs in 15.
Apache in 30.”
“Send two to the hospital and the third to the University.
The Apache will continue to the main force in the north, but inform them to keep their ears open.”
“Sir.”
Colonel Richards wiped his hand down his face as he paced across the floor.
Elves and magic wielding armies.
What is going on?

Chapter 19
“The Master of Time and the Bridge between Worlds”
Jethro breathed in the warm air that tasted faintly of ash.
“The air is so much easier to breathe in this world.
The air in Whinhlem is too suffocating.”
The gravel of the driveway crunched beneath his boots.
There was no sense of urgency in his gait.
The city before him was ablaze.
Smoke rose into the sky in such volume that grey mist was beginning to tint the otherwise blue sky, and if Jethro looked closely, he could see small flecks of black drifting down around him.
If he ignored the destruction, the buildings of the cityscape had an almost nostalgic feel.

It felt like ages since he had last seen tall rectangular structures, yet their shape and form still looked primitive, confirming his earlier assumptions after viewing the handgun now strapped to his waist.
Jethro vanished, and the scenery changed in an instant to a lively city.
He appeared in midair, but before he could fall a barrier supported him from underneath.
It held stable in space and was unaffected by gravity.
The wind blew strong and tasted of ash, but at his height it was not thick enough to obscure his view of the city.
He only stood at about three times the height of the two- and three-story buildings below.
He would have liked to stand atop the tallest buildings in the city, but the view would be obscured by the plentiful smoke.
No progress had been made on the residential districts bordering the river, but smoke rose from both the university and hospital.
General Makstev had succeeded in diverting enough of the city’s fighting power to enable General Hattn and General Teppo to reach their targets.
A small column of smoke even rose from Fect’s estimated location of the city guard headquarters.
“Or, given the similarities, it was probably more of a police force or constabulary.”
Jethro chuckled to himself.
It was like looking at a window into ancient history.
Whinhlem was far too dissimilar to elicit the same feeling of nostalgia.
In the distance, two dots hovered in the air above the city.
He could not make out precisely what they were, but they did not attack.
“Observation?”
Jethro vanished again and appeared in a freefall near the flying vehicle.
It suspended itself in the air with a large propeller mounted on top and a smaller propeller on the tail for areal stability.
“Truly primitive.
And here I got my hopes up that technology here would be a little more advanced than this.”
His descent grew level with the helicopter.
A swipe of his arm sliced off the tail.
The helicopter immediately spun out of control and lost elevation.
Jethro vanished again and reappeared on top a nearby building to watch the vehicle crash.
There was no safety or escape mechanism built in.
This world’s flying vehicles were nothing but death traps.
After a disappointed sigh, Jethro teleported to the window of the second helicopter.
A man controlled a large machine with what looked like a lens.
The operator jumped back into the other side of the compartment in surprise.
These flying machines were not weaponized.
As expected, they only observed the battle.
Jethro jumped out and swung his arm.
The propeller detached from the top of the helicopter and spun upwards while the machine plummeted.
“That should halt some of the information passing to their forces.
Now, to the hospital.”
Back in the communication room at Fort Samper, Colonel Richards happened to be watching the news feed when a man appeared out of thin air before the camera.
Shortly after the man jumped away, the helicopter dropped from the sky amid the screams of its passengers.
Cold sweat beaded on Colonel Richard’s forehead.
He scrambled to the side of the table and shuffled through a stack of papers.
Those in the room who were not actively engaged in another task watched their usually composed commander with confusion.
Colonel Richards found the paper, a facial composite made by the imposter Eydis FeAmel of a man she stated was unrivaled in magic ability, a man who could cut through their defenses like butter.
He rushed to relay new orders.
A superhuman weapon had appeared on the battlefield.

* * *
Justin, Sammy, and Chloe ran onward toward the hospital ignoring their aching bodies screaming in protest.
In the distance, smoke rose from the hospital.
Oh God, please let Eydis be okay.
Justin had never prayed seriously once in his life, but if there was ever a time he needed a miracle, it was now.
Two ambulances had passed them on the road heading north as well as a handful of vans and busses.
Evacuation was in full force, and he hoped with every heavy beat of his thundering heart that Eydis was on one of them, but he also knew he could not make any assumptions.
Until he saw Eydis personally, he would never feel safe.
Until he was with Eydis again, he would not feel relief.
The driving force that cut deep in his heart and kept him moving was the gunfire he heard before Sean’s phone cut out.
“Hurry it!” Sammy was in far better shape than Justin.
She looked back at him from twenty or so yards ahead.
Chloe was even further ahead.
Justin’s chest burned.
He did not know how much further he could go, but the hospital was in sight, so he had to push through the pain and exhaustion.
When Justin caught up to Sammy, she grabbed his wrist and pulled him along.
“Only two more blocks.
You can make it.
We’ll see Eydis.
I promise.”
Her heavy, wheezing breaths showed the extent of her own exhaustion.
The hand grasping his arm shook with fatigue and was slick with sweat.
“If the hospital was near the river, I’d be there already!
If I had parked the car somewhere else, we’d be there already!
Gah!”
There was nothing she could have done.
They were just unlucky.
Justin forced himself to keep hope.
If he let doubt fill his already worried heart, he would collapse on the spot.
They were lucky enough to escape campus alive after being directly targeted by soldiers.
One block to go, but now the road inclined.
The hospital and the rest of the city westward sat atop an elevated fluvial terrace rising out of what had anciently been the river’s flood plain.
Each step up the shallow incline was heavier than the last.
If Sammy was not half pulling him up, he would not make it.
“They’re under attack!” Chloe called from atop the incline.
Spurred by energy Justin did not know he had, he raced beside Sammy up the remainder of the incline.
Two of the hospital buildings burned, and numerous soldiers were attacking people trying to load patients into vans and busses.
They had not seen any more vehicles pass down the road because those vehicles could no longer leave.
Two police officers fought desperately to shoot the assailants, but they were killed as Justin watched.
The number of dead was low from what they could see, so the massacre had only just begun.
“We need to help them!” Chloe ran off towards the soldiers, but Justin and Sammy hesitated.
Neither of them had any confidence in their combat ability.
Justin’s hesitation vanished in an instant.
Two swift-footed soldiers caught a fleeing woman cradling a young, bleeding boy in her arms.
One of them ran both woman and child through with a single thrust of his spear.
Justin’s exhausted feet moved forward after Chloe.
He had to do something.
He could not sit back and watch these innocent people die.
“Damn it.
Damn it.
Damn it!”
He shouted, both to fent his anger and to spur his exhausted body forward.
Ahead, Chloe intercepted the pair of spearmen.
They were not expecting retaliation from a woman, and their hesitation proved fatal to the one who struck the killing blow.
Chloe’s fist erupted in flames and exploded upon impact with the face of the soldier’s open helmet.
The second soldier backed away and used the length of his spear to his advantage.
Chloe was barely able to avoid the thrusts and was forced to retreat.
Sammy conjured a ball of water and threw it with perfect aim, hitting the soldier in the face.
That minor distraction was all Chloe needed to close the distance.
She swung her arms together, and when they clapped, a flame shot out into the soldier’s face.
It was not powerful, but the soldier cried out.
His face charred and his eyes sealed shut.
Sammy grappled the wailing soldier to the ground, and Chloe stomped his head at an angle.
His neck snapped with a pop.
Both Sammy and Justin grabbed one of the bloody spears and ran at the main body of the soldiers.
A bitter feeling in the pit of Justin’s stomach told him that he was running to his death.
How many soldiers were there?
Forty?
Fifty?
They were lucky that the two spearmen could not use magic, but a few of the soldiers ahead of them were clearly using fire, water, and earth magic to massacre the people.
He did not doubt there was wind magic intermixed but invisible in the chaos.
One lone, aged soldier took notice of their approach and separated himself from the group.
From his gait and how he held his sword, he gave the impression of a battle-hardened veteran unlike the two teenaged spearmen from before.
He called out in a language that was not Elven and grew a smile.
Another soldier followed for backup, but the man waved him off.
He noticed them take out the two young spearmen and was looking for something better than a one-sided massacre.
Unlike Chloe’s earlier reckless charge, she approached cautiously.
Only her fists grew flames to keep her heat under control.

Sammy conjured a water ball and tossed it to create another opening, but the soldier flicked his sword and hit the water ball with the flat side of the blade without even moving his torso or breaking his stride.
This man was a professional.
“Chloe… this is a bad idea,” Sammy said.
The soldier charged and covered the remaining distance in a second.
Chloe jumped back to avoid the sword’s downward swing.
The blade nicked the tip of her chin and the front of Justin’s hoodie.
The damage to her face was only a scratch and the blade only cut a small portion of fabric.
Leaving no time for Chloe to recover, a thrust came next.
Justin swung the tip of his spear upwards, and time slowed to a crawl.
He could see the soldier’s sword move forward inch by inch.
His own spear was going to miss.
It was not extended far enough.
Chloe was going to be killed.
Justin stretched his arm out, abandoning his balance, to increase the reach of the spear.
The sword’s edge caught on the socket and wings of the spear’s tip.
The force was weak, but it deflected the blade enough to pass just under Chloe’s arm.
The soldier jumped back, and Justin tripped to the ground.
Time resumed its normal pace.
Justin expected the soldier to attack, but he was given enough time to right himself.
The soldier expressed both amazement and joy.
Justin parried a veteran’s blade.
The veteran brandished his sword in a stance that Justin felt was defensive despite knowing nothing about swordplay.
Sammy hurried to Chloe to make sure she was okay.
Justin stood alone between them and the soldier.
“We can’t fight him,” Sammy screamed.
“We need to run!”
“He’s not going to let us go,” Justin said, not breaking eye contact with his opponent.
The spear felt like lead in his hands as the veteran stared him down.
The veteran grew more and more confused.
His eyes kept jumping between Justin’s grip on the haft and Justin’s eyes before lowering his guard slightly.
The next strike did not hold the same ferocity as before.
It swung diagonally down to cut at Justin’s right arm.
Time slowed the moment Justin moved his spear.
He stepped to the side and blocked the slash with the butt of the haft.
The sword cut in and got caught in the hard wood.
Justin almost lost his balance while ducking under and spinning the back end of the spear to the side to deflect the blade.
Time returned to normal.
The face of the veteran grew even more confused as if wondering whether Justin was actually skilled in combat or simply lucky.
The next attack thrust at Justin’s unguarded stomach.
The blade approached at a snail’s pace and was easy enough for Justin to sidestep so the blade slid under his arm.
The veteran stepped forward and shifted his body weight.
The blade swung sideways at Justin’s torso.
The spear was on the other side of the blade and could not be brought in to block the strike.
Justin had no other choice but to release the spear and drop his body while jutting back away from the incoming blade.
His body moved slower than the blade.
He watched the blade approach as he reeled back.
The blade touched his shirt and dragged it along his chest until the tension forced the blade to cut the fabric.
He felt the cold chill of the blade slide across his right breast, but it did not cut in.
It finished its horizontal arch an inch over his face.
Justin’s back hit the pavement.
Time resumed.
Fire flew over Justin and forced the veteran to retreat a few steps.
Justin kicked frantically back against the pavement to place as much distance as he could from the soldier.
His hand felt the torn shirt on his chest but there was no blood.
The moisture he felt was the sweat seeping from every pore in his body.
Sammy pulled Justin up, and they ran as Chloe’s punches spewed flames behind their flight to keep back their potential pursuer.
Fear and bitterness welled up in Justin’s stomach and brought tears to the corner of his eyes.
He realized how foolish they had been.
The only reason they killed the soldiers pursuing them at the university and the two spearmen that killed the woman and child was because they caught them by surprise.
They could not compete against these trained soldiers in a real fight.
He looked behind at the innocent people in the thick of slaughter.
They could not help.
All they could do was find Eydis, Sean, and Miriam and then run for their own lives.

* * *
A sense of relief washed over Eydis.
She arrived at the edge of the parking lot in time to see the thrust and sideways slash of the soldier.
Justin avoided any harm, and Eydis knew she had his time magic to thank.
After one final glance at the carnage, Justin did not look back.
He and Sammy and Chloe ran off around the side of the building.
The soldier who had confronted them called back towards his fellow soldiers.
“We have priority targets!
Let’s move!”
No less than ten or twelve heard his call.
A sense of urgency laced with adrenaline spurred Eydis’s aching body to action, numbing the pain.
“You will not harm him.”
Pavement buckled under her bare feet with the thrust of her good leg.
The gap between her and the first soldier disappeared in an instant.
Her fist collided with the side of his helmet with the creak of buckling metal.
Red gore spewed from the opening, and the crushed head ripped clean off its shoulders at the completion of her swing.
Unable to stop on her injured leg, Eydis collided with the side of the building twenty yards from where the soldier’s body dropped.
The impact knocked the wind out of Eydis, but she recovered quickly and stared down the other soldiers who looked back with terrified faces.
One of them noticed Eydis’s eyes.
“It’s a Lurr!”
All soldiers immediately prepared for combat.
Eydis grabbed the trunk of a young tree no thicker than her arm and ripped it from the bed lining the side of the building.
The roots left a trail of dirt as it dragged.
Eydis snapped off the top of the tree where the first branches grew and brandished her makeshift club still caked with rock and dirt.
She charged.
The first swing hit three soldiers and sent them flying through the air.
Their light weight in this world only added to the distance.
Two shields blocked the second swing, but both buckled under the force, and the two soldiers flew.
Eydis smiled.
None of these soldiers had magic or they would have used it.
It was purely a contest of strength.
“Die.”
Her voice was calm but reeked of an unbridled hatred of humanity, or at least the humans of her world.
Swing after swing killed soldier after soldier.
The clumps of dirt and rock broke away leaving gnarled bunches of fractured and broken roots that impaled the faces, torsos, and appendages of the soldiers where armor was weak or missing.
One last swing and the trunk finally snapped.
The sole survivor of the onslaught brandished a shaking spear at Eydis.
Eydis’s eyes flared.
The soldier tried to run back to his companions, but she easily caught the back of his neck and squeezed until her hand gripped tight around his neck bone.
Blood seeped from where her hand dug into flesh and dripped down her arm.
A little more force and the bone snapped.
The soldier’s head hung from the small bit of flesh that could not fit into her grasp.
Eydis looked back in the direction Justin fled.
No more soldiers would pursue him.
She wanted to chase after, but something in her heart stopped her.
I cannot see him.
I do not deserve to.
She turned her attention to the ongoing slaughter.
Some of the soldiers who witnessed her one-sided assault stopped and tried to motion others to focus on the new threat.
Most humans of Earth were good people.
They did not deserve this.
Eydis grabbed a sword from a felled soldier.
It felt no heavier than a twig in her hand.
Unlike before, she could not recklessly charge into the fray.
There were innocent civilians intermixed with the soldiers.
Instead, she ran with enough presence that many of the nearby soldiers halted their slaughter and changed their focus to her.
She chuckled.
They were not cowards like that minum.
They were willing to die.
The soldiers formed a defensive wall, but Eydis ignored it.
She jumped right over and targeted the first spellcaster she saw.
She had to look back to see if her swing even made contact.
There was no resistance, almost like slicing air, but the head of the wind mage slid from the woman’s shoulders as she collapsed to the ground.
The chaos of the massacre played in Eydis’s favor.
Those who could use magic were so preoccupied with the ones they were killing that they did not notice Eydis until their head was on the ground.
The sword grew blunt, but the strength of Eydis’s arm more than compensated.
In truth, she was happier to feel some resistance because she could move onto the next mage or archer without worry of having missed or the soldier surviving.
One last swing and all ranged fighters were corpses on the ground.
No more innocent people fell prey to Jethro’s army.
The only prey was the soldiers now.
Eydis’s rampage caught the attention of all remaining soldiers.
The surviving citizens did not mistake their opening and fled.
Eydis laughed.
She reveled in the thrill of finally having a personal hand in stopping Jethro’s plans and killing the human soldiers that had caused so much pain in her world.
A circle of armed men formed around her.
Shields took the front with spears in the back, but the faces of the soldiers showed no confidence.
They knew as well as Eydis that they had no hope.
An intelligent Lurr was far too fierce an opponent to fight without magic, and only an intelligent Lurr would think to remove all ranged fighters first.
Eydis took a few steps forward, and the circle of soldiers followed to center her in their radius.
Her hand grabbed the metal frame of what looked like a thin, burnt bed.
She flung it with all her strength.
Not one soldier had time to react.
It hit a group of six and sent them flying back in a spray of metal and blood.
None of the soldiers moved.
None took command or gave orders.
Everyone was silent.
“Heh.”
Eydis raced to the gap and swung her sword.
The shield bearers attempted to block, but one hit with the sword sent their shields awry with enough force to twist and break their arms.
The sword snapped from the force of impact, but she quickly grabbed another from the broken shieldman.
The next swing cut them down without resistance.
Spearmen tried to use their reach, but their thrusts were too slow for a Lurr’s eyes.
Eydis closed in and dispatched them with ease.
The circle tried to enclose from behind, but Eydis simply jumped to the outside to continue her massacre.
Twenty soldiers dropped to ten, then five, then one.
The sole remaining spearman sat on his back looking up at the red-eyed woman dyed in the blood of his comrades.
He pointed his spear at her chest, but she only laughed.
“This world is under my protection now.
You were foolish to come here.”
The soldier thrust his spear, but Eydis caught it just behind the wings and yanked it from his grip without effort.
She then spun it around and stabbed the man in the heart.
“Monster…” The man’s eyes grew still.
“I am no monster.”
Eydis surveyed the carnage.
Countless innocents had lost their lives.

In her heart, she wished she could have arrived quicker, but the injuries to her leg and chest, not to mention her inability to teleport due to being out of clean ven, had slowed her down tremendously.
Even now, the pain that had been suppressed by adrenaline returned with full force.
Eydis ran through the complex following the trail of dead bodies to make sure Justin and Sammy were safe, but what she heard from the other side of the complex made her heart sink.
A battle was still raging.
She let Justin go without even thinking that there were more soldiers elsewhere at the hospital.
The combat hinted that most mages were with the first group she already eliminated, but there was an unfamiliar sound coming from the direction Justin fled.
It buzzed like the quick flapping of large wings and was accompanied by the sound of rapid gunfire.
This unknown filled Eydis with fear.
Justin’s life was in danger.
A familiar sensation from above washed through Eydis’s body, freezing her in place.
The fear in her heart heightened to an unbearable sense of dread.
It had been weeks since she last felt it, but the signature was unmistakable.
Why did she not realize sooner?
If the army was here, so was their commander.
She looked up in the sky and saw a lone man hovering in the air as if standing on some invisible platform, a barrier.
“Jethro…” The name escaped her lips like a phantom.
Jethro eyed the destruction of the hospital but soon noticed Eydis.
He disappeared from her vision and reappeared in front of her in a flash of light.
Fear paralyzed her.
She could not speak or breathe.
She knew that she had no chance against him.
Her ven was poisoned.
Even the powerful magic she learned from him was useless.
“My dear doppelganger.
I am so happy to see you well.”
Eydis dropped the sword that once belonged to one of Jethro’s men.
Her body was dyed red with their blood.
He’s going to kill me.
He knows I have been slaughtering his men!
The look on Jethro’s face was not anger but unbridled joy.
“I want to congratulate you on a job well done!
I never expected you to have accomplished so much in your short time here.”
Eydis’s mind went blank.
“Truly, the First Princess was a serious cause for worry.
I knew none of my men could fight her.
Her skill with magic is absurd.
I did not know just how skilled she was until I tried to assassinate her.
But you, you did what even I could not!”
No…
“On your own, you rendered her helpless.
Of course, I did not expect you to kill her.
You are an incomplete doppelganger after all.”
No… I did not do it for…
“Without you, this mission never would have worked!
All that is left is to find her.
She is here, is she not?”
Eydis’s eyes unconsciously flicked in the direction she felt the presence of her “prey.”
Jethro’s well-trained eyes caught the very subtle movement, and Eydis immediately knew she had made a terrible, terrible mistake.
That was where Justin was headed, or perhaps he was already there.
“I did not do it for you… I did not mean…”
“Of course not.
It was only your instinct after all, but a promise is a promise.
I will let you live free in this world.”
“No!
I wanted to stop you!
I wanted to fight you!
After what you did to me, after what you did to Rynn!”
Eydis swung her fist at Jethro but it broke against an invisible wall.
The smile disappeared from Jethro’s face as he shook off the numbness from the recoil.
Eydis shrunk back.
He would not forgive her now.
“I guess you would not want me to take away your prey, but I cannot have you interfering.”
No… I… If I am gone, he will kill Justin.
Please… “Please… please, do not kill Justin.
You can take Eydis, but please… do not hurt Justin!”
Jethro’s eyes grew wide.
This doppelganger was letting her prey go for the safety of another.
A faint smile returned to his face.
“Is Justin the man who was living with the princess?”
Eydis managed a nod.
“If he gets in my way, I may have to kill him.”
Eydis prostrated herself.
“I beg you!
Anything but him!”
Jethro sighed.
“Alright, get up, get up.”
At his command, Eydis stood, but she kept her head down and eyes closed in submission.
“Our agreement was for you to live in the princess’s place, and that place was with that man, correct?
I will not go back on my word.
I will not kill you, and I will let you live in this world with Justin.”
Relief washed over Eydis.
Her body shook and tears welled in her eyes.
“However, I cannot rule out that you will not attempt to cross me.”
Eydis’s breath caught in her throat.
Her eyes rose.
Jethro’s hand was extended with his palm facing her chest.
An incredible force hit Eydis like a high-speed boulder.
Jethro immediately shrunk in her vision.
She flew backwards and broke through two walls of a hospital building.
“How troublesome,” Jethro sighed.
“I hope that was enough to keep her down.
I should probably kill her anyway, but I did make a promise.”

* * *
Corpses littered the ground, mostly hospital workers and patients.
Justin only counted two of the medieval soldiers among them.
The traumatic scene slowed them down due to the pure mental and emotional exhaustion.
The hospital complex was not even that large, but the number of dead made the distance between two buildings feel like a mile.
To make the trauma even worse, behind them they heard the massacre escalate, and ahead of them they heard more fighting.
People were dying all around them.
They held in their nausea and fought to ignore the pungent smell of iron and filth that permeated every square slab of sidewalk or black stretch of asphalt.
Twice Justin had to stop and vomit out bile from his empty stomach.
He could imagine that his pallor was just as sheet white as Sammy’s and Chloe’s.
With every step his legs wanted to give in.
He wanted to ball up on the ground and cry.
In his head, he kept on repeating one thing.
“I caused all this.”
He never regretted saving Eydis that early morning in November, but Sean was right.
He should have contacted the police after learning assassins were after her.
Eydis trusted him to be always with her, but he got lax in his watch allowing Jethro’s men to capture her.
They learned of the university, and Justin couldn’t even begin to guess how many died and how many more will die there.
He was the closest to Eydis but never noticed the other Eydis took her place.
Through prolonged abuse, Eydis grew too weak to wake, so they could not properly handle the preliminary attacks on Gullivan in her absence, allowing them to escalate into an invasion.
Because of his own toxic body, the other Eydis became ill and incapable of using magic.
Justin did not know where she was, but he doubted she could stop the attack on Gullivan in her state.
She could barely stand when she left his hospital room with Rynn.
All his mistakes culminated into the carnage before him.

This was his fault, and disregarding whether that was true or not, he did not have the mental capacity to refute it, not among all this death, not next to the large man sprawled at his feet with his fat and entrails seeping out of the deep gash in his stomach.
“Come on.
We need to hurry,” Sammy said.
But there are more of them that way!
Sammy’s voice was kind albeit shaken, so Justin could not find within himself to shout his thoughts.
She and Chloe each grabbed one of Justin’s hands and pulled him along.
They were far stronger than him in so many ways, and Justin knew he would never make it through this without them.
They neared the opposite side of the hospital to where the sound of a helicopter and gunfire originated.
They waited behind the corner of one of the buildings.
Sammy peeked out with an audible gasp.
Chloe and Justin then followed.
A couple hundred yards down the road in front of their destination, two small attack helicopters fired ceaselessly at a group of soldiers.
Soldiers launched a few fireballs and shards of ice in retaliation, but the helicopters were able to avoid most of them from their distance.
One of the ice shards hit but shattered on contact with minimum damage.
Most of the soldiers were dead, their corpses littering the road with the vast majority amassing where the current struggle unfolded.
From what Justin saw, the soldiers had not quite reached Eydis.
His legs moved with unconscious effort down the road.
Sammy called after him but soon followed with Chloe when Justin would not stop.
Only a handful of soldiers remained.
Two archers released futile arrows and one last mage hurled large spikes of ice like javelins.

The remaining two held as many shields as they could carry to try to defend their ranged comrades, but the guns of the small attack helicopters ripped through one of the shieldmen and the mage behind him.
The apparent victory pushed Justin to move faster.
One of the helicopters lost its propeller and crashed to the ground.
A man in the air disappeared and reappeared in a freefall next to the second helicopter as it tried to make distance.
A visible shockwave expanded from the front of the man and crumpled the side of the helicopter.
Pieces of glass and propeller blew outward as if hit by a massive, invisible explosion, and the machine fell from the sky.
Justin froze.
The remaining three soldiers cheered.
A verbal and wide-gestured exchange traded between the man now standing in the air and the soldiers on the ground.
He pointed.
The soldiers ran towards the nearby single-story hospital wing.
Eydis’s room was there.
Fear could no longer hold him.
Justin ran, and Sammy and Chloe pleaded in desperation for him to come back.
Twice Justin nearly tripped over the ever-increasing corpses.
Sammy tried to reach him and pull him back, but Justin kept running.
They were too conspicuous.
They would be seen.
The man standing in the air vanished and reappeared in front of Justin.
He tried to stop but collided with an invisible wall and fell back over the body of a fallen soldier.
Justin trembled.
He had seen the facial composite created by the fake Eydis.
Pure white fear spread through his body and locked his arms and legs.
“Do you know a Justin?”
The man’s voice was slow, like he had to think specifically about each English word he spoke.
“Jethro…”
Jethro smiled and spoke an elated sentence in some unknown language.
Sammy and Chloe reached Justin and pulled him away.
They were shaking just as much as him.
They knew who stood before them.
“You are Justin!
You are lucked.
Lucky?”
Jethro’s manner of speech was reminiscent of Eydis when she was first learning English, but Justin did not have the leisure to feel nostalgic.
“A Lurr asked me do not kill you.”
Justin knew that Lurr.
Another feeling of unease spread through him.
He knew he shouldn’t care about her, but that part of him he hated worried about what happened to the other Eydis.
“But, I must make Eydis FeAmel hurt.” Jethro’s eyes grew narrow.
“You three are her friends.
I will not kill Justin.
I can kill you and you.”
His fingers pointed to Sammy and Chloe.
Justin spread his arms to cover Sammy and Chloe and pulled them in behind him.
Jethro vanished with a light crack, and a flash appeared behind them.
Time slowed around Justin.
A near invisible planar object that split the air extended from Jethro’s downward-swinging hand.
Eydis’s assassin could cut anything with magic.
He had heard that from Eydis a long time ago.
Justin pulled on Sammy’s coat to move her where he stood and away from the slow moving, near-invisible blade.
The blade missed, and time returned to its normal pace.
Chloe was far slower on her reaction and swung a flaming knife-hand behind her.
The fire arched out from her swing but stopped against the invisible force.
She could not reach Jethro with her magic.
Justin prepared for a second attack, but one did not follow.
Jethro looked at Justin with a surprise on his face not unlike the veteran soldier from before.
However, unlike the soldier, Jethro voiced his surprise with a single English word.
“Time…”
Jethro laughed within himself.
Not only could this boy connected with the princess use time magic, but he could also activate it instantly upon the first appearance of a threat.
Spatial magic usually required time to cast due to the formulas needed to use it efficiently, but it could then be cast instantly once the formula was memorized.
Time was different in that a channeling period was required before any time magic could be cast.
Even the channeling radiated ven to signal its use, so one who was sensitive would always be alerted before the time magic activated.
One of his former colleagues during his youth was a time mage researching how to remove or shortcut that same channeling time.
It was not a magic that could be use instantly.
However, Jethro had gained invaluable knowledge on spatial magic from Emer.
Perhaps there were more magical unknowns in this world.
His internal laughter escaped as a small chuckle.
He felt a small kinship with Justin not unlike what he felt with Emer.
This boy could become an unparalleled master of time magic with enough study.
“Why are you after Eydis?”
Justin’s sudden words broke Jethro out of his introspection.
“What crime has she done that would make you come to our world to kill so many people to get to her?!”
Pain grew in Jethro’s heart like the slow insertion of a hot knife.
Eyes fueled with hatred glared back at Justin.
There was no joyful surprise remaining.
Noticing the change in demeanor, Justin once again pulled Sammy and Chloe behind him.
Part of Jethro wanted to kill them all and be done.
His spatial rejection magic could eliminate them instantly.
The doppelganger only survived it twice because she was a Lurr and he was holding back.
The Mountain Elf only survived due to her reinforcement magic.
A normal human would be obliterated, and Justin’s time magic would be unable to stop it.
But Jethro couldn’t.
Losing such a rare time magic prodigy would be a crime.
The sound of shattering rock redirected Jethro’s attention down the road.
The archer that Jethro sent to search the building for the princess flew back onto the street and crumbled into an unmoving heap.
A terribly injured Mountain Elf limped out onto the road.
He recognized the escaped slave that he had used for his transmission experiment, the one that survived his spatial rejection magic.
The shieldman and final archer were missing and had likely fallen to her as well.
Behind the Mountain Elf another battered woman walked out of the structure.
Finally, a taller man exited supporting an elven woman with her arm over his shoulder, the First Princess, Eydis FeAmel.
She noticed Jethro and those who stood near him.
The strength in her legs gave out, and she began sobbing.
“Eydis! Run!”
Justin’s shout confirmed Jethro’s suspicion.
He erected a barrier around the princess and those with her.
He reinforced it with an anti-teleportation encryption so she could not escape.
The Mountain Elf hammered at the barrier with her fists and then a stone baton.
The damage was so insignificant that Jethro could not feel any recoil.
She placed her hand on the barrier, but the pulse that had shattered his barrier once in the past barely registered as what he could consider recoil.
That elf was barely holding onto life.
She would not be a threat.
The stage was set.
The princess would now watch as those that she loved suffered because of her.
A flick of Jethro’s wrist sent a small barrier flying at the orange-haired woman’s head.
Justin noticed it at the last conceivable moment and shifted her away.
The small blade only sliced a small lock of hair and continued on until it dissipated, but Justin’s movements left the shorter woman open.
Jethro launched a larger barrier at the unguarded woman.
The panic on Justin’s face pleased Jethro.
Justin kicked the woman.
She jolted to the side and fell to the ground.
Justin barely retracted his foot before the barrier could sever it at the ankle.
Jethro’s barriers were too slow against a time mage.
He reached to his waist and removed the small handgun.
His aim was not perfect, but at this distance he could not miss.
He aimed at the fallen girl and fired.
Justin consciously slowed time the moment Jethro drew the gun.
He dove for Sammy.
The bullet travelled at an incredible speed even in his slow world.
Justin had no control over where the bullet hit.
He could feel it break the skin of his abdomen and tear the muscle.
He felt the snap of each individual fiber and tissue until the bullet stopped.
When time resumed its pace, he landed on top of Sammy with a white-hot burning in his stomach.
““Justin!””
Screams rose from both Sammy and the princess in the distance.
It all happened in an instant to those who saw.
The reflexes and response were so inhuman that it was enough to make Jethro pause in admiration.
“Oh, God.”
The woman Justin saved sat up and pressed her hand on Justin’s stomach to stop the bleeding.
She glared at Jethro with fear and anger.
Jethro could only laugh despite himself.
He realized his own stupidity.
“I cannot believe I did not do this first…”
He extended his hand, and a barrier formed around Justin and held him in place.
The woman tried to move him and cover the wound, but the boy’s blood spilled out inside the barrier uninhibited.
Fire from the red headed woman assaulted Jethro, but it could not touch him through his barrier.
“Stop this!
Please,” the short woman cried.
“Why are you doing this?!”
Jethro did not answer, but the plea of the woman holding Justin gave him an idea.
He looked into the tear-filled, distressed eyes of the time mage.
“Do you want to know why I hate Amel?
Why I hate Eydis?”
Changing the destination coordinates of his transmission spell was not difficult now that he had two partnered formulas with inverted coordinates.
He knew precisely where the two worlds were in relation to each other.
Jethro modified the return formula Emer created and targeted a specific room in the home of one if his associates in Tolmyur.
Jethro extended his hand.
“Justin… no… Justin…”
Eydis crawled up the street with her body broken and battered from Jethro’s magic.
The spell was far more powerful than the first time he used it on her after her fight with the Alukah.
She fought through the intense pain and exhaustion to chase after the man she loved only to watch Jethro shoot him.
Jethro did not keep his promise, and deep down, Eydis hoped he would, because Jethro never lied.
But, she was too late.
Now Jethro had his hand extended in a hostile gesture she knew would end Justin’s life.
All she could think of was the magic Jethro used against her.
Justin, Sammy, and Chloe would not survive like she did.
They were not Lurr.
Nothing would remain.
She extended her hand and forced her toxic ven through.
Her body rebelled in a wave of burning pain throughout her entire body that surpassed the damage she had already taken and overpowered the adrenaline trying to keep her pain in check.
Still, she pushed further to create a barrier that would save their life.
Her vision grew hazy.
Her nausea caused irrepressible vomiting.
Her body felt as if all the blood that flowed through it was replaced by a powerful acid that melted her from the inside.
Her consciousness was slipping.
When she could endure the pain no longer, she cast the barrier and whited out for but a moment.
Jethro cast the transmission.
A tiny woman no larger than his hand appeared and touched the back of his hand with her fingers.
He could feel an alteration in the makeup of the transmission formula as it cast, but it happened so fast that he could not tell what changed.
All he felt was the sensation of his spatial magic mixing with another’s.
After a strong suction that pulled the bodies that littered the ground towards it and threatened to pull him in, not only Justin but also the two women with him vanished.
In desperation, Jethro used the strongest spatial rejection spell he could on the small feminine figure before the suction finished.
The entire area in front of him blew away in an immense cloud of dirt, rock, and gore from the many bodies that were pulled into the empty space left by the transmission.
Lurr Eydis’s eyes regained focus in time to watch the massive explosion where the bodies of her three friends once stood.
Rocks, metal, and pieces of flesh peppered the road and fell on Eydis, but she did not blink until the light breeze removed the dust.
Her heart sunk into a pit of dread and sorrow.
Nothing remained in front of Jethro.
Her barrier did not hold.
Justin, Sammy, and Chloe were gone.
The blood and pieces of flesh that fell on her could have been the remnants of her friends.
No words came from her mouth.
No thoughts entered her mind.
Only tears welled and fell from her eyes as the distant cries of the other Eydis sounded over the destroyed roadway.
In her immense sorrow and guilt of her failure to save the man she loved and the friends she held most dear, Eydis succumbed to the pain and exhaustion in her body and lost consciousness.
“Justin!
Justin!”
Princess Eydis flailed in Sean’s arms.
She kept calling Justin’s name as if Sammy and Chloe had not been caught in the same explosion.
He struggled to keep her light frame from running after the man who had killed their friends.
“Eydis…” Sean fought back his own sorrow and anger to try and calm her down, but she was inconsolable.
“Let go!
Justin!”
Sean held Eydis tight.
Her arm flailed about and clawed at the air.
“Eydis!” He shouted at her.
Something locked around Sean’s foot and before he knew what happened, he was on his back on the ground.
He managed to grab Eydis’s ankle before she could run.
She looked back at him with seething wrath.
A wind spear grew in her hands.
Fear spread through every corner of his body, but he did not let go.
He had to trust that she would not attack him.
Behind Eydis, Sean saw Jethro turn to face them.
“Justin’s gone!
They’re gone!” Sean screamed.
The spear dispersed as the pain of loss contorted Eydis’s face in anguish.
“No… Justin.”
“We need to leave.” Miriam said.
“No.
No!” Eydis would not listen.
Miriam slapped Eydis hard across the face and grabbed the front of her hospital gown.
“You are the only one who can teleport us away from here!
Do you want us to die too?!”
“I do not care about you!
I want Justin!”
Sean realized something was wrong with Eydis.
She was not in her right mind.
They couldn’t escape like this.
Eydis felt like the most important part of her had been stolen away.
The large void in her heart filled rapidly with anguish and fury.
She wanted to kill the man who stole that most important part from her, who took Justin away from her.
Now, these two humans were trying to stop her.
They had protected her, and she felt like she knew them intimately, but she could not remember who they were, only that they were stopping her.
The Mountain Elf accompanying them knelt and bowed her head.
“My Lady, I beseech you!
Stop this foolishness.
You are the sole heir to the Amelian Empire.
Your life matters more than any of us, even Justin.
We must flee!
You can only get revenge on Tolmyur if you survive.”
That… I… That is right.
I am Eydis FeAmel, First Princess of the Amelian Empire.
Eydis did not know how she had forgotten such an important piece of herself.
Her heart yearned for Justin, the one who took her in, protected her, and supported her.
She loved him with all her heart.
Her longing for him was all that occupied her long imprisonment in the dark caverns of her mind, but the man was right.
The Mountain Elf was right.
Justin was gone.
She witnessed the bloody explosion that not even the pavement of the road endured.
But if she had the power of an entire empire on her side, she could have revenge.
She reluctantly nodded her head, shamefaced.
“We must retreat.”
Eydis worked out a teleportation formula.
She did not know where to go, but anywhere other than the city would be safe.
She reached out and tore open a portal in space in front of her.
Jethro fumed with anger.
He pounded on the barrier around him.
Every attempt to cut it failed.
He tried reading the flow of the spatial ven to find a way to dispel it, but it was of such an impossible complexity that he could not even begin to understand it.
Somehow, the barrier he had placed around himself was repurposed without his knowledge the moment he turned to attack the princess.
Worst of all, the barrier around the princess had vanished, and she was teleporting away.
The small womanly figure floated at face level in front of Jethro just outside the barrier.
“I am sorry, but both you and Eydis FeAmel have a much greater role to play than revenge, so I am compelled to restrain your hand.
I ask that you discontinue your plans to invade this world.
We cannot have you angering Kalya and force her into action.
However, feel free to continue your vendetta against Amel on Whinhlem.
We will not stop you, but I will have to hold you here for a time.”
The small woman appeared inside the barrier, placed her hand on his forehead, and sent a pulse through his body.
She then reappeared outside the barrier and gave a cheerful wave before Jethro could retaliate.
“Until we meet again, Bridge between Worlds.”
The figure flew away and entered the portal created by the princess just before it closed.
The moment she disappeared, the barrier around Jethro vanished.

Epilogue
“The Aftermath”
Colonel Richards sat back in his chair.
His complexion was sickly from both bewilderment and lack of sleep.
Over 5000 civilians lost their lives in the assault on the city and tens of thousands more were injured.
The commander of the enemy forces, Jethro, had been reported at the hospital by the two AH-6 Little Birds before they were promptly destroyed.
The Apache dispatched to aid the battle on the north side of the city was sent back to intercept, but Jethro was gone, and no more sightings followed.
The citizens had repelled those attacking the southeast.
Those attacking the hospital had been killed by the attack helicopters and the work of various individuals.
By the time the ground forces arrived, the police of the nearest cities had been able to suppress most of the invaders.
The army was repurposed to disaster relief and the search for survivors in the devastated northern quarter of the city.
Regrettably, there was not one survivor among Gullivan’s on-duty police.
Of the entire enemy army that invaded, only two soldiers survived.
One was a giant of a man and the second an elderly woman whom he protected.
They were currently imprisoned and did not show any hostility after capture.
There was no word yet on what to do with them, but Colonel Richards assumed that they would receive capital punishment after questioning.
Among the group of youth who had knowledge about the invaders, only half of them survived the attack including the elven princess who was the target of the invading army.
They were discovered walking along the highway fifteen miles south of the city and somehow gained a new elf companion.
They were now residing at Fort Samper for better protection.
“She should have been taken there from the start.”
Colonel Richards wiped his hand down his face.
He had a feeling that he had been doing this more over the past two weeks than he had his entire military career.
When he first saw Sean and Miriam, they were utterly distraught.
After discussing what happened at the hospital, he learned that they witnessed the gruesome death of Sammy Thompson, Chloe Hearn, and the one most involved with the elven princess, Justin Hapfeld.
The Mountain Elf was a subject of the princess and was only relieved that Eydis was alive.
Eydis on the other hand was possessed by an anger that threatened to lash out at the slightest provocation.
The moment she arrived at Fort Samper, she demanded they ally with her to defeat their common enemy.
In return, she would teach the soldiers magic.
Her request was denied until a formal decision could be made at the federal level.
“Magic…”
That was the most bizarre part of these events.
The invaders were not from some far away hidden village or city.
Sean was upfront about the truth.
They came from another world or dimension using teleportation magic.
Magic was real, and no doubt the world would soon find out.
There were many skeptics, but the sheer number of personal accounts and videos of the assault on the city created proof that was impossible to hide.
Even now, all branches of the federal government were requesting to meet Colonel Richards.
No press briefing had been held yet because nothing had been decided on what to say or what could be said.
This only fueled the conspiracy theorists trying to piece together the truth.
Before any decisions could be made, Colonel Richards wanted input from the last survivor personally involved with not only the princess but also the enemy commander, the imposter Eydis FeAmel.
A tired looking medical staff entered the room.
The clock on the wall read 3:13am.
“Sir, she’s awake.”
The moment Colonel Richards learned the imposter Eydis’s health improved and that she could wake, he rushed to visit her.
This was the second day of mulling over the events that transpired while waiting for her to wake.
He ignored orders and requests and remained at the hospital because he could not afford to miss the moment she woke.
He cared little about whatever punishment would come for him later.
She was far more important.
He rushed behind the doctor to the neighboring room, but the moment he stepped in the door and met eyes with the imposter Eydis, the writhing woman vanished with a loud crack.
Colonel Richards wiped his hand down his face.
“What else did I expect…?”
At least she was not an enemy to the people of this world.
Or at least he was fairly sure.
According to eyewitness accounts at the hospital, she had single-handedly killed half the attacking army in order to help the survivors escape.
To him, anyone who was willing to fight themselves to a state near death in order to save lives was a hero.

Declaration of War 
Part 1
